Rock Island, Illinois
City Code
This code was last updated by
PREAMBLE
The Rock Island City Code, originally published by Municipal Code Corporation in 1984, has been kept
current by regular supplementation. In 1995, Sterling Codifiers began providing supplement service for
the City Code.
This City Code of the City of Rock Island, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including
ordinance 056-2018, passed September 24, 2018. Ordinances of the City adopted after said ordinance
supersede the provisions of this City Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the City office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the Code has been
amended, superseded or repealed.
Sterling Codifiers
Coeur d'Alene, Idaho
PREFACE
This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the ordinances of the City of Rock Island of a general
and permanent nature. As expressed in the Adopting Ordinance, the Code supersedes all such
ordinances not included herein or recognized as continuing in force by reference thereto.
The chapters of the Code arranged in alphabetical order and the sections within each chapter are
catchlined to facilitate usage. Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1963 Rock
Island Code and ordinances subsequently adopted by the governing body. The source of each section is
included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note
indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use
of the Comparative Tables appearing in the back of this volume, the reader can locate any section
included herein.
Footnotes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant provisions of the
state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within
the Code is included, at the back of this volume.
Numbering System
The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local codes. Each
section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash
representing the chapter number and the figure after the dash indicating the position of the section within
the chapter. Thus, the first section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-1 and the second section of Chapter 3 is
3-2. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and, at that same time, new sections
or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper places, simply by using the decimal system for
amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come
between sections 2-4 and 2-5 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 2-4.1, 2-
4.2 and 2-4.3, respectively. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to
be included between Chapters 6 and 7, it will be designated as Chapter 6.1. Care should be taken that
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 2/735
the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and
new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of
the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article
embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division.
Index
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under
several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology,
and still others in language generally used by government officials and employees. There are numerous
cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item
in which he is interested.
Looseleaf Supplements
A special feature of this Code is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental service, by which the
Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be
properly edited and the page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to
holders of copies of the Code, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting
the obsolete pages. Each such amendment, when incorporated into the Code, may be cited as a part
thereof, as provided in section 5 of the Adopting Ordinance.
The successful maintenance of this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of
the volume. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have
the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the
publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them
and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes.
Acknowledgments
The publication of this Code was under direct supervision of George R. Langford, President, and Milton
E. Lefkoff, Supervising Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is
gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able
assistance throughout the project.
The publishers are most grateful to Mr. Bernard C. Gilliman, City Attorney, and Ms. Jacqueline Vander
Meersch, City Clerk, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this Code. It
is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will
make the active law of the City readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the
day-to-day administration of the City's affairs.
August, 1984
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION
Tallahassee, Florida
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 84-36
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the City of Rock Island, Illinois; Establishing the
Same Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing for the Manner of
Amending and Supplementing Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall
Become Effective.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 3/735
Be It Ordained by the City Council of the City of Rock Island, Illinois:
Section 1. That the Code of Ordinances, consisting of Chapters 1 to 16, each inclusive, is hereby
adopted and enacted as the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Rock Island, Illinois", which Code shall
supersede all general and permanent ordinances of the City adopted on or before November 8, 1982, to
the extent provided in section 2 hereof.
Section 2. That all provisions of such code shall be in full force and effect from and after November 1,
1984, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the City, adopted on final passage on or
before November 8, 1982, and not included in such Code or recognized and continued in force by
reference therein, are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of such Code.
Section 3. That the repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance
or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance.
(Ord. 84-36, 8-27-1984)
Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, a violation of any provision of such Code, or
any ordinance shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) and not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00), as provided in section 1-13 of such Code. Any fine imposed by this code
which increases by the passage of time alone, shall not increase if, prior to the time the increase occurs
pursuant to the terms of the ordinance, the alleged violator files a written request for review of the
alleged violation with the appropriate agency. If, after the alleged violator exhausts his review rights, the
violation has not been paid or rescinded, the violator shall have a like time to pay the fine as provided in
the ordinance before the increase shall take effect. (Ord. 84-36, 8-27-1984; Ord. 23-2003, § 1, 4-14-
2003)
Section 5. Any and all additions and amendments to such Code, when passed in such form as to
indicate the intention of the Council to make the same a part of such Code, shall be deemed to be
incorporated in such Code, so that reference to such Code shall be understood and intended to include
such additions and amendments.
Section 6. That in the case of the amendment of any section of such Code for which a penalty is not
provided, the general penalty, as provided in section 4 of this ordinance and in section 1-13 of such
Code shall apply to the section as amended, or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a
penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section in the same
chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended,
unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein.
Section 7. Any ordinance adopted after November 8, 1982, which amends or refers to ordinances which
have been codified in such Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of such
Code.
Section 8. This ordinance and the Code adopted hereby, shall become effective November 1, 1984.
/s/ James R. Davis
Mayor
PASSED: August 27, 1984
APPROVED: August 28, 1984
ATTEST: Jacqueline L. Vander Meersch

Chapter 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 1-1. Designation Of Code 1:
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall be designated as the
Code of Ordinances of the City of Rock Island, Illinois. (1963 Code, Ch. 1, Art. I)
Sec. 1-2. Definitions; Rules Of Construction 2:
In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances now in force or which may hereafter be passed, the
rules in this Section shall be observed unless such construction is excluded by express provision of the
Code or ordinance, is inconsistent with the manifest intent of the City Council or is repugnant to the
context thereof:
City : The City of Rock Island in the State of Illinois, except as otherwise provided.
Computation Of Time : The time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first day and including the last, unless the last day is Sunday or a legal
holiday, and then it shall also be excluded. If the day succeeding such Sunday or holiday is also a
holiday or a Sunday, then such succeeding day shall also be excluded.
Council, City Council : The Council of the City of Rock Island, Illinois.
County : Rock Island County in the State of Illinois.
Court : The term "court" includes courts not of record as well as courts of record.
Gender : Words importing the masculine gender may be applied to females and to firms,
partnerships, associations, corporations, companies and organizations.
Generally : All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions shall be liberally construed, in
order that the true intent and meaning of the Council may be fully carried out.
Heretofore; Hereafter : The word "heretofore" shall mean any time previous to the day on which the
ordinance takes effect, and the word "hereafter" shall mean at any time after such day.
Ill. Rev. Stat : The abbreviation "Ill. Rev. Stat," shall mean the latest edition of the Illinois Revised
Statutes, as amended. Except as otherwise provided in this Code or any other ordinance of the City,
the rules of construction set out in Ill. Rev. Stat. chapter 1, section 1001 et seq., shall apply to this
Code and to all other ordinances of the City as far as is practicable.
In The City : The words "in the City" or "within the City" mean and include all territory over which the
City shall now possess or hereafter acquire jurisdiction for the exercise of its police powers or other
regulatory powers by virtue of any Constitutional law or State statute.
Joint Authority : Words purporting to give a joint authority to three (3) or more public officers or other
persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or persons.
Laws Or Ordinances Now In Force : The term "laws or ordinances now in force" or words of similar
import shall mean the laws and ordinances in force at the time the ordinance containing the words
takes effect.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 5/735
Mayor : The term "Mayor" shall apply as well to the acting mayor.
Month : A calendar month.
Number : Words importing the singular number may extend and may be applied to several persons
or things, and words importing the plural number may include the singular.
Oath : The word "oath" shall be deemed to include an affirmation and the word "sworn" shall be
construed to include the word "affirmed".
Occupant Or Tenant : The word "occupant" or "tenant", applied to a building or land, means any
person who holds a written or oral lease of or who actually occupies the whole or part of such
building or land, either alone or with others.
Officers And Departments Generally : Whenever any officer, department or other agency is referred
to by title, such as "clerk", "chief of police", "police department" or "chief building inspector", such
reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Rock Island, Illinois".
Or, And : "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or", if the sense requires it.
Owner : The word "owner" applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common or joint tenant of the whole or a part of such building or land.
Person : "Person" shall mean and include any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company or organization of any kind.
Personal Property : "Personal property" includes every species of property, except real property as
defined by this Section.
Preceding, Following : The word "preceding" means the next before, and the word "following" means
the next after.
Property : The word "property" shall include real and personal property.
Real Property : "Real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments and shall embrace
all chattels real.
Shall, May : The word "shall" is mandatory; the word "may" is permissive.
Sidewalk : That portion of a street between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the
adjacent property lines, intended for the use of pedestrians.
State : The term "State" or "the State" means the State of Illinois.
Street : The entire width between property lines of every way or place when any part thereof is open
to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular traffic.
Tense : Words in the present tense include the future.
Written, In Writing : The term "written" or "in writing" may include printing and any other mode of
representing word; and letters.
Year : A calendar year unless otherwise expressed. (1963 Code, Ch. 1, Art. I)
Sec. 1-3. Catchlines Of Sections:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 6/735
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such
sections, nor as any part of the section, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when
any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted.
Sec. 1-4. History Notes:
The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code are not intended to have any
legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the sections.
Sec. 1-5. Provisions Construed As Continuations Of Existing Ordinances:
The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances existing at the
time of the adoption of this Code shall be construed as a continuation thereof and not as new
enactments.
Sec. 1-6. Severability Of Parts Of Code 3:
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code and of every code adopted by
reference herein are severable, and if any such phrase, clause, sentence or paragraph shall be declared
unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction,
such invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and
sections of this Code, including any code adopted by reference. (1963 Code, Ch. 1, Art. I)
Sec. 1-7. Certain Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect
the validity of:
(1) Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the City, or authorizing the
issuance of any bonds of the City or any evidence of the City's indebtedness, or any contract or
obligation assumed by the City.
(2) Any ordinance fixing salaries of officers or employees of the City.
(3) Any budget or appropriation ordinance.
(4) Any right or franchise granted by the City Council to any person.
(5) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening,
vacating, etc., any street or public way in the City, or acquiring or vacating any easement in the City.
(6) Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the City.
(7) Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor.
(8) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the City, or providing regulations
for the same.
(9) Any ordinance annexing property to the City.
(10) Any zoning ordinance of the City.
(11) Any temporary ordinance.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 7/735
All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set
out at length herein.
Sec. 1-8. Amendments To Code; Amendatory Language:
(a)Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by
specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That
section of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Rock Island, Illinois, is hereby amended to read as
follows: . . . ." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired.
(b)If a new section not heretofore existing in this Code is to be added, the following language may be
used: "That the Code of Ordinances of the City of Rock Island, Illinois, is hereby amended by adding
a section, to be numbered , which section reads as follows: . . . ." The new section shall then be set
out in full as desired.
Sec. 1-9. Supplementation Of Code:
(a)By contract or by City personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever
authorized or directed by the City Council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive
parts of permanent and general ordinances passed by the City Council during the period covered by
the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so
numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which
have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they
have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance
included in the supplement.
(b)In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be
excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages.
(c)When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization
authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and
parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them
into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may:
(1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions.
(2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the
Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles.
(3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and,
where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision
numbers.
(4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter", "this article",
"this division", etc., as the case may be, or to "sections to " (inserting section numbers to indicate the
sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the
Code).
(5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance
sections inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or
effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code.
Sec. 1-10. Altering Code:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 8/735
It shall be unlawful for any person in the City to change, by additions or deletions, any part of this Code,
or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner which
will cause the law of the City to be misrepresented.
Sec. 1-11. When Ordinances Are Repealed:
Whenever any ordinance or part of any ordinance that is required by law to be published shall be
repealed or modified by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of ordinance thus repealed or
modified shall continue in force until the due publication of the ordinance repealing or modifying the
same shall take effect, unless therein otherwise expressly provided. When any ordinance repealing any
former ordinance, clause or provision shall itself be repealed, such last repeal shall not be construed to
revive the former original ordinance, clause or provision, unless therein so expressly provided. (1963
Code, Ch. 1, Art. I)
Sec. 1-12. Passage Of New Ordinances:
No new ordinances shall be construed to repeal a former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is
expressly repealed or not, as to any offense committed against the former ordinance, or as to any one
act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred or any right accrued or claim arising under the
former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or done, or any
penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any claim arising before the new ordinance takes effect,
save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform, so far as practicable, to the ordinances in force
at the time of such proceedings. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment is mitigated by any provision of a
new ordinance, such provision may, by the consent of the party affected, be applied to any judgment
pronounced after the new ordinance takes effect. This section shall extend to all repeals, either by
express words or by implication. (1963 Code, Ch. I, Art. I)
Sec. 1-13.1. Attempt To Commit Violation Of An Ordinance:
(a)A person commits an attempt when he does any act which constitutes a substantial step toward the
commission of that violation, with intent to commit one of the following offenses:
(1) Chapter 10, section 10-54 of this code, attempted retail theft under one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00).
(2) Chapter 10, sections 10-56 and 10-88 of this code, attempted criminal damage to property less
than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
(3) Chapter 10, section 10-67 of this code, attempted theft of property generally.
(4) Chapter 3, section 3-10 of this code, attempt to gain entry into a liquor establishment without
presenting identification.
(5) Chapter 3, section 3-10 of this code, attempt to purchase alcohol by a person under twenty one
(21) years of age.
(b)The minimum fine for a violation of this provision shall be one-half (1/2) of the minimum fine imposed
for violation of the actual offense. In the event a person is accused of a violation of this section and
does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, then
the person so accused may pay to the city, at police headquarters, a penalty in the sum of one-half
(1/2) of the amount provided for in this section as a minimum fine for the actual violation for and in full
satisfaction of the violation. (Ord. 97-20, 3-17-1997)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 9/735
Sec. 1-14. How Actions Are Brought; Costs:
All actions and prosecutions to recover any fine or to enforce any penalty under this Code or any other
ordinance of this City shall be brought and the proceedings therein conducted as provided by law in
such cases. (1963 Code, Ch. I, Art. II)
Chapter 2
ADMINISTRATION 5
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. Corporate Seal Established 1:
The seal heretofore provided and used by and for the City (the impression of which is, in the center an
Indian with bow and arrow, standing beneath a tree; on the right a steamboat, with hills in the distance;
and on the left a locomotive, surrounded by the inscription "City of Rock Island, Illinois") is established
and declared to be the Corporate Seal of the City. (1963 Code art. 1-3)
Sec. 2-2. Municipal Year 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2.2:
(a)The Municipal year of the City shall coincide with the calendar year. Therefore, the Municipal year
shall commence on January 1 in each year and conclude on December 31 of the same year.
(b)Beginning January 1, 2015, the City will use the calendar year as the fiscal period and the
Municipality's budget, financial statements, and comprehensive annual financial report shall be
prepared to reflect financial activities based upon an operating period of January 1 through
December 31 of each year. The Mayor, City Manager, City Attorney, Accounts and Financial Officer,
City Treasurer and all other City staff are authorized to do all things necessary to efficiently and
effectively accomplish this change.
(c)In order to efficiently and effectively accomplish this change, there will be an interim Municipal year
commencing on Tuesday, April 1, 2014, and concluding on Wednesday, December 31, 2014.
(d)This section shall be effective as of January 1, 2015, with regard to the Code change and shall be
effective with regards to all other portions from and after passage, approval, and, if required by law,
publication in the manner provided for by law. (Ord. 052-2013, 9-9-2013)
Secs. 2-3, 2-4. Reserved:
Sec. 2-5. Legal Department - Created:
There is hereby created a Legal Department in the City. This department shall consist of attorneys duly
licensed to practice law in the State, to be appointed by and subject to the direction and control of the
City Manager on a retainer basis. The attorneys shall be designated as City Attorney and Assistant City
Attorneys, and shall be paid a monthly retainer and additional hourly compensation as provided in a
contract approved by the City Council. (1963 Code art. 2-3; Ord. 83-17, 5-23-1983; Ord. 058-2008, 8-25-
2008)
Sec. 2-6. Legal Department - Duties:

The attorneys in the Legal Department for their respective retainers shall provide legal counsel for all
Council meetings, provide legal advice for the officers of the City, City Manager and all City departments,
and prosecute, on behalf of the City, cases in the Rock Island Division of Circuit Court, 14th Judicial
Circuit. (1963 Code art. 2-3; Ord. 83-17, 5-23-1983; Ord. 058-2008, 8-25-2008)
Secs. 2-7, 2-8. Reserved:
Sec. 2-9. Commencement Of Terms Of Office:
All City officials elected or appointed in April shall take office on the first Monday in May. (Ord., 4-6-1981)

Sec. 2-11. Circuit Court:

Sec. 2-12. Availability Of City Records Under State Freedom Of Information Act:
(a)Procedure: Request forms are provided by the City Clerk and are available on the City's website but
are not required. Requests for information must be submitted in writing. For requests seeking law
enforcement records, requests can be directed by mail to 1212 - 5th Avenue, Rock Island, IL, 61201,
or personal delivery, email, or fax to the Rock Island Police Department. All other requests can be
directed by mail to 1528 - 3rd Avenue, Rock Island, IL, 61201, or personal delivery, email, or fax to
the Office of the City Clerk.
(b)Appeals: Any person denied access to inspect or copy any public record may refer to 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 140/1 et seq.
(c)Fees: Refer to 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/1 et seq., for any fee imposed for the reproduction of
information in relation to the State Freedom of Information Act. (Ord. 011-2018, 3-26-2018)
Sec. 2-13. Personnel Department - Created:
There is hereby created a Personnel Department in the City. This department shall be administered by a
Personnel Director appointed by and subject to the direction and control of the City Manager. (Ord. 87-
22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 2-14. Personnel Department - Duties Of Director:
The Personnel Director shall supervise and coordinate activities relating to health insurance, risk
management, employee benefits, recruitment, legal services, training, public access channel and labor
negotiations, and in addition thereto, shall perform such further duties as may from time to time be
directed by the City Manager. (Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987; Ord. 058-2008, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-15. Martin Luther King, Jr., Center Board:
(a)Established; Duties: There is hereby established a Martin Luther King, Jr., Center Board, which will be
involved in the continual planning process for the Martin Luther King, Jr., Center and the supervision
and distribution of the Activity Fund. This board will consider policy matters and will make
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 11/735
recommendations to the City Council regarding services, priorities and operation of the facility. Such
recommendations shall be channeled through the Director of Martin Luther King, Jr., Center and the
City Manager for their consideration and comments. This board shall be created and operated
consistent with the articles of incorporation and bylaws of the Martin Luther King, Jr., Center, Inc., an
Illinois not for profit corporation.
(b)Members; Terms: The membership of the Martin Luther King, Jr., Center Board shall consist of one
Alderman appointed by the Mayor, Finance Director and nine (9) members representing the
neighborhood of the Martin Luther King, Jr., Center and the community at large. All members of the
board shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. The Finance Director
shall be a permanent member of the board.
(c)Chairman; Meetings: After appointment, the Martin Luther King, Jr., Center Board shall meet and
choose a Chairman from its membership. Meetings of the committee shall be held from time to time
upon the call of the Chairman or three (3) members of the board. At least one meeting shall be held
each year, and an annual report shall be submitted each year to the City Council. (Ord. 87-22, 3-23-
1987; Ord. 93-79, 8-9-1993; Ord. 94-65, 7-25-1994; Ord. 98-64, 9-14-1998; Ord. 003-2019, 1-14-
2019)
Sec. 2-16. Trespassing On King Center Property:
No person shall be on the following described premises: between Eighth and Ninth Streets and Sixth
and Seventh Avenues in the City, including the public right-of-way surrounding that area, unless he or
she is on those premises to attend a function sponsored by the Martin Luther King, Jr. Center, or
conducted in conjunction with any office or activity in the center; and, in any event, that person shall
leave the premises when requested to do so by the Martin Luther King, Jr. Center Director, or his
designee, or police authority. (Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 2-17. Smoke Free Areas In City Owned Facilities:
(Rep. by Ord. 058-2008, 8-25-2008)

ARTICLE II. MAYOR AND COUNCIL GENERALLY
Sec. 2-26. Composition Of Council; Election:
The City of Rock Island shall be divided into wards as established in section 2-302 of this chapter with
one Alderman elected from each ward and the Mayor elected from the City at large. (1963 Code art. 2-1;
referendum dated 4-12-1983)
Sec. 2-27. Qualifications 1:
No person shall be eligible to the Office of Councilman or Mayor unless he is a qualified elector of the
City, and also complies with all requirements set forth in the Illinois Compiled Statutes. (1963 Code art.
2-1)
Sec. 2-28. Mayor As Presiding Officer:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 12/735
The Mayor shall preside at all Council meetings and shall have the powers as provided in 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/5-3-1 through 5-3-5. (1963 Code art. 2-1; referendum dated 4-12-1983)
Sec. 2-29. Mayor Pro Tem 65 ILCS 5/3-11-7.2:
If a temporary absence or disability of the Mayor incapacitates him from the performance of his duties
but does not create a vacancy in the office, the City Council shall elect one of its members to act as
Mayor Pro Tem. The Mayor Pro Tem, during this absence or disability, shall perform the duties and
possess all the rights and powers of the Mayor. (1963 Code art. 2-1)
Sec. 2-30. General Powers 65 ILCS 5/5-3-6.3:
The Council has and shall exercise all legislative powers, functions and duties conferred upon the City or
its officers. Without limitation of the foregoing, the Council shall have power to:
(1) Appoint and remove the City Manager.
(2) Establish other administrative departments.
(3) Adopt the budget of the City.
(4) Authorize the issuance of bonds by a bond ordinance.
(5) Inquire into the conduct of any office, department or agency of the City and make investigations
as to Municipal affairs.
(6) Provide for an annual independent audit.
(7) Approve payment of expenses and liability. (1963 Code art. 2-1)
Sec. 2-31. Rules Of Procedure 65 ILCS 5/3-10-7, 5/3-11-11.4:
The Council shall determine its own rules of procedure, as provided by State Statute. All parliamentary
questions will be determined by "Robert's Rules of Order". Minutes of each Council meeting shall be
kept by the City Clerk, and the minutes shall be available for public inspection as provided in the Illinois
Open Meetings Act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq. (1963 Code art. 2-1; Ord. 058-2008, 8-25-
2008)
Sec. 2-32. Meetings - Regular:
Regular meetings of the City Council shall be held twice a month at six forty five o'clock (6:45) P.M. on
the second and fourth Mondays of the month except for December when regularly scheduled meetings
shall be held on the second and third Monday of the month. If the day for holding a regular meeting falls
on a holiday on which the City Hall is closed for business, then the meeting shall be held on the third
Monday of the month. Meetings shall be held in the City Hall.
(1) Policy Statement: It is the policy of the City of Rock Island, Illinois, that a member of the City
Council, which is subject to the provisions of the Open Meetings Act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes
120/1 et seq., may attend and participate in any open or closed meeting of the City Council from a
remote location via telephone, video or internet connection, provided that such attendance and
participation is in compliance with this policy and any other applicable laws.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 13/735
(2) Prerequisites: Any member of the City Council shall be provided the opportunity to attend an open
or closed meeting via electronic means from a remote location if a quorum is physically present at
the meeting site, the quorum votes to approve the attendance by electronic means, and the
requesting member meets the following conditions:
a. The member must notify the City Clerk at least forty eight (48) hours prior to the scheduled
meeting, unless such notice is impractical, so that necessary communications equipment can be
arranged. Inability to make the necessary technical arrangements will result in denial of a request
for electronic attendance.
b. The member must assert one of the three (3) following reasons why he or she is unable to
physically attend the meeting:
1. Due to personal illness or disability;
2. Due to employment purposes or other City business;
3. Due to a family emergency or other emergency.
3. Due to a family emergency or other emergency. (3) Quorum And Vote Required: Providing the
above prerequisites have been met and following roll call to establish that a quorum is physically
present at the meeting site, a motion shall be made and considered as to whether to allow the
member to remotely attend the meeting via electronic means. A vote may be taken to permit
participation for a stated series of meetings if the same reason applies to each case and proper
notice has been provided to the City Clerk. Otherwise, a vote must be taken to allow each remote
participation via electronic means. The motion must be approved by a vote of a majority of the City
Council.
(4) Adequate Equipment Required: Any member participating electronically and other members of
the City Council must be able to communicate effectively, and members of the audience must be
able to hear all communications at the meeting site. Before allowing remote attendance via electronic
means at any meeting, the City Council must be satisfied that adequate remote access is available to
satisfy these requirements.
(5) Meeting Minutes: Any member attending remotely via electronic means shall be counted as
present for the meeting. The meeting minutes shall reflect and state specifically whether each
member is physically present, absent, or present by electronic means and shall state the approved
reason necessitating attendance via electronic means.
(6) Rights Of Remote Member: Any member permitted to participate remotely via electronic means
shall be permitted to express his or her comments during the meeting and participate in the same
capacity as those members physically present, subject to all general meeting guidelines and
procedures previously adopted and adhered to. The remote member shall be heard, considered, and
counted as to any vote taken. Accordingly, the name of any remote members shall be called during
any vote taken and his or her vote counted and recorded by the City Clerk and placed in the meeting
minutes. A member participating remotely via electronic means may leave a meeting and return as in
the case of any member, provided the member attending via electronic means shall announce his or
her leaving and returning to the quorum present.
(7) Costs: Any member participating remotely via telephone shall be reimbursed for the cost of the
telephone call upon a valid receipt shown. Any other costs associated with attendance and
participation via electronic means, including video conferencing and other audio and video
equipment, must be approved by the City Council prior to incurring such costs. (Ord. 072-2018, 12-
10-2018)

Sec. 2-33. Meetings - Special 5 ILCS 120/1 - 120/6, 120/2.02 et seq.; 65 ILCS 5/3-11-13.5:
Special meetings of the City Council may be called by the Mayor or three (3) Councilmen and notice
thereof shall be given to each member of the Council by the City Clerk at least twenty four (24) hours
prior to said meeting and notice thereof shall be given the public as provided in the Illinois Open
Meetings Act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq.

120/1 et seq., may attend and participate in any open or closed meeting of the City Council from a
remote location via telephone, video or internet connection, provided that such attendance and

to allow each remote participation via electronic means. The motion must be approved by a vote of a
majority of the City Council.
(4) Adequate Equipment Required: Any member participating electronically and other members of

satisfy these requirements.
(5) Meeting Minutes: Any member attending remotely via electronic means shall be counted as

Sec. 2-34. Quorum; Compelling Attendance:
A majority of the members of the city council shall constitute a quorum to do business. A smaller
number, however, may adjourn from time to time and may compel absentees to attend any regular or
special meeting by a written citation, which citation shall be signed by the mayor or councilman issuing
the same and shall be served upon the absentee by any officer authorized by law to serve processes in
the city, by reading the same to such absentee and serving him with a copy thereof. Any councilman
refusing to obey such citation shall forfeit ten dollars ($10.00), to be deducted out of his salary; and upon
the repeated refusal to obey such citation, without good cause, such councilman may be expelled and
his office declared abandoned. The council may also compel members of boards and commissions to
attend meetings of those bodies. (1963 Code, ch. II, art. I)
Sec. 2-35. Ordinances - Adoption:
No ordinance shall be adopted by the city council at the same meeting at which it is offered for
consideration, but each ordinance shall pass to a second reading and shall not be adopted at a meeting
occurring less than five (5) days after the meeting at which its consideration was moved, or at which it
was referred. A motion may be made to consider, suspend operation of this rule, and adopt the
ordinance; and the ordinance shall be adopted if two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the city council vote
favorably therefor. (1963 Code, ch. II, art. I; Ord., § 1, 5-3-1976)
Sec. 2-36. Ordinances - Publication:
The city clerk shall cause to be published all ordinances required to be published by law. (1963 Code,
ch. II, art. I)
Sec. 2-37. Independent Annual Audit:
As soon as possible after the close of each fiscal year the council shall cause an audit of the funds and
accounts of the city by independent certified public accountants; and copies of the audit shall be filed
with the city clerk, the comptroller of the state, and such other places as required by law. (1963 Code,
Ch. II, Art. I)
Sec. 2-38. Term Of Office:
The term of office of the mayor and councilmen shall be four (4) years and until their successors are
elected and qualified. Their election shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois Compiled
Statutes. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. I)
Sec. 2-39. Vacancy:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 16/735
If a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor or councilman, the vacancy shall be filled by appointment or
election as provided in the state statutes. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. I)
Sec. 2-40. Conduct At City Council Meetings:
It shall be unlawful for any person to by his conduct interfere with the orderly conduct of a city council
meeting after first being warned that his conduct is disrupting the assembly and is given the opportunity
to cease and yet fails to do so.
It shall also be unlawful for any person to use or possess any bullhorn or similar sound amplification
equipment in the city council chambers other than the equipment utilized by the city or by members of
the regular news media in the course of the news reporting functions.
Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 94-49, 5-23-1994)
Sec. 2-41. Violation Of City Council Policies At City Council Meetings:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the policies adopted by the city council for the
conduct of its meetings after first being warned that his conduct is disrupting the assembly and is given
the opportunity to cease and yet fails to do so.
Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 94-49, 5-23-1994)
Sec. 2-42. Repeal Of Conflicting Ordinances:
All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with section 2-40 or 2-41 of this article are hereby
repealed insofar as they do so conflict. (Ord. 94-49, 5-23-1994)
Sec. 2-43. Effective Date:
Sections 2-40 and 2-41 of this article shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and
approval as required by law. (Ord. 94-49, 5-23-1994)
Secs. 2-44--2-50. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 2-51. Oaths; bonds:
(a)Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices and positions, all officers elected or
appointed shall take and subscribe the oath as required by state statute.
(b)Officials and employees of the city designated by the council shall execute a bond in the amount
required by the council with security to be approved as provided by law. Each bond shall be payable
to the city, shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the office and the
payment of all money received by such officer, and shall be filed with the city clerk. (1963 Code, Ch.
II, Arts. I, III; Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976)

Sec. 2-52. Residency Requirement For City Employees:
(a)All employees of the city hired after June 11, 1991, shall live within ten (10) miles of the intersection of
17th Street and 31st Avenue in Rock Island, Illinois, and within the state of Illinois unless their
collective bargaining agreement grants an exception to this section.
(b)All new employees of the city hired after June 11, 1991, shall be allowed up to six (6) months from the
expiration of their probationary period to relocate into the defined area.
(c)This section shall not apply to employees where both husband and spouse are employees of the city
of Rock Island and one of said employees was hired prior to June 10, 1991, and the other spouse
subsequent to said date. (Ord. 91-72, § 1, 6-10-1991; Ord. 91-131, §§ 1-3, 12-2-1991; Ord. 94-75, §§

DIVISION 2. CITY MANAGER
Sec. 2-66. Office created:
The office of city manager is hereby created. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III)
Sec. 2-67. Appointment:
The city manager shall be appointed by majority vote of the city council for an indefinite term. The city
manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications, with
special reference to his actual experience in, or his knowledge of, accepted practice in respect to the
duties set forth in this division. At the time of his appointment he need not be a resident of the city or the
state, but during his tenure of office he shall reside within the city. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III)
Sec. 2-68. Powers And Duties:
The city manager shall be the head of the administrative branch of the city. The manager shall have and
exercise all powers and duties assigned to him by statute and such other authority as may be granted by
the city council. In addition to the powers and duties required by statute, the manager shall have the
following powers and duties:
(1) To enforce all laws and ordinances within the city insofar as the enforcement is within the powers
of the city.
(2) To attend all meetings of the city council and to recommend to the council such action as may be
necessary or expedient for the welfare of the city.
(3) To hire and discharge all employees authorized by the city council to be hired at such
compensation as may be set or authorized by the city council. All employees shall perform their
duties subject to the direction of the city manager or that of the superior to whom the manager may
assign such employee. Provided that the manager may delegate to any other official or employee the
authority to hire or discharge any employees so authorized.
(4) To retain, appoint and discharge the city attorney and assistant city attorneys. In addition to the
aforesaid legal staff, to appoint, with the consent of the city council, such legal counsel as the city
manager deems necessary to perform such duties as may from time to time be directed by the city
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 18/735
manager or the city attorney. The special counsel as may be appointed shall not perform any
services for the city until the manner in which they shall be compensated for their services shall be
resolved. The city council shall determine the manner of compensation for the special counsel.
(5) All appointive offices of the city shall be filled by appointment by the city manager, except where
otherwise required by statute and except for offices on boards and commissions established by local
ordinances; and the manager shall report to the mayor and to the city council such appointments, or
any removal from office, made by him as soon as possible after the appointment or removal. Every
administrative department of the city shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager,
who shall have the power to appoint and remove all department heads except where otherwise
specifically required by statute.
(6) The city manager shall examine all proposed contracts to which the city may be a party and may
sign on behalf of the city any contract authorized by the city council, excepting where the city council
directs or has directed that some other officer or officers shall do so. Any contract for purchase of
supplies, materials and equipment, and any and all contracts for contractual services made by the
city wherein said total price or contractual service price exceeds two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00), except for operating supplies, shall be made only after prior authorization by the city
council. The city manager shall see that all terms of any contract to which the city is a party are fully
performed by all parties thereto.
(7) The city manager shall cause to be prepared each year the annual budget in time for
consideration and enactment by the city council, during the first quarter of the fiscal year; and to
prepare the tax levy ordinance for passage, and file a certified copy thereof with the county clerk
within the time required by law. He shall keep current accounts of the amounts appropriated and the
amounts spent out of such appropriation, showing the unexpended appropriations at all times.
(8) The city manager shall recommend to the city council the salaries to be paid each appointive
officer and subordinate employee of the city.
(9) The city manager may make investigations into the affairs of the city or any department or division
thereof, and may investigate all complaints in relation to the administration of the government of the
city and in regard to service maintained by the public utilities in the city, and see that all franchises,
permits and privileges granted by the city are faithfully observed.
(10) The city manager shall maintain an office in the city hall and shall devote his entire time to the
discharge of his official duties.
(11) The city manager may consolidate or combine offices, positions, departments or units under his
jurisdiction, with the approval of the city council, and he may be the head of one or more
departments.
(12) The city manager shall appoint the members of the board of local improvements. This board
shall consist of not less than three (3) nor more than five (5) members. One of such members shall
be designated by the city manager as president of the board. The board shall meet at such times as
it may determine or upon call of the president thereof, and shall have the powers and duties granted
to it by statute.
(13) In cases of an accidental injury to or death of firemen and policemen, the city manager will follow
all applicable state laws such as the workers' compensation act 1, workers' occupational disease act
2, line of duty compensation act 3, public safety employee benefits act 4 and public employee
disability act 5.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 19/735
a. Medical Care: In case of an accident resulting in an injury to or death of a policeman or fireman
in the employ of the city while in the performance of his duties, the city manager or his designee
shall have authority to secure and provide all necessary first aid, medical and surgical services,
and all necessary medical, surgical, and hospital services thereafter incurred, limited, however, to
that which is reasonably required to cure or relieve the effects of the accidental injury.
b. Investigation Of Facts: It shall be the duty of the city manager or his designee to make a
complete investigation of all facts surrounding any accident resulting in an injury to or death of a
policeman or fireman in the employ of the city while in the performance of his duties, to obtain the
statements of all material witnesses and to present a report thereof to the council. Such report
shall also show the date and hour of any such accident, the place of occurrence of the same, the
names and addresses of witnesses, the apparent nature and extent of the injury and whether the
injury or death was caused under circumstances creating a legal liability for damages on the part of
some person other than the city. Where the injury or death for which compensation is payable was
caused by some other person other than the employer, then legal proceedings may be taken
against such other person to recover damages notwithstanding such employer's payment of or
liability to pay compensation.
c. Payment Of Expenses: All bills showing the items of expenses incurred for any medical care and
hospital treatment referred to in subsection (13)a of this section shall be presented to the city
manager, who shall satisfy himself as to the reasonableness of the charges made for the services
so rendered and approve the bills submitted by the personnel department and make his
recommendation to the council as to the payment of such claim expenses by the city.
d. Reimbursement By Third Person: If the city attorney is of the opinion that any accident referred
to in this section created a legal liability for damages on the part of some person other than the
city, it shall be the duty of the city manager or his designee to demand from such person
reimbursement to the city for the amount expended by the city for the medical care and hospital
treatment of any such policeman or fireman. In default of payment of such amount so expended,
the city attorney may institute proceedings to recover for the city the amount so expended.
(14) The city manager shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by the city council.
(1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III; Ord., § 2, 2-14-1977; Ord. 93-08, § 1, 2-8-1993; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-
2008)
Sec. 2-69. Absence Or Incapacity:
In the event that the city manager shall be absent from the city or incapacitated from performing the
duties of his position, the city council may designate a qualified administrative officer to act as city
manager during such absence or incapacity. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III)
Sec. 2-70. Removal 21:
The city manager may be removed by the council by a majority vote of its members. The city manager
may demand written charges or a written statement of the reasons for removal, which the council shall
furnish to the city manager within twenty (20) days after the filing of such request. During this period, the
city manager may be suspended from office without pay. The action of the council in removing the city
manager shall be final. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III)
Sec. 2-71. Administrative Assistant:
(a)Position Created: There is hereby created the position of administrative assistant to the city manager.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 20/735
(b)Residence; Appointment; Removal: The administrative assistant shall be appointed and removed by
the city manager. At the time of his appointment he need not be a resident of the city or the state, but
during his employment by the city he shall reside within the city.
(c)Duties: The administrative assistant shall be directly responsible to the city manager, and his duties
shall be assigned to him from time to time by the city manager. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III)
Secs. 2-72-2-85. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. CITY CLERK
Sec. 2-86. Appointment; Term Of Office 22:
The city clerk shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years as provided by law. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art.
I; Ord., 11-22-1976)
Sec. 2-87. Duties Generally 23:
(a)The corporate seal of the city shall be and remain in the custody and keeping of the city clerk, to be
used by him in all cases provided for by the ordinances of the city or the laws of the state, and in all
such other cases where, by the laws and customs of any state or nation, the use of the corporate
seal of the city may be requisite or proper.
(b)He shall keep all papers belonging to the city, the custody and control of which are not given to other
officers. He shall attend all meetings of the city council and keep a full record of its proceedings in the
journal.
(c)He shall keep and maintain a license record showing to whom, for what purpose, for what time, for
what license fee and for what length of time licenses have been granted.
(d)He shall perform such additional duties as are assigned to him from time to time by the director of
finance of the city. Further, he shall keep a current index of all special ordinances of the city and keep
a current revision of the revised ordinances of the city. (1963 Code, Ch. I, Art. III, and Ch. II, Art. I;
Ord., 11-22-1976)
Sec. 2-88. Deputy Clerk 24:
The city clerk may designate a deputy clerk to do such acts and exercise such authority as is granted by
law. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. I)

DIVISION 4. CITY TREASURER 25
Sec. 2-101. Appointment; Term Of Office 26:
The city treasurer shall be appointed and serve for a term of four (4) years. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. I;
Ord., 11-22-1976)
Sec. 2-102. Duties Generally 27:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 21/735
The city treasurer shall receive all monies belonging to the city, and he shall keep accurate and
