ARTICLE V. FINANCE 40
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 2-141. Fiscal Year 41:
The fiscal year of the city shall commence on April 1 of each calendar year. Beginning January 1, 2015,
the fiscal year shall commence on January 1 of each calendar year. (1963 Code, ch. I, art. V; Ord. 052-
2013, 9-9-2013)
Sec. 2-142. Director-Generally:
(a)Office Created, Appointment: There shall be a department of finance, the head of which shall be the
director of finance, who shall be, or be appointed by, the city manager with the approval of the city
council.
(b)Qualifications: The director of finance shall have knowledge of municipal accounting and shall have
had experience in budgeting and financial control. (Ord., 11-22-1976)
Sec. 2-143. Director-Powers And Duties:
The director of finance shall have charge of the administration of the financial affairs of the city and to
that end he shall:
(1) Compile the current expense estimates for the budget for the city manager.
(2) Compile the capital estimates for the budgets for the city manager.
(3) Supervise and be responsible for the disbursement of all monies and have control over all
expenditures to ensure that budget appropriations are not exceeded.
(4) Maintain a general accounting system for the city government and each of its offices,
departments and agencies; keep books for and exercise financial budgetary control over each office,
department and agency; keep separate accounts for the items of appropriation contained in the city
budget, each of which accounts shall show the amount of the appropriation, the amounts paid
therefrom, the unpaid obligations against it, and the unencumbered balance; and require reports of
receipts and disbursements from each receiving and spending agency of the city government to be
made daily or at such intervals as he may deem expedient.
(5) Submit to the council through the city manager a monthly statement of all receipts and
disbursements in sufficient detail to show the exact financial condition of the city.
(6) Prepare for the city manager, as of the end of each fiscal year, a complete financial statement and
report.
(7) Supervise and be responsible for all special assessments for the city government, and give such
notice of special assessments as may be required by law.
(8) Collect all special assessments, license fees and other revenues of the city or for whose
collection the city is responsible and receive all money receivable by the city from the state or federal
government, or from any court, or from any office, department or agency of the city.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 33/735
(9) Deposit all funds coming into his hands in such depositories as may be designated by resolution
of the council, or, if no such resolution is adopted, by the city manager, subject to the requirements of
law as to surety and the payment of interest on deposits; but all such interest shall be the property of
the city and shall be accounted for and credited to the proper account.
(10) Approve all proposed expenditures; unless he shall certify that there is an unencumbered
balance of appropriation and available funds, no appropriation shall be encumbered and no
expenditure shall be made. (1963 Code, ch. I, art. IV; Ord., § 1, 10-12-1968; Ord., § 1, 6-21-1976;
Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-144. Work Programs; Allotments:
Before the beginning of the budget year, the head of each office, department or agency shall submit to
the city manager, when required by him, a work program for the year, which program shall show the
requested allotments of the appropriations for such office, department or agency for the entire budget
year. The city manager shall review the requested allotments in light of the work program of the office,
department or agency concerned and may revise, alter or change such allotments before approving the
same. The aggregate of such allotments shall not exceed the total appropriation available to said office,
department or agency for the budget year. (Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-145. Allotments Constitute Basis Of Expenditures And Are Subject To
Revision:
The city manager shall file a copy of the allotments with the director of finance, who shall authorize all
expenditures for the offices, departments and agencies to be made from the appropriations on the basis
of approved allotments and not otherwise. An approved allotment may be revised during the budget year
in the same manner as the original allotment was made. If, at any time during the budget year, the city
manager shall ascertain that the available income, plus balances, for the year will be less than the total
appropriations, he shall reconsider the work programs and allotments of the several offices, departments
and agencies and revise the allotments so as to forestall the making of expenditures in excess of the
said income. (Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976)
Sec. 2-146. Transfers Of Appropriations:
The city manager may at any time transfer any unencumbered appropriation balance or portion thereof
between general classifications of expenditures within an office, department or agency. At the request of
the city manager and within the budget year, the council may by resolution transfer any unencumbered
appropriation balance or portion thereof from one office, department or agency to another. (Ord., § 1, 11-
22-1976)
Sec. 2-147. Accounting Supervision And Control:
The director of finance shall:
(1) Prescribe the forms of receipts, vouchers, bills or claims to be used by all the offices, departments
and agencies of the city government.
(2) Audit and approve before payment all bills, invoices, payrolls and other evidences of claims,
demands or charges against the city government and with the advice of the legal department
determine the regularity, legality and correctness of such claims, demands or charges.
(3) Inspect and audit any accounts or records of financial transactions which may be maintained in
any office, department or agency of the city government apart from or subsidiary to the accounts kept
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 34/735
in his office. (Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-148. When Contracts And Expenditures Prohibited:
No officer, department or agency shall, during any budget year, expend or contract to expend any money
or incur any liability, or enter into any contract which by its terms involves the expenditure of money, for
any purpose, in excess of the amounts appropriated or that general classification of expenditure. Any
contract, verbal or written, made in violation of this chapter shall be null and void. Any officer or
employee of the city who shall violate this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction
thereof, shall cease to hold his office or employment. Nothing in this section, however, shall prevent the
making of contracts or the spending of money for capital improvements to be financed in whole or in part
by the issuance of bonds, nor the making of contracts of lease or for services for a period exceeding the
budget year in which such contract is made, when such contract is permitted by law. (Ord., § 1, 11-22-
1976)
Sec. 2-149. Appropriations Lapse At End Of Year:
All appropriations shall lapse at the end of the fiscal year to the extent that they shall not have been
expended or lawfully encumbered. (Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976)
Sec. 2-150. Fees Shall Be Paid To City Government:
All fees received by any officer or employee shall belong to the city government and shall be paid daily
to the department of finance. (Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976)
Sec. 2-151. Division Of Purchases:
(Rep. by Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-152. Competitive Bidding:
Before any purchase of or contract for supplies, materials or equipment, city departments shall give
ample opportunity for competitive bidding, under such rules and regulations, and with such exceptions,
as the council may prescribe; however, the council shall not exempt individual contracts, purchases or
sales from the requirement of competitive bidding. (Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-
2008)
Sec. 2-153. Contracts For City Improvements:
Any city improvement costing more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall be executed by contract
except where such improvement is authorized by the council to be executed directly by a city
department in conformity with detailed plans, specifications and estimates. All such contracts, except in
an emergency situation, for more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall be awarded to the lowest
responsible bidder after such public notice and competition as may be prescribed by ordinance, provided
the city manager shall have the power to reject all bids and advertise again. Alterations in any contract
may be made when authorized by the council upon the written recommendation of the city manager.
(Ord., § 1, 11-22-1976)
Sec. 2-154. Accounting Control Of Purchases:
Purchases shall be made pursuant to the purchasing policies, rules and regulations as prescribed by the
city council. All purchases made and contracts executed shall be pursuant to a written requisition from
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 35/735
the head of the office, department or agency whose appropriation will be charged; and no contract or
order shall be issued to any vendor unless and until the director of finance certifies that there is to the
credit of such office, department or agency a sufficient unencumbered appropriation balance to pay for
the supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services for which the contract or order is to be issued,
unless authorized by the purchasing policies, rules and regulations prescribed by the city council. (Ord.,
§ 1, 11-22-1976; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-155. Returned Checks:
Any person who attempts to pay to the city for any city obligation by the use of a check which is later
dishonored by the drawer's bank shall pay to the city a service fee in the amount of thirty five dollars
($35.00) and any additional fees incurred by the city for the returned check. (Ord. 044-2013, 8-12-2013)
Sec. 2-156. Options On City Owned Property-Requests:
(Rep. by Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-157. Options On City Owned Property-Consideration Paid:
(Rep. by Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-158. Options On City Owned Property-Applicability:
(Rep. by Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-159. Bids On Behalf Of City At Tax Sales, Etc.:
The finance director and the city attorney are authorized to attend annually any sale of property to
enforce the collection of any tax or special assessment and bid for and on behalf of the city all
delinquent special assessments offered for sale, on default of other bidders therefor, as provided for in
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/9-2-98. (Ord. 82-32, § 1, 9-27-1982)
Sec. 2-160. Public Works Contract Wages:
(a)To the extent and as required by "an act regulating wages of laborers, mechanics and other workers
employed in any public works by state, county, city or any public body or any political subdivision or
by anyone under contract for public works", approved June 26, 1941, as amended, the general
prevailing rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics and other workers engaged in
construction of public works coming under the jurisdiction of the city is hereby ascertained to be the
same as the prevailing rate of wages for construction work in Rock Island County area as determined
by the department of labor of the state of Illinois as of June of the current year. As required by said
act, any and all revisions of the prevailing rate of wages by the department of labor of the state of
Illinois shall supersede the department's June determination and apply to any and all public works
construction undertaken by the city. The definition of any terms appearing in this section which are
also used in aforesaid act shall be the same as in that act.
(b)Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply general prevailing rate of wages as herein
ascertained to any work or employment except public works construction of the city to the extent
required by the aforesaid act.
(c)The city clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any interested party in the main
office of the city this determination of such prevailing rate of wages.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 36/735
(d)The city clerk shall mail a copy of this determination to any employer, and to any association of
employers and to any person of association of employees who have filed or file their names and
addresses, requesting copies of any determination stating the particular rates and particular class of
workers whose wages will be affected by such rates.
(e)The city clerk shall promptly file a certified copy of this section with both the secretary of state and the
department of labor of the state. (Ord. 85-18, §§ 1-4, 6-17-1985; Ord. 86-40, 8-11-1986; Ord. 058-
2008, 8-25-2008)
Secs. 2-161--2-170. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. BUDGET POLICIES AND PROCEDURES
Sec. 2-171. Establishment Of Policy:
There is hereby established a Budget Policy, which shall be implemented by the City Manager in the
orderly preparation of an annual budget. (Ord., 3-15-1982)
Sec. 2-172. Implementation By Manager:
The City Manager shall:
(1) Establish and encourage the use of efficient fiscal management procedures in all departments of
the City.
(2) Prepare and present to the Council an annual budget.
(3) Obtain detailed information from all City departments for the purpose of compiling the budget.
Such information shall be in the form required by the City Manager. (Ord., 3-15-1982)
Sec. 2-173. Budget - Compilation; Contents:
The budget shall contain estimates of revenue available to the City for the fiscal year for which the
budget is drafted, together with recommended expenditures for all departments. Revenue and
expenditure recommendations shall be presented in a manner which is in conformity with good fiscal
management practices. The budget shall contain actual revenues and expenditures for the two (2)
budget years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. The budget shall
show the specific fund from which each anticipated expenditure is to be made. (Ord., 3-15-1982)
Sec. 2-174. Budget - Passage; Effect:
Passage of the annual budget by the City Council shall be in lieu of the passage of the appropriation
ordinance as heretofore required. The budget shall be adopted by ordinance before the beginning of the
fiscal year to which it applies. Subsequent to the passage of the budget, an ordinance shall be passed
establishing Property Taxes to be levied for the fiscal year in accordance with applicable law. This
ordinance shall establish Property Taxes as may be required by the approved budget and shall be
known and referred to as the tax levy ordinance. (Ord., 3-15-1982)
Sec. 2-175. Budget - Revision:
During the fiscal year, the City Manager may make adjustments with any departmental budget as
becomes necessary, providing that those revisions do not delete or basically change any activity or
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 37/735
program approved by the City Council in the budget document. Any such adjustments shall not cause
total expenditures within the budget to exceed revenues. (Ord., 3-15-1982)
Sec. 2-176. Contingency Funds:
The annual budget may contain funds set aside for contingency purposes not to exceed five percent
(5%) of the budget. (Ord., 3-15-1982)
Sec. 2-177. Public Inspection, Notice And Hearing On Budget:
The City Manager shall make the proposed annual budget conveniently available for public inspection at
least ten (10) days prior to the public hearing on the budget as provided in this division. Notice of the
availability for inspection of the proposed budget shall be given at least ten (10) days prior to the time of
the hearing. (Ord., 3-15-1982)
Sec. 2-178. Holding Of Hearing; Notice Published:
At least one public hearing shall be held on the proposed annual budget prior to final approval thereof.
Notice shall be given by publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the City at least ten
(10) days prior to the date of the hearing. (Ord., 3-15-1982)
Sec. 2-179. Annual Financial Report; Home Rule:
Following the conclusion of each fiscal year the City Manager shall prepare and submit to the City
Council an annual report of the financial condition of the City and a summary of revenues and
expenditures for the preceding fiscal year. This report shall be substantially in accordance with the
recommendations of the Government Finance Officers Association for such reports. It shall be the
responsibility of the City Manager to see that the annual fiscal report is complete and made available for
public inspection. The State law requiring an annual appropriation ordinance and an annual Treasurer's
report shall not be applicable within the City. This division is adopted pursuant to the Illinois Constitution
and the City's power as a home rule unit. (Ord., 3-15-1982; Ord. 058-2008, 8-25-2008)
Secs. 2-180-2-200. Reserved:
ARTICLE VI. BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES GENERALLY
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 2-201. Meetings:
All boards and commissions created by the City Council shall hold meetings at least four (4) times each
year. (Ord., 6-28-1965)
Secs. 2-202-2-215. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. APPOINTMENTS; REMOVALS
Sec. 2-216. Compliance:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 38/735
(a)All appointments to boards and commissions of the City shall be for a three (3) year term unless
otherwise provided by State Statute or which are otherwise specifically provided by City ordinance
passed subsequent to the effective date hereof. All appointments to boards or commissions having
less than three (3) year terms prior to adoption of this section shall be for staggered terms in the
initial appointments made during the year commencing with the effective date hereof.
(b)A person is not eligible to serve on a board or commission if that person is in arrears in the payment
of a tax or other indebtedness due to the Municipality or has been convicted in any court located in
the United States of bribery or perjury.
(c)If, during a term of service on a board or commission, a violation of subsection (b) of this section
comes to the attention of the Mayor, the Mayor may give a 30-day written notice to cure the violation.
In the event the violation is not cured or not susceptible to cure, the Mayor may remove the board
member or Commissioner.
(d)Removal of the board member or Commissioner pursuant to subsection (c) of this section is
cumulative and not exclusive of other procedures that may be available to the City for any violation of
subsection (b) of this section. (Ord. 041-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 2-217. Application Forms:
The City Clerk shall have available in his office and at the City Hall reception desk application forms
wherein citizens of the City may apply for consideration to appointment to any board or commission in
the City. Any application received by the City Clerk pursuant to this division shall be submitted by him to
the mayor and city council for consideration at the time appointments are considered. (Ord., § 1, 1-14-
1974)
Sec. 2-218. Council Notified Of Vacancy:
Not later than thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the term of any member of a board or commission
of the city, the mayor's office shall notify the members of city council in writing of the forthcoming
vacancy. In the event of a resignation, termination for cause or death of any member of any board or
commission of the city, the mayor's office shall notify the members of the city council in writing of this
information when the mayor's office receives the information. (Ord., § 1, 1-14-1974)
Sec. 2-219. Consideration Of Appointments:
During the thirty (30) day period prior to the expiration of a term of any member of a board or
commission of the city, or during the thirty (30) day period following the resignation, termination for
cause or death of any member of any board or commission, the mayor shall consult with the members of
the city council regarding possible candidates for the appointment to the vacant position; and all
applications from citizens of the city for appointment as set forth in this division shall also be considered.
(Ord., § 1, 1-14-1974)
Sec. 2-220. Decision Of Mayor And Council:
After due consideration of candidates for appointment described in this division, the mayor shall, within
the aforementioned thirty (30) day period, appoint the member or members to the boards or
commissions of the city with the consent of the members of the city council. (Ord., § 1, 1-14-1974)
Sec. 2-221. Failure To Appoint:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 39/735
In the event the mayor fails to make an appointment within the period described in this division, or in the
event the mayor makes an appointment within the period which is not confirmed by the city council, the
city council may, at the conclusion of the thirty (30) day period, appoint, at its discretion, someone to fill
the vacant position by a simple majority vote. (Ord., § 1, 1-14-1974)
Sec. 2-222. Termination For Cause:
The mayor and city council may terminate the term of any member of any board or commission of the
city if, after a hearing thereon, it is determined that there is due cause for the termination of the term of
the member. This action shall take place only after a majority of the city council and mayor vote to take
such action. (Ord., § 1, 1-14-1974)
Secs. 2-223-2-230. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
Sec. 2-231. State Law In Effect:
All the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-1 et seq., not inconsistent with the provisions
of this division shall remain in full force and effect in the city. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980)
Sec. 2-232. Created:
There is hereby created in the city a board of fire and police commissioners, referred to in this division
as the "board". The mayor, with the consent of the city council, shall appoint the members of the board.
The board shall consist of three (3) members, whose terms of office shall be four (4) years and until their
respective successors are appointed and have qualified for office. Each member of the board shall take
an oath of office when appointed thereto. The members shall be subject to removal from office in the
same manner as other appointed officers in the city. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III; Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980)
Sec. 2-233. Quorum:
A majority of the board of fire and police commissioners constitutes a quorum for the conduct of all
business. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980)
Sec. 2-234. Duties Generally:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall have charge of examinations for membership in the fire
and police departments and in conjunction with the chiefs of each department, making promotions within
the departments. The board shall also hear charges which may be brought against any fireman or police
officer of the city and may determine what punishment, in accord with section 2-241 of this division, is
appropriate if the board finds any of the charges have been proved. The board shall further act as an
appeal board to review any appeals of suspensions imposed by either chief of the fire or police
departments as hereinafter provided. The board shall also perform such other functions as provided by
ordinance. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III; Ord., § 1, 2-23-1970; Ord., § 1, 5-20-1974; Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980;
Ord. 82-75, § 1, 3-14-1983)
Sec. 2-235. Appointments Generally:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the fire and police
departments according to rules and regulations adopted by the board of police and fire commissioners of
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 40/735
Rock Island, not inconsistent with the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-1 et
seq. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-236. Examinations Of Applicants; Disqualifications; Removals:
(a)All qualified applicants, excluding those applicants accepted by the board of fire and police
commissioners under the lateral entry option of the police department, other than applicants for chief,
shall be subject to examination which shall be public, competitive and free to all applicants. All
applicants shall be subject to reasonable limitations as to health, habits and moral character in order
to qualify for examination. The board of police and fire commissioners of Rock Island shall establish
rules and regulations setting forth qualifications and disqualifications of applicants. The board of
police and fire commissioners shall, in accordance with its regulations, determine whether applicants
are qualified or disqualified.
(b)The examinations shall be practical in character and relate to those matters which will fairly test the
capacity of the persons examined to discharge the duties of the positions to which they seek
appointment. The examinations may include, but not be limited to: 1) a polygraph test; 2) a written
examination; 3) an oral examination; 4) a test of physical agility; 5) a psychological test; and 6) a
medical examination. No applicant shall be examined concerning his political or religious opinions or
affiliations. The examination of applicants shall be as set forth by rules and regulations of the board
of police and fire commissioners of Rock Island. The examinations shall be conducted by or at the
direction of the board of police and fire commissioners. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980; Ord., § 2, 1-12-1981;
Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-237. Probationary Period:
(a)All original appointments are subject to a probationary period of not less than twelve (12) months and
shall be served by all members or officers of the fire or police department. Probationary periods may
be extended and are subject to the rules and regulations adopted by the board of police and fire
commissioners of Rock Island. A member or officer shall only obtain "certified status" upon
completion of the probationary period and successful completion of the basic training course
prescribed by the Illinois government law enforcement officers training board, for police officers or the
certified firefighter II course as prescribed by the Illinois fire protection personnel standard and
education commission for firefighters, within the probationary period.
(b)Any employee promoted to a higher classification shall be subject to a probationary period and shall
not receive a permanent appointment for six (6) months and may be returned to his previous certified
status, for cause, within six (6) months from the date of promotion. This time period may be extended
an additional six (6) months by the chief. The promoted employee shall retain the right to
reemployment with the rank from which he was promoted and hold certified status providing the
previous rank still exists, and the employee is still otherwise qualified. Upon successful completion of
the probationary period, the promoted employee, upon the written request of the fire or police chief,
shall attain "certified" status in the new title and may be listed by the board in the official record of
"certified" employees for the new title. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-238. Temporary Appointments 1:
In order to prevent a stoppage of public business, to meet extraordinary emergencies or to prevent
material impairment to the fire or police department, the police or fire chief, with the approval of the city
manager, may make temporary appointments to remain in force until regular appointments may be made
under the provisions of this division, but never to exceed six (6) consecutive months. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-
1980)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 41/735
Sec. 2-239. Promotions 2:
(a)Police Department:
(1) Basis; Eligibility: The board of fire and police commissioners, by its rules, shall provide for
promotion in the police department on the basis of ascertained merit, seniority in service and
examinations, and shall provide whenever it is practical, that vacancies be filled by promotion. All
examinations for promotion shall be competitive. All certified officers or members of the police
department appearing on the record of certified employees maintained by the commission who meet
the necessary training and experience requirements, as specified in the fire and police commission
rules and regulations, shall be eligible to take the promotional examination for a vacancy in the police
department.
(2) Promotional Examination: The promotional examination procedures shall be established by the
board of police and fire commissioners of Rock Island. Promotional examinations shall consist of a
written examination, an oral interview, seniority, and military credit where provided by statute.
(3) Eligibility List: All persons who have successfully completed the promotional examinations shall
be certified to the promotional list by the board in the order of their scores. An eligibility list for
promotion shall be in effect for a period of twenty four (24) months unless during that period of twenty
four (24) months a vacancy or vacancies existed which were not filled by promotion as provided
herein. In the event that a vacancy or vacancies existed for a period of time during the twenty four
(24) months, eligibility list shall be extended for a period of time equal to the time that the vacancy or
vacancies existed during the twenty four (24) month period. At the end of the twenty four (24) month
period or any extensions thereof which is heretofore described, a new list shall be compiled.
(4) Selection: At the time that a promotion is required in the police department, the top five (5)
individuals on the "certified promotion list" shall be eligible to be considered for the promotion. The
decision as to the person to be promoted to the open position shall be determined in the following
manner: Each of the top five (5) individuals for the promotional position shall be evaluated by the
board and the chief of the department involved, jointly. Upon completion of all five (5) evaluations
with the eligible candidates, the board and the chief of the department involved shall make a
determination as to the candidate to receive the promotion. The decision as to which candidate shall
be promoted shall be determined by a vote of the board and the chief, with each commissioner
having one vote and the chief of the department involved having two (2) votes.
(5) Appointment : After a decision is made as aforesaid, the candidate to be appointed shall be
appointed by the board to his new position subject to final certification upon recommendation as
provided by the police chief, as stated in the fire and police commission rules and regulations.
(b)Fire Department:
(1) The board of fire and police commissioners shall provide for promotion for each rank in the fire
department, except for the fire chief, according to the rules and regulations which are in compliance
with the fire department promotions act 3 of 2003. The board of fire and police commissioners may
promulgate rules and regulations supplementing the fire department promotions act but may not
promulgate any rule or regulation which alters or modifies a specific standard contained in the fire
department promotions act.
(2) The board of fire and police commissioners, in consultation with the fire chief, shall determine
when a vacancy exists. When a vacancy exists it shall be filled as soon as possible from the list of
qualified individuals. No employee is eligible for promotion who does not have at least three (3) years
of seniority in the Rock Island fire department.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 42/735
(3) Employees eligible for promotion are those who appear on the promotion list for each rank. An
individual's position on a promotion list shall be determined by a combination of factors including a
written examination, ascertained merit, seniority and subjective evaluations. Each factor shall be
measured in terms of one hundred (100) points per factor but the score for each factor shall then be
reduced by the weight assigned to each factor. The total weighted score may be subsequently
augmented by the application of any veteran's preference as provided by applicable law. (Ord., § 1,
1-7-1980; Ord., § 1, 1-12-1981; Ord. 88-48, § 1, 8-22-1988; Ord. 88-49, § 1, 8-22-1988; Ord. 004-
2005, § 1, 1-24-2005; Ord. 058-2008, § 1, 8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-240. Lateral Entry Option:
Any person who is presently employed full time as a sworn, commissioned law enforcement officer, and
who has successfully completed a certified state basic course at a law enforcement academy may apply
to the board for consideration under the police lateral entry option. If the board of fire and police
commissioners, in its discretion, accepts the applicant's application under this program, he or she shall
have the option of taking the written exam or in lieu thereof, accepting a score of seventy percent (70%)
without being required to take the exam. In addition to the foregoing, each applicant shall be required to
take an oral examination and a medical examination by the city physician and the pension board
physician if the applicant is eligible for the pension program. In addition, the board shall require the
applicant to take a test of physical agility and a psychological test. Upon successful completion of the
foregoing, the applicant's name shall be placed on the list of certified eligibles by the board as set forth
in section 2-235 of this division. (Ord., § 3, 1-12-1981; Ord. 87-46, § 1, 4-27-1987)
Sec. 2-241. Suspension; Demotion; Removal; Discharge:
(a)Except as hereinafter provided and as provided by the police and fire commission regulations, no
"certified" member of the fire or police department shall be suspended, removed, demoted or
discharged, except upon a hearing before the board of police and fire commissioners and a finding
by the board that the charge or charges of misconduct have been proven by a preponderance of the
evidence. All hearings and hearing procedures shall be as set forth in the police and fire commission
regulations.
(b)A demotion is an assignment of an officer for cause to a position in a lower class or rank and may be
imposed only by the board after a hearing, as provided in this section.
(c)The chiefs of the fire and police department may suspend for cause, without pay, a member of his
department for a period of not more than five (5) days. Any member so suspended by the fire or
police chief as aforesaid shall have the right to appeal that action within seven (7) calendar days from
notification thereof to the board in writing. Any of the aforementioned disciplinary action by the chiefs
shall be in writing and shall contain a statement of facts which show good cause for the disciplinary
action. The notice of disciplinary action shall be served upon the officer personally or by certified
mail.
(d)If an appeal of a suspension imposed by a chief is filed, the board of fire and police commissioners
shall conduct a fair and impartial hearing of the appeal to be commenced within thirty (30) days of the
filing thereof, which hearing may be continued from time to time. In the event the board determines
that there was cause for the action taken by the chief, the action shall be affirmed by the board. If the
board determines that the charges are not sustained or that there was not just cause for the action
taken, then the officer shall be reimbursed for any portion of his wages he might be entitled to after
the decision of the board. The board shall also have the authority to modify the disciplinary action
taken against the particular individual involved, to include any discipline which the board has
authority to impose under this division subject to any limitations contained in any applicable contract.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 43/735
(e)In the conduct of any hearing on written charges, or on any appeal, each member of the board shall
have the power to administer oaths and affirmations; and the board shall have the power to secure
by its subpoena both the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of books and
papers relevant to the hearing. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980; Ord. 82-75, § 2, 3-14-1983; Ord. 058-2008, § 1,
8-25-2008)
Sec. 2-242. Administrative Review Law:
The provisions of the administrative review law and all amendments and modifications thereof and the
rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply to and govern all proceedings for the judicial review of final
administrative decisions of the board of fire and police commissioners under this division. The term
"administrative decision" is defined as in section 3-101 of the code of civil procedure 4. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-
1980)
Sec. 2-243. Retirement:
The age for retirement of certified members or officers of the fire or police department in the service of
the city shall be as required by state law. The city manager may extend the retirement date for one year;
such extension may be repeated on a year to year basis. Such mandatory age shall not apply to the fire
chief or police chief. (Ord., § 1, 1-7-1980)
Secs. 2-244--2-255. Reserved:
DIVISION 4. FAIR HOUSING BOARD 43
Sec. 2-256. Application Of Division:
(a)Nothing in this division shall require an owner to offer property to the public at large before selling or
renting it, nor shall this division be deemed to prohibit owners from giving preference to prospective
tenants or buyers for any reason other than religion, race or ancestry.
(b)Nothing in this division shall require an owner to offer property for sale or lease to any person if the
owner has any reason to believe that such person is not negotiating for the purchase or lease of such
property in good faith. (Ord., § 3, 10-9-1967)
Sec. 2-257. Generally:
(a)Established: For the purpose of this division the human rights commission of the city shall serve as
the fair housing board of the city.
(b)Duties: It shall be the duty of the fair housing board to:
(1) Process written and signed complaints of discrimination from bona fide applicants for housing
upon the filing of complaints with the city clerk and the payment of the filing fee.
(2) Seek conciliation of such complaints, hold hearings, make findings of fact and make
recommendations to the city council in accordance with the provisions of this division.
(3) Render from time to time, but not less than once a year, a written report of its activities to the city
council.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 44/735
(4) Adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary to carry out the purposes and provisions
of this division.
(c)Compensation: Members of the board shall serve without compensation from the city. The city shall
appropriate and make available funds for any necessary secretarial or investigative expenses
incurred by the board in performing its duties.
(d)Procedures For Complaints:
(1) Filing: Any person aggrieved in any manner by a violation of the provisions of this division shall
file a written complaint setting forth his grievance with the city clerk. The complaint shall state the
name and address of the complainant and of the persons against whom the complaint is brought and
shall also state the alleged facts surrounding the alleged violation of this division.
(2) Duty Of Clerk: The city clerk shall immediately transmit the complaint to the fair housing board.
(3) Investigation; Notice Of Hearing: After the filing of any complaint, the chairman of the board shall
designate two (2) of the members to make a prompt investigation in connection therewith; and if such
members shall determine after such investigation that probable cause exists for crediting the
allegations of the complaint, they shall immediately endeavor to eliminate the unlawful discriminatory
practice complained of by conference, conciliation and persuasion. In case of failure so to eliminate
such practice, or in advance thereof, if in their judgment circumstances so warrant, they shall cause
to be issued and served in the name of the board a written notice, together with a copy of such
complaint to all parties, of a full hearing of the complaint, at a time and place to be specified in such
notice. The person charged with having engaged in or engaging in the unfair housing practices shall
have the right to file an answer to the complaint, to appear at the hearing in person or to be
represented by counsel, and to submit testimony. The complainant shall be allowed to present
testimony in person or by counsel.
(4) Hearing; Report: Such hearing shall be conducted by the board. The board shall not be bound by
the strict rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity. The board shall have full power to
subpoena witnesses and pertinent documents, which power may be enforced by the board by proper
petition to the circuit court of the judicial circuit. The board shall have power to administer oaths and
to take sworn testimony. At the conclusion of the hearing the board shall render a written report and
recommendations, which shall be served by mail upon the parties. No report shall be delayed more
than sixty (60) days after the date of issuance of notice for commencement of the first hearing.
(5) Prosecution: In addition thereto, the board may include as part of its report a recommendation to
the city council that the city attorney prosecute any person or persons who violated any of the
provisions of this division. The penalty for violation of this division shall be a fine not exceeding two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
(6) Revocation Of License: In addition thereto, the city council may direct the corporation counsel to
file with the department of registration and education of the state a complaint against any real estate
broker found guilty of violating any provision of this division, seeking suspension or revocation of the
license issued to such broker by the state. (Ord., § 2, 10-9-1967; Ord., § 1, 11-20-1967; Ord., §§ 1, 2,
3-8-1971; Ord. 87-56, § 1, 6-1-1987; Ord. 011-2008, 2-4-2008)
Sec. 2-258. Unfair Practices:
(a)It shall be an unfair practice and unlawful for any person to:
(1) Publish, circulate, issue or display, or cause to be published, circulated, issued or displayed, any
communication, notice, advertisement, sign or other writing of any kind relating to the sale, rental or
leasing of any housing accommodation within the city which will indicate or express any limitation or
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 45/735
discrimination in the sale, rental or leasing of such housing accommodation, predicated upon the
race, religion or ancestry of any prospective buyer, lessee or renter of such property.
(2) Discriminate or participate in discrimination in connection with borrowing or lending of money,
guaranteeing loans, accepting mortgages or otherwise obtaining or making available funds for the
purchase, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of any housing
accommodation in the city because of race, religion or ancestry.
(3) Solicit for sale, lease or listing for sale or lease of any housing accommodation within the city on
the grounds of loss of value due to the present or prospective entry into any neighborhood of any
person or persons of any particular race, religion or ancestry.
(4) Distribute or cause to be distributed written material or statements designed to induce any owner
of any housing accommodation in the city to sell or lease his property because of any present or
prospective change in the race, religion or ancestry of persons in the neighborhood.
(5) Make any misrepresentations concerning the listing for sale or the anticipated listing for sale or
the sale of any housing accommodation for the purpose of inducing or attempting to induce the sale
or listing for sale of any housing accommodation by representing that the presence or anticipated
presence of persons of any particular race, religion or ancestry in the area will or may result in the
lowering of property values in the block, neighborhood or area in which the property is located.
(6) Deliberately and knowingly refuse examination of any listing of residential real estate within the
city to any person because of race, religion or ancestry.
(7) Refuse to sell, lease or rent any real estate for residential purposes within the city because of the
race, religion or ancestry of the proposed buyer or renter.
(b)The provisions of this section shall not apply to the rental of a room or rooms in a single-family
dwelling and the rental of an apartment in an owner occupied two-family building. (Ord., § 1, 10-9-
1967)
Secs. 2-259--2-270. Reserved.
DIVISION 5. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
Sec. 2-271. Generally:
(a)Created: There is hereby created the Rock Island human rights commission, referred to in this
division as the "commission", which shall consist of twelve (12) members, who are residents of the
city. The membership of the commission shall be broadly representative of the community, such as
representatives of the several religious faiths and of racial and nationality groups, and shall include
one member of the legal profession, one member from a lending institution, and one member who is
a realtor.
(b)Purpose: The overall purpose of the commission shall be through persuasion and education to
eliminate prejudice and discrimination based solely on the basis of race, color, creed, age, sex,
national origin, ancestry, religion, marital status, physical or mental disability, military status, sexual
orientation, or unfavorable discharge from military service and to safeguard the rights of all citizens
as defined by our laws and constitution. Areas of discrimination shall pertain to, but shall not be
limited to, employment, housing, public accommodations, finance/credit, public education and
economic opportunity. Furthermore, the commission shall protect all citizens from retaliation resulting
from filing a complaint to secure compliance with this division.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 46/735
(c)Objectives: The objectives of the commission shall be:
(1) To strive to remove the artificial barriers and controls which deny persons of the right to choose
their own homes.
(2) To seek through law, education, persuasion, negotiation and mediation the elimination of
discrimination in employment, including, but not limited to, selection, status, eligibility, promotion,
transfer, apprenticeship, membership, terms and conditions, privileges or benefits directly or
indirectly related to one's employment which may be affected by an employer, employment agency or
labor organization.
(3) To assist in the development of programs that aim toward equality and inclusion in educational
facilities and programs, and to ensure that they are available to all children according to their
potential and varying needs.
(4) To implement programs with the chief of police that address the diversity of the community.
(5) To stimulate active involvement of the business community in social programs encouraging
economic opportunity and full employment for all citizens.
(6) To develop a procedure to anticipate, prepare for and help ease community discomfort that may
arise from racial tensions.
(7) To act as a mediator and conciliator in instances of tension erupting into civil disturbance or riots,
and to offer recommendations that hasten necessary change which might eliminate the reoccurrence
of upheaval.
(8) To work for greater citizen participation in the planning and execution of public policy in all phases
of municipal life.
(d)Appointments: The members of the commission shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of
the city council. Special appointments to the commission shall be made by the mayor with the
approval of the city council as vacancies occur.
(e)Term: Each group of four (4) members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, thus assuring
a balance of twelve (12) members at all times.
(f)Meetings: The commission shall meet monthly at the city hall or at other venues at the call of the
chairman and at such further times as meetings are called by the chairman or majority of the
members of said commission. A majority of the commissioners shall constitute a quorum which shall
be required before any business may be conducted. At the April meeting of the commission,
commission members shall elect a chair and vice chair who shall serve for a term of one year. (1963
Code, Ch. II, Art. III; Ord., § 1, 2-13-1967; Ord., § 1, 6-23-1975; Ord. 87-55, § 1, 6-1-1987; Ord. 011-
2008, 2-4-2008)
Sec. 2-272. Duties And Powers:
(a)Generally: The commission shall advise and consult with the mayor, city manager and city council on
all matters involving racial, religious, ethnic, age or sex prejudice or discrimination.
(b)Investigations: The commission shall conduct informal investigations with regard to complaints of acts
of prejudice or discrimination as defined by this division. Complaints filed with the commission shall
be on forms provided by the commission and shall be filed not later than ninety (90) days from the
date upon which the alleged prejudicial or discriminatory act occurred. Upon the filing of a complaint,
the chair and/or the commission's designated city staff member shall present the complaint to the
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 47/735
commission for discussion at its next meeting. Complaints referred to the commission may be
reviewed and discussed by the commission and the commission shall seek to mediate and resolve
the dispute to the parties' satisfaction. The commission shall have the authority to refer the complaint
to such professional, governmental or adjudicatory agency as may be deemed appropriate based on
the nature of the complaint. In all matters, the commission shall give due consideration to other
proceedings which may already be in process and, where appropriate, delay its consideration until
such time as other proceedings have been concluded. Any two (2) members of the commission may
request review of a prior complaint or previous mediation.
(c)Report: The commission shall render an annual report to the mayor and city council.
(d)Community Groups: The commission shall invite and enlist the cooperation of racial, religious and
ethnic groups, community organizations, fraternal and benevolent societies, veterans' organizations,
professional and technical organizations and other groups in the city in carrying on its work. The
commission may aid in the formation of local community groups in such neighborhoods as it may
deem necessary or desirable to carry out specific programs designed to lessen tensions or improve
understanding in the community.
(e)City Departments: The commission shall request and obtain such cooperation, assistance and data
from city departments through the city manager as may be reasonably necessary to carry out its
work. (1963 Code, ch. II, art. III; Ord., §§ 2, 3, 6-23-1975; Ord. 011-2008, 2-4-2008; Ord. 005-2013,
2-11-2013)
Secs. 2-273--2-285. Reserved:
DIVISION 6. BUILDING CODE BOARD OF APPEALS
Sec. 2-286. Created; Members:
In order to determine the suitability of alternate materials and methods of construction, and to provide for
reasonable interpretations of the provisions of this code, there is hereby created a building code board of
appeals. This board shall consist of five (5) members who are qualified by experience and training to
pass on matters pertaining to building construction. One member shall be a practicing architect, one a
competent builder, one a lawyer and two (2) structural engineers, each of whom shall have at least ten
(10) years of experience as an architect, builder, lawyer or structural engineer. The building official shall
be an ex officio member and shall act as secretary to the board. The board of appeals shall be
appointed by the mayor and shall hold meetings at its pleasure. The board shall adopt reasonable rules
and regulations for conducting its investigations, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to
the building official, with a duplicate copy to the appellant, and may recommend to the city council such
new legislation as is consistent therewith. (Ord. 92-03, § 1, 1-6-1992)
Sec. 2-286.1. Right Of Appeal:
Any person whose application for a building permit for the use of an alternate material or method of
construction that has been refused by the building official, or who may consider that the provisions of
this code do not cover the point raised, or that any particular provisions would cause a manifest injury to
be done, may appeal to the building code board of appeals by serving a written notice to the building
official within fifteen (15) days after the decision is made, in which it shall be stated that the applicant
desiring to use the alternate materials or method of construction shall guarantee payment of all
expenses for necessary tests made or ordered by the board of appeals. Such notice shall be at once
transmitted to the board, which board shall arrange for a hearing within fifteen (15) days on the particular
point raised. (Ord. 92-03, § 1, 1-6-1992)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 48/735
DIVISION 6A. PLUMBING CODE BOARD OF APPEALS 46
Sec. 2-287. Created; Members:
In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official
relative to the application and interpretations of this code, there is hereby created a plumbing code board
of appeals consisting of members who are qualified by experience and training to pass upon matters
pertaining to the plumbing design, construction, maintenance and the public health aspects of plumbing
systems. Such board shall consist of seven (7) members, four (4) of whom shall be qualified and active
in the plumbing field. The Board shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall hold meetings at its pleasure,
choosing its own meeting time and rules of procedure. The Building Official shall be an ex officio
member and shall act as secretary to the Board but shall have no vote upon any matter before the
Board. The Board shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy
to the Building Official. (Ord. 92-05, 1-6-1992)
Sec. 2-287.1. Appeal Procedure:
Any person directly interested who is aggrieved by any decision of the inspector of the Plumbing Code
or from any requirement resulting from any enforcement of the Plumbing Code may appeal from such
decision to the Plumbing Code Board of Appeals. Any appeal may be made in writing to the Secretary
within fifteen (15) days after the decision is made, and the Chairman shall cause each member of the
Board to be notified of the appeal. The Board shall meet for a hearing within fifteen (15) days from the
date of appeal and shall render a decision within fifteen (15) days from the day of hearing. (Ord. 92-05,
1-6-1992)
DIVISION 6B. MECHANICAL CODE BOARD OF APPEALS
Sec. 2-287.2. Created; Members:
In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the Building Official
relative to the application and interpretations of the Mechanical Code of the City, there is hereby created
a Mechanical Code Board of Appeals consisting of members who are qualified by experience and
training to pass upon matters pertaining to mechanical design, construction and maintenance and the
public health aspects of mechanical systems and who are not employees of the City. Such Board shall
consist of at least seven (7) members: two (2) may be license holders engaged in the forced air, air
conditioning and ventilation business; one may be a license holder engaged in the hydronic and air
conditioning business; one may be a supervisor employed by the local gas utility company; one may be
a journeyman sheet metal worker; one may be a journeyman pipe fitter; and one may be a journeyman
refrigeration mechanic or a license holder engaged in the refrigeration business. A registered
professional engineer may serve as Chairman of the Board. The Building Official shall be an ex officio
member and shall act as secretary to the Board but shall have no vote upon any matter before the
Board. The Board shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall hold meetings at its pleasure. The Board
shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business and shall render all decisions and findings in
writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the Building Official. (Ord. 92-04, 1-6-1992)
Sec. 2-287.3. Appeal Procedure:
Any person directly interested who is aggrieved by any decision of the inspector or from any requirement
resulting from any enforcement of this Code may appeal from such decision to the Mechanical Code
Board of Appeals. The appeal shall be made by the person aggrieved giving written notice of such
appeal to the building inspector or his designee within fifteen (15) days after the decision is made. The
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 49/735
appeal Board shall meet within fifteen (15) days after the giving of such notice, and shall render a
decision within fifteen (15) days thereafter. Any interested party, including the Building Official or his
designee, shall have the right to present the case to such appeal Board, whose decision shall be final
unless appealed to the court as provided by law. (Ord. 92-04, 1-6-1992)
DIVISION 6C. ELECTRICAL CODE BOARD OF APPEALS
Sec. 2-287.3.1. Electrical Code Board Of Appeals:
There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Electrical Code Board of Appeals of the City,
which shall consist of six (6) members:
(1) The electrical inspector to serve as an ex officio member and act as Secretary of the commission.
(2) The Chief of the Fire Department.
(3) A licensed electrical contractor.
(4) A journeyman electrician.
(5) An electrical engineer.
(6) A representative of the local electric utility company.
This commission shall be appointed by the Mayor. If there is no person residing in the Municipality who
is qualified under any one of these descriptions, the Mayor may appoint some other person to fill that
position.
The Electrical Code Board of Appeals shall be and is charged with the duties of recommending safe and
practical standards and specifications for installing, altering, and use of electrical equipment designed to
meet the necessities of the Electrical Code of the City. The Electrical Code Board of Appeals may from
time to time as need or occasion demands, and in the interest of the public, require or recommend such
changes in the standards, specifications and fees as it may deem are necessary. Upon the changes of
any of the provisions set forth in this section, a copy of the same shall be filed in the Offices of the City
Clerk and the electrical inspector. Such recommendations made by the Electrical Code Board of Appeals
shall be subject to approval by the City Council. This commission shall also act as an Appeals Board for
appeals by individuals or organizations who wish to appeal a decision of the electrical inspector. This
Board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business and shall render all decisions and
findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the building official. (1963 Code art. 2-3; Ord.,
11-8-1965; Ord., 6-26-1978; Ord. 92-06, 1-6-1992; Ord. 005-2018, 1-22-2018)
Sec. 2-287.3.2. Appeal Procedure:
Any person directly interested who is aggrieved by any decision of the inspector of this Code or from any
requirement resulting from any enforcement of this Code may appeal from such decision to the Board of
Appeals. The appeal shall be made by the person aggrieved giving written notice of such appeal within
fifteen (15) days after the decision is made. The Appeal Board shall meet within fifteen (15) working
days after being given such notice and shall render a decision within fifteen (15) days thereafter in
writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the building official. Any interested party, including the
building official or his designee, shall have the right to present the case to such Appeal Board, whose
decision shall be final unless appealed to the court as provided by law. (1963 Code art. 2-3; Ord., 11-8-
1965; Ord., 6-26-1978; Ord. 92-06, 1-6-1992; Ord. 005-2018, 1-22-2018)

DIVISION 6D. COMMUNITY/YOUTH PARTNERSHIP COMMISSION
Sec. 2-287.4. Generally:
(a)Created: There is hereby created a Community/Youth Partnership Commission, which shall consist of
twenty seven (27) members, two (2) of which will be ex officio members. The membership of the
board shall be broadly representative of the community and include five (5) representatives from
social service agencies, five (5) representatives from the community at large, four (4) representatives
from youth representatives, four (4) representatives from the schools, four (4) representatives from
City government, and three (3) representatives from churches. The other two (2) members of the
commission shall be ex officio members who shall serve as staff for the commission. They shall be
Martin Luther King Center Director and the Recreation Director.
(b)Appointments: The members of the commission shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of
the City Council. Special appointments to the commission shall be made by the Mayor with consent
from the City Council as vacancies occur.
(c)Terms: Members shall be appointed for a period of three (3) years with the exception of the youth
representatives, who shall serve until their nineteenth birthday, and agency representatives, who
shall serve their term as long as they are employed by the agency.
(d)Meetings: The commission shall meet at City Hall at the call of the Chairman at least four (4) times
each year, and at such further times as meetings are called by the Chairman or a majority of
members of the commission. (Ord. 93-88, 10-18-1993)
Sec. 2-287.5. Purpose And Functions:
The Community/Youth Partnership Commission shall serve in an advisory capacity with the City Council
and shall be responsible for the following:
(a)Review the programs available for youth and identify areas that need changing and strengthening;
(b)Monitor the implementation of the goals established by the advisory task force on youth concerns;
(c)Provide leadership in raising funds and needed resources to establish and maintain the identified
youth programs;
(d)Promote the coordination of services by youth service providers; and
(e) Ensure that the public is made aware of all available youth services
and programs. (Ord. 93-88, 10-18-1993)
DIVISION 6E. PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE BOARD OF APPEALS
Sec. 2-287.6. Created; Members:
In order to hear and decide appeals or orders, decisions or determinations made by the chief building
official relative to the application and interpretations of the Property Maintenance Code of the City, there
is hereby created a Property Maintenance Code Board of Appeals consisting of members who are
qualified by experience and training to pass on matters pertaining to property maintenance and who are
not employees of the City. Such Board shall consist of three (3) members and not less than two (2)
alternate members. A member shall not hear an appeal in which that member has a personal,
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 51/735
professional or financial interest. The chief building official shall be an ex officio member but shall have
no vote upon any matter before the Board. The Board shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall hold
meetings at its pleasure, and shall serve staggered and overlapping terms. The Board shall render all
decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the chief building official. (Ord.
005-2018, 1-22-2018)
Sec. 2-287.6.1. Appeal Procedure:
Any person directly affected by a decision of the chief building official or a notice or order issued under
this Code shall have the right to appeal to the Board of Appeals, provided that a written application for
appeal is filed within twenty (20) days after the day the decision, notice or order was served. An
application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this Code or the rules legally
adopted thereunder have been incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of this Code do not fully apply, or
the requirements of this Code are adequately satisfied by other means. The Board of Appeals shall meet
within twenty (20) days after receipt of the application for appeal and shall render a decision thereafter in
writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the chief building official. Said decision shall be final
unless appealed to the court as provided by law. (Ord. 005-2018, 1-22-2018)
DIVISION 7. SUNSET MARINA BOATERS ADVISORY COMMITTEE
Sec. 2-288. Created; Members; Term:
There is hereby created a Sunset Marina Boaters Advisory Committee consisting of eleven (11)
members to be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. Nine (9) of the members

The other two (2) members of the committee shall be residents of Rock Island representing the general
public. All members shall be appointed for a period of three (3) years. (Ord. 87-39, 4-13-1987; Ord. 91-
75, 6-17-1991; Ord. 98-82, § 1, 10-19-1998)
Sec. 2-289. Meetings:
The Sunset Marina Boaters Advisory Committee shall meet on the third Wednesday of each month. The
Public Works Department shall provide staff support to the committee and record the minutes of each
meeting. (Ord. 87-39, 4-13-1987; Ord. 91-75, 6-17-1991; Ord. 055-2017, 12-18-2017; Ord. 001-2018, 1-
8-2018)
Sec. 2-290. Purpose And Functions:
The committee shall serve in an advisory capacity with the City Council and shall serve as a method of
communication between the boat owners and the marina management. (Ord. 87-39, 4-13-1987)
Secs. 2-291-2-294. Reserved:
DIVISION 8. LABOR DAY PARADE ADVISORY BOARD 48
Sec. 2-295. Established; Purpose:
A Labor Day Parade Advisory Board is hereby established in the City. The purpose of the board shall be
the planning and coordinating of an annual Labor Day parade to be held in September. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-
1989)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 52/735
Sec. 2-296. Duties:
Duties of the Labor Day Parade Advisory Board shall be:
(1) To identify, and encourage groups, organizations, and individuals to participate in a Labor Day
parade which represents the rich labor history in the City of Rock Island.
(2) Foster civic pride in the City's cultural, social, business, educational and political
accomplishments.
(3) Foster and encourage a family-oriented event to promote the general welfare of the community.
(Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
Sec. 2-297. Membership; Appointment:
The Labor Day Parade Advisory Board shall consist of at least eight (8) board members to be appointed
by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. All board members, including the Chairperson and the
Treasurer of the board, shall be citizens of the City except for one board member who may reside
outside the City. The present volunteers who have been involved in the planning of the Labor Day
parade shall be given first consideration for appointment to the advisory board. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
Sec. 2-298. Term:
The terms of the Labor Day Parade Advisory Board members shall be four (4) years except for the first
appointments, wherein half of the board members will have a two (2) year term and the other board
members a four (4) year term. Thereafter, all appointments shall be for a four (4) year term. (Ord. 89-2,
1-23-1989)
Sec. 2-299. Municipal Parade Fee Waived:
The Municipal parade fee is expressly waived for the Labor Day parade organized by the Labor Day
Parade Advisory Board. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
Sec. 2-300. Participants To Be Held Harmless From Claims:
The City will hold harmless any participants in the annual Labor Day Parade sponsored by the City from
any claims that might arise because of those individuals' participation in said parade. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-
1989)
DIVISION 8A. NEIGHBORHOOD PARTNERS BOARD
Sec. 2-300A. Board Created:
(a)Created : There is hereby created the Neighborhood Partners of Rock Island, referred to in this
division as "Neighborhood Partners", which shall consist of full and associate members. Only full
members shall be voting members of the board. One-third (1/3) of the full membership, which is
determined at the annual membership meeting, will consist of City appointments. The membership of
the board shall be broadly representative of neighborhood interests in the City.
(b)Appointments : The one-third (1/3) City representatives on the board shall be appointed by the Mayor
with the consent of the City Council. Replacement appointments to the board shall be made as
vacancies occur. The number of City appointments will be reevaluated at the annual membership
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 53/735
meeting in February of each year so that the same ratio of appointments will continue from year to
year. The revised number of City appointments will be made by the Mayor and City Council no later
than April 30 following the annual membership meeting. The Mayor, with the consent of the City
Council, shall appoint the member organizations. Each member organization shall appoint its own
representative(s) to the board.
(c)Terms : Members shall be appointed for a period of three (3) years. Appointees may serve only two
(2) consecutive terms, but may be appointed again after a three (3) year waiting period. All initial
terms will officially begin with the first membership meeting in February 1997.
(d)Meetings : The neighborhood partners shall meet at least three (3) times each year, and at such
further times as meetings are called by the board president, board secretary or at least one-third
(1/3) of the members of the board. All neighborhood partners' meetings shall be held at such times
and in such locations as shall be convenient for the attendance of the membership. (Ord. 96-75, 10-
7-1996)
DIVISION 9. SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT ADVISORY TEAM
Sec. 2-300.1. Establishment:
There is hereby established a sustainable development advisory team (hereinafter SDAT) for the city of
Rock Island, Illinois, whose primary purpose shall be to offer advice, input and guidance on the
application of sustainable development principles for projects and activities for the city of Rock Island,
Illinois. (Ord. 003-2007, § 1, 1-8-2007)
Sec. 2-300.2. Duties:
SDAT will serve in an advisory capacity as a resource for suggested methods and processes for the
incorporation of sustainable design concepts, methods and technologies into public and private
operations and/or into the construction or remodeling of buildings or properties within the city of Rock
Island, Illinois. (Ord. 003-2007, § 2, 1-8-2007)
Sec. 2-300.3. Objectives:
The primary objectives of the SDAT will be as follows:
(1) To provide the city of Rock Island, Illinois, with the unique development tool to assist businesses
desiring to expand or locate in the city of Rock Island, Illinois;
(2) To reinforce concepts, principles and benefits of sustainable design and development;
(3) To serve as a resource for input and advice on the sustainable design and construction of
facilities as they pertain to the built environment;
(4) To provide suggestions and guidance on the application of sustainable principles for city projects.
(Ord. 003-2007, § 3, 1-8-2007)
Sec. 2-300.4. Membership, Appointment And Term:
(a)The SDAT shall consist of eight (8) members appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city
council. Appointees shall represent the following professions: two (2) members shall be attorneys;
two (2) members shall be architects; two (2) members shall be engineers, and two (2) members shall
be urban planners.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 54/735
(b)The term of the SDAT membership shall be four (4) years. (Ord. 003-2007, §§ 4, 5, 1-8-2007)
Sec. 2-300.5. Meetings:
The community and economic development director or his designee shall call meetings of the SDAT at
such time when a public or private party wishing to utilize the service of the SDAT requests a review of a
project or process. The advice, guidance and input provided by the SDAT shall be given at no cost to the
party requesting the service, shall be advisory in nature, and shall not be binding on the requesting
party. (Ord. 003-2007, § 6, 1-8-2007)
