Chapter 7
HEALTH GENERALLY 3
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 135/735
Sec. 7-1. Title And Application:
This Chapter and Article II of Chapter 13 shall be known as the Health Code of the City of Rock Island
and shall be applicable to all residential, business and commercial properties within the corporate limits
of the City. The requirements imposed by this Health Code shall be in addition to any and all other
applicable requirements imposed by other ordinances and regulations of the City. In any case where a
provision of this Health Code is found to be in conflict with any provision of any other ordinance of the
City, the provision establishing the higher standard shall prevail. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-82)
Sec. 7-2. Purpose:
The purpose of this Health Code is to provide for the public health through establishment of minimum
standards to the end that properties, mobile home parks and recreational areas within the City shall be
free from health hazards and shall not cause a blighting or deteriorating influence upon the City; to
regulate the disposal of garbage and refuse; and to ensure that foods served to the consuming public
are safe, wholesome and prepared in and served under sanitary conditions. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-82)
Secs. 7-3-7-20. Reserved:
ARTICLE II. ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 7-21. Chief Building Inspector To Enforce Laws And Ordinances:
The Chief Building Inspector or his designated representative shall be responsible for enforcing all
provisions of the Health Code. For the purpose of carrying out responsibilities, the Chief Building
Inspector or his designated representative is hereby empowered to enter onto a premises for the
purpose of conducting an inspection where there is reasonable cause to believe that a violation of the
Health Code exists. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-82; Ord. 87-22 3-23-87)
Sec. 7-22. Health Code Board Of Appeals 1:
(a)Creation, Membership And Procedure:
(1) A Health Code Board of Appeals consisting of five (5) members shall be appointed by the Mayor
and approved by the Council. Members shall serve for a period of three (3) years. One member shall
be engaged in the restaurant business, one member shall be engaged in the tavern business and
three (3) members shall not be engaged in either of the two (2) aforementioned occupations. The
City physician shall be an ex officio member. The Chief Building Inspector or his designated
representative shall be an ex officio member and shall serve as secretary of the Health Code Board
of Appeals.
(2) The Board shall elect its own chairman and have the power to adopt rules and regulations for its
own government, not inconsistent with law or with the provisions of this Health Code or any other
ordinance of the City. Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as
the Board may determine. The chairman or, in his absence, the vice-chairman may administer oaths
and compel attendance of witnesses.
(3) Meetings of the Board shall be open to the public; minutes shall be kept of the proceedings,
showing the action of the Board and the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent and
failing to vote, indicating that fact; and records shall be made of the Board's examinations and other
official actions, all of which shall be filed immediately in the office of the Board.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 136/735
(4) A record of the entire proceedings shall be made by tape recordings. A transcript of the
proceedings shall be made available to all parties upon request and upon payment of the fees
prescribed therefor. Such fees may be established by the Board but shall in no event be greater than
the cost involved.
(5) Three (3) members of the Board shall constitute a quorum. The Board shall act by resolution, and
the concurring vote of three (3) members shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement,
decision or determination of the public health sanitarian, or to decide in favor of an applicant as to
any matter upon which it is required to pass under this Health Code, or to affect any violation in the
requirements of said Code. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-82)
(b)Applications And Appeals:
(1) An application to the Board, in cases in which it has original jurisdiction under the provisions of
this Health Code, may be taken by any property owner, including a tenant, or by any governmental
officer, department, board or bureau. Such application shall be filed with the Inspection Division,
which shall transmit the same, together with all the plans, specifications and other papers pertaining
to the application, to the Board.
(2) An appeal to the Board may be taken by any property owner, including a tenant, or by any
governmental officer, department, board or bureau affected by any ruling of the Chief Building
Inspector or his designated representative. The appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days from the
service of such order or action of the Chief Building Inspector or his designated representative with
the Inspection Division. The Inspection Division shall forthwith transmit to the Board such notice of
appeal, together with all the plans and papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed
from was taken.
(3) As soon as practicable after receiving the written appeal, the Health Code Board of Appeals shall
fix a date, time and place for the hearing of the appeal by the Board. Due regard shall be shown for
the convenience and necessity of any parties or their representatives.
(c)Powers Of The Board: The Board shall have the following powers:
(1) To hear and decide all appeals from enforcement decisions made by the Chief Building Inspector
or his designated representative in enforcing the Health Code.
(2) To determine from a public health standpoint revocation of any license issued to any person
engaged in the handling, distribution or serving of food within the corporate limits of the City.
(3) To hear and decide appeals on the interpretations of the provisions of this Code.
(d)Actions Of The Board: In exercising its powers, the Board may, in conformity with the provisions of the
Illinois Compiled Statutes, and of this Health Code, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify
the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and may make such order,
requirement, decision or determination as, in the Board's opinion, ought to be made, and to that end
the Board has all the officer's power from whom the appeal is taken.
(e)Judicial Review: All final administrative decisions of the Board of Appeals shall be subject to judicial
review pursuant to the provisions of the Administrative Review Law, and all amendments and
modifications thereof, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto. (See the code of civil procedure 735
Illinois Compiled Statutes) (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982)
Secs. 7-23-7-35. Reserved:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 137/735
ARTICLE III. FOOD AND BEVERAGES
Sec. 7-36. Scope:
(a)This article shall regulate food service establishments and retail food stores, the operation of such
facilities, and the licensing of food service establishments and retail food stores within the city.
(b)The mayor and city council has deemed it necessary and desirable to regulate food sanitation for
health purposes, and accordingly recommended the adoption of the following provisions. (Ord. 90-
39, 6-6-1990)
Sec. 7-37. License:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a food service establishment, or retail food store within the
city who does not possess a valid license issued to such person by the health authority. Only a person
who complies with the requirements of this article shall be entitled to receive or retain such a license. A
license is not transferable from one person to another person; nor shall a license be applicable to any
locations, buildings or places other than that for which it is issued. A valid license shall be posted in each
food service establishment or retail food store. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-1990)
Sec. 7-38. Issuance Of Licenses:
(a)(1) Any person desiring to operate a food service establishment or retail food store or to renew an
expired license shall make a written application for a license on forms provided by the health
authority of the city. Such application shall include the name and address of each applicant, the
location and type of proposed operation, and the signature of each applicant, whether such applicant
is an individual, firm or corporation; and if a partnership, the names of the partners, together with
their addresses, shall be included. Payment for the license shall accompany the application form.
(2) If the application is for a temporary food service establishment or a temporary retail food store, it
shall also include the inclusive dates of the proposed operations.
(b)Licenses for food service establishments and retail food stores are valid for a period of one year from
the date of issuance. Licenses for temporary food service establishments or temporary retail food
stores shall not exceed fourteen (14) days. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-1990)
Sec. 7-39. Adoption By Reference:
This article shall be interpreted and enforced in accordance with provisions set forth in the unabridged
form of the current "Illinois Food Service Sanitation Rules And Regulations" and the "Illinois Retail Food
Store Sanitation Rules And Regulations", and any subsequent amendments or revisions thereto, three
(3) copies of each which shall be on file in the office of the city clerk which publications are incorporated
herein and adopted by reference as part of this article. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-1990)
Sec. 7-40. Definitions:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article:
Adulteration: The condition of any food:
(1) If it bears or contains any poisonous or deleterious substance in a quantity which may render it
injurious to health.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 138/735
(2) If it bears or contains any added poisonous or deleterious substance for which no safe
tolerance has been established by regulation or in excess of such tolerances if one has been
established.
(3) If it consists in whole or in part of any filthy, putrid, or decomposed substance or if it is
otherwise unfit for human consumption.
(4) If it has been processed, prepared, packaged or held under unsanitary conditions whereby it
may have been contaminated with filth or whereby it may have been rendered injurious to health.
(5) If it is in whole or in part the product of a diseased animal or animal which has died otherwise
than by slaughter.
(6) If its containers are composed in whole or in part of any poisonous or deleterious substance
which may render the contents injurious to health.
Health Authority: The chief building inspector of the city of Rock Island or his delegated
representative. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-1990)
Sec. 7-41. Provisions For Licensing:
(a)License Fee Schedule:
(1) Annual Fee: Determined by the square footage of floor space in the establishment including
dining areas, retail sales area and storage areas. Licenses for food service establishments and retail
food stores are valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance. Establishments that fail to
apply for renewal within fifteen (15) days after expiration date will cease food service operations.
2,000 square feet or less $200.00
2,001 square feet to 3,000 square feet
250.00
3,001 square feet and over 300.00
Mobile food units and retail sales units
80.00
Temporary food services establishment (5 day maximum)
Temporary permit obtained 2 working days prior to event
35.00
Less than 2 working days before event
60.00
Seasonal concession stands (potentially hazardous food)
70.00
Valid for 180 days (non- potentially hazardous food)
40.00
Schools and recognized churches
50.00
Schools serving food no more than once each week and not open to the general public will be
exempt from annual fee.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 139/735
(2) Inspection Required: Prior to approval of an application for a license, the health authority shall
inspect the food service establishment or retail food store to determine compliance with the
requirements of this article.
(3) Issuance Of License: The health authority shall issue a license to the applicant if its inspection
reveals that the applicable requirements of this article have been met, and upon payment of the
required fee.
(b)Renewal Of License:
(1) Whenever the inspection for renewal of a license reveals serious or repeated violations of this
article, the license shall not be issued and the health authority shall notify the applicant immediately
thereof. Such notice shall also state that an opportunity for a hearing shall be provided for the
applicant at a time and place designated by the health authority. Such hearing shall be scheduled not
later than ten (10) days from the date of notice. A license which has expired shall be removed from
the establishment by the health authority.
(2) Operators of food service establishments who fail to apply for renewal within fifteen (15) days
after the expiration of their current license, will have to submit a food service establishment review
application and a fifty dollar ($50.00) fee, in addition to their regular license fee. Until the food service
review application has been evaluated and accepted by the health authority, the food service
establishment will cease food service operations.
(c)Reinstatement Of Suspended License: Any person whose license has been suspended may, at any
time make application for a reinspection for the purpose of reinstatement of the permit. Within the ten
(10) days following receipt of the written request, including a statement signed by the applicant that,
in his opinion, the conditions causing suspension of the permit have been corrected, the health
authority shall make a reinspection. If the applicant is found to be in compliance with the
requirements of this article, the license shall be reinstated.
(d)Revocation Of License:
(1) For serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this article, or for interference with
the health authority in the performance of his/her duties, the license may be permanently revoked
after an opportunity for a hearing has been provided before the health code board of appeals.
(2) Prior to such action, the health authority shall notify the license holder in writing, stating the
reasons for which the license is subject to revocation, and advising that the license shall be
permanently revoked at the end of five (5) days following service of such notice, unless a request for
a hearing is filed with the health authority by the license holder, within such five (5) day period. A
license may be suspended for a cause pending its revocation or a hearing relative thereto. (Ord. 90-
39, 6-6-1990; Ord. 95-43, 6-5-1995; Ord. 02-2004, § 1, 1-5-2004; Ord. 011-2009, § 1, 2-2-2009)
Sec. 7-42. Notices:
A notice provided for in this Article is properly serviced when it is delivered to the holder of the license or
the person in charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the
last known address of the holder of the license. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the
Health Authority. A completed inspection report form or a letter are considered proper forms of notice.
(Ord. 90-39, 6-6-90)
Sec. 7-43. Inspections:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 140/735
(a)Inspection Schedule: The health authority shall inspect each establishment every six (6) months or as
often as he deems necessary for the enforcement of this article.
(b)Access To Establishments: The health authority, after showing proper identification shall be permitted
to enter, at any reasonable time, any food service establishment or retail food store within the city for
the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this Article. The health authority
shall be permitted to examine the records of the establishment to obtain information pertaining to
food and supplies purchased, received or used, and information concerning persons employed.
(c)Report Of Inspections: Whenever an inspection of a food service establishment or retail food store is
made, the findings shall be recorded on an inspection report form. The inspection report form shall
summarize the requirements of this article and shall set forth a weighted point value for each
requirement. Inspection remarks shall be written to reference, by item number, the item violated and
shall state the correction to be made. The rating score of the establishment shall be the total of the
weighted point values for all violations, subtracted from one hundred (100). A copy of the completed
inspection report form shall be furnished to the person in charge of the establishment at the
conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection report is a public document that shall be
made available for public disclosure to any person who requests it according to law. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-
1990)
Sec. 7-44. Suspension Of License:
(a)Licenses may be suspended temporarily by the health authority for failure of the license holder to
comply with the requirements of this Article. Whenever a license holder or operator has failed to
comply with any notice issued under the provisions of this article, the license holder or operator shall
be notified in writing that the license is, upon service of a notice, immediately suspended and that an
opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request for a hearing is filed with the health
authority by a license holder. Upon suspension of the license, all operations as a food service
establishment or retail food store are to be discontinued at the direction of the health authority. The
license shall be removed from the establishment by the health authority.
(b)Notwithstanding the other provisions of this article, whenever the health authority finds unsanitary or
other conditions in the operation of a food service establishment or retail food store which in his/her
judgment, constitute a substantial hazard to the public health, he/she may without warning, notice or
hearing, issue a written notice to the license holder or operator citing such condition, specifying the
corrective action to be taken, and if deemed necessary, such order shall state that the license is
immediately suspended, and all operations as a food service establishment or retail food store are to
be immediately discontinued. Any person to whom such an order is issued shall comply immediately
therewith, but upon written petition to the health authority shall be afforded a hearing as soon as
possible. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-1990)
Sec. 7-45. Correction Of Violation:
(a)The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of
the violations found. Correction of the violations shall be accomplished within the period specified in
accordance with the following provisions:
(1) If an imminent health hazard exists, including, but not limited to, complete lack of refrigeration or
sewage backup into the establishment, the establishment shall immediately cease food service or
sales operations.
(2) All violations of four (4) or five (5) point weighted item shall be corrected as soon as possible, but
in any event within ten (10) days following inspection. Within fifteen (15) days after the inspection, the
holder of the license shall notify the health authority stating that four (4) or five (5) point weighted
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 141/735
violations have been corrected. A follow up inspection, as deemed necessary by the health authority
shall be conducted to confirm correction.
(3) All one or two (2) point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event,
by the time of next routine inspection.
(4) When the rating score of the establishment is less than sixty (60) the establishment shall initiate
corrective action on all identified violations within forty eight (48) hours. One or more reinspections
will be conducted at reasonable time intervals to assure correction.
(5) In the case of temporary food service establishments, all violations shall be corrected within
twenty four (24) hours. If violations are not corrected within twenty four (24) hours, the establishment
shall immediately cease food service operations until authorized to resume by health authority.
(b)Failure of the license holder or operator to comply with any time limits for corrections may result in
cessation of food service operations. An opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time
limitations, or both, will be provided if a written request is filed with the Health Authority within ten
(10) days following cessation of operations. If a request for hearing is received, a hearing shall be
held within twenty (20) days of receipt of the request.
(c)Whenever a food service establishment or retail food store is required under the provisions of Section
7-44 to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is shown on reinspection that
conditions responsible for the order to cease operations no longer exist. Opportunity for reinspection
shall be offered within a reasonable time. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-90)
Sec. 7-46. Examination And Condemnation Of Food And/Or Equipment:
(a)Food: Food may be examined or sampled by the Health Authority as may be necessary to determine
freedom from adulteration or misbranding. The Health Authority may, upon written notice to the
owner or person in charge, place a hold order on any food which he determines or has probable
cause to believe to be unwholesome or otherwise adulterated or misbranded. Under a hold order,
food shall be permitted to be suitably stored. It shall be unlawful for any person to move or alter a
hold order notice or tag placed on food by the Health Authority. Neither such food nor the containers
thereof shall be relabeled, repackaged or reprocessed, altered, disposed of, or destroyed without
permission of the Health Authority, except on an order by a court of competent jurisdiction. After the
owner or person in charge has had a hearing as provided in this Article, and on the basis of evidence
produced at such hearing, or on the basis of examination in the event of written request for a hearing
is not received within ten (10) days, the Health Authority may vacate the hold order or may, by written
notice, direct the owner or person in charge of food which was placed under the hold order to
denature or destroy such food or bring it into compliance with the provisions of this Article. Such
order shall be stayed if the order is appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction within three (3)
days.
(b)Equipment: Where equipment used in the preparation of food products is found to be in a state of
disrepair, unsafe, unsuitable for use, or unsanitary, such equipment shall be taken out of use and
hold order placed on said items by the Health Authority. Such equipment may not be put back into
service until written permission is obtained from the Health Authority. It shall be unlawful for any
person to move or alter a hold order notice or tag placed on equipment by the Health Authority. Such
equipment shall not be altered, disposed of, or destroyed without permission of the Health Authority
except on an order by a court of competent jurisdiction. After the owner or person in charge has had
a hearing as provided in this Article, and on the basis of evidence produced at such hearing or on the
basis of examination in the event a written request for a hearing is not received within ten (10) days,
the Health Authority may vacate the hold order or may, by written notice, direct the owner or person
in charge of the equipment which was placed under the hold order to remove such equipment or
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 142/735
bring it into compliance with the provisions of this Article. Such order shall be stayed if the order is
appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction within three (3) days. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-90)
Sec. 7-47. Procedure When Infection Is Suspected:
When the Health Authority has reasonable cause to suspect possible disease transmission by an
employee of a food service establishment or retail food store, it may secure a morbidity history of the
suspected employee or make any other investigation as may be indicated and take appropriate action.
The Health Authority may require any or all of the following measures:
(1) The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in a food service establishment or
retail food store;
(2) The immediate closing of the food service establishment or retail food store concerned until, in
the opinion of the Health Authority, no further danger of disease outbreak exists;
(3) Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the establishment where there will be no
danger of transmitting disease;
(4) Adequate medical and laboratory examinations of the employee or other employees and of his or
their body discharges. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-90)
Sec. 7-48. Food Handlers' Classes:
The Health Authority may order any food handler to attend an immediate food handler training course
when, in the judgment of the Health Authority, the work habits of said food handler constitute a hazard to
public health. Fees may be charged by the Health Authority to offset any costs incurred by the Health
Authority. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-90)
Sec. 7-49. Plan Review Of Future Construction:
(a)Plans Submitted: Whenever a food service establishment or retail food store is constructed or
extensively remodeled, and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food service
establishment or retail food store, properly prepared plans and specifications for construction,
remodeling, or conversion shall be submitted to the Health Authority for review and approval before
construction, remodeling, or conversion is begun. The plans and specifications shall indicate the
proposed layout, arrangement, mechanical plans, and construction materials of work areas, and the
type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. All applicable food service equipment
shall be of a quality as approved by the National Sanitation Foundation (NSF) or equivalent. New
equipment which is approved for a certain use by NFS shall be automatically approved by the Health
Authority. Other applicable equipment or used equipment shall be evaluated or otherwise approved
by the Health Authority. The Health Authority shall approve the plans and specifications if they meet
the requirements of this Article. No food service establishment or retail food store shall be
constructed, extensively remodeled, or converted except in accordance with plans and specifications
approved by the Health Authority.
(b)Pre-Operational Inspection: Whenever plans and specifications are required by subsection (a) of this
Section to be submitted to the Health Authority, the Health Authority shall inspect the food service
establishment or retail food store prior to the start of operations, to determine compliance with the
approved plans and specifications with the requirements of this Article. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-90)
Sec. 7-50. Penalties:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 143/735
Any person violating any provisions of this Article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction thereof shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 90-39, 6-6-90)

ARTICLE IV. RECREATIONAL
VEHICLE PARKS 1
Sec. 7-56. Definitions; Rules Of Construction:
The provisions of this Article shall be minimum requirements, adopted for the promotion of the public
health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity and general welfare. When this article imposes greater
restrictions upon the development and operation of recreational vehicle parks than are imposed or
required by other provisions of law or ordinance, the provisions of this article shall prevail. The following
definitions shall apply herein:
Awning: A shade structure supported by either; 1) posts or columns and a recreational vehicle; 2)
only posts or columns not attached to or supported by the recreational vehicle; or 3) only the
recreational vehicle to which it is attached.
Building: Any structure designed or built for the support, enclosure, shelter or protection of people,
animals, chattels or property of any kind. Any structures with interior areas not normally accessible
for human use shall not be considered as buildings.
License: A certificate required by the City of Rock Island to operate and maintain a recreational
vehicle park.
Permit: A certificate required by the City of Rock Island to construct, alter or expand a recreational
vehicle park.
Person: Any individual, firm, trust, partnership, public or private association or corporation.
Recreational Activities: Those activities which may be available at a recreational vehicle park,
including but not limited to fishing, swimming, boating, camping, picnicking, hiking, festivals, public
gatherings and visiting historical, archeological, scenic or scientific sites, for any purpose, including
but not limited to educational, vocational and religious activities and assemblies.
Recreational Campsite: A plot of ground within a recreational vehicle park intended for the
accommodation of either a recreational vehicle, tent or other individual camping unit on a temporary
basis. Campsites shall be of the independent (having no sanitary facilities) or dependent (having all
sanitary facilities) type.
Recreational Vehicle: A vehicular type of unit primarily designed as temporary living quarters for
recreational, camping or travel use, which either has its own motor power or is mounted on or drawn
by another vehicle, including but not limited to travel trailer, camping trailer, truck camper and motor
home. Recreational vehicles may be of the independent (with holding tank and sanitary facilities) or
dependent (lacking some or all sanitary facilities) type.
Recreational Vehicle Park: A parcel of land upon which two (2) or more recreational campsites are
located, established or maintained for occupancy by recreational vehicles, tents or other individual
camping units of the general public as temporary living quarters for recreational purposes.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 144/735
Sanitary Dumping Station: A facility used for removing and disposing of wastes from recreational
vehicle holding tanks.
Service Building: A building in a recreational vehicle park, including but not limited to a manager's
office or residence, laundry facilities, equipment storage, toilets and showers or other services which
may be provided for the use and benefit of those persons occupying a recreational campsite or
employed at the recreational vehicle park.
Water Station: A facility used for filling recreational vehicle water storage tanks. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-
1982)
Sec. 7-57. Penalties:
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction thereof shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982)
Sec. 7-58. Administration; Appeals:
(a)General: This article shall be administered by the City's chief building inspector or his designated
representative except for those provisions dealing with the construction of the recreational vehicle
park roadways, walkways, parking areas, service buildings and water, sewer and electrical systems.
During construction of a recreational vehicle park, those City officials established as having
jurisdiction shall assure that said park is constructed to meet all requirements of this article and all
other codes and ordinances which may apply.
(b)Right Of Inspection: Upon a presentation of proper credentials, City officials or their duly authorized
representatives may enter at reasonable times any recreational vehicle park or building therein in the
City to perform any duty imposed upon them by this article.
(c)Right Of Appeal: Any person aggrieved by any ruling of any City official charged with the
administration of this article may take any appeal to the appropriate Appeal Board as provided in
other City codes and ordinances.
(d)Jurisdiction:
(1) Construction: Appeals taken from requests relating to construction of the recreational vehicle park
shall be filed with the appropriate Appeal Board subject to the procedures established under other
codes and ordinances.
(2) Operation: Appeals taken from requests relating to operation of the recreational vehicle park shall
be filed with the Health Code Board of Appeals, subject to the procedures established under article II
of this chapter.
(3) Expansion: Expansion of a recreational vehicle park and its facilities shall be subject to
authorization by the Health Code Board of Appeals in accordance with the procedures established
under section 7-60 of this article, even if said expansion does not increase the total area of nor
change the boundaries of the recreational vehicle park. Construction of additional systems, facilities
and campsites not shown on the approved plot plan of the recreational vehicle park shall be
considered as expansions of said park. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-59. Establishment Of Park:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 145/735
(a)Authorization: Any person wishing to establish a recreational vehicle park shall submit to the Rock
Island Board of Zoning Appeals a request for authorization in accordance with appendix A, article V
of this Code. Said parks are allowed only in B-4 (Highway Business) and C-1 (Conservation) Zoning
Districts.
(1) Plan Approval: Plans, specifications and/or construction drawings for water and sewer facilities,
roadways and buildings shall be prepared by a registered Illinois engineer or architect, and shall be
approved by the appropriate City authorities prior to the authorization of the recreational vehicle park
by the Board of Zoning Appeals.
(2) Contents: A plat plan of the recreational vehicle park shall be approved by the Public Works and
Fire Department, and the chief building inspector prior to the authorization by the Board of Zoning
Appeals. Said plat plan shall include the following information:
a. The area and dimensions of the park site and surrounding zoning.
b. The number, type, size and location of all campsites and parking areas.
c. The location, right-of-way and surfaced roadway width, the surfacing material of roadways and
walkways and the interior vehicular and pedestrian circulation patterns.
d. The location of all service buildings and sanitary stations.
e. The location of all water and sewer lines, riser pumps, all lighting, electric and gas systems and
all drainage easements.
(b)Permits Required: Upon receiving authorization from the Board of Zoning Appeals, all permits
required by the City shall be secured from the appropriate authorities for construction of the
recreational vehicle park.
(c)As-Built Drawings: If the construction of the recreational vehicle park varies from the approved plans,
specifications and/or construction drawings, as-built drawings shall be filed with the City Engineer. If
said construction does not vary from said plans, an affidavit so certifying shall be filed with the
Director of Public Works or his designated representative. The as-built drawings or affidavit shall be
accepted by the appropriate authorities prior to the issuance of a license for the operation of the
recreational vehicle park. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-60. Operation Of Park:
(a)License Required: The operator of a recreational vehicle park shall secure from the City a license
prior to the operation of the park. Said license shall be issued by the City's chief building official or his
designated representative following the approval of the recreational vehicle park by the Board of
Zoning Appeals and the acceptance of the as-built drawings or affidavit.
(1) Application: The application for said license shall be made with the chief building official or his
designated representative on forms provided by his/her office.
(2) Fee: The annual fee for said license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus five dollars
($5.00) per recreational campsite, payable at the City Finance Department prior to May 1 of each
year. The licensing year shall begin on May 1 of each year and end on April 30 of the next
succeeding calendar year. All licenses shall expire on said April 30 in each calendar year.
(b)Park Occupancy: There shall be no permanent year-round occupancy of any recreational campsite in
a recreational vehicle park. Storage of recreational vehicles at a recreational vehicle park shall be
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 146/735
allowed. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987; Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord. 042-2017, 11-
6-2017)
Sec. 7-61. Standards For Parks:
(a)Water Supply: All recreational vehicle parks shall be adequately served by City water in accordance
with chapter 16, article II of this Code.
(1) Water Distribution System: All components of the water system of a recreational vehicle park,
including plumbing, shall be installed and maintained to meet or exceed City specifications.
(2) Drinking Fountains: All outlets established for the provision of drinking water, except for the filling
of recreational vehicle water storage tanks, shall consist of drinking fountains. Common drinking cups
shall be prohibited.
(3) Water Stations: There shall be at least one water station for each one hundred (100) independent
recreational vehicle campsites or portion thereof. The fill hose shall be suspended so that no part of
said hose or appurtenances shall come in contact with the ground. A sign shall be posted at each
water station indicating that said water is potable and not to be used for flushing wastes from
recreational vehicle holding tanks.
(b)Sewage Disposal: All sewage disposal for recreational vehicle parks shall be through the City sanitary
sewer system in accordance with chapter 16, article III of this Code.
(1) Sewage System: All components of the sewage system of a recreational vehicle park, including
plumbing, shall be installed and maintained to meet or exceed City specifications.
(2) Sanitary Dumping Stations: There shall be at least one sanitary dumping station with a hose for
each one hundred (100) independent recreational vehicle campsites or portion thereof. A sign shall
be posted at each sanitary dumping station indicating that the water is not potable and is to be used
only for flushing wastes from recreational vehicle holding tanks.
(c)Bathhouses: Bathhouses to be used by both sexes simultaneously shall be divided into two (2) parts,
separated by a tight partition and designated for men and women. The entrances and exits shall be
screened to break the line of sight. Floors, drains, walls, partitions, fixtures, lighting and ventilation
shall be installed to conform with all City requirements. All walls, floors and partitions shall be
constructed of nonabsorbent materials. Bathhouses shall provide both cold and hot (90 degrees
Fahrenheit) water at a rate of three (3) gallons per minute.
(1) Toilets: One toilet for each sex shall be provided for each twenty (20) dependent recreational
campsites or portion thereof.
(2) Lavatories: Two (2) lavatories for each sex shall be provided for each twenty (20) dependent
recreational campsites or portion thereof.
(3) Showers: One shower for each sex shall be provided for each twenty (20) dependent recreational
campsites or portion thereof.
(4) Cleanliness: All bathhouses shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition.
(d)Laundry Facilities: When provided for the occupants of a recreational vehicle park, all laundry facilities
shall be properly installed and connected to the water, sewer and electrical or gas systems of the
recreational vehicle park. For each one washing machine provided, there shall be provided at least
one dryer. Commercial dryers having capacities of greater than one washing machine load may be
substituted for the number of single-load dryers needed to equal the capacity of the multi-load dryer.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 147/735
(e)Refuse Disposal: The storage, collection and disposal of refuse produced in a recreational vehicle
park shall be conducted in accordance with chapter 13, article II of this Code. The recreational
vehicle park shall be kept free of litter and accumulations of rubbish, and shall be maintained in a
sanitary condition at all times.
(f)Food Service: Food service, when provided, shall be conducted in accordance with article III of this
chapter.
(g)Buildings: All buildings in recreational vehicle parks shall be constructed to meet or exceed all City
requirements.
(h)Roadways And Parking Areas: All roadways and parking areas in a recreational vehicle park shall be
of a dustless surface.
(1) One-Way Roads: One-way roads with no parking shall have a surface width of at least twelve feet
(12'), and those with parking on one side shall have a surface width of at least eighteen (18) feet.
One-way streets with parking on both sides shall not be allowed.
(2) Two-way roads. Two-way roads with no parking shall have a surface width of at least eighteen
(18) feet, those with parking on one side shall have a surface width of at least twenty-five (25) feet
and those with parking on both sides shall have a surface width of at least thirty-one (31) feet.
(3) Parking areas. There shall be provided within the recreational vehicle park at least one parking
space for each two (2) recreational campsites in addition to the required parking pads. Parking lots,
spaces and access drives shall comply with the size requirements for parking areas in the Rock
Island zoning ordinance.
(i)Campsites. Each recreational campsite shall contain at least one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250)
square feet.
(1) Density. Each campsite shall be occupied by no more than one recreational vehicle or two (2)
tents at any one time.
(2) Setbacks. No part of any recreational vehicle (including awnings), tent or other vehicle shall be
placed on a recreational campsite closer than two (2) feet to any campsite line.
(3) Parking pad. Each recreational campsite shall contain a stabilized vehicular parking pad of shell,
marl or other suitable, dustless material.
(4) Vehicle restriction. At no time shall a dependent recreational vehicle be allowed to occupy an
independent recreational campsite.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 4), 9-27-82)
Cross reference--Zoning, App. A.
Sec. 7-62. Safety.
(a)Building and fire codes. The grounds, buildings, utilities, roadways, parking areas and other facilities
shall be constructed, maintained and used in accordance with applicable city building codes and fire
prevention regulations.
(b)Flammable liquids. Liquid petroleum gas, fuel oil, gasoline and other flammable liquids shall be
handled and used in a safe manner and shall not be stored inside or beneath any recreational
vehicle.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 148/735
(c)Play areas. Play equipment, when provided for children, shall be designed for safety, maintained in
good repair and placed in play areas which are free from hazards.
(d)First aid. All recreational vehicle parks shall have at least one first aid kit as recommended by the
American Red Cross, one stretcher and one blanket for each two hundred (200) recreational
campsites or portion thereof.
(e)Communications. One telephone for each two hundred (200) recreational campsites or portion thereof
shall be reasonably available for emergency use. The telephone numbers of the city police, state
police, city fire department, ambulance service and the closest hospital shall be posted near each
telephone.
(f)Fires. Fires shall be allowed only in facilities such as fireplaces, fire pits or charcoal braziers which
have been provided for such purposes. No fire shall be left unattended, left unextinguished upon
vacation of a recreational campsite or fueled by materials which emit dense smoke or objectionable
odors.
(g)Park location. Recreational vehicle parks shall not be located in areas which may create health
hazards for occupants of the park. Surface water within two hundred (200) feet of park buildings shall
be drained, filled, constructed or treated to prevent mosquito breeding.
(h)Vector control. Implementation of preventive and control measures for use against flies, ticks,
mosquitoes, rats and other potential vectors of disease in and around recreational areas shall be in
accordance with city health codes.
(i)Occupant list. A register containing the names, addresses and recreational vehicle license plate
numbers of all recreational vehicle park occupants shall be maintained at all times.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 5), 9-27-82)
Cross references--Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 4; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6.
Sec. 7-63. Recreational activities.
(a)Setbacks. All buildings used for recreational activities provided at recreational vehicle parks shall
meet the setback requirements for such uses identified in the Rock Island zoning ordinance.
(b)Swimming facilities. All swimming areas and related facilities for use by recreational vehicle park
occupants shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with state regulations.
(c)Boating facilities. All boating facilities for use by recreational vehicle park occupants shall be
constructed and maintained in accordance with state regulations.
(d)Fish cleaning facilities. All fish-cleaning facilities for use by recreational vehicle park occupants shall
provide for the storage and safe disposal of fish offal and shall be maintained in a sanitary condition.
(e)Stables. All stables for use by recreational vehicle park occupants shall be maintained in a clean and
sanitary condition and shall be conducted in accordance with all applicable provisions of the Rock
Island zoning ordinance.
(f)Commercial establishments. No commercial establishments shall be operated in any recreational
vehicle park except those operated by the owner of said park for recreational vehicle park occupants.
Such establishments shall present no visible evidence from any street outside the recreational
vehicle park of their commercial character which would attract customers other than recreational
vehicle park occupants.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 149/735
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 6), 9-27-82)
Cross reference--Zoning, App. A.
Secs. 7-64--7-80. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. MOBILE HOME PARKS 1
Sec. 7-81. Definitions.
The following definitions shall apply in this article:
Accessory structure: A building subordinate to and smaller than a principal building or mobile home, that
contributes to the comfort, convenience or necessity of the occupants of the principal building or mobile
home.
Chief building inspector: The legally designated health authority or his authorized representative of the
City of Rock Island, Illinois.
Dependent mobile home: A dependent mobile home means a trailer home which does not have a toilet
or bath or shower facilities, and its use is prohibited in the mobile home park.
Independent mobile home: A transportable non-permanent single-family dwelling unit suitable for yearround
occupancy and containing the same water supply, waste disposal, heating and air conditioning
and electrical conveniences as conventional housing, meeting "American Standard Association"
construction requirements of 1974, and subsequent revisions. This definition is not intended to include
travel trailers or camper buses.
Mobile home: Any transportable nonpermanent single-family dwelling unit suitable for year-round
occupancy.
Mobile home lot: A parcel of land designed for the exclusive use of the occupants of a single mobile
home, also termed mobile home space.
Mobile home park: An area of land upon which two (2) or more occupied mobile homes are harbored
either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and this shall include any building used or intended for
use as a part of the equipment of such mobile home parks. This does not include travel trailers, tents or
camper buses.
Mobile home stand: That part of an individual lot which has been reserved for the placement of the
mobile home, appurtenant structures or additions.
Permit: A written permit issued by the chief building inspector or his designated representative permitting
the mobile home park to operate under this health code and regulations promulgated hereunder.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 1(A--L)), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, § 22, 3-23-87)
Sec. 7-82. Penalties.
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction thereof shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 150/735
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 13), 9-27-82)
Sec. 7-83. License--Required.
No person shall establish, maintain, conduct or operate a mobile home park without first obtaining a
license from the chief building inspector or his designated representative. Such license shall be issued
for one (1) year and shall expire April 30th of each year, and the license shall be renewed from year to
year upon payment of the annual license fee provided in this article.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 2), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, § 22, 3-23-87; Ord. No. 89-16, § 1, 4-3-89)
Cross reference--Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 8.
Sec. 7-84. Same--Application.
In order to obtain a permit to construct, or an original license to operate a mobile home park, the
applicant shall file with the chief building inspector or his designated representative a written application
containing the following information:
(1) The full name and address of the applicant or applicants, or names and addresses of the partners
if the applicant is a partnership, or the names and addresses of the officers if the applicant is a
corporation.
(2) Location and legal description of the tract of land drawn to a scale of one (1) inch equals one
hundred (100) feet, or larger.
(3) The proposed and existing facilities in the park for water supply, sewage, garbage and waste
disposal.
(4) The proposed method of lighting the structures and land upon which the park is to be located.
(5) All corners and points of tangency are to be marked by galvanized or wrought iron pipe or iron or
steel bars at least eighteen (18) inches in length and not less than one-half inch in diameter. The top
of the pipe or bar is to be set level with the established grade of the ground.
(6) The plat plans of the park drawn to a scale of one hundred (100) feet to an inch, building plans
and specifications for existing buildings and facilities, and the plans and specifications for new
buildings and facilities or the proposed alterations in existing facilities, all showing compliance with
the provisions of this article. The plat plans shall contain, among other things, the following:
a. The date on which such plat plans were prepared.
b. An arrow indicating north.
c. All mobile home sites properly numbered on the plat plans.
d. Complete information regarding storm sewers.
e. Storm water runoff.
(7) A copy of the soil and water conservation district report prepared in accordance with 70 ILCS
405/22.02a.
(8) Where a permit to construct as well as an original license to operate is sought by the applicant,
request therefor shall be made in the same application. Each application for a permit to construct or
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 151/735
for an original license shall be accompanied by an application fee amounting to twenty-five dollars
($25.00) for each ten (10) acres of land, or fraction thereof, proposed to be used as a park. Each
application fee shall be paid to the city clerk, and said application fee, once so paid, shall not be
refunded.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 3), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, § 22, 3-23-87)
Sec. 7-85. Inspections.
(a)Upon receipt of an application for a permit to construct a park or an application for a license to
operate and maintain the same, the chief building inspector or his designated representative shall, if
the park is or the proposed park will be, in conformity with this health code, issue a permit to
construct or an original license, as the case may be.
(b)If the application for a permit to construct or a license is declined, the chief building inspector or his
designated representative of the city shall give the reasons therefor in writing to the applicant, and if
the objections can be corrected, the applicant may amend his application and resubmit it for
approval.
(c)If a permit to construct a park has been issued, the applicant shall, upon completion thereof, notify the
chief building inspector or his designated representative, who shall then inspect the park and, if
completed in accordance with the accepted application, shall issue the license. The chief building
inspector, the electrical inspector, the plumbing inspector and the director of public works or his
designated representative must approve any new park or additions before the inspection division will
issue a permit to construct or a license for occupancy of the mobile home park.
(d)No change in any methods of water supply, sewer, drainage, garbage, or waste disposal, and no
change in the plat plan, shall be made without first making a written application to the chief building
inspector or his designated representative and receiving a permit therefrom. Such application shall
be made in the way and manner hereinbefore set forth, except that a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for
each ten (10) acres or fraction thereof used to harbor mobile homes thereon shall accompany each
application for a permit to alter such mobile home park. No application fee shall be required to
accompany an application for a permit to alter a park where such alternative involves only a
reduction in the number of trailer spaces to a smaller number than the license for such park currently
authorizes. Such change or changes shall comply with such safety and sanitary code, building code,
rules and regulations as are applicable thereto.
(e)Such permit does not relieve the applicant from securing any other permit required or from complying
with any other ordinance of the city. No license to operate and maintain a park shall be issued if such
a park is, at such time, in violation of any other ordinance or regulation of the city.
(f)The annual license fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus five dollars ($5.00) for each mobile
home lot. All fees shall be made payable to the city.
(g)Applications for license shall be made to the chief building inspector or his designated representative,
who shall issue a license upon compliance by the applicant with the provisions of this health code
and of any regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and for any other applicable legal requirements. No
license or permit shall be transferable.
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 4), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, §§ 22, 25, 2-23-87; Ord. No. 91-14, § 9, 2-11-
91)
Sec. 7-86. Notices; hearings; orders.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 152/735
(a)Whenever the chief building inspector or his designated representative determines that there are
reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this article or of any
regulation adopted pursuant hereto, he shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person to
whom the permit was issued, as provided in this section. Such notice shall:
(1) Be in writing.
(2) Include a statement of the reasons for its issuance.
(3) Allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act it requires.
(4) Be served upon the owner or his agent as the case may require, provided that a notice or order
shall be deemed to have been properly served upon such owner or agent when a copy thereof has
been sent by registered mail to his last known address, or when he has been served with such notice
by any other method authorized or required by the laws of this state.
(5) Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of
this health code and with regulations adopted pursuant hereto.
(b)Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any
provisions of this article, or of any regulation adopted pursuant hereto, may request and shall be
granted a hearing on the matter before the health code board of appeals, provided that such person
shall file in the office of the chief building inspector or his designated representative a written petition
requesting such hearing and setting forth a statement of the grounds therefor within ten (10) days
after the day the notice was served. The filing of the request for a hearing shall operate as a stay of
the notice and of the suspension, except in the case of an order issued under subsection (e). Upon
receipt of such petition, the chief building inspector or his designated representative shall set a time
and place for such hearing and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. At such hearing, the
petitioner shall be given an opportunity to speak and to explain why such notice should be modified
or withdrawn.
(c)After such hearing, the health code board of appeals shall make findings as to compliance with the
provisions of this article and regulations issued thereunder and shall issue an order in writing
sustaining, modifying or withdrawing the notice which shall be served as provided by subsection (a)
(4). Upon failure to comply with any order sustaining or modifying a notice, the permit of the mobile
home park affected by the order shall be revoked.
(d)The proceedings at such hearing including the findings and decision of the health code board of
appeals, together with a copy of every notice and order related thereto, shall be entered as a matter
of public record in the office of the chief building inspector or his designated representative, but the
transcript of the proceedings need not be transcribed unless judicial review of the decision in any
court of competent jurisdiction as provided by laws of this state is undertaken.
(e)Whenever the chief building inspector or his designated representative finds that an emergency exists
which requires immediate action to protect the public health, he may, without notice or hearing, issue
an order reciting the existence of such emergency and requiring that such action be taken as he may
deem necessary to meet the emergency, including suspension of the permit. Notwithstanding any
other provisions of this article, such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such
an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but, upon petition to the chief building
inspector or his designated representative, shall be afforded a hearing before the health code board
of appeals as soon as is possible.
(f)Any person operating or constructing a mobile home park may petition the health code board of
appeals of the city for a variance from any of the provisions of this article.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 153/735
(Ord. No. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 5), 9-27-82; Ord. No. 87-22, § 22, 3-23-87)
Sec. 7-87. Environmental, open space and access requirements.
(a)Existing parks generally. Mobile home parks in existence on the effective date of this article which
have less than the minimum prescribed requirements, other than the minimum area requirements
specified in subsection (b), may continue to operate.
(b)Minimum area. Present existing mobile home parks shall not be required to comply with the minimum
area requirements of this article, but may continue to operate with their present minimum area of not
less than one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet for each mobile home.
(c)Expansion of size. Any presently existing mobile home park that expands the size of its park shall be
required to comply with all provisions of this article in its expanded area.
(d)Nonresidential uses. No part of any mobile home park shall be used for nonresidential purposes,
except such uses that are required for the direct servicing and well-being of park residents and for
the maintenance of the park. No commercial establishments shall be operated in any mobile home
park except those operated by the owner of said park for mobile home park occupants. Such
establishments shall present no visible evidence from any street outside the mobile home park of
their commercial character which would attract customers other than mobile home park occupants.
(e)Setbacks on lot. Mobile homes shall be located not less than six (6) feet from the side or rear lot lines
of the lot upon which they are located, except that every mobile home lot shall contain a minimum of
three thousand two hundred (3,200) square feet. All roofed-over patios and carports shall be
considered part of the mobile home.
(f)Accessory structures. Any accessory structure, such as storage facilities, shall be located no closer
than three (3) feet from the side and rear lot lines and three (3) feet from the mobile home and shall
be located on the rear half of said lot.
(g)Setbacks, buffer strips and screening generally.
(1) All mobile homes shall be located at least twenty-five (25) feet from any park property boundary
line abutting upon a public street or highway and at least ten (10) feet from any other park property
boundary lines. There shall be a minimum distance of ten (10) feet between an individual mobile
home, including accessory structures attached thereto, and adjoining pavement of park street or
sidewalk, or common parking area, or other common areas accessible to park residents.
(2) All mobile home parks shall be provided with a screening buffer strip at least five (5) feet wide
along all property boundary lines. Where effective visual barriers do not already exist along such
property boundary lines, the buffer strip shall be furnished with screening at least five (5) feet high
and consisting of fences, free-standing walls or natural growth. Such growth shall consist of a
compact growth of shrubbery, hedges, evergreens or other suitable plantings sufficient to serve as an
effective visual screen. Fences or walls shall not contain electrical charges, barbed wire, broken
glass or other material designed to do bodily harm.
(h)Park street system.
(1) General requirements. All mobile home parks shall provide safe, continuous and convenient
vehicular access from abutting public streets or roads to each mobile home space. For purposes of
this article, all streets or roads providing such vehicular access hereinafter shall be referred to as the
"park street system" and shall be maintained by the owner or owners.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 154/735
(2) Primary entrance road. The primary entrance road connecting the park street system with a public
street or road shall have a minimum road pavement width of forty-one (41) feet, where guest parking
is permitted at both sides; or a minimum road pavement width of twenty-five (25) feet, where guest
parking is limited to one side. Where the primary entrance road is more than one hundred (100') feet
long and does not provide access to abutting property within such distance, the minimum road width
may be twenty-five (25) feet, provided parking is prohibited at both sides.
(3) Secondary entrance road. In addition to the required primary entrance road, all parks containing
twenty-five (25) or more acres in total area and/or providing for the accommodation of two hundred
(200) or more mobile homes, shall have at least one secondary entrance road connecting the park
street system with a public street or road. Such a secondary road or roads shall have a minimum
pavement width of twenty-five (25) feet. Where primary and secondary entrance roads connect to the
same public street or road, there shall be a minimum separation of one hundred-fifty (150) feet
between such access points. Where this is not feasible or possible, there shall be clearly marked
one-way entrance and exit lanes with a pavement width of each one-way road to be at least twentytwo
(22) feet.
(4) Interior streets. All interior streets in the park street system shall have a minimum pavement width
of twenty-five (25) feet on a twenty-five-foot right-of-way with parking prohibited on one side. Deadend
streets shall be limited in length to one thousand (1,000) feet and shall be provided at the closed
end with a turn-around having an outside roadway diameter of at least sixty-five (65) feet.
(5) Street construction standards shall meet the requirements of the subdivision regulations of the
city, as amended.
(i)Parking: Off street parking shall be provided in all parks for the use of park occupants. Such areas
shall be furnished at the rate of at least two (2) car spaces for each mobile home. Parking bays shall
be located so as to provide convenient access to mobile home spaces.
(j)Sidewalks: All mobile home parks shall provide safe, convenient, four foot (4') wide, four inch (4")
Portland cement concrete sidewalks on both sides of the park street system between each mobile
home space and all open areas, community structures and facilities.
(k)Electricity; Lighting: All mobile home parks shall be furnished with sufficient electrical systems and
lighting units at the owner's expense, so spaced and equipped with luminaires placed at such
mounting heights as will provide the average maintained levels of illumination for the safe movement
of pedestrians and vehicles at night, as required for city streets by the city engineer, with guidance
from Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 6), 9-27-1982)
Sec. 7-88. Water Supply:
Each mobile home park shall be provided with a complete water distribution system adequate to serve
the entire park. The water system must be designed in conformance with the requirements of the
subdivision regulations of the city and meet the approval of the director of public works or his designated
representative. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 7), 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-89. Storm Water Sewers:
Each mobile home park shall be provided with a storm water sewer adequate to serve the entire park.
The storm water sewer system must be designed in conformance with the requirements of the
subdivision regulations of the city and meet the approval of the director of public works or his designated
representative. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 8), 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-90. Sanitary Sewers:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 155/735
Each mobile home park shall provide for the satisfactory disposal of sanitary sewage. The sanitary
sewer system shall be designed in conformance with the requirements of the subdivision regulations of
the city and meet the approval of the director of public works or his designated representative. (Ord. 82-
28, § 1(Art. V, § 9) 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-91. Refuse Disposal:
Disposal of refuse shall follow the standards set in chapter 13, article II of this code. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art.
V, § 10), 9-27-1982)
Sec. 7-92. Electrical Distribution System:
The electrical system of each mobile home park shall be adequate to serve the entire park. The
electrical system shall be designed in conformance with the requirements of the subdivision regulations
of the city and approved by the director of public works or his designated representative. (Ord. 82-28, §
1(Art. V, § 11), 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-93. Safety:
Liquid petroleum gas, fuel oil, gasoline and other flammable liquids shall be handled and used in a safe
manner and shall not be stored inside or beneath any mobile home. (Ord. 82-28, § 1(Art. V, § 12), 9-27-
1982)
Secs. 7-94-7-110. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. ANIMALS 1, 2
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 7-111. Definitions:
The following words and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings respectively ascribed
to them in this section:
Animal: Any animal, poultry, bird, reptile or any other dumb creature.
Animal Control Officer: Any person employed by the department for the purpose of enforcing the animal
control ordinances or having custody and control of the city animal shelter and of animals therein.
Cat: Except where specifically distinguished means all animals of the feline species of the age of four (4)
months or older.
Dangerous Animal:
(1) Any animal that while off the property of the owner or custodian of the animal unreasonably and
without provocation causes injury to a person.
(2) Any animal that while off the property of the owner or custodian of the animal unreasonably
attacks another domestic animal and causes serious physical injury or death to the other
domesticated animal.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 156/735
(3) Any animal that while on the property of the owner or custodian of the animal unreasonably
attacks and causes injury to any person lawfully on the property of the owner.
(4) Any animal that has been declared a "potentially dangerous animal" on one prior occasion and is
found upon investigation of a new incident to meet the definition of "potentially dangerous animal".
Department: The department of police, unless otherwise specifically designated.
Distemper And Hepatitis Injection: Any serum approved by the Illinois department of agriculture for
temporary use.
Dog: Except where specifically distinguished means all animals of the canine species of the age of four
(4) months or older.
Impounded: Taken into the custody of the public pound in the city or county where the animal is found.
Inoculation: The injection, subcutaneously or in such other manner as may be approved by the
department of agriculture of the state of Illinois pursuant to the rabies control law of the state, of antirabic
vaccine meeting standards approved by the department of agriculture of the state and by the United
States department of agriculture.
Licensed Veterinarian: Any veterinarian duly licensed as such under the laws of the state of Illinois or of
any other state which by law provides for the licensing of veterinarians.
Owner Or Keeper: Any person who shall harbor, suffer or permit any dog or cat to remain on any
premises within the city of Rock Island under his charge.
Potentially Dangerous Animal:
(1) Any individual animal while off the premises of the owner and when unmuzzled, unleashed, or not
under the control of its owner or custodian that behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would
believe poses a serious and unjustified imminent threat of serious physical injury or death to a person
or domesticated companion animal.
(2) Any animal that has been declared a "dangerous animal" on a prior occasion and that is not
properly confined as required by subsection 7-117.1(g) of this division.
(3) Any animal that while off the property of the owner or custodian of the animal unreasonably
attacks and causes injury to another domesticated animal.
Serious Physical Injury: Shall include, but not be limited by, those instances where the animal causes
serious or permanent disfigurement or impairment to health or bodily function of the person.
Unreasonably Attacks: An unprovoked and unjustified direct action on the part of the animal.
Vicious Animal:
(1) Any animal that unreasonably attacks a person and causes serious physical injury or death.
(2) Any animal that has been declared a "dangerous animal" on one prior occasion and is found upon
investigation of a new incident to meet the definition of "dangerous animal". (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973;
Ord. 82-25, § 1, 9-13-1982; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§§ 1-3), 10-25-1982; Ord. 86-56, § 1, 11-3-1986; Ord.
87-81, § 1, 10-5-1987; Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-112. Penalty:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 157/735
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this article shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00). In
the event a person is accused of a violation of this article and does not wish to contest said allegation
prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, the person so accused may pay to the city, at
police headquarters, a penalty in the sum of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for and in full satisfaction of
said violation. (Ord., 1-12-1981; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 83-57, 2-6-1984; Ord. 91-136, 12-9-1991)
Sec. 7-113. Animal Shelter:
The city shall provide and maintain an animal shelter suitable for the impounding and maintenance of
dogs and other small animals and shall provide and furnish all other equipment and supplies required in
the application of this article. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-114. Animal Control Officer:
(a)The animal control officer shall be a staff member of the department of police and shall be directly
responsible to the chief of police in the application of this article and the proper operation of the
animal shelter.
(b)The animal control officer shall have the care, custody, control and supervision of the animal shelter
of the city and of all dogs and other animals confined and impounded therein, and shall have the
care, custody and control of all trucks and other paraphernalia used by him or his assistants in and
about the impounding of such animals.
(c)All assistants assigned to the animal control program shall be responsible to the chief of police in the
performance of their duties.
(d)While on duty, the animal control officer shall wear a star engraved "Animal Control Officer" as an
emblem of this authority.
(e)The animal control officer shall deliver to the city collector, at least once a month, all fees and monies
collected by him.
(f)Any animal kept or found under the conditions which may constitute a violation of this article may be
impounded by the animal control officer. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 86-56, 11-3-
1986)
Sec. 7-115. Cruelty To Animals 3:
No person or owner shall beat, cruelly treat, torment, starve, overwork or otherwise abuse any animal.
Each owner shall provide for each of his animals:
(1) Sufficient quantity of good quality, wholesome food and water, served in clean containers with
water available at all times;
(2) Adequate shelter and protection from the weather; and
(3) Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering.
No owner shall abandon any animal where it shall become a public charge or shall suffer injury, hunger,
or exposure. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 86-56, 11-3-1986)
Sec. 7-116. Running At Large Generally:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 158/735
(a)No domestic animal, including horses, mules, cattle, sheep, swine or domestic fowl of the species of
geese, ducks, turkeys, chickens, or barn fowl shall be suffered, allowed or permitted to run at large
within the corporate limits of the city.
(b)Any dog shall be considered to be running at large if it leaves the premises of its owner or keeper
when not under control by leash and a person who is willing and able to prevent the dog from
violating any city ordinance.
(c)Every animal running at large within the city shall be liable for impoundment at any time by the animal
control officer or other member of the police department. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982;
Ord. 54-2003, § 1, 7-14-2003)
Sec. 7-117. Vicious Animal:
(a)Vicious Animals Prohibited: No person shall own, keep, harbor, sell, abandon or give away any
animal found to be vicious within the city, whether or not owned by such person, except to relinquish
the animal for impoundment. Such animals are hereby declared nuisances and are subject to
impoundment and disposal.
(b)Declaration Of Animal As Vicious; Procedure:
(1) The Rock Island animal control officer or law enforcement officer shall classify an animal as
vicious if probable cause is established to believe that the animal falls within the definition set forth
for "vicious animal" in section 7-111, "Definitions", of this division.
The finding must be based upon: a) the written complaint of a citizen who is willing to testify that the
animal has acted in a manner which causes it to fall within the definition of "vicious animal" as set
forth in section 7-111, "Definitions", of this division; or b) the reports filed with the police department;
or c) actions of the animal witnessed by any animal control officer, law enforcement officer or citizen
who is willing to sign a complaint; or d) other substantial evidence.
(2) Once the police department becomes aware of an animal that may fall within the definition of
"vicious animal" as set forth in section 7-111, "Definitions", of this division, an animal control officer or
law enforcement officer shall complete an investigation within five (5) days with a recommendation as
to whether or not the animal should be declared a vicious animal. During this investigation, the
animal shall be impounded at the animal control facility utilized by the city.
This recommendation shall be reviewed with the animal's owner and the victim, or the victim's
parent/guardian if the victim is a minor. If either of these persons should choose to dispute this
recommendation, the investigating animal control officer or law enforcement officer shall consult: a) a
