board certified veterinarian who deals with this type of animal or b) an animal behavior specialist who
has completed a certification or formal program of education in a related field or has at least three (3)
years of work experience in a related field. The opinion of the veterinarian or animal behavior
specialist shall then be used as the basis for the final recommendation on the declaration of the
animal as vicious. The results of this consultation shall also be shared with the animal's owner and
the victim, or the victim's parent/guardian if the victim is a minor.
(3) The declaration of vicious animal shall be in writing and shall be served on the owner in one of
the following methods: a) certified mail to the owner's last known address; or b) personally; or c) if
the owner cannot be located by one of the first two (2) methods, by publication in a newspaper of
general circulation in this community.
(4) The declaration shall state at least: a) the description of the animal; b) the name and address of
the owner of the animal, if known; c) the whereabouts of the animal, if it is not in the custody of the
owner; d) the facts upon which the declaration of vicious animal is based; e) the availability of a
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 159/735
hearing in case the person objects to the declaration, if a request is made within ten (10) days; f) the
fact that the animal shall be euthanized after ten (10) days unless a request for a hearing has been
received.
(c)Owner Objection To Declaration Of Vicious Animal: If the owner of the animal wishes to object to the
declaration of the animal as vicious:
(1) The owner may request a hearing before the code hearing officer, by submitting a written request
and payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00) administrative review fee to the city within ten (10) days
of receipt of the declaration, or within ten (10) days of the publication of the declaration pursuant to
subsection (b)(3) of this section.
(2) If the code hearing officer finds that there is insufficient evidence to support the declaration, it
shall be rescinded, and the penalty to be imposed thereby annulled.
(3) If the code hearing officer finds sufficient evidence to support the declaration, the owner may
appeal such decision to the circuit court, pursuant to the administrative review act.
(4) During the entire appeal process, the animal shall be held at the animal control facility utilized by
the city.
(d)Disposal Of Vicious Animal: Following a declaration of an animal as vicious and the exhaustion of any
appeal therefrom, the animal shall be euthanized. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-25, 9-13-1982; Ord. 82-
41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 86-56, 11-3-1986; Ord. 87-81, 10-5-1987; Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-117.1. Dangerous Animal:
(a)Directing Animal With Malicious Intent Prohibited: No person having control or custody of any animal
shall, without legal cause or justification, direct, encourage, cause, allow, or otherwise aid or assist
any animal to threaten, charge at, intimidate, bite, harass, menace, or attack any person within the
city.
(b)Use Of Animal In Illegal Activity Prohibited: No person shall keep, maintain, control, or retain custody
of any animal in conjunction with or for the purpose, whether in whole or in part, of aiding, abetting, or
conducting any illegal activity or committing any crime within the city.
(c)Directing Animal With Malicious Intent Toward Public Safety Officer Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for
any person having control or custody of any animal to allow, direct, encourage, cause, or otherwise
aid or assist any animal to threaten, charge, intimidate, bite, harass, menace, or attack any public
safety officer engaged in the conduct of his/her duties.
(d)Probable Cause To Impound: Any law enforcement officer having probable cause to believe that any
person has violated the restrictions against dangerous animals hereof may impound or cause to be
impounded any animal. Such impoundment shall be subject to all other sections of this article and all
other municipal laws, including, but not limited to, this code dealing with animals.
(e)Declaration Of Animal As Dangerous; Procedure:
(1) The Rock Island animal control officer or law enforcement officer shall classify an animal as
dangerous if probable cause is established to believe that the animal falls within the definition set
forth for "dangerous animal" in section 7-111, "Definitions", of this division.
The finding must be based upon: a) the written complaint of a citizen who is willing to testify that the
animal has acted in a manner which causes it to fall within the definition of "dangerous animal"; or b)
reports filed with the police department; or c) actions of the animal witnessed by any animal control
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 160/735
officer, law enforcement officer or citizen who is willing to sign a complaint; or d) other substantial
evidence.
(2) Once the police department becomes aware of an animal that may fall within the definition of
"dangerous animal" set forth in section 7-111, "Definitions", of this division, an animal control officer
or law enforcement officer shall complete an investigation within five (5) days with a recommendation
as to whether or not the animal should be declared a dangerous animal. During this investigation, the
animal shall be impounded at the animal control facility utilized by the city.
This recommendation shall be reviewed with the animal's owner and the victim, or the victim's
parent/guardian if the victim is a minor. If either of these persons should choose to dispute this
recommendation, the investigating animal control officer or law enforcement officer shall consult: a) a
board certified veterinarian who deals with this type of animal or b) an animal behavior specialist who
has completed a certification or formal program of education in a related field or has at least three (3)
years of work experience in a related field. The opinion of the veterinarian or animal behavior
specialist shall then be used as the basis for the final recommendation on the declaration of the
animal as a dangerous animal. The results of this consultation shall also be shared with the animal's
owner and the victim, or the victim's parent/guardian if the victim is a minor.
(3) The declaration of dangerous animal shall be in writing and shall be served on the owner in one
of the following methods: a) certified mail to the owner's last known address; or b) personally; or c) if
the owner cannot be located by one of the first two (2) methods, by publication in a newspaper of
general circulation in this community.
(4) The declaration shall state at least: a) the description of the animal; b) the name and address of
the owner of the animal, if known; c) the whereabouts of the animal, if it is not in the custody of the
owner; d) the facts upon which the declaration of dangerous animal is based; e) the availability of a
hearing in case the person objects to the declaration, if a request is made within ten (10) days; f) the
restrictions placed on the animal as a result of the declaration of dangerous animal; g) the penalties
for violation of the restrictions, including the possibility of destruction of the animal, and/or fining of
the owner.
(f)Owner Objection To Declaration Of Dangerous Animal: If the owner of the animal wishes to object to
the declaration of dangerous animal:
(1) The owner may request a hearing before the code hearing officer, by submitting a written request
and payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00) administrative review fee to the city within ten (10) days
of receipt of the declaration, or within ten (10) days of the publication of the declaration pursuant to
subsection (e)(3) of this section.
(2) If the code hearing officer finds that there is insufficient evidence to support the declaration, it
shall be rescinded, and the restrictions imposed thereby annulled.
(3) If the code hearing officer finds sufficient evidence to support the declaration, the owner may
appeal such decision to the circuit court, pursuant to the administrative review act.
(g)Confinement Of Dangerous Animal: Following a declaration of dangerous animal and during the
entire appeal process or after the exhaustion of any appeal therefrom, it shall be unlawful for the
person owning or having care of such dangerous animal to allow or permit such animal to: 1) be
unconfined on the premises of such person; or 2) go beyond the premises of such person unless
such animal is securely leashed and muzzled. The leash shall be no longer than six feet (6') in
length. The muzzle shall be made in such a manner that it will not cause injury to the animal or
interfere with its vision or respiration but will prevent it from biting or causing injury to any person or
animal. Being confined on the premises shall consist of the animal being kept: 1) within the residence
or other building, or 2) within an enclosure from which the animal cannot escape and with openings
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 161/735
no more than two and one-half inches (21/2") in width, or 3) on a run line or chain within an area
enclosed by a fence that the animal is unable to reach and that prevents the entry of small children.
Additionally, signs indicating the presence of a dangerous animal on the property shall be posted on
any enclosure and at the most conspicuous points of entry to the property. The dangerous or
potentially dangerous animal shall not be returned to the person owning or having care of such
animal until these conditions are met to the satisfaction of the animal control officer.
(h)Notification Of Status Of Dangerous Animal: The owner of an animal which has been classified as
dangerous shall immediately notify the police department when the animal: 1) is loose or unconfined;
2) has bitten a human being or attacked another animal; 3) is sold or given away, or dies; 4) is moved
to another address.
(i)Sale Of Dangerous Animal: Prior to selling or giving away an animal that has been classified as
dangerous, the owner shall provide the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner to
the police department and shall certify to the police department that the new owner has been notified
of such classification. The new owner shall comply with all of the requirements of this section.
(j)Custodial Liability: In the event the owner or keeper of the dangerous animal is a minor, the custodian,
parent, or guardian, legally responsible for such minor shall be liable for all injuries and property
damage sustained by any person or domestic animal caused by an unprovoked attack by said
dangerous animal.
(k)Penalty For Violation: Any person who violates a provision of this section, upon conviction thereof,
shall be punished by a fine in an amount not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). In
addition, any person found guilty of violating this section shall pay all expenses, including shelter,
food, veterinary expenses for identification or certification of the breed of the animal or boarding and
veterinary expenses necessitated by the seizure of any animal for the protection of the public, and
such other expenses as may be required for the destruction of any such animal. Any dangerous
animal that is in violation of the restrictions contained in subsection (g) of this section or restrictions
imposed as part of a declaration as a dangerous animal shall be seized and impounded. (Ord. 98-09,
1-19-1998; Ord. 54-2003, § 2, 7-14-2003; Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-117.2. Potentially Dangerous Animal:
(a)Declaration Of Animal As Potentially Dangerous; Procedure:
(1) The Rock Island animal control officer or law enforcement officer shall classify an animal as
potentially dangerous if probable cause is established to believe that the animal falls within the
definitions set forth for "potentially dangerous animal" in section 7-111, "Definitions", of this division.
The finding must be based upon: a) the written complaint of a citizen who is willing to testify that the
animal has acted in a manner which causes it to fall within the definition of "potentially dangerous
animal"; or b) reports filed with the police department; or c) actions of the animal witnessed by any
animal control officer, law enforcement officer or citizen who is willing to sign a complaint; or d) other
substantial evidence.
(2) Once the police department becomes aware of an animal that may fall within the definition of
"potentially dangerous animal" set forth in section 7-111, "Definitions", of this division, an animal
control officer or law enforcement officer shall complete an investigation within five (5) days with a
recommendation as to whether or not the animal should be declared a potentially dangerous animal.
During this investigation, the animal shall be impounded at the animal control facility utilized by the
city.
This recommendation shall be reviewed with the animal's owner and the victim, or the victim's
parent/guardian if the victim is a minor. If either of these persons should choose to dispute this
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 162/735
recommendation, the investigating animal control officer or law enforcement officer shall consult: a) a
board certified veterinarian who deals with this type of animal or b) an animal behavior specialist who
has completed a certification or formal program of education in a related field or has at least three (3)
years of work experience in a related field. The opinion of the veterinarian or animal behavior
specialist shall then be used as the basis for the final recommendation on the declaration of the
animal as a potentially dangerous animal. The results of this consultation shall also be shared with
the animal's owner and the victim, or the victim's parent/guardian if the victim is a minor.
(3) The declaration of potentially dangerous animal shall be in writing and shall be served on the
owner in one of the following methods: a) certified mail to the owner's last known address; or b)
personally; or c) if the owner cannot be located by one of the first two (2) methods, by publication in a
newspaper of general circulation in this community.
(4) The declaration shall state at least: a) the description of the animal; b) the name and address of
the owner of the animal, if known; c) the whereabouts of the animal, if it is not in the custody of the
owner; d) the facts upon which the declaration of potentially dangerous animal is based; e) the
availability of a hearing in case the person objects to the declaration, if a request is made within ten
(10) days; f) the restrictions placed on the animal as a result of the declaration of potentially
dangerous animal; g) the penalties for violation of the restrictions, including the possibility of
destruction of the animal, and/or fining of the owner.
(b)Owner Objection To Declaration Of Potentially Dangerous Animal: If the owner of the animal wishes
to object to the declaration of potentially dangerous animal:
(1) The owner may request a hearing before the code hearing officer, by submitting a written request
and payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00) administrative review fee to the city within ten (10) days
of receipt of the declaration, or within ten (10) days of the publication of the declaration pursuant to
subsection (a)(3) of this section.
(2) If the code hearing officer finds that there is insufficient evidence to support the declaration, it
shall be rescinded, and the restrictions imposed thereby annulled.
(3) If the code hearing officer finds sufficient evidence to support the declaration, the owner may
appeal such decision to the circuit court, pursuant to the administrative review act.
(c)Restriction Of Potentially Dangerous Animal: Following a declaration of potentially dangerous animal
and during the entire appeal process or after the exhaustion of any appeal therefrom, it shall be
unlawful for the person owning or having care of such potentially dangerous animal to allow or permit
such animal to go beyond the premises of such person unless such animal is securely leashed and
muzzled. The leash shall be no longer than six feet (6') in length. The muzzle shall be made in such
a manner that it will not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but will
prevent it from biting or causing injury to any person or animal.
(d)Notification Of Status Of Potentially Dangerous Animal: The owner of an animal which has been
classified as potentially dangerous shall immediately notify the police department when the animal: 1)
is loose; 2) has bitten a human being or attacked another animal; 3) is sold or given away, or dies; 4)
is moved to another address.
(e)Sale Of Potentially Dangerous Animal: Prior to selling or giving away an animal that has been
classified as potentially dangerous, the owner shall provide the name, address, and telephone
number of the new owner to the police department and shall certify to the police department that the
new owner has been notified of such classification. The new owner shall comply with all of the
requirements of this section.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 163/735
(f)Custodial Liability: In the event the owner or keeper of the potentially dangerous animal is a minor, the
custodian, parent, or guardian, legally responsible for such minor shall be liable for all injuries and
property damage sustained by any person or domestic animal caused by an unprovoked attack by
said potentially dangerous animal.
(g)Penalty For Violation: Any person who violates a provision of this section, upon conviction thereof,
shall be punished by a fine in an amount not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). In
addition, any person found guilty of violating this section shall pay all expenses, including shelter,
food, veterinary expenses for identification or certification of the breed of the animal or boarding and
veterinary expenses necessitated by the seizure of any animal for the protection of the public, and
such other expenses as may be required for the destruction of any such animal. Any potentially
dangerous animal that is in violation of the restrictions contained in subsection (c) of this section or
restrictions imposed as part of a declaration as a potentially dangerous animal shall be seized and
impounded. (Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-118. Surrender Of Unclaimed Impounded Animals For The Purposes Of
Medical Research:
(a)Whenever any reputable institutions of learning, hospitals, research laboratories or their allied
institutes within a reasonable distance of the city shall make application to the chief of police or his
authorized agent for permission to use humanely unclaimed impounded animals for the good of
mankind and the increase of knowledge relating to the cause, prevention, control and cure of
disease, the chief of police or his authorized agent, upon being satisfied that the animals are to be so
used, shall, from time to time, release such acceptable unclaimed impounded animals for medical
research or otherwise as above specified.
(b)In order to give the owners of impounded animals time within which to reclaim the same, no animal
shall be surrendered for such uses until it has been impounded for a period of at least seven (7)
days.
(c)No impounded animal wearing an unexpired county tag may be released for purposes of medical
research. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 7-119. Authority To Enter Premises:
For the purpose of discharging the duties imposed by this article upon the department, the animal
control officer, any sworn police officer or any member of the department is hereby authorized and
directed to enter upon any premises upon which any dog or cat is kept or harbored and to demand the
exhibition by the person owning or having charge or control of such dog or cat, of the license tag for
such dog or cat. Whenever there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation,
each member of the department or any sworn police officer is hereby authorized and directed to enter
upon any such premises for the purpose of inspecting the same to ascertain if any provision of this
article or of any law of the state relating to the care, treatment or impounding of dumb animals or for the
prevention of cruelty thereto is being violated. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-120. Animal Bites:
All bites or attacks on human beings by any animal within the city shall be immediately reported to the
chief of police. In the event of a bite by an animal, a detailed report shall be completed by the receiving
officer including the complainant's name, address and phone number, the name and address of the
owner of such animal, if known, and the doctor treating the wound. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-
1982)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 164/735
Sec. 7-121. Public Nuisance:
It is unlawful for any person to maintain a public nuisance by permitting any dangerous or potentially
dangerous animal to leave the premises of its owner when not under control by leash or other
recognized control methods.
Professionally trained guide dogs for the blind or hearing impaired, support dogs for the physically
handicapped, and sentry, guard, or police owned dogs are exempt from this section; provided, an attack
or injury to a person occurs while the dog is performing duties as expected. To qualify for exemption
under this section, each such dog shall be currently inoculated against rabies in accordance with 510
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8. It shall be the duty of the owner of such exempted dog to notify the animal
control officer of this city of changes of address. In the case of a sentry or guard dog, the owner shall
keep the animal control officer advised of the location where such dog will be stationed. The animal
control officer shall provide police and fire departments with a categorized list of such exempted dogs,
and shall promptly notify such departments of any address changes reported to him. (Ord. 87-81, 10-5-
1987; Ord. 54-2003, § 3, 7-14-2003; Ord. 082-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Secs. 7-122-7-135. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. DOGS AND CATS GENERALLY
Sec. 7-136. Inoculation Required 1:
Every owner or keeper of a dog or cat within the limits of the city shall have a valid rabies inoculation
certificate issued by the state department of agriculture. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-137. Rabies:
Any animal which comes under the Illinois rabies control law will be handled as provided by this law.
(Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-138. Certificate Of Veterinarian Prerequisite To Registration:
No dog or cat shall be registered or licensed under this article unless a certificate of a licensed
veterinarian certifying to the fact and date of inoculation of such dog or cat shall have been filed with or
exhibited to the authorized agent of the city in the city collector's office, showing inoculation to have
been made as required by section 7-136 of this division. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-139. Nonresident Owners:
The provisions of this article relating to the licensing of dogs and cats shall not apply to dogs or cats of
nonresidents remaining temporarily in or passing through the city, provided that such dogs or cats have
a license from some other jurisdiction. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-140. License-Required; Amount Of Fee:
(a)Any person who owns a dog or cat six (6) months or older shall pay the annual fee as set forth below.
The license will be in full force and effect until the anniversary date of the rabies vaccination of the
animal and thereafter shall be renewable annually.
(1) Pet license for unaltered dog or cat $30.00
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 165/735
(2) Pet license for altered dog or cat 6.00
(3) Senior citizen (age 65 or older) or handicapped person, unaltered dog or cat 15.00
(4) Senior citizen (age 65 or older) or handicapped person, altered dog or cat 3.00
(5) All replacement tags 3.00
Upon issuance of a license as aforesaid, the city shall issue a voucher in the amount of twenty
dollars ($20.00) to a person who has paid for a pet license for an unaltered dog or cat. A voucher for
ten dollars ($10.00) shall be issued by the city to senior citizens who have paid for such a license.
(b)Persons making a license renewal application received after thirty (30) calendar days of license
expiration date shall pay as a penalty an additional sum of ten dollars ($10.00). No late penalties
shall be charged on new applications if:
(1) The owner submits proof of purchase or acquisition of the animal within the preceding thirty (30)
calendar days; or
(2) The owner has moved into the city within the preceding thirty (30) calendar days; or
(3) The animal is currently or has been within the preceding thirty (30) calendar days under the age
which requires a license.
(c)The provisions of this section shall not apply to dogs or cats in the custody of a veterinarian or animal
shelter or animal rescuer or breeder or whose owners are nonresidents temporarily within the city for
a period not exceeding thirty (30) calendar days.
(d)It shall be a violation of this section for any person to knowingly issue a check for which funds are
insufficient or to stop payment on any check written in payment of fees contained in this Section. Any
license(s) or penalties paid for with such checks are, in the case of the license, invalid, and in the
case of the penalty, still outstanding. (Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord. 92-149,
12-21-1992; Ord. 93-31, 4-19-1993; Ord. 97-30, 4-14-1997)
Sec. 7-141. License-Tag:
Upon payment to the city collector of the fee provided for in this article and upon producing a certificate
of inoculation, the city collector shall furnish to the person paying such fee a license tag and
memorandum or registry for each dog or cat for which such fee has been paid. It shall be a violation of
this section for any person to sell or transfer ownership of any dog or cat over six (6) months without a
dog or cat license. (Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982; Ord. 92-149, 12-21-1992)
Sec. 7-141.1. Display Of License-Tag:
It shall be a violation for any person to be in control of a dog over the age of six (6) months that does not
have a visibly displayed license tag affixed to its collar when it leaves the premises of its owner or
keeper. In the event a dog is found to be without a license tag displayed, the animal control officer or
other member of the police department may impound or cause to be impounded said dog. Said dog shall
be released from impoundment upon proof of a valid license tag issued by the city or other government
body having jurisdiction over the dog's owner or keeper or proof that such jurisdiction has no such
requirement. (Ord. 54-2003, § 4, 7-14-2003)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 166/735
Sec. 7-142. Chief Of Police To Provide Metal License Tags:
The chief of police shall provide each year such number of metal tags as may be necessary having
stamped thereon the year for which the license is paid and the number of the tag. The city collector shall
issue a metal tag, numbered to correspond with the number of the registry of the dog or cat, to the
person who paid the license fee upon each dog or cat. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-143. Registry Of Licensed Animals:
The chief of police or his authorized agent shall keep a complete registry of all licensed dogs and cats,
and their breed, color and sex, and shall also enter therein the name and address of the owner as given
and the number of the license tag. (Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord., 6-24-1974; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-144. Sanitation:
The owner or keeper of any dog or cat in the city shall keep the pen clean and odor free at all times.
(Ord., 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-145. Defecation On Public Property:
No owner or keeper of any pet shall permit said pet to defecate on any public way or public property or
upon any private property without the permission of the occupant or the owner of the private property
without immediately removing said defecation and depositing same in a refuse container or similar
depository. (Ord. 86-21, 5-5-1986; Ord. 56-2004, § 1, 5-10-2004)
Sec. 7-146. Spaying And Neutering:
(a)No person shall own, harbor or keep within the city any cat or dog over the age of six (6) months
which has not been spayed or neutered, unless such person holds either a license for breeding cats
or dogs issued by the city or possesses an unaltered dog or cat license as stated in this division or a
written certificate from a licensed veterinarian that, due to health considerations, the animal should
not be spayed or neutered.
(b)An altered dog or cat shall be those that fall into one of the two (2) categories listed herein:
(1) Neutered Male : Any male dog or cat which has been rendered sterile by a surgical procedure
(orchiectomy).
(2) Spayed Female : A female dog or cat which has been rendered sterile by surgical means
(ovariohysterectomy). (Ord. 92-149, § 3, 12-21-1992)
Sec. 7-147. Health And Cruelty:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any animal owner or person to cruelly deprive food, water, shelter, and
protection to any animal under their control and/or custody, or to abandon, poison, cruelly beat,
cruelly whip or kill any animal under their, another's or no one's control and/or custody, or to mutilate,
overdrive, overload, overwork, torment, torture or otherwise cruelly ill use any animal. This section
shall not apply to wild animals killed in the hunt (not within city limits) by customary and nonbrutal
methods nor to wild rats, mice, insects, fish, arthropods or vermin; nor shall this section apply to
medical research organizations duly licensed and/or otherwise recognized or supported by state or
federal law.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 167/735
(b)It shall be unlawful for any animal owner to permit, either wilfully or through failure to exercise due
care and control, any animal to bark, cry, howl, whine or cause other objectionable noises which
disturb the comfort, peace, quiet or repose of any person residing in the vicinity.
(c)It shall be unlawful for any animal owner, either wilfully or through failure to exercise due care and
control, to maintain an animal or the premises upon which the animal is maintained, in such a
manner as to emit such offensive odors which disturb the comfort, peace or repose of any person
residing in the vicinity.
(d)It shall be unlawful for any animal owner to abandon any animal where it may become a public
charge, or may suffer injury, hunger or exposure.
Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than two
hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 92-149, § 3, 12-21-1992)
Sec. 7-148. Commercial Kennels, Pet Shops, Breeders, And Animal Rescuers And
Rehabilitators License:
No person shall operate in the city a commercial kennel pet shop, be a breeder of dogs and/or cats, or
be an animal rescuer and rehabilitator without having first obtained a license therefor as set forth herein.
(1) Definitions :
Animal Rescuer And Rehabilitator : Any person licensed by the state and federal government to
rescue and rehabilitate wild animals and fowl that are sick or injured.
Breeder : A person or persons who own or breed dogs and/or cats primarily for personal recreational
use, such as participation in recognized conformation shows, field or obedience trials, racing,
scenting, specialized hunting or working trials, and water trials, and for the purpose of improving the
physical soundness, temperament, and conformation of a given breed to standard, such person to
sell or exchange, at retail only, and other than for purposes of research, testing, or experimentation,
dogs or cats bred from male/female dogs or cats owned or leased by the breeders.
Commercial Kennel : A structure or premises where dogs and cats over four (4) months of age are
kept, raised, bred or boarded for commercial purposes, excluding animal hospitals, clinics and pet
shops.
Pet Shop : Any person, establishment, store or department of any store that acquires live animals,
including dogs and cats, and sells or offers to sell or rent such live animal to the public or to retail
outlets.
(2)Application For License : Any person, firm, or corporation desiring to be licensed as aforesaid shall
file an application for the license with the city clerk and pay the annual fee thereof as set forth below.
Upon the filing of an application for a license required by this article, the city clerk shall forward
copies of same to the health officer, animal control officer and the zoning enforcement official for
inspection of the premises for compliance with state and city public health regulations and all city
ordinances and for compliance with all zoning ordinances. Upon receipt of reports of compliance with
regulations and ordinances from city officials, the city clerk, upon receipt of the license fee, shall
issue a license to the applicant.
(3)Inspection Of Premises :
a. The animal control officer, health inspector or any city inspector shall have the right, for the
purpose of investigating a complaint, to enter during normal business hours upon any premises
where the animal or animals described in the complaint are housed or kept provided such entry shall
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 168/735
not be made into any building which is a person's residence except by the consent of the owner, a
search warrant, or a court order. Any person who denies, prevents, or obstructs such access is guilty
of a violation of this section. The officer or inspector shall have the proper identification and/or
uniform and identification.
b. It shall be unlawful to interfere with any animal control officer or inspector in the legal performance
of their duties, or take or attempt to take an animal from any animal control officer or inspector, or
from any vehicle used by them to transport any animal, or to take or attempt to take any animal from
the animal shelter without proper authority.
c. Any premises may be entered for the purposes of inspection for the purposes of issuing a license
for a commercial kennel license, pet shop license or breeder's license.
(4)License Fees : The following annual fees are applicable under the provisions of this section:
Commercial kennel license $200.00
Pet shop license 75.00
Breeder's license 50.00
Plus, for each dog over 10.00
the age of 6 months
Rescuer and rehabilitation 25.00
license
Any license issued under this section shall be in effect for one year. The license year shall be May 1 to
April 30. Any person who attempts to renew a license after thirty (30) calendar days of the license
expiration date shall be subject to a penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) in addition to the license fee. (Ord.
92-149, § 3, 12-21-1992)
Secs. 7-149--7-155. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. IMPOUNDMENT
Sec. 7-156. Authorized.
(a)The owner, possessor or keeper of any dog or cat shall keep his dog or cat under restraint at all
times. Such dog or cat shall not be at large off the premises or property of such owner, possessor or
keeper unless under the control of a competent person.
(b)A dog is under restraint within the meaning of this section if it is controlled by a leash attached to a
collar or harness, "at heel" beside a competent person and is obedient to that person's commands,
or when under the control of a competent person on or within a vehicle being driven or parked on the
street.
(c)A cat is under restraint within the meaning of this section if it is controlled by a leash or confined.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 169/735
(d)(1) Every dog or cat running at large within the city shall be subject to impoundment at any time by
the animal control officer.
(2) The owner of any dog or cat that is impounded and claims that animal shall pay a penalty of the
sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first impoundment.
(3) Any dog or cat that is impounded a second time within a one year period shall be altered. The
owner shall pay a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a second impoundment and in
addition thereto the reasonable cost for the mandatory altering of the animal if the altering would not
endanger the health of the animal. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982; Ord. 86-
56, § 1, 11-3-1986; Ord. 92-149, § 4, 12-21-1992; Ord. 88-2004, § 1, 9-20-2004)
Sec. 7-157. Duty Of Animal Control Officer Generally:
The animal control officer shall impound, or cause to be impounded, and shall dispose of according to
the provisions of this article, all dogs running at large within the city and shall keep a record of every dog
so impounded, describing the breed, color and sex, together with the time and place such dog was
captured or received and the final disposition made of each dog, together with such other information as
may come to his attention. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 4), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-158. Records:
The animal control officer or the person in charge of the animal shelter to which any dog or cat is taken
in accordance with the provisions of section 7-156 of this division, shall immediately enter in a register
the breed, color and sex of such dog or cat, whether licensed or not, and if licensed, the name and
address of the owner or keeper. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-159. Notice To Owner:
When the owner of any impounded dog or cat is known, he shall be notified by telephone or mail
immediately after its impoundment by the person in charge of the animal shelter. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973;
Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-160. Claiming After Impoundment:
The owner of any animal impounded under the provisions of this article must claim the animal within
seven (7) days from the date of impounding upon payment of the following fees to the animal control
officer:
(1) The amount of the license fee for the current year, if not paid.
(2) The amount of the current veterinarian fee for rabies inoculation, if a valid certificate is not shown.
(3) The amount for the temporary hepatitis and distemper injection for dogs under one year of age.
(4) A redemption fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first impounding and a fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) for subsequent impounding within a year and in addition thereto the cost of altering as set
forth in section 7-156 of this division if there has been a second offense.
(5) Residents shall pay a fee of three dollars fifty cents ($3.50) for each day the animal has been
impounded. Nonresidents shall pay a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each day the animal has been
impounded. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord., § 1, 3-17-1975; Ord., § 1, 11-7-1977; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2),
10-25-1982; Ord. 85-30, § 1, 8-26-1985; Ord. 87-34, § 13, 4-6-1987; Ord. 92-149, § 5, 12-21-1992)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 170/735
Sec. 7-161. Animals Sold To New Owners:
Any person may purchase an animal impounded under the provisions of this article after seven (7) days
of impoundment, by complying with the following fee schedule:
(1) Dogs under four (4) months of age, the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) plus the cost of temporary
hepatitis and distemper injection, and an adoption in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) to cover the
cost of neutering or spaying.
(2) Dogs over four (4) months of age, the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) plus the cost of rabies
inoculation and an adoption deposit in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) to cover the cost of
neutering or spaying.
(3) Cats, the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) plus the cost of rabies inoculation, if the cat is over four
(4) months of age, and an adoption deposit in the amount of forty dollars ($40.00) to cover the cost of
neutering or spaying. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord., § 1, 5-19-1975; Ord., § 2, 11-7-1977; Ord. 82-41, §
1(§ 2), 10-25-1982; Ord. 85-30, § 2, 8-26-1985; Ord. 87-34, §§ 10-12, 4-6-1987)
Sec. 7-162. Disposition Of Dogs Or Cats Not Claimed:
If any dog or cat impounded under the provisions of this article is not claimed within seven (7) days after
being impounded, the animal control officer may dispose of such animal in a humane way by approved
methods. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-163. Injured Animals:
The animal control officer shall remove from any street or public place within the city any injured animal
not being attended and properly cared for by the owner and shall, if he deems it necessary, impound and
confine such animal with some veterinarian within the city. If such veterinarian shall treat such animal, he
shall advise the animal control officer of the cost of such treatment and in the event such dog is claimed
as provided in this article, the person so claiming such animal shall also pay the charges of the
veterinarian. If such animal is not claimed, it shall be disposed of in the manner herein provided. (Ord., §
1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 4), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-164. Animals That Cannot Be Impounded:
If any dangerous, fierce or vicious dog or cat cannot safely be taken up and impounded, such dog or cat
may be slain by any sworn officer; provided, however, that in all cases where any dog or cat so slain has
bitten any person or caused an abrasion of the skin of such person, it shall be the duty of the officer
slaying such dog or cat to immediately deliver the carcass and the head of such dog or cat to the animal
control officer. (Ord., § 1, 12-3-1973; Ord. 82-41, § 1(§ 2), 10-25-1982)
Sec. 7-165. Animals Released To Animal Shelter For Disposal:
Any nonresident releasing an animal to the animal shelter for disposal shall pay a fee of five dollars
($5.00) per animal or ten dollars ($10.00) for a litter. (Ord. 87-34, § 14, 4-6-1987)
Sec. 7-166. Penalty:
Any person violating the provisions of this article which is not covered by a specific fee and/or fine listed
herein as a first offense shall be subject to a citation, which citation shall be paid at the police
department in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00); if paid within seven (7) days of the date issued
the amount shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). Any second and subsequent violation of this article shall be
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 171/735
subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord.
92-149, § 6, 12-21-1992)
DIVISION 4. URBAN CHICKENS
Sec. 7-167. Definitions:
Chicken: A member of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus, a domesticated fowl.
Chicken Tractor: A lightweight portable chicken coop without a floor that allows the chickens to forage for
weeds and insects.
Henhouse: A henhouse or chicken coop is a structure where female chickens are kept.
Permitted Tract Of Land: The tract of land as identified on the application upon which a permit is granted
for keeping chickens pursuant to this division.
Permittee: An applicant who has been granted a permit to raise, harbor, or keep chickens pursuant to
this division.
Permitting Officer: The city manager or designee.
Single-Family Dwelling: Any building that contains only one dwelling unit that is used, intended, rented,
leased, let or hired to be occupied for living purposes.
Tract Of Land: A lot that has one single-family dwelling located on that property or zoned lot.
Urban Chicken: A chicken kept on a permitted tract of land pursuant to a permit issued under this
chapter. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-168. Permit Required:
(a)Annual Permit Required: No person shall raise, harbor or keep chickens within the city of Rock Island
without a valid permit obtained from the permitting officer under the provisions of this division.
(b)Application: In order to obtain a permit, an applicant shall submit a completed application on forms
provided by the permitting officer, either online or in paper form, and pay all fees required by this
division.
(c)Requirements: The requirements to receive a permit include:
(1) All requirements of this division are met.
(2) All fees, as may be provided for from time to time by city council resolution, for the permit are paid
in full.
(3) All judgments in the city's favor and against the applicant have been paid in full.
(4) The tract of land to be permitted shall contain only one single-family dwelling occupied and used
as such by the permittee. Owner permission shall be required if the single-family dwelling is occupied
by a renter.
(5) The applicant has provided notice to the residents of all immediately adjacent dwellings, including
those across the street and/or alley, of the applicant's intent to obtain a permit.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 172/735
(6) The applicant has successfully completed an approved class in raising chickens in an urban
setting. A certificate, or other documentation, of completion shall be provided to the permitting officer.
The permitting officer shall maintain a current list of such approved classes.
(d)Issuance Of Permit: If the permitting officer concludes as a result of the information contained in the
application that the requirements for a permit have been met, then the officer shall issue the permit.
(e)Denial, Suspension, Revocation, Nonrenewal: The permitting officer may deny, suspend, revoke, or
decline to renew any permit issued for any of the following grounds:
(1) False statements on any application or other information or report required by this section to be
given by the applicant;
(2) Failure to pay any application, penalty, reinspection or reinstatement fee required by this section
or city council resolution;
(3) Failure to correct deficiencies noted in notices of violation in the time specified in the notice;
(4) Failure to comply with the provisions of an approved mitigation/remediation plan by the permitting
officer, or designee;
(5) Failure to comply with any provision of this division.
(f)Notification: A decision to revoke, suspend, deny, or not renew a permit shall be in writing, delivered
by ordinary mail or in person to the address indicated on the application. The notification shall specify
reasons for the action.
(g)Effect Of Denial Or Revocation: When an application for a permit is denied, or when a permit is
revoked, the applicant may not reapply for a new permit for a period of one year from the date of the
denial or revocation.
(h)Appeals: No permit may be denied, suspended, revoked, or not renewed without notice and an
opportunity to be heard is given the applicant or holder of the permit. In any instance where the
permitting officer has denied, revoked, suspended, or not renewed a permit, the applicant or holder
of an urban chicken permit may appeal the decision to the city council within ten (10) business days
of receipt by the applicant or holder of the permit of the notice of the decision. The applicant or holder
of the permit will be given an opportunity for a hearing. The decision of the permitting officer which is
not appealed in accordance to this division shall be deemed final action. All final administrative
decisions made under this article shall be subject to judicial review, pursuant to the provisions of the
"administrative review act", approved May 8, 1945, and all amendments and modifications thereof,
and the rules adopted pursuant thereto. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-169. Number And Type Of Chickens Allowed:
(a)The maximum number of chickens allowed shall be six (6) hens.
(b)Only female chickens (hens) are allowed. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-170. Zoning Districts Allowed:
Permits will be granted only for tracts of land located in the following residential districts: R-1, R-2, SE-1
and SE-2, as well as R-3, R-4, R-5 and R-6 with only one single-family dwelling. (Ord. 058-2016, 12-19-
2016)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 173/735
Sec. 7-171. Noncommercial Use Only:
A permit shall not allow the permittee to engage in chicken breeding or fertilizer production for
commercial purposes. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-172. Enclosures:
(a)Secure Enclosure: Chickens shall be kept in an enclosure or fenced area at all times. Chickens shall
be secured within a henhouse or chicken tractor during nondaylight hours.
(b)Sanitation: Enclosures shall be kept in a clean, dry, odor free, neat and sanitary condition at all times.
(c)Ventilation; Penetration: Henhouses shall provide adequate ventilation and adequate sun and shade
and shall be impermeable to rodents, wild birds and predators, including dogs and cats.
(d)Henhouses And Chicken Tractors:
(1) Henhouses shall be designed to provide safe and healthy living conditions for the chickens with a
minimum of four (4) square feet per bird while minimizing adverse impacts to other residents in the
neighborhood.
(2) A henhouse shall be enclosed on all sides and shall have a roof and doors. Access doors shall be
able to be shut and locked at night. Opening windows and vents shall be covered with predator and
bird proof wire of one inch (1") or smaller openings.
(3) The materials used in making a henhouse shall be uniform for each element of the structure such
that the walls are made of the same material, the roof has the same shingles or other covering, and
any windows or openings are constructed using the same materials. The use of scrap, waste board,
sheet metal, or similar materials is prohibited. Henhouses and chicken tractors shall be well
maintained.
(4) Henhouses shall only be located in the rear yard unless the setback requirements cannot be met
in which case they may be kept in a side yard but within the required setbacks.
(5) Henhouses and chicken tractors shall be located at least ten feet (10') from the property line and
at least twenty five feet (25') from any principal structure, and shall meet all other accessory structure
provisions of the zoning ordinance.
(Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-173. Odor And Noise Impacts:
(a)Odors from chickens, chicken manure or other chicken related substances shall not be perceptible to
persons of reasonable sensitivity beyond the boundaries of the permitted tract of land.
(b) Noise from chickens shall not be loud enough beyond the boundaries of the permitted tract of land at
the property boundaries to disturb persons of reasonable sensitivity. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-174. Predators, Rodents, Wild Birds, Insects And Parasites:
The permittee shall take necessary action to reduce the attraction of predators, rodents and wild birds
and the potential infestation of insects and parasites. Chickens found to be infested with insects and
parasites that may result in unhealthy conditions to human habitation may be removed by a Rock Island
animal control officer. (Ord. 014-2017, 4-10-2017)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 174/735
Sec. 7-175. Feed And Water:
Chickens shall be provided with access to feed and clean water at all times. The feed and water shall be
unavailable to rodents, wild birds and predators. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-176. Waste Storage And Removal:
All stored manure shall be covered by a fully enclosed structure with a roof or lid over the entire
structure. No more than three (3) cubic feet of manure shall be stored on the permitted tract of land. All
other manure not used for composting or fertilizing shall be removed. The henhouse, chicken tractor,
chicken pen and surrounding area shall be kept free from trash and accumulated droppings. Uneaten
feed shall be removed in a timely manner. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-177. Chickens At Large:
(a)The permittee shall not allow the permittee's chickens to roam off the permitted tract of land. No dog
or cat or other domesticated animal which kills a chicken off the permitted tract of land will, for that
reason alone, be considered a dangerous or aggressive animal or the city's responsibility to enforce
its animal control provisions. (Ord. 014-2017, 4-10-2017)
Sec. 7-178. Unlawful Acts:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to keep chickens in violation of any provision of this division or any
other provision of this code.
(b)It shall be unlawful for any owner, renter or leaseholder of property to allow chickens to be kept on the
property in violation of the provisions of this division.
(c)No person shall keep chickens inside a dwelling unit or any other structure other than an approved
henhouse or chicken tractor.
(d)No person shall slaughter any chickens within the city of Rock Island.
(e)No person shall keep a rooster.
(f)No person shall keep chickens on a vacant or uninhabited tract of land. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-179. Nuisances:
Any violation of the terms of this division that constitutes a health hazard or that interferes with the use
or enjoyment of neighboring property is a nuisance and may be abated under the general nuisance
abatement provisions of article IX of this chapter. (Ord. 043-2016, 10-24-2016)
Sec. 7-180. Reserved:
