ARTICLE VIII. REGULATION OF PIGEON LOFTS AND
CARRIER OR RACING PIGEONS
Sec. 7-221. Purpose And Definitions:
(a)Purpose: The purpose of this Article is to protect the health and safety of the community by regulating
and controlling the raising, keeping, and exercising of carrier and racing pigeons in order to prevent
disease and nuisance.
(b)Definitions:
(1) Carrier Pigeon: Homing and racing pigeons which have the name of the owner stamped upon the
wing or tail, or are banded upon the leg with the name or initials of the owner or with an identification
or registration number stamped on the band.
(2) Health Authority: The Chief Building Inspector or his designated representative of the City of Rock
Island.
(3) Loft: Any structure in which carrier, homing and racing pigeons are housed.
(4) Racing Pigeon: A pigeon registered with a national pigeon racing organization and used as a
game competitive bird. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-222. Permit:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect a loft or raise, keep, or exercise carrier and racing pigeons
without first obtaining a permit from the health authority in the manner prescribed in this Article. (Ord. 86-
47, 9-15-1986)
Sec. 7-223. Application:
The applicant shall file an application for such a permit with the Chief Building Inspector or his
designated representative on a form he shall prescribe. At this time, the applicant shall pay a filing fee of
twenty dollars ($20.00). The application shall include a statement in writing by the applicant and
adequate evidence showing that the construction and operation of the proposed loft will conform to the
standards set forth in Section 7-224 of this Article. The application shall also include the name of the
pigeon club or organization the birds are registered with, a contact person within the organization and a
phone number where this person can be reached. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986; Ord. 87-2, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-224. Standards:
No permit shall be issued by the health authority unless such authority shall find:
(1) That no odor related to the keeping of pigeons is to be present at the property line at any time.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 176/735
(2) That the droppings be handled in a sanitary manner within a closed container to prevent fly
breeding and odor.
(3) That the pigeons shall be controlled by their owner so that they will not constitute a nuisance to
neighboring property owners. A nuisance may, among other actions, be defined as the exercising of
pigeons at an unacceptable time of day.
(4) That all lofts constructed after passage of this Article shall be in no yard other than the rear yard;
nor shall it occupy more than thirty percent (30%) of a required rear yard. It shall not exceed fifteen
feet (15') in height and shall be distant at least three feet (3') from alley lines of adjoining lots and at
least six feet (6') from alley lines and any other building or structure on the same lot.
(5) That the construction of the structure meet all other City regulations, including but not limited to
Building Code regulations. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986)
Sec. 7-225. Conditions And Safeguards:
(a)Prior to the granting of such a permit, the health authority shall stipulate such standards as described
in Section 7-224 above.
(b)Said permit, when granted, shall be in full force and effect only as long as the owner of said loft
retains ownership at that particular location. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986)
Sec. 7-226. Authority And Inspection:
The Chief Building Inspector or his designated representative is hereby authorized and directed to
enforce all the provisions of this Article. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-227. Fees:
An annual license fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be charged. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986)
Sec. 7-228. Penalties:
(a)Finding Of Violation: Upon finding a violation of the provisions of this Article, or the conditions
specified by the health authority, the Chief Building Inspector or his designated representative shall
notify the owner of the pigeons and the club contact person as specified at the time of licensing. The
owner shall then have fourteen (14) days to remedy the violations. After this fourteen (14) day period,
the Chief Building Inspector or his designated representative shall reinspect the loft to determine if
violations still exist.
(b)Revocation Of Permit: If violations continue to exist past the fourteen (14) day period, the Chief
Building Inspector or his designated representative shall revoke any permit issued under the
provisions of this Article.
If a license is cited for violation of this Article three (3) times in a twelve (12) month period, said
license shall be permanently revoked.
(c)Civil Remedy: If said pigeon loft is not dismantled and pigeons removed from the premises upon
revocation of said permit, then action shall be brought by the City Attorney, his designee, or by
designated representative of the Community Services and Development Department. (Ord. 86-47, 9-
15-1986; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 177/735
Sec. 7-229. Appeals:
(a)Prior to the revocation of said permit on grounds of violation which do not constitute a nuisance to
neighboring property owners, including but not limited to subsection 7-224(4) and (5), the Chief
Building Inspector or his designated representative shall provide written notice to the permit holder
stating the reasons for which the permit is subject to revocation and advising that the permit shall be
permanently revoked at the end of five (5) days following service of such notice, unless a written
request for a hearing before the appropriate board is filed with the health authority by the permit
holder within such five (5) day period.
(b)Revocation of the permit shall occur prior to an appeal hearing if the violations constitute a nuisance
to neighboring property owners, including but not limited to subsection 7-224(1), (2), and (3).
(c)If revocation is a result of violations of subsection 7-224(4) of this Article, appeals will be made to the
Board of Zoning Appeals within five (5) days following service of a notice of revocation by the Chief
Building Inspector or his designated representative. (Ord. 86-47, 9-15-1986; 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 7-230. Applicability:
Owners of existing pigeon lofts as well as proposed lofts shall be subject to the provisions of this article.
Existing lofts shall be exempted from the requirement found in subsection 7-224(4) of this chapter. (Ord.
86-47, 9-15-1986)
ARTICLE IX. NUISANCES AND REFUSE
Sec. 7-231. Definitions:
See chapter 13, article II, "Solid Waste", of this code. (Ord. 96-40, 6-10-1996)
Sec. 7-232. General Conditions:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any refuse upon any street, alley, lane or public or
private property in the city.
(b)It shall be the responsibility of the owner of record to keep the property in compliance with this article.
(Ord. 96-40, 6-10-1996)
Sec. 7-233. Enforcement:
(a)In the event of a violation of any provision(s) of this article, the chief building inspector or his
designated representative shall issue a citation to the owner of the property in violation of the
provision(s) of this article either by regular mail or in person and shall give said owner a period of not
more than seven (7) days to correct the violation(s). In the event the said owner fails to correct the
violation(s) in the time given to correct same, the chief building inspector or his designated
representative shall issue a second citation for said violation(s).
(b)In addition to the foregoing, the chief building inspector or his designated representative shall notify
the director of public works of the violation of the provision(s) of this article, and the director of public
works may cause the removal of refuse and debris from the area which is in violation of the
provision(s) of this article and may collect a fee of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). This
cost shall be a lien upon the real estate affected superior to all subsequent liens and encumbrances
except tax liens if a notice of lien is filed in the office of the county recorder of deeds within seven (7)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 178/735
months of completion of removal activities by the city from the parcel setting forth a description of the
real estate involved, the amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred for the
services, and the date or times when such costs and expenses were incurred by the city.
(c)In addition, the city attorney is authorized and directed to initiate litigation in court to recover costs
incurred. (Ord. 96-40, 6-10-1996; Ord. 085-2014, 12-1-2014)
Sec. 7-234. Nuisances:
Within the territorial jurisdiction of the city it is hereby declared a nuisance for any person:
(1) Nuisances At Common Law: To cause any of those acts or omissions that are declared to be
nuisances by the state and such as are known as nuisances to the common law of the land, not
hereinafter specially enumerated.
(2) Premises To Be Kept Clean: To keep or suffer to be kept within the city limits in a foul, offensive,
nauseous, or filthy condition any building, lot, yard, premises or junkyard.
(3) Junk: To keep or suffer to be kept within the city limits in a foul, offensive, nauseous, filthy,
dilapidated or unsafe condition any vehicle, machinery, appliance or household item.
(4) Furniture: For the owner or keeper of any lot or premises to suffer to remain thereon, to the
annoyance and detriment of other persons outside the buildings located on the premises, any
furniture not designed for outdoor use.
(5) Garbage And Rubbish Storage And Pick Up Areas: It shall be the responsibility of the owner of
record to keep the garbage and rubbish storage and pick up areas on public rights of way (defined in
chapter 13 of this code) free from garbage and rubbish on the ground.
(6) Refuse Disposal: For the owner and/or tenant of any lot or premises to place or allow to be placed
any refuse container, yard waste or brush at the street, curb or alley on the public right of way pick up
site earlier than twelve o'clock (12:00) noon the day before pick up or to allow any refuse containers
to remain at the pick up site no later than twelve o'clock (12:00) noon the day after pick up.
(7) Brush: For the owner and/or tenant of any lot or premises to allow brush or brush in piles to
remain on the property longer than thirty (30) days of breaking or cutting.
(8) Animals: For the owner or keeper of any lot or premises to allow animal wastes to accumulate to
a point where odors are present at the property line or the presence of insects creates a health
hazard for surrounding properties. Animal wastes shall be handled as garbage.
(9) Unburied Animals: For the owner or possessor of an animal which may die within the city to leave
the same unburied less than twenty four inches (24") below ground or properly dispose of the
carcass therein for more than eight (8) hours after its death, or for any person to bring and leave the
carcass of any such animal within the city. In case the animal is not removed within the eight (8) hour
period after notification, the inspection division shall cause the removal of said animal and certify the
cost of such removal as a lien against the property. Notification shall consist of a posting on the
premises.
(10) Slaughter Of Animals: To kill or slaughter any animals within the city limits, to the injury,
discomfort or annoyance of any inhabitants of the neighborhood.
(11) Animal And Vermin Harborage: For the owner and/or tenant of any residential lot or premises to
allow any material such as lumber, boxes, barrels, scrap iron, construction material or any other
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 179/735
materials which would provide harborage for rats, mice, snakes or other vermin. Firewood must be
neatly stacked and elevated a minimum of four inches (4") above the ground.
(12) Vector Control: For the owner and/or tenant of any lot or residence to permit water to stand in
containers of any kind unless mosquito controls have been taken or allow animal or vermin
harborages under any garage, shed, porch, residential structure or other buildings on the premises
without taking necessary measures to destroy or capture the animals or vermin. Poisons may not be
used unless placed in areas not readily accessible to persons or domesticated animals. For single
user nonowner occupied lots or premises, the owner and/or occupant shall be responsible for the
extermination of any rodents, vermin or other pests of public health significance therein on the
premises. In multi-tenant lots or premises, the owner and/or tenant is responsible for extermination of
such pests.
(13) Offensive Matter In River: For the owner and/or tenant of any lot or property to allow or suffer to
allow any blood, bone, offal, and any other offensive matter to run, fall, or get into any storm drain,
drainage ditch or other watercourse which leads into the Mississippi River. (Ord. 96-40, 6-10-1996)
Sec. 7-235. Penalties:
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to the following penalties, to be paid in
the City Office of Collections:
(1) Upon detection of the first nuisance violation, the owner and/or tenant of the real estate shall be
issued a notice of the violation(s) and shall be issued a warning ticket. The owner of the property is
required to abate the violation(s) within seven (7) days of the date of the warning ticket.
(2) Upon detection of any second violation during any consecutive twelve (12) month period of the
issuance of the first nuisance violation, or for failure to abate the previous violation within a seven (7)
day period or appeal said alleged nuisance violation within said time, the owner of the real estate
shall be issued a notice of violation and shall pay a penalty of twenty five dollars ($25.00). In the
event the penalty is not paid in seven (7) days from the date of the notice, the owner of the real
estate shall pay as the penalty the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00).
(3) Upon detection of any third or subsequent violation during this consecutive twelve (12) month
period, the owner of the real estate shall be issued a notice of violation and shall pay a penalty of fifty
dollars ($50.00). In the event the penalty is not paid in seven (7) days from the date of the notice, the
owner of the real estate shall pay as the penalty the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(4) Failure of the person violating the provisions of this Article to pay the above listed penalties will
result in the Chief Building Inspector instructing the City Attorney to seek fines and other remedies in
court. Fines are to be a minimum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per occurrence and a maximum of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) per occurrence.
(5) An appeal of any alleged violation of this Article may be filed with the Community and Economic
Development Director in writing no later than seven (7) days from the date of the notice. Results of
this appeal will be sent in writing within seven (7) days of the receipt of the appeal. No further
penalties will be assessed during this appeal process. (Ord. 96-40, 6-10-1996)
Chapter 8
LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS 1, 2
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 180/735
Sec. 8-1. Licenses Subject To Ordinances:
All licenses which may at any time be issued under any ordinance of the City shall be subject to all
ordinances and regulations of the City which may be in force during the period of such license, or any
portion of such period, and shall also be subject to all laws of the State and conditioned upon their
faithful observance, and a violation of any of the provisions of said ordinances or laws by any licensed
person shall, in addition to the penalties which may be provided for such violation, subject him to a
revocation of his license. (1963 Code art. 6-1)
Sec. 8-2. How Issued; Terms:
All licenses which may be issued under any ordinance of the City, unless such ordinance shall otherwise
provide, shall be signed by the City Clerk under the Corporate Seal of the City, and shall specify the kind
of license. Fees shall be payable at the City Finance Department prior to May 1 of each year. The
licensing year shall begin on May 1 of each year and end on April 30 of the next succeeding calendar
year. All licenses shall expire on said April 30 in each calendar year. In the case of new businesses, new
license applications, or additional licenses for existing businesses only where the application for the
license is made after October 31 of any year, the fee for the license shall be one-half (1/2) of the stated
fee for the remainder of that license year only. (Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 8-3. Assignment; Surrender; New License; Bond:
(a)Except as provided in this section, licenses are not transferable.
(b)Any person to whom a license may have been issued under any ordinance of this City may, with the
permission of the Council, or other authorized City official, have the same transferred or surrender
such license and have the same cancelled and have a like license issued for the unexpired term of
the one so surrendered to the person or place of business to which he may wish to transfer the same
upon the licensee named in such new license giving bond (if bond is required in such case) and
complying with the ordinances and laws under which the license is issued. (1963 Code art. 6-1)
Sec. 8-4. Revocation By Mayor Or Council:
Any license granted under the provisions of an ordinance of the City may be revoked at any time, upon
written notice by the Council or other authorized City official, when it shall appear that the licensed party
has violated or failed to comply with any provision of any ordinance of the City or the laws of the State
applicable to the person, business occupation or place so licensed. (1963 Code art. 6-1)
Sec. 8-5. Register Of Licenses:
The City Clerk shall keep a record of all licenses issued; the date, term and kind of license, the amount
paid therefor and the name and place of business of the licensee. (1963 Code art. 6-1)
Sec. 8-6. Garage And Yard Sales 1 2:
Garage, yard and related sales are hereby authorized on residentially zoned property in the City only
upon compliance with the following conditions:
(1) The sale on the premises shall not exceed a seventy two (72) hour period.
(2) No residentially zoned premises in the City shall be used for the site of a sale more than twice in
any calendar year.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 181/735
(3) Property to be sold in said sale shall be limited to items of personal property owned by the
persons on whose premises the sale is being conducted.
(4) Any person authorized by this section shall be allowed to place a sign advertising same on his or
her premises or on other private property when authorized by the owner thereof during the time of
said sale and said sign shall be removed at the end of said sale period. No sign shall be placed or
permitted on a public right-of-way. (Ord., 10-13-1975; Ord., 11-3-1975; Ord., 11-10-1975; Ord. 87-34,
4-6-1987; Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord. 96-89, 11-11-1996)
Sec. 8-7. Sound-Amplifying Equipment 415 ILCS 5/24.3:
(a)Definitions: As used in this section:
Person: Any corporation, partnership or two (2) or more individuals having a joint or common interest.
Sound-Amplifying Equipment: Any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music
or any other sound. It shall not be construed as including sound-amplifying devices when used and
heard only by occupants of the vehicle or building in which located, or such devices when used for
authorized traffic-safety purposes.
(b)License - Required: No person either as principal or agent shall operate or cause to be operated any
sound-amplifying equipment, either stationary or mounted on vehicles, in the City, without a license
as provided in this section.
(c)License - Application: Any person, within the meaning of this section, desiring to use "soundamplifying
equipment", as herein defined, shall make, and file with the City Clerk, a written
application stating the applicant's name, residence, place of business, kind of business, the purpose
for which the sound-amplifying equipment shall be used, the proposed hours of operation, the
number of days of the proposed operation, a general description of said equipment and the
maximum sound-producing power of the equipment, including the following:
(1) The wattage to be used.
(2) The volume in decibels of sound which will be produced.
(3) The approximate maximum distance from which sound will be thrown from the equipment.
(d)License - Fee; Issuance: The applicant shall, at the time, pay to the City Collector as a license fee
twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each day or part of a day for each unit. Such license shall be issued
by the City Clerk.
(e)Regulations For Use: The use of sound-amplifying equipment and its operation shall be subject to the
following regulations:
(1) The only sounds permitted are music and the human voice.
(2) Operation is permitted between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
each day except on Sundays and legal holidays, when no operation shall be authorized.
(3) Sound shall not be emitted within one hundred (100) yards of hospitals, schools, churches or
courthouses.
(4) The human speech and music amplified shall not be profane, slanderous or obscene as defined
in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 182/735
(5) The volume of sound shall be controlled so that it will not be audible for a distance in excess of
one hundred feet (100') from the sound amplifying equipment, and so that said volume is not
unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within the area of audibility.
(1963 Code art. 6-2(Q); Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991)
Sec. 8-8. Gasoline Filling Stations 820 ILCS 205/7.1:
Any person operating a filling station for the sale of gasoline or other motor fuel in the City and any
person to whom a license to operate such filling station shall be hereafter granted shall pay to the City
Finance Department an annual fee. The fee for said license shall be forty five dollars ($45.00) for each
nozzle, whether in use or not, located at said filling station, payable in accordance with section 8-2 of
this chapter. (Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 8-9. Going Out Of Business Sales:
(a)State Law: All persons holding going out of business sales shall comply with 815 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 350/1 through 350/12, which provides for the licensing and regulation of said sales as
defined therein.
(b)Inspection: In addition to the regulations and requirements set forth in said State Statute, any person
conducting a sale defined in said Act shall comply with the inspection requirements as set forth in this
section. The Mayor shall, upon the filing of an application for a sale, appoint an inspector or
inspectors, not to exceed three (3) in number, accordingly as the requirements of the situation seem
to demand, said inspector or inspectors to be residents of the City and who may be City officials or
employees or otherwise, whose duty it shall be to inspect and investigate the inventory submitted
with the application for license, and the stock of goods or merchandise offered for sale thereunder,
and who shall either singly, or as a body, as directed by the Mayor, attend the sale held under the
license when issued, and report to the Mayor whether any goods not listed in the inventory had been
offered for sale, and whether the other requirements of this section are being complied with. The
Mayor shall require that the articles enumerated in said inventory be numbered in sequence and that
tags, corresponding to the numbers so shown in the inventory, be placed on each article when
offered for sale and accompany the article when sold. Such inspector or inspectors attending any
sale shall have with them a copy or copies of the inventory as originally furnished with the application
and shall check or compare the articles offered for sale with the inventory. For the purpose of such
inspection said inspector or inspectors shall have access to the place where such sale is to be held
at any time prior to the opening of any such sale. Such inspector or inspectors shall not receive any
compensation for duties performed hereunder prior to the opening of any such sale, but shall each
be compensated at the rate determined by the City Council for attendance at any sale held under any
license granted hereunder. Provided, however, that no City employee attending any such sale
hereunder shall be entitled to or receive any extra compensation above his regular salary or wage.
Any person holding a sale within the meaning of this section shall deposit with the City Collector prior
to the issuance of a license as aforesaid, a cash deposit in an amount to be determined by the
Mayor, not to exceed one-half of one percent of the cost inventory of the goods to be sold, to
guarantee payment to the City of a sum equal to the cost of inspection as above defined. (1963 Code
art. 6-2(P))
Sec. 8-10. Sale Of Merchandise On Street, Etc.:
No person shall place or allow to be placed on public sidewalks or public ways, any merchandise or
goods for the purpose of advertising or selling same without prior approval of the City Council. (Ord., 6-
23-1975)

ARTICLE II. ALARM BUSINESSES, SYSTEMS AND USERS 1
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-26. Title:
This article shall be known and may be cited as the ROCK ISLAND CITY ORDINANCE REGULATING
BURGLAR AND HOLDUP ALARM BUSINESSES, SYSTEMS, AND USERS. (Ord., 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-27. Definitions:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the
meaning given herein:
Alarm Agent: Any person who is employed by an alarm business, either directly or indirectly, whose
duties include selling, maintaining, leasing, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing
on or in any building, structure or facility, any alarm system. Exemption: The provisions of this article do
not apply to a person who engages in the manufacture or sale of an alarm system from a fixed location
and who neither visits the location where the alarm system is to be installed, nor designs the scheme for
physical location and installation of the alarm system in a specific location.
Alarm Business: The business by any individual, partnership or corporation or other entity of selling,
leasing, maintaining, inspecting, servicing, repairing, moving or installing any alarm system in or on any
building, structure or facility. Exemption: Said definition shall not apply to persons engaged solely in the
manufacture or sale of alarm system components from a fixed location, and who do not install, alter,
maintain, service or plan the alarm system for a specific location.
Alarm System: Any mechanical or electrical device which is designed or used for the detection of an
unauthorized entry into a building, structure or facility or for alerting others of the commission of an
unlawful act within a building, structure or facility, or both; and which emits a sound or transmits a signal
or message when actuated and to which police are expected to respond. In this article, the term "alarm
system" shall include the terms "audible alarm", "automatic dialing device", "burglar alarm system" and
"holdup alarm system" as those terms are hereinafter defined.
Answering Service: A telephone answering business providing among its services receiving, on a
continuous basis through trained employees, emergency signals from alarm systems, and thereafter
immediately relaying the message by live voice over a signal channel circuit to the communication
center of the Police Department.
Appellant: A person who perfects an appeal pursuant to this article.
Applicant: A person, firm or corporation that files an application for a new or renewal permit as provided
in this article.
Audible Alarm: A device designed for the detection of unauthorized entry on premises which generates
an audible sound on the premises when it is actuated. This audible alarm may or may not be combined
with a method of transmitting a signal to a remote point. Exemption: The provisions of this article are not
applicable to audible alarms affixed to motor vehicles.
Automatic Dialing Device: An alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by
direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of
the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 184/735
Burglar Alarm System: A method of detecting and signaling the presence, entry or attempted entry of an
intruder into protected premises.
Central Station System: A system or group of systems, usually operated from its customers by a person,
in which the operations of protected circuits and devices are transmitted to, recorded in, maintained and
supervised from a central station having trained operators and guards in attendance at all times, that
have the duty to take appropriate action upon receipt of a signal or message including the relaying of
messages by a signal channel circuit to the communications center of the police department.
City: The city of Rock Island or its authorized employees or agents.
Direct Alarm System: An alarm system which has the capability of transmitting signals to and receiving
them at the communications center of the Rock Island police department.
False Alarm: The intentional or unintentional activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure,
malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his
employees or agents which necessitates response by the Rock Island police department where an
attempted or actual burglary or holdup does not exist. Such terminology does not include, for example,
alarms caused by tornadoes, earthquakes or other violent conditions.
Holdup Alarm System: An alarm system signaling a robbery or attempted robbery.
Modified Central Station: An office to which remote alarm and supervisory signaling devices are
connected, where operators supervise the circuits and relay the messages by a "signal channel circuit"
to the communications center of the police department.
Police Chief: The chief of the police department of the city of Rock Island, or his authorized
representative.
Primary Trunk Line: A telephone line leading into the communications center of the police department,
that is for the purpose of handling emergency calls on a person to person basis, and which line is
identified by a specific listing among the emergency numbers in a telephone directory issued by the
telephone company serving the city.
Protected Premises: That part of a building, structure or facility to which protection is afforded by an
alarm system.
Signal Channel Circuit: A telephone service that only provides a two-way telephone service from one
location to another location. In the police station, it will be used to report emergency signals from an
"answering service", a "central station" or from a "modified central station" to the police communication
center on a person to person basis.
Subscriber: A person who buys and/or leases, or otherwise obtains an alarm signaling system and
thereafter contracts with or hires an alarm business to monitor and/or service the alarm device. (Ord., §
3(A-V), 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-28. Penalty:
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this article shall be one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of this article and does not wish to contest said
allegations prior to the time a complaint is issued for said violation, the person accused may pay to the
city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for and in full
satisfaction of said violation. (Ord. 005-2011, 2-7-2011)
Sec. 8-29. Purpose:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 185/735
The purpose of this article is to provide minimum standards and regulations applicable to burglar and
holdup alarm systems, alarm businesses, alarm agents and alarm users; require permits therefor;
establish fees; and provide for punishment of violations of provisions as defined in this article. (Ord., § 2,
10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-30. Standards And Regulations Prescribed By Police Chief:
The police chief may prescribe reasonable minimum standards and regulations for the construction and
maintenance of all alarm systems installed within the city. All devices shall meet or exceed such
standards and regulations before permits may be issued pursuant to this article. The police chief may
require inspection and approval of all alarm systems installed within the city. (Ord., § 4, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-31. Audible Alarms:
All alarm systems that emit an audible signal that may be heard by persons outside the protected
building, structure or facility shall conform to the following requirements:
(1) Every person maintaining an audible alarm shall provide the police chief with the names and
telephone numbers of the persons to be notified to render repairs or service and secure the premises
during any hour of the day or night that the alarm system is activated. It is the responsibility of every
person maintaining an alarm system to assure that the names and telephone numbers recorded with
the police department are kept current.
(2) No person shall install an audible alarm system which creates a sound similar to that of an
emergency vehicle siren or a civil defense warning system.
(3) No person shall install an audible alarm system which does not automatically discontinue emitting
an audible sound within one-half (1/2) hour after it is activated. (Ord., § 5, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-32. Prohibited Systems:
(a)Automatic Dialing Devices: No alarm system using an automatic dialing device will be allowed to send
a prerecorded voice message or coded signal over a primary trunk line or direct line into the
communications center of the police department.
(b)Panic Alarm: Panic or trouble alarms used to signal any type of fight, disturbance or any other activity
other than an actual or attempted burglary or holdup will not be allowed. (Ord., § 6, 10-2-1978; Ord.
82-23, § 1, 8-9-1982)
Sec. 8-33. Automatic Dialing Device; Intermediary Services:
(a)Persons owning or leasing an automatic dialing device may have the device interconnected to a
telephone line transmitting directly to:
(1) A central station;
(2) A modified central station; or
(3) A licensed answering service.
(b)The relaying of messages by intermediate services to the police department shall be over a signal
channel circuit on a person to person basis.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 186/735
(c)The police chief may limit the number of "signal channel circuits" that come into the communications
center of the police department. (Ord., § 7, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-34. Police Alarms:
No alarm system equipment, unless police owned and operated, shall transmit any message on the
police base radio frequency. (Ord., § 8, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-35. Responsibility For Alarm Response:
Every person who has on his premises under his control or ownership an alarm system, audible or
silent, shall, upon notification that the alarm system is giving a signal, proceed within twenty (20) minutes
to the premises and render all necessary services. Provided, however, that the owner of the premises
may enter into an agreement with an alarm business to respond in his stead. Failure to respond to an
activated alarm shall be considered a violation of this provision and shall result in a penalty of fifty dollars
($50.00) ($25.00 if paid within 30 days). (Ord., § 24, 10-2-1978; Ord. 91-17, § 1, 2-18-1991; Ord. 91-74,
§ 1, 6-17-1991; Ord. 93-65, § 1, 6-14-1993)
Sec. 8-36. Service Available:
Each alarm business shall have licensed alarm agents and supplies and equipment so located as to be
able to respond to a request for repair or adjustment on any alarm system that such an alarm business
sold, maintained, or inspected within four (4) hours of the request for this service. They shall respond
within four (4) hours of the request, except that if the request occurs within the hours that protected
premises is open for business or otherwise substantially occupied, repair or adjustment may be made at
any time prior to closing of the protected premises. (Ord., § 25, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-37. Liability Of City:
The city shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm signals received by the city are
given appropriate attention and are acted upon with dispatch. Nevertheless, the city shall not be liable
for any defects in operation of any alarm devices or signal lines system, for any failure or neglect to
respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from such a source, nor for the failure or neglect of any
person with a permit issued pursuant to this article, in connection with the installation and operation of
equipment, the transmission of alarm signals or the delaying of such signals. In the event the city finds it
necessary to disconnect a defective automatic protective device or signaling device, the city shall incur
no liability by such action. (Ord., § 27, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-38. Conflict Of Interest:
No employee of the police department nor member of any such employee's immediate family shall have
any interest, directly or indirectly, in any alarm business within the limits of the city. No such employee or
member of his immediate family shall be employed by an alarm business, subject to the provisions of
this article. (Ord., § 28, 10-2-1978)
Secs. 8-39-8-50. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. PERMIT
Sec. 8-51. Generally:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 187/735
(a)Alarm System Permit: No person shall possess or use an alarm system without first applying for and
receiving an alarm system permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article. The permit
shall be kept on the premises where the alarm system is located. The police chief may issue an
appropriate identification number and establish requirements for its posting.
(b)Alarm Business Permit: No person shall engage in, conduct or carry on an alarm business without
first applying for and receiving an alarm business permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of
this article. This includes a central station, modified central station and an answering service. The
permit shall be kept on the premises where the business is located. The police chief may issue an
appropriate identification number and establish requirements for its posting.
(c)Agent Permit: No person shall engage in, conduct or operate as an alarm agent without first applying
for and receiving an alarm agent permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article.
(1) Every person engaged in the business of repairing, servicing, altering, replacing, removing,
designing, selling, leasing, maintaining or installing alarm systems shall carry on his person at all
times while so engaged a valid alarm agent permit and shall display the permit to any police officer
upon request.
(2) It shall be a violation of this article for the applicant to wilfully fail to return an identification card to
the issuing agency or business upon termination of his employment with an alarm business. It shall
also be a violation of this article for the alarm business to fail to return to the police chief an
identification card issued by the police chief upon termination of the employment of the alarm agent.
(d)Direct Alarm System Permit: No direct alarm system shall be permitted within the police department
except such as is connected to an indicator panel installed in uniform consoles with uniform
operation within the communication facilities of such department pursuant to a permit issued in
accordance with the provisions of this article.
(1) An owner or lessee of an alarm system may authorize an alarm business or alarm agent to
connect such system to an indicator panel installed in the communication facilities of the police
department in accordance with this article, upon first obtaining a permit therefor.
(2) If the location of the communication facilities of the police department shall be changed at any
time, the cost of moving any alarm system or parts thereof shall be borne by permittees.
(3) The police chief may limit the number of such permits and may set standards and regulations
governing direct alarm systems. (Ord., § 9, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-52. Application-Form:
Applications for all permits required under this article shall be on a form prescribed by the chief of police
and may request such information as is necessary to evaluate and act upon the permit application.
Applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable requisite fee. The fee is established to cover part
of the cost of investigating and processing the applications and permits. (Ord., § 10, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-53. Application-Investigation; Denial:
(a)Alarm Business; Alarm Agent: Every application for an alarm business or alarm agent permit shall
require a picture and fingerprints of the applicant. The police chief shall conduct an appropriate
investigation of the applicant to determine whether the permit shall be issued. The police chief may
require additional information of applicants which he deems necessary to conduct his investigation.
The permit shall be denied by the chief of police if:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 188/735
(1) The character or reputation of the applicant is determined to be inimical to the safety or general
welfare of the community;
(2) The applicant for the alarm business permit or alarm agent does not comply with the standards
and regulations adopted pursuant to this article;
(3) The applicant, his employee or agent has knowingly made any false, misleading or fraudulent
statement of a material fact in the application for a permit; or
(4) The applicant has had a similar type permit previously revoked for good cause within the past
year unless the applicant can show a material change in circumstances since the date of revocation.
(b)Alarm Systems; Direct Alarm Systems: The permit shall be denied by the police chief if the alarm
system does not comply with the standards and regulations adopted pursuant to this article. The
permit shall be issued to the person owning, using or possessing the alarm system. If the permit is
denied, the reasons for denial shall be set forth in writing and provided to the applicant. If the basis
for denial can be corrected, the writing shall so state and shall explain how these corrections may be
made and set a reasonable time limit for making such corrections. The notice of denial shall inform
the applicant that he may appeal the denial and set forth the procedure for appeal. (Ord., § 15, 10-2-
1978)
Sec. 8-54. Application-Notice Of Information Change:
Whenever any change occurs relating to the written information requested by this article, the applicant or
permittee shall give written notice thereof to the services division of the police department within fifteen
(15) days after such change or at any hearing conducted under this article if such hearing is conducted
before the notice has been given. (Ord., § 11, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-55. Fees:
(a)Permit fees under this article shall be paid to the city collector. Said fees are as follows:
(1) For an alarm system permit, sixty dollars ($60.00).
(2) For an alarm business, central station, modified central station or telephone answering system
permit, one hundred dollars ($100.00) annual fee payable in advance of July 1 of each year.
(b)The city reserves the right to own all indicator panels and accessory equipment for direct alarm
systems located within the station. In such case, each permittee, in addition to the annual permit fee,
shall pay an initial installation fee and an annual user fee, as the same may be established by
ordinance, and uniformly applied to cover the cost of the maintenance of such facilities. In the event
the city decides not to own the equipment within the station, but to provide for its installation and
maintenance by a third party, it shall establish and regulate reasonable fees and charges which may
be charged permittees. All such fees provided for in subsection (a)(1) of this section to be charged by
the city shall be payable on the date of installation and shall cover the system until the resident or
occupant changes.
(c)Regardless of the status of an alarm permit, the members of the police department will always
respond as promptly and effectively as possible to any and all alarm actuations. However, there will
be a service charge for each false alarm that the police department responds to while the alarm
permit is under suspension or revocation. A fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) will be assessed for
each false burglary alarm and a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) will be assessed for each false
holdup alarm that the police department responds to during this period. This service charge will be
deposited into the city's general citizens' fund. This service charge will not exempt the permit holder
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 189/735
from the violation penalty adopted pursuant to this article. (Ord., §§ 12, 16, 10-2-1978; Ord. 82-23, §
2, 8-9-1982; Ord. 87-34, §§ 8, 9, 4-6-1987; Ord. 91-17, §§ 2, 3, 2-18-1991; Ord. 91-74, §§ 2, 3, 6-17-
1991; Ord. 35-2003, § 1, 4-28-2003; Ord. 012-2009, § 1, 2-2-2009)
Sec. 8-56. Failure To Pay Ad Valorem Taxes:
No permit shall be issued or renewed pursuant to this article if any ad valorem taxes upon any real
property or personal property used directly or indirectly in connection with the proposed business or
service are delinquent. A receipt of payment of ad valorem taxes shall be provided for inspection to the
city clerk at the time of issue or renewal of a permit. Where a permit has been issued and ad valorem
taxes on such property thereafter become delinquent, the permit shall be subject to cancellation
immediately without notice and without right of appeal. (Ord., § 26, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-57. Issuance:
Upon approval by the chief of police of applications for a permit or for renewal thereof, the chief shall
endorse his approval thereon and transmit the application to the city clerk, who shall be responsible for
the issuance of such permit or renewal thereof. (Ord., § 14, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-58. Suspension Or Revocation-Violation Of Article:
Any permit issued under this article may be suspended by the police chief for violation of any of the
provisions of this article. (Ord., §§ 16, 17, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-59. Suspension Or Revocation-Additional Grounds:
The following shall constitute grounds for suspension and/or revocation of a permit issued under this
article:
(1) Where an alarm system is knowingly activated by a subscriber, his employee or agent in a
situation where no burglary or robbery is actually in progress;
(2) Where the permittee, his employee or agent has knowingly made any false, misleading or
fraudulent statement of material fact in the application for a permit or in any report or record required
to be filed with any city agency;
(3) Where any alarm business permittee or alarm agent is charged with a crime involving moral
turpitude or where the character, reputation or moral integrity of the permit holder or his employee is
determined inimical to public safety or the general welfare of the community;
(4) Where the permittee has had a similar type permit previously revoked for good cause within the
past year, unless the applicant can show a material change in circumstances since the date of
revocation; or
(5) Where an alarm system, while under a valid permit, actuates excessive false alarms, it shall
constitute a public nuisance. There shall be no penalty for the first two (2) false alarms by the system
in any one calendar year. Thereafter, there shall be a penalty for the third false alarm violation in said
year in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) each or seventy five dollars ($75.00) if paid
within thirty (30) days of the issuance of the citation. For any additional false alarms in said year,
there shall be a penalty of two hundred dollars ($200.00) each or one hundred dollars ($100.00) if
paid within thirty (30) days of the issuance of the citation. (Ord., § 16, 10-2-1978; Ord. 91-17, § 5, 2-
18-1991; Ord. 91-74, § 5, 6-17-1991; Ord. 93-102, § 1, 11-15-1993; Ord. 67-00, § 1, 9-11-2000; Ord.
01-2003, § 1, 1-6-2003)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 190/735
Sec. 8-60. Suspension Or Revocation-Procedure:
(a)The police chief, in the case of suspension, shall serve the permittee with a written order of
suspension which shall state the reasons for such suspension. The order shall be effective
immediately if personally served, or forty eight (48) hours after the same has been deposited in the
course of transmission in the United States postal service. Immediately upon such an order
becoming effective, the permittee shall discontinue the use of any alarm system requiring a permit
under this article and cease all operations conducted under the authority of any permit issued
pursuant to this article.
(b)The suspension shall become a revocation fifteen (15) days after the order of suspension becomes
effective unless the permittee files an appeal of the order of suspension in the manner set forth in this
article. Where an appeal is filed, the order of suspension shall be stayed, pending a final
determination of the appeal. The suspension shall become a revocation if the decision of the city
manager upholds the suspension, unless said decision is overruled by the city council. The
suspension shall be dissolved immediately if the decision of the city manager reverses the
suspension. (Ord., §§ 18, 19, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-61. Appeal Procedure:
(a)The permittee shall have a period of ten (10) days after the issuance of a ticket in order to present to
the chief of police or his designee as to the circumstances surrounding the incident which the
permittee considers to be beyond the control of the permittee or its alarm agent. The chief shall have
the authority to dismiss the ticket upon good cause shown.
(b)Failure to file a letter of appeal within the said fifteen (15) days shall constitute a waiver of appellant's
right to review, but the city manager, in his discretion, may nevertheless grant such review.
(c)If the city manager affirms the decision of the chief of police, the appellant may have a hearing before
the city council on said matter. If the city manager does not approve the decision of the chief, he shall
transmit this decision to the chief, who will comply with same. (Ord., §§ 21-23, 10-2-1978; Ord. 91-
17, § 6, 2-18-1991; Ord. 91-74, § 6, 6-17-1991)
Sec. 8-62. Surrender Of Permit:
If any permit is revoked pursuant to this article, the permittee shall surrender the permit to the services
division of the police department. (Ord., § 20, 10-2-1978)
Sec. 8-63. Renewal:
(a)Alarm business permits and alarm agent permits issued pursuant to this article shall expire annually
on June 30. All applications for renewal of such permits shall be filed with the chief of police on forms
provided for that purpose. The fee for renewal of each permit required hereunder shall be the same
as the initial permit fee and shall be paid to the city collector prior to the time the permit is issued.
(b)Alarm system permits need not be renewed. Any modifications of or additions to an alarm system will
require a new permit and may require an inspection as determined by the chief. (Ord., § 13, 10-2-
1978; Ord. 91-17, § 4, 2-18-1991; Ord. 91-74, § 4, 6-17-1991)
DIVISION 3. FIRE ALARM BUSINESSES, SYSTEMS, AND USERS
Sec. 8-64. Title:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 191/735
This division shall be known and may be cited as the ROCK ISLAND CITY ORDINANCE REGULATING
FIRE ALARM BUSINESSES, SYSTEMS, AND USERS . (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-65. Definitions:
Alarm Agent: Any person who is employed by an alarm business, either directly or indirectly, whose
duties include selling, maintaining, leasing, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing
on or in any building, structure or facility, any alarm system. Exemption: The provisions of this division do
not apply to a person who engages in the manufacture or sale of an alarm system from a fixed location
and who neither visits the location where the alarm system is to be installed, nor designs the scheme for
physical location and installation of the alarm system in a specific location.
Alarm Business: The business by any individual, partnership or corporation or other entity of selling,
leasing, maintaining, inspecting, servicing, repairing, moving or installing any alarm system in or on any
building, structure or facility. Exemption: Said definition shall not apply to persons engaged solely in the
manufacture or sale of alarm system components from a fixed location, and who do not install, alter,
maintain, service or plan the alarm system for a specific location.
Alarm System: Any mechanic or electrical device which is designed or used for the detection of fire or its
byproducts in a building, structure or facility or for alerting others of a fire hazard within a building,
structure or facility, or both; and which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when actuated
and to which the fire department personnel are expected to respond. In this division, the term "alarm
system" shall include the terms "audible alarm", "automatic dialing device" and "fire alarm system" as
those terms are hereinafter defined. Exemption: The provisions of this division shall not apply to those
detection devices and systems that are not monitored by an alarm business.
Answering Service: A telephone answering business providing among its services receiving, on a
continuous basis through trained employees, emergency signals from alarm systems, and thereafter
immediately relaying the message by live voice over a signal channel circuit to the communications
center of the police and fire departments.
Appellant: A person who perfects an appeal pursuant to this division.
Audible Alarm: A device designed for the detection of fire or its byproducts on premises, which
generates an audible sound on the premises when it is actuated. This audible alarm may or may not be
combined with a method of transmitting a signal to a remote point. Exemption: The provisions of this
division are not applicable to audible alarms affixed to motor vehicles.
Automatic Dialing Device: An alarm system, which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by
direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of
the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect.
Central Station System: A system or group of systems, usually operated from its customers by a person,
in which the operations of protected circuits and devices are transmitted to, recorded in, maintained and
supervised from a central station having trained operators and guards in attendance at all times, that
have the duty to take appropriate action upon receipt of a signal or message including the relaying of
messages by a signal channel circuit to the communications center of the police and fire departments.
City: The city of Rock Island or its authorized employees or agents.
False Alarm: The intentional or unintentional activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure,
malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his
employees or agents which necessitates response by the Rock Island fire department where an actual
fire or emergency does not exist. Such terminology does not include, for example, alarms caused by
tornadoes, earthquakes or other violent conditions.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 192/735
Fire Chief: The chief of the fire department of the city of Rock Island, or his authorized representative.
Modified Central Station: An office to which remote alarm and supervisory signaling devices are
connected, where operators supervise the circuits and relay the message by a "signal channel circuit" to
the communications center of the police and fire departments.
Nuisance Alarm: An alarm caused by mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or lack of
proper maintenance.
Primary Trunk Line: A telephone line leading into the communications center of the police and fire
departments, that is for the purpose of handling emergency calls on a person to person basis, and which
line is identified by a specific listing among the emergency numbers in a telephone directory issued by
the telephone company serving the city.
Protected Premises: That part of a building, structure or facility to which protection is afforded by an
alarm system.
Signal Channel Circuit: A telephone service that only provides a two-way telephone service from one
location to another location.
Subscriber: A person who buys and/or leases, or otherwise obtains an alarm signaling system and
thereafter contracts with or hires an alarm business to monitor and/or service the alarm device. (Ord. 37-
2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-66. Penalty:
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this division, unless otherwise provided, shall be fifty
dollars ($50.00). In the event a person is issued a notice of a violation of this division and does not wish
to contest said allegations prior to the time a complaint is issued for said violation, the person accused
may pay to the city finance office a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for and in full satisfaction
of said violation. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-67. Purpose:
The purpose of this division is to provide minimum standards and regulations applicable to fire alarm
systems, alarm businesses, alarm agents and alarm users and to provide for punishment of violations of
the provisions of this division. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-68. Standards And Regulations Enforced By Fire Chief:
The fire chief shall enforce reasonable minimum standards and regulations for the construction and
maintenance of all fire alarm systems installed within the city as provided in NFPA 72 (the national fire
alarm code handbook). All devices shall meet or exceed such standards, regulations and adopted codes
before their operation is allowed within the city. The fire chief may require inspection and approval of all
alarm systems installed within the city. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-69. Audible Alarms:
All alarm systems that emit an audible signal that may be heard by persons outside the protected
building, structure or facility shall conform to the following requirements:
(1) Every person maintaining an audible alarm shall provide the fire chief with the names and
telephone numbers of the persons to be notified to render repairs or service and secure the premises
during any hour of the day or night that the alarm system is activated. It is the responsibility of every
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 193/735
person maintaining an alarm system to assure that the names and telephone numbers recorded with
the fire department are kept current.
(2) No person shall install an audible alarm system, which creates a sound similar to that of an
emergency vehicle siren or a civil defense warning system. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-70. Prohibited Systems:
(a)Automatic Dialing Devices: No alarm system using an automatic dialing device will be allowed to send
a prerecorded voice message or coded signal over a primary trunk line or direct line into the
communications center of the police and fire departments.
(b)Panic Alarm: Panic or trouble alarms used to signal the need for help, medical assistance or any
other activity other than an actual fire will be allowed. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-71. Automatic Dialing Device; Intermediary Services:
(a)Persons owning or leasing an automatic dialing device may have the device interconnected to a
telephone line transmitting directly to:
(1) A central station;
(2) A modified central station; or
(3) A licensed answering service.
(b)The relaying of messages by intermediate services to the fire department shall be over a signal
channel circuit to the communications center of the police and fire departments on a person to
person basis.
(c)The police and fire chiefs may limit the number of "signal channel circuits" that come into the
communications center of the police and fire departments. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-72. Fire Alarms:
No alarm system equipment, unless city owned and operated, shall transmit any message on the fire
base radio frequency. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-73. Responsibility For Alarm Response:
Every person who has on his premises under his control or ownership an alarm system, audible or
silent, shall, upon notification that the alarm system is giving a signal, proceed within twenty (20) minutes
to the premises and render all necessary services, provided, however, that the owner of the premises
may enter into an agreement with an alarm business to respond in his stead.
(1) Failure to respond to notification of an activated alarm shall be considered a violation of this
provision and shall result in a penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00).
(2) The members of the fire department shall respond as promptly as possible to any and all alarm
actuations. However, there will be a service charge for excessive false alarms or nuisance alarms to
which the fire department is required to respond. There shall be no penalty for the first false alarm by
the system in any one fiscal year. Thereafter there shall be a penalty for each false alarm in said
fiscal year in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 194/735
Sec. 8-74. Service Available:
Each alarm business shall have licensed alarm agents and supplies and equipment so located as to be
able to respond to a request for repair or adjustment on any alarm system that such an alarm business
sold, maintained, or inspected within four (4) hours of the request for this service. They shall respond
within four (4) hours of the request, except that if the request occurs within the hours that the protected
premises is open for business or otherwise substantially occupied, repair or adjustment may be made at
any time prior to closing of the protected premises. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-75. Permits:
There shall be no permit required of any alarm businesses, alarm agents or subscribers for the purposes
of this division. The provisions of this division shall not affect the provisions of any other article within the
code of ordinances of the city of Rock Island and the required permitting as called for under any other
provisions contained therein. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-76. Notice Of Information Change:
Whenever any change occurs relating to the written information requested by this division, the
subscriber shall give written notice thereof to the fire prevention division of the fire department within
fifteen (15) days after such change or at any hearing conducted under this division if such hearing is
conducted before the notice has been given. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Sec. 8-77. Appeals Procedure:
(a)The appellant shall have a period of ten (10) days after the issuance of a complaint for violation in
order to present to the chief of the fire department or his designee as to the circumstances
surrounding the incident, which the appellant considers to be beyond the control of the system user
or its alarm agent. The chief shall have the authority to dismiss the complaint of violation upon good
cause shown.
(b)Failure to file a letter of appeal within the said fifteen (15) days shall constitute a waiver of appellant's
right to review, but the city manager, in his discretion, may nevertheless grant such review.
(c)If the city manager affirms the decision of the chief of the fire department, the appellant may have a
hearing before the code hearing division (see section 4-148 of this code) on said matter. If the city
manager does not approve the decision of the chief, he shall transmit this decision to the chief, who
will comply with same. (Ord. 37-2002, § 1, 4-22-2002)
Secs. 8-78-8-80. Reserved:

It shall be unlawful for any person to own, conduct, manage or exhibit for gain, within the City, any
circus, carnival, theater, game or amusement machine where money is charged directly or indirectly for
admission to see, hear or operate the same, unless a license for the same shall have first been obtained
from the City. Provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any public entertainment
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 195/735
given, the proceeds of which are for the benefit of any religious, charitable or educational institution
located in the City. (1963 Code art. 6-2(A); Ord. 16-2000, 3-13-2000)
Sec. 8-82. Issuance:
A license under this division may be issued by the City Clerk upon application and the payment to the
City Finance Department of such sum as the Council may fix in each case, except where the amount of
the license fee is specifically designated herein. (1963 Code art. 6-2(A); Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 8-83. Scope; Duration; Maintenance Of Order:
Every license issued under this division shall specify the object and length of time for which it is issued.
It shall be the duty of the person licensed to keep good order about his place of entertainment. (1963
Code art. 6-2(A))
Sec. 8-84. Circuses, Carnivals, Etc.:
(a)For each circus, carnival or like exhibition, the license fee shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per
day.
(b)Proprietors of theaters in the City may be licensed for one year, upon the payment to the City Finance
Department as follows:
(1) is less than 500 Where the seating capacity $25.00
(2) is 500 to 1,000 Where the seating capacity 50.00
(3) is over 1,000 Where the seating capacity 75.00
(1963 Code art. 6-2(A); Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord. 92-47, 3-23-1992; Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 8-85. Automatic Musical Instrument:
(Rep. by Ord. 16-2000, 3-13-2000)
Sec. 8-86. Youth Dance License:
(a)Definition; License Required: No person, firm or corporation, either as owner, lessee, manager, officer
or agent, shall operate or permit to be operated on any premises, including any enclosed or
unenclosed structure, and the surrounding premises used for parking or any activity used for the
dancing operation in the City for a dance club where an admission is charged and where any of the
participants are under the age of twenty one (21) without first obtaining a license for use of said
premises for said purposes. Only patrons twenty (20) years of age or younger are allowed on all
premises during operating hours unless they are employees of said club, or a parent or legal
guardian of a patron. Nonprofit organizations shall be excluded upon proof of tax exemption.
(b)Application: To obtain a youth dance license, the applicant shall file an application with the City Clerk
upon a form provided by said Clerk, which shall contain, among other information, a petition signed
by a majority of the property owners, representing at least a majority of the frontage within three
hundred feet (300') in each direction of the proposed location on both sides of the street on which the
proposed location shall front, signifying their willingness to have a license issued hereunder;
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 196/735
providing that in any case if the property owners of at least forty feet (40') of the property immediately
adjacent to or abutting on any side of the proposed location shall not appear as signers on said
petition, no license shall be issued hereunder. The approval requirement of property owners and/or
abutting owners can be waived under the procedure set forth in subsection (j) of this section.
(c)Investigation: The City Clerk upon receipt of such application shall:
(1) Cause the Police Department to investigate all the statements contained in each application to
determine if the matters and things therein are true.
(2) Cause the City's building inspectors, health inspectors and Fire Department to inspect the
proposed licensed premises to determine that said premises comply with all City codes and are safe
for occupancy as a dance club.
(3) If upon investigation the City Clerk shall be satisfied that the matters and things therein contained
in said application are true, and that the applicant has complied with all the requirements thereof, and
that the premises to be licensed has complied with all City codes and is safe for occupancy, she shall
approve the same and upon receipt by the City Collector of the required license fee, issue a license
in accordance with the provisions herein.
(d)Fee: An annual license fee for such license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00), which shall be
paid to the City Clerk. No license issued herein shall be transferable or refunded.
(e)Term Of License: Youth dance licenses shall be in effect for a term of one year and issued on May 1
of each year, expiring April 30 of the next year. Prior to the reissuance of a license for an ensuing
year, the requirements of investigation as set forth in subsection (c) of this section shall again be
complied with by said licensee.
(f)Display Of License: Any person receiving a youth dance license under the provisions of this section
shall display said license prominently in the licensed premises.
(g)Enforcement: The licensee or agent shall permit any police officer or other official of the City free and
unrestricted access to the licensed premises for the purposes of inspecting the same.
(h)Violations And Penalties: The Chief of Police may suspend, or revoke any youth dance license
granted hereunder if, the operation of the licensed premises is found to be detrimental to the health
or safety of the neighborhood, or if the licensee has been found to be guilty of the violation of any
City ordinance or State law in the operation of the licensed premises. In addition thereto the Chief of
Police may in lieu of a suspension or revocation, impose a fine of up to one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500.00) for any violation of this section or the laws of the State of Illinois.
In addition to all other requirements for operation of a youth dance club contained herein, no licensee
hereunder shall allow any loitering, gathering of unruly individuals or crowds, or any unlawful or
dangerous behavior whether inside of the premises or in any parking lot or other adjacent areas
serving the premises; and the licensee shall have the primary responsibility of hiring adequate
numbers of supervisory personnel as identified in subsection (m) of this section, and taking other
appropriate measures to observe compliance with this subsection. In the event of a violation of the
law has taken place, the licensee or his agents shall immediately notify the Police Department.
(i)Appeal: Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Police Chief to suspend, fine or revoke a license
under this article shall have the right of appeal. An appeal must be filed within fifteen (15) days after
notice of revocation by filing with the city manager a letter of appeal briefly stating therein the basis
for the appeal. Failure to file a letter of appeal within the said fifteen (15) days shall constitute a
waiver of appellant's right to review, but the city manager, in his discretion, may nevertheless grant
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 197/735
such review. If the city manager does not approve the decision of the chief, he shall transmit his
decision to the chief, who will comply with same.
(j)Waiver Of Approval Of Signature Requirement: The city council may waive the approval requirements
relating to property owners and/or adjacent owners set forth in subsection (b) of this section after
holding a public hearing concerning said matter at the request of an applicant for a youth dance
license. In the event the city council determines that it is in the best interest of the city that said
waiver be granted then, in that event, the city council shall take official action thereon and refer said
matter to the city clerk, who then may issue said license if all other requirements for the issuance of
said license have been complied with.
(k)Procedure For Waiver Of Approval: Any person that wants a waiver of approval shall submit an
appeal in writing to the city clerk who will determine the date of the public hearing in conjunction with
the city council. After said date is determined, the following procedure shall be followed:
(1) A letter will be mailed to all adjacent property owners whose signatures would normally be
required for the approval of a youth dance license application and said letter shall contain the name
of the person appealing the decision, the date of the public hearing, and instructions for the recipients
to file written objections, if any, and/or attend the public hearing in person. These letters will be
signed and mailed by the city clerk who will also be the designated person to receive any written
responses relating to the appeal process.
(2) The notice of appeal letters described above shall be deposited in the U.S. mail at least two (2)
weeks prior to the public hearing date and a copy of said letter shall be furnished to the applicant.
(3) The city clerk shall provide the city council with a list of persons to whom the letters are
addressed, along with a copy of the form letter which was mailed to said persons. The clerk shall
also provide a copy of the written appeal and information concerning the youth dance license
requested and the result of compliance efforts made by the applicant to obtain the required property
owner's signature as set forth in this section. The city clerk, upon receipt of written objection(s) to
appeal, if any are received, shall furnish copies of said written objection(s) to the city council, the
applicant, and the Rock Island police department.
(4) The public hearing, on an appeal, will be held during a regular city council meeting using the
same procedures at said meeting as followed by other public hearings held in said council.
(5) At the completion of the public hearing, the city council will then consider a motion as to whether
or not to make a recommendation to the city clerk to waive the signature requirement of subsection
(b) of this section.
(l)Hours Of Operation: All premises licensed under the provisions of this section shall be closed between
the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. each day. It shall be the obligation of
the owner or operator of said youth dance facility to clear all patrons from the premises fifteen (15)
minutes after closing.
(m)Supervision: It shall be the obligation of the owner, lessee, manager, officer or agent of said youth
dance facility offering a dance to minors under the age of twenty one (21) to provide one person
twenty five (25) years or older per each twenty (20) patrons to ensure proper supervision of said
premises. The person or persons provided for supervision shall not be inclusive of anyone employed
to dispense food, beverages, or other operational duties. All adults who will be on site in the capacity
of security or supervisory personnel shall wear clothing which identifies them as security or
supervisory personnel. The owners shall also provide to the city clerk the names and addresses of
any managers who will be on the premises during the club's hours of operation.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 198/735
(n)Curfew: The owner, lessee, manager, officer or agent of any youth dance facility shall cause any
minor patrons to be removed from said premises one-half (1/2) hour prior to curfew hours regulated
by state law. For the purposes of this section, "curfew" shall be defined as: "It is unlawful for a person
less than seventeen (17) years of age to be present at or upon any public assembly, building, place,
street, or highway at the following times unless accompanied and supervised by a parent, legal
guardian, or other responsible companion at least twenty-one (21) years of age approved by a parent
or legal guardian, or unless engaged in a business or occupation which the laws of this state
authorize a person less than seventeen (17) years of age to perform: (1) Between 12:01 A.M. and
6:00 A.M., Saturday. (2) Between 12:01 A.M. and 6:00 A.M., Sunday. (3) Between 11:00 P.M. on
Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and 6:00 A.M. on the following day". It is unlawful for a parent, legal
guardian or other person to knowingly permit a person in his custody or control to violate this section.
(o)Insurance: All owners of a licensed youth dance club shall be required to carry liability insurance with
limits of liability in an amount of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). The city of Rock
Island, Illinois, must be named as an additional insured under said policy and identified on the
owners' certificate of insurance. Proof of insurance under these conditions is a prerequisite for the
issuance or renewal of any youth dance club license. (Ord. 084-2010, 12-20-2010)
Secs. 8-87-8-95. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. GAMES 1
Sec. 8-96. License-Required:
No person shall, within the corporate limits of the city, keep for public use or let for hire, gain or profit any
coin operated amusement or game machine, including, but not limited to, pool table, dart game, video
game, kiddie ride, video gaming terminal, without a license issued by the city as set forth in this division.
