(Ord. 004-2010, § 1, 1-18-2010)
Sec. 8-97. License - Duration; Fee:
(a)A license for each game or device set forth in section 8-96 of this division may be granted for the term
of the license year in which the same is granted or any unexpired portion thereof upon payment by
the licensee to the City Clerk for the use of the City the following license fees: for each coin operated
amusement or game machine, sixty five dollars ($65.00) and for each video gaming terminal, two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). No license shall be issued for less than one year, and in no case shall
any portion of the license fee be repaid to the licensee. The license issued hereunder shall be posted
in a conspicuous place in the establishment for which it is issued.
(1) Fine; Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of these sections shall be subject to a fine in
the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) upon the first violation within the license year. Upon each
subsequent violation within the same license year, a fine of seventy five dollars ($75.00) will be
imposed. For any noncompliance incurred within the license year, a penalty of ten dollars ($10.00)
per day will be imposed beginning June 1 of the license year until such time as licensee has
complied with these provisions.
(2) Payment Of Penalty: In the event a person is accused of a first violation within the license year
and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation,
then the person so accused may, within seven (7) days of the notice of violation, pay to the City at
police headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for and in full satisfaction of the
violation.
(b)The annual license fee for bowling alleys shall be as follows:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 199/735
1 - 25 lanes $250.00
26 - 50 lanes 500.00
51 or more lanes 750.00
(c)No license for any video gaming terminal shall be issued to any applicant until and unless the
applicant provides information to the satisfaction of the Liquor Commissioner demonstrating that the
applicant's proceeds from video gaming machines are secondary to the applicant's combined
proceeds from alcohol and food sales for the location at which the applicant is making application for
a video gaming license or video gaming licenses. The final determination on whether the applicant
has satisfied this requirement rests with the Liquor Commissioner. This subsection shall only apply to
new gaming licenses issued after the effective date hereof. It shall not affect any licensed
establishments seeking to renew gaming licenses which were acquired prior to the date hereof.
No more than twenty one (21) total licenses for video gaming establishments including licenses in
existence at the time of passage of this section shall be in existence at any time. Once twenty one
(21) active licenses are in existence, no new licenses shall be issued unless and until the number of
licenses falls below twenty one (21). (Ord. 070-2018, 12-10-2018)
Sec. 8-98. Pool Halls:
(a)Definition; License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or manage a pool hall in
the city without having first secured a license to do so from said city. A "pool hall" for the purposes of
this section, shall be defined as any place or establishment that has on its premises for public use, or
let for hire, one or more pool tables, billiard tables or bank pool tables. Any person who has a liquor
license in the city may have two (2) such tables on its premises without complying with the
requirements of this section.
(b)Application: To obtain a pool hall license, the applicant shall file an application therefor with the city
clerk upon a form provided by said clerk. Said application form shall contain, among other
information, a statement of whether or not the property owners within two hundred feet (200') of the
front door of the proposed location of the pool hall in either direction and on both sides of the street,
object to the pool hall. The city clerk, upon receipt of a properly completed application, shall refer
same to the city council for determination of the issuance of said license.
(c)Fee: An annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged for a pool hall license.
(d)Term Of License: Pool hall licenses shall be in effect for a term of one year and issued on May 1 of
each year.
(e)Display Of License: Any person receiving a pool hall license under the provisions of this section shall
display said license prominently in the licensed premises.
(f)Revocation Of License: The city council may revoke any pool hall license granted hereunder if, after a
hearing before said council, the operation of the licensed premises is found to be detrimental to the
health or safety of the neighborhood, or if the licensee has been found to be guilty of the violation of
any city ordinance or state law in the operation of the licensed premises.
(g)Hours Of Operation: All premises licensed under the provisions of this section shall be closed
between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. each day. Liquor licensees
are exempt from this provision based on their individual license option. (1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(H);
Ord., § 1, 6-2-1980; Ord. 91-14, § 10, 2-11-1991; Ord. 16-2000, §§ 5, 6, 3-13-2000)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 200/735
Sec. 8-99. Video Games:
(Rep. by Ord. 16-2000, § 8, 3-13-2000)
Secs. 8-100 - 8-110. Reserved:
ARTICLE IV. AUCTIONEERS 1
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-111. Definitions:
As used in this article:
Auctioneer : Includes any person, firm, association or corporation that shall engage in the conducting
of auction sales or crying off property at auction (except those who act by virtue of legal process).
The term "auctioneer" includes those who conduct an auction sale or cry off their own property at
auction, as well as those who conduct a sale of, or cry off, the property of others.
Legal Process : Any writ, process or order of any kind issued out of any court.
Property : Includes personal property of every kind but not real property, except where a different
meaning is specified.
Selling At Auction : All sales of property within the city of Rock Island by public outcry to the highest
bidder, as well as to the public offer of property at a price beyond its value, then lowering the price, or
increasing the number of articles till someone accepts the property offered as a purchase. (1963
Code, ch. VI, art. II(B))
Sec. 8-112. Penalties:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this article, or shall in any particular wilfully fail or refuse to
comply with any of its terms, conditions or requirements, where no fine is otherwise particularly provided
for herein, shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00).
(1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(B))
Sec. 8-113. Excluded Sales:
The provisions of this article shall not extend to any officer or person executing any process or order of
any court in this state, selling any property or effects directed by law to be sold at public vendue, auction
or outcry; nor shall this article apply to property or effects of any deceased person when sold by order of
the executor or administrator of such person; nor to the property and effects of any bankrupt or insolvent
debtor when sold by order of any court of competent jurisdiction; nor to apply or in any way affect regular
merchants of the city in the sale of any goods, wares or merchandise in their stores, by retail, wholesale
or in any other manner, except by auction; nor to apply or in any way to affect the sale of household
furniture at the dwelling of the owner, or real estate sold on the premises; nor to any sale had by virtue of
any bona fide mortgage or chattel mortgage. (1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(B))
Sec. 8-114. Hours Of Sale:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 201/735
No auctioneer shall sell or offer for sale any goods, wares or merchandise between the hours of five
o'clock (5:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. on weekdays, and no selling at auction is permitted at
any time on Sundays; provided that the mayor and city council upon evidence that the peace and quiet
of the neighborhood will not be disturbed may allow auction sales between the hours of five o'clock
(5:00) P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on weekdays, and for certain designated hours on Sundays.
(1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(B); Ord., § 2, 4-10-1972; Ord., § 1, 6-25-1973)
Sec. 8-115. Substitution Of Sale Articles:
Any auctioneer who shall exhibit and offer for sale any article, and induce its purchase by any bidder,
and who shall afterwards substitute any article in lieu of that offered to and purchased by the bidder,
shall forfeit his license and be liable to a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than fifty
dollars ($50.00). (1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(B))
Sec. 8-116. False Bids:
No person shall act as a bidder or what is commonly known as a "capper", "booster" or "shiller" at any
auction or place regulated by this article, or offer or make any false bid to buy or pretend to buy any
article sold or offered for sale at any auction. (1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(B))
Sec. 8-117. Fraudulent presentations.
Any auctioneer or person being present when any article of property is offered for sale, who shall
knowingly, with intent to induce any person or persons to purchase the same or any part thereof, make
any false representation or statement as to the ownership of, or the character or quality of the article or
articles so offered for sale, or as to the poverty or circumstances of the owner or pretended owner of
such article or articles, shall, on conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than ten dollars
($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00); and if such false representation is made by such
auctioneer, or by any other person with such auctioneer's knowledge and consent or connivance, the
license of such auctioneer shall be forfeited.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 17)
Sec. 8-118. Advertising.
No bellman or crier, nor any drum or fife or other instrument of music, nor any show signal, or means of
attracting the attention of the public, other than a sign or flag, shall be employed or suffered or permitted
to be used in connection with any auction sale at or near any place of such sale or at or near any auction
room.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 19)
Sec. 8-119. Sale book.
At every auction sale within the city there shall be kept a sale book in which each purchaser shall
immediately after making a purchase sign his true name and address, opposite which the auctioneer
shall write the name of the article purchased as the same appears upon said tag and the sale price
thereof, and said article shall be delivered to said purchaser with said tag intact and attached thereto.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 20)
Secs. 8-120--8-130. Reserved.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 202/735
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 8-131. Exceptions.
Sections 8-134--8-138 shall not apply to an auction or livestock, used household furniture, used farm
machinery or used cars.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 22)
Sec. 8-132. Required.
It shall be unlawful for any person to exercise the business or trade of an auctioneer, or sell or offer for
sale by way of public vendue, auction or outcry, within the city, any goods, wares, merchandise or other
effects whatsoever, without first having obtained a license and executed a bond to the city, as provided
in this division.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 2)
State law reference--Authority of city to license auctioneers, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-42-1.
Sec. 8-133. Application--Generally.
An application for a license under this article shall be verified, stating the name of the applicant; his
residence; the street and number of the proposed place of sale; the length of time for which the license
is desired and the date to begin; whether the applicant has been previously engaged in a like or similar
business; and the name of the owner or owners of the merchandise to be auctioned.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 3)
Sec. 8-134. Same--Inventory.
The application shall be accompanied by a full and complete inventory of the stock or merchandise to be
sold. Three (3) copies of such inventory shall be so furnished. The articles enumerated in said inventory
shall be numbered, and tags corresponding to the numbers so shown in the inventory shall be placed on
each article when offered for sale. No additional stock or merchandise (other than so inventoried) shall
be offered for sale or auctioned at any auction held under any license granted upon such application.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 4)
Sec. 8-135. Same--Filing.
The application and inventory required in this division shall be filed with the city clerk, by whom any
license to be issued hereunder shall be authorized in accordance with section 8-140, at least fifteen (15)
days prior to the granting of the license. (Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 5)
Sec. 8-136. Appointment of inspectors.
The mayor may, upon the ding of an application under this division, appoint an inspector or inspectors,
not to exceed three (3) in number, accordingly as the requirements of the situation seem to demand,
said inspector or inspectors to be residents of the city and who may be city officials or employees or
otherwise, whose duty it shall be to inspect and investigate said inventory submitted with said application
as aforesaid, and the stock of goods or merchandise offered for sale thereunder, and who shall either
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 203/735
singly or as a body, as directed by the mayor, attend the auction sales held under the license when
issued, and report to the mayor whether any goods not listed in the inventory had been offered for sale,
and whether the other requirements of this article are being complied with. Such inspector or inspectors
attending any auction sale shall have with them a copy or copies of the inventory as originally furnished
with the application, and shall check or compare each article as offered for sale with the inventory. For
the purpose of such inspection said inspector or inspectors shall have access to the place where such
sale is to be held at any time prior to the opening of any such sale. Such inspector or inspectors shall not
receive any compensation for duties performed hereunder prior to the opening of any such sale, but
shall each be compensated at a rate determined from time to time by the city council for attendance at
any sale held under any license granted hereunder. Provided, however, that no city employee attending
any such sale hereunder shall be entitled to or receive any extra compensation above his regular salary
or wage.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 6)
Sec. 8-137. Sale of uninventoried goods.
Any licensee under this article who offers for sale at any auction sale any goods or merchandise not
included in the inventory filed with the application for the license for such sale, shall upon conviction
thereof be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) or more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for every
such offence. Upon such conviction, the mayor shall immediately declare the license forfeited, and no
further sales shall be held thereunder. No refund shall be made to any licensee on account of any
license paid in advance upon any such conviction and forfeiture of the license. No appeal taken from any
conviction hereunder shall stay any such forfeiture so declared pending the final determination of such
appeal.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 7)
Sec. 8-138. Period of ownership.
No merchandise shall be sold by any auctioneer licensed under this article, which has not been the
property of said auctioneer for a period of at least thirty (30) days and which has not been stored or kept
at the location at which the auction is to be held, as set out in the application, for a similar period of thirty
(30) days next preceding the filing of said application, or if the property to be sold is owned by a person
other than the auctioneer, said property must have been owned by said person for a similar period of
time next preceding the filing of said application for auctioneer's license.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 8)
Sec. 8-139. Bond.
No person shall receive a license to sell goods at auction in the city until he shall first have executed to
the city a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with corporate surety approved by
the city clerk, conditioned for the strict observance of all ordinances of the city respecting auctions and
auctioneers and for the indemnification of any purchaser at such public auction who suffers any loss by
reason of misrepresentation at such auction. The above-mentioned bond shall be kept in full force and
effect during the period for which the license is granted, and shall in addition thereto be kept in full force
and effect for thirty (30) days after the expiration date of such license.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 10)
Sec. 8-140. Fee.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 204/735
Any person may become an auctioneer and be licensed to sell personal property at public auction in this
city upon complying with the provisions of this division relating to the filing of an inventory and bond in
the time and manner herein prescribed, and the payment to the city collector of the sum of fifteen dollars
($15.00) for each day said license is in force, or the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a
yearly license.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 11; Ord. of 2-23-76, § 1)
Sec. 8-141. Transfer.
No license issued under the provisions of this article shall be transferable or be held to authorize any
person other than the one named therein to sell or cry goods at auction. In no case shall any license be
issued to cover more than one place of business or to authorize auction sales at any place of business
other than the one set out in the application for license. The license shall in all cases be posted in a
conspicuous place where the sale is to be held.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(B), § 12; Ord. of 4-10-72, § 1)
Secs. 8-142--8-155. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. BENCHES
Sec. 8-156. Installation.
It shall be lawful for any person to install or maintain public benches upon public property for the
accommodation of any person or persons awaiting transportation and to place advertising matters and
signs thereon.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(C), § 1)
Sec. 8-157. Size.
No bench, as provided for in this article, shall be more than forty-two (42) inches high nor more than
thirty (30) inches wide, nor more than seven (7) feet long. No bench shall carry any advertising or sign
containing any pictures or words that would be deemed obscene under Ill. Rev. Stat. Chapter 38, section
11-20, and only such advertising matter shall be placed thereon as is ordinarily displayed by other
advertising media. No advertisement or sign on any such bench shall mislead or distract traffic.
Advertising shall be displayed only on the front and rear surfaces of the backrest of said benches. All
benches shall be kept in a safe and sightly condition and shall be inspected periodically by the owner
thereof. All of such benches shall be installed in a location approved by the city council.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(C), § 4)
Sec. 8-158. License--Required.
No bench or benches shall be installed or maintained under this article without the consent of the city
council therefor. Application for the installation and maintenance of such bench or benches shall give the
name of the applicant, the location where the proposed bench or benches will be installed and such
other information as said city council shall require. All such applications shall be referred to the chief
building inspector and the director of public works for investigation, and they shall report to the city
council their recommendation of such applications.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 205/735
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(C), § 2)
Sec. 8-159. Same--Fee.
The annual license fee for the installation of each bench under this article shall be five dollars ($5.00),
payable to the city collector on May 1 of each year. Any license issued for such bench for a term of six
(6) months or less shall be two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50). All such licenses are issued subject to and
with the express agreement of the licensees that any or all of such licenses may be summarily revoked
by the city council in its sole discretion.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(C), § 6)
Sec. 8-160. Bond.
Every applicant under this article, when the license for the installation of a bench or benches shall be
issued, shall file with the city clerk a public liability bond, with suitable sureties thereon, to save and keep
harmless the city from any and all damages of any kind or nature through the installation and
maintenance of said bench or benches. The amount of such bond for death, personal injury or property
damage shall be determined by said city council.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(C), § 3)
Sec. 8-161. Removal.
The city council reserves the right to order the removal of any benches, in its sole discretion, at any time
when the interests of the public are best served by the removal of same. If any such bench is ordered
removed by said city council, no remission of the license fees for the unexpired portion of the license
year shall be made.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(C), § 5)
Secs. 8-162--8-175. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEMS 1
Sec. 8-176. Definitions.
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, abbreviations and their derivations
shall have the meaning given in this section:
CATV: A "community antenna television system" as hereinafter defined.
City: The City of Rock Island, a municipal corporation of the State of Illinois, in its present incorporated
form or in any later reorganized, consolidated, enlarged or reincorporated form.
Community antenna television system: A system of antennas, coaxial cables, wires, wave guides or
other conductors, equipment or facilities designed, constructed or used for the purpose of providing
television or frequency-modulation radio service by cable or through its facilities as contemplated in this
article. CATV shall not mean or include the transmission of any special program or event for which a
separate and distinct charge is made to the subscriber in the manner commonly known and referred to
as "pay television."
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 206/735
Council: The present governing body of the city or any future board constituting the legislative body of
the city.
Grantee: The person, firm or corporation to whom or which a franchise, as described in this article, is
granted by the council under this article, and the lawful successor, transferee or assignee of said person,
firm or corporation.
Gross annual receipts: Any and all compensation and other consideration in any form whatever and any
contributing grant or subsidy received directly or indirectly by a grantee from subscribers or users in
payment for television or frequency-modulation radio signals or service received within the city, and also
shall include any other revenues received by a grantee from the sale of advertising or any other source.
"Gross annual receipts" shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the grantee imposed
directly on any subscriber or user by any city, state or other governmental unit and collected by the
grantee for such governmental unit.
Street: The surface of and the space above and below any public street, road, highway, freeway, lane,
path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway or drive, now or hereafter existing as such within the city.
Subscriber: Any person or entity receiving for any purpose the CATV service of a grantee. (Ord. of 9-28-
70, § 1(a--h))
State law reference--"Community antenna television system" defined, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-42-11.
Sec. 8-177. Franchise to operate.
A nonexclusive franchise to construct, operate and maintain a CATV system within all or any portion of
the city may be granted by the council to any person, whether operating under an existing franchise or
not, who offers to furnish and provide such system under and pursuant to the terms and provisions of
this article.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-178. Uses permitted by grantee.
(a)Any franchise granted pursuant to the provisions of this article shall authorize and permit the grantee
to engage in the business of operating and providing a CATV system in the city, and for that purpose
to erect, install, construct, repair, replace, reconstruct, maintain and retain in, on, over, under, upon,
across and along any public street, such poles, wires, cable, conductors, ducts, conduit, vaults,
manholes, amplifiers, appliances, attachments and other property as may be necessary and
appurtenant to the CATV system; and in addition, so to use, operate and provide similar facilities or
properties rented or leased from other persons, including but not limited to any public utility or other
grantee franchised or permitted to do business in the City. Any franchise granted pursuant to the
provisions of this article shall prohibit the grantee thereof from selling, leasing or servicing of
television receivers within the corporate limits of the City.
(b)The grantee may make a charge to subscribers for installation or connection to its CATV system and
a fixed monthly charge as filed and approved as herein provided. No increase in the rates and
charges to subscribers, as set forth in the schedule filed and approved with grantee's application,
may be made without the prior approval of the Council expressed by resolution. (Ord., 9-28-1970)
Sec. 8-179. Duration Of Franchise:
No franchise granted by the Council under this article shall be for a term longer than ten (10) years
following the date of acceptance of such franchise by the grantee or the renewal thereof. Any such
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 207/735
franchise granted hereunder may be terminated prior to its date of expiration by the Council in the event
that said Council shall have found, after thirty (30) days' notice of any proposed termination and public
hearing, that:
(1) The grantee has failed to comply with any provision of this article or has, by act or omission,
violated any term or condition of any franchise or permit issued hereunder;
(2) Any provision of this article has become invalid or unenforceable and the Council further finds that
such provision constitutes a consideration material to the grant of said franchise; or
(3) The City acquires the CATV system property of the grantee. (Ord., 9-28-1970)
Sec. 8-180. Acceptance Fee:
The grantee shall, upon the acceptance of this franchise, pay to the City, in consideration of the granting
of this franchise, the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). (Ord., 9-28-1970)
Sec. 8-181. Franchise Payments:
(a)MCC Illinois LLC shall pay an annual service provider fee to the City in an amount equal to five
percent (5%) of the annual gross revenues derived from the provision of cable or video service to
households located within the City. The 12-month period for the computation of the service provider
fee shall be a calendar year.
(b)The service provider fee payment shall be due quarterly and payable within forty five (45) days after
the close of the quarter. Each payment shall be accompanied by a brief report prepared by a
representative of the grantee showing the basis for the computation. If mailed, the fee shall be
considered paid on the date it is postmarked.
(c)For purposes of the calculation of the service provider fee, "gross revenues" shall mean consideration
of any kind of nature including, without limitation, cash, credits, property, and in-kind contributions
received by MCC Illinois LLC for the operation of its cable system to provide cable or video service
within the City, including the following: 1) recurring charges for cable service or video service; 2)
event-based charges for cable service or video service, including but not limited to, pay-per-view and
video-on-demand charges; 3) rental of set-top boxes and other cable service or video service
equipment; 4) service charges related to the provision of cable service or video service, including but
not limited to, activation, installation, and repair charges; 5) administrative charges related to the
provision of cable service or video service, including but not limited to service order and service
termination charges; and 6) late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds check charges, and
other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent payments; 7) a pro rata portion
of all revenue derived by the holder of its affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for
advertising or for promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation of
the holder's network to provide cable service or video service within the local unit of government's
jurisdiction. The location shall be based on the number of subscribers in relation to the relevant
regional or national compensation arrangement; 8) compensation received by the holder that is
derived from the operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service with
respect to commissions that are received by the holder as compensation for promotion or exhibition
of any products or services on the holder's network, such as a "home shopping" or similar channel,
subject to item 9 of this subsection; 9) in the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled
or integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the portion of the holder's
revenue attributable to the other services, capabilities, or applications shall be included in gross
revenue unless the holder can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from its
books and records that are kept in the regular course of business; 10) the service provider fee
permitted by 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b).
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 208/735
(d)For purposes of the calculation of the service provider fee, "gross revenues" shall not include: 1)
revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt, subject to item 6 of subsection (c) of
this section; 2) refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the amount of gross
revenues received by the holder of the State-issued authorization to the extent the refund, rebate,
credit, or discount is attributable to cable service or video service; 3) regardless of whether the
services are bundled, packaged, or functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any
revenues received from services not classified as cable service or video service, including, without
limitation, revenue received from telecommunications services, information services, or the provision
of directory or internet advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and
electronic publishing, or any other revenues attributed by the holder to noncable service or non-video
service in accordance with the holder's books and records and records kept in the regular course of
business and any applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards, or orders; 4) the sale of cable
services or video services for resale in which the purchaser is required to collect the service provider
fee from the purchaser's subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that it will resell
the service within the local unit of government's jurisdiction and pay the fee permitted under 220
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b) with respect to the service; 5) any tax or fee of general
applicability imposed upon the subscribers or the transaction by a city, state, Federal, or any other
governmental entity and collected by the holder of the state-issued authorization and required to be
remitted to the taxing entity, including Sales and Use Taxes; 6) security deposits collected from
subscribers; 7) amounts paid by subscribers to "home shopping" or similar vendors for merchandise
sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the cable service or video service. (Ord.
020-2018, 5-14-2018)
Sec. 8-182. Limitations Of Franchise:
(a)Nonexclusive: Any franchise granted under this article shall be nonexclusive.
(b)Privileges Specified: No privilege or exemption shall be granted or conferred by any franchise granted
under this article except those specifically prescribed herein.
(c)Prior Occupancy Of Street, Etc.: Any privilege claimed under any such franchise by the grantee in any
street or other public property shall be subordinate to any prior lawful occupancy of the streets or
other public property.
(d)Transfer: Any such franchise shall be a privilege to be held in personal trust by the original grantee,
and cannot in any event be sold, transferred, leased, assigned or disposed of, in whole or in part,
either by forced or involuntary sale, or by voluntary sale, merger, consolidation or otherwise, without
the prior consent of the Council expressed by resolution, and then only under such conditions as may
therein be prescribed.
Any such transfer or assignment shall be made only by an instrument in writing, a duly executed
copy of which shall be filed in the Office of the City Clerk within thirty (30) days after any such
transfer or assignment. The said consent of the Council may not be arbitrarily refused; provided,
however, the proposed assignee must show financial responsibility and must agree to comply with all
provisions of this article; and provided further, that no such consent shall be required for a transfer in
trust, mortgage or other hypothecation as a whole, to secure an indebtedness.
(e)Promptness: Time shall be of the essence of any such franchise granted hereunder. The grantee
shall not be relieved of his obligation to comply promptly with any of the provisions of this article by
any failure of the City to enforce prompt compliance.
(f)Functions Of City: Any right or power in, or duty impressed upon, any officer, employee, department or
board of the City shall be subject to transfer by the City to any other officer, employee, department or
board of the City.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 209/735
(g)Recourse Against City: The grantee shall have no recourse whatsoever against the City for any loss,
cost, expense or damage arising out of any provision or requirement of this article or of any franchise
issued hereunder or because of its enforcement.
(h)Other Regulations: The grantee shall be subject to all requirements of City ordinances, rules,
regulations and specifications heretofore or hereafter enacted or established. (Ord., 9-28-1970)
Sec. 8-183. Rights Reserved To City:
(a)Nothing in this article shall be deemed or construed to impair or affect, in any way, to any extent, the
right of the City to acquire the property of the grantee, either by purchase or through the exercise of
the rights of eminent domain, at a fair and just value, which shall not include any amount for the
franchise itself or for any of the rights or privileges granted, and nothing herein contained shall be
construed to contract away or to modify or abridge, either for a term or in perpetuity, the City's right of
eminent domain.
(b)There is hereby reserved to the City every right and power which is required to be herein reserved or
provided by any ordinance of the City, and the grantee, by its acceptance of any franchise, agrees to
be bound thereby and to comply with any action or requirements of the City in its exercise of such
rights or power, heretofore or hereafter enacted or established.
(c)Neither the granting of any franchise hereunder nor any of the provisions contained herein shall be
construed to prevent the City from granting any identical, or similar, franchise to any other person
within all or any portion of the City.
(d)There is hereby reserved to the City the power to amend any section or part of this article so as to
require additional or greater standards of construction, operation, maintenance or otherwise, on the
part of the grantee.
(e)Neither the granting of any franchise or any provision hereof shall constitute a waiver to the exercise
of any governmental right or power of the city.
(f)The council may do all things which are necessary and convenient in the exercise of its jurisdiction
under this article and may determine any question of fact which may arise during the existence of
any franchise granted hereunder. The city manager is hereby authorized and empowered to adjust,
settle or compromise any controversy or charge arising from the operations of any grantee under this
article, either on behalf of the city, the grantee or any subscriber, in the best interest of the public.
Either the grantee or any member of the public who may be dissatisfied with the decision of the city
manager may appeal the matter to the council for hearing and determination. The council may
accept, reject or modify the decision of the city manager, and the council may adjust, settle or
compromise any controversy or cancel any charge arising from the operations of any grantee or from
any provision of this article.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-184. Permits, installation and service.
(a)Within sixty (60) days after acceptance of any franchise under this article the grantee shall proceed
with due diligence to obtain all necessary permits and authorizations which are required in the
conduct of its business, including but not limited to, any utility joint use attachment agreements,
microwave carrier licenses and any other permits, licenses and authorizations to be granted by duly
constituted regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the operation of CATV systems or their
associated microwave transmission facilities.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 210/735
(b)Within ninety (90) days after obtaining all necessary permits, licenses and authorizations, grantee
shall commence construction and installation of the CATV system.
(c)Within one hundred eighty (180) days after the commencement of construction and installation of the
system, grantee shall proceed to render service to subscribers, and the completion of the
construction and installation shall be pursued with reasonable diligence thereafter, so that service to
all areas designated on the map accompanying the application for franchise, as provided in section
8-193 hereof, shall be provided within one year from the date that service was first provided.
(d)Failure on the part of the grantee to commence and diligently pursue each of the foregoing
requirements and to complete each of the matters set forth herein, shall be grounds for termination of
such franchise, under and pursuant to the terms of section 8-179 hereof; provided, however, that
under any circumstances the grantee shall complete construction and be in operation eighteen (18)
months after acceptance of franchise. The council in its discretion may extend the time for the
commencement and completion of construction and installation for additional periods in the event the
grantee, acting in good faith, experiences delays by reason of circumstances beyond his control.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-185. Location of property of grantee.
(a)Any poles, wires, cable lines, conduits or other properties of the grantee to be constructed or installed
in streets shall be so constructed or installed only at such locations and in such manner as shall be
approved by the director of public works or his designated representative acting in the exercise of his
reasonable discretion.
(b)The grantee shall not install or erect any facilities or apparatus in or on other public property, places
or right-of-way, or within any privately-owned area within the city which has not yet become a public
street but is designated or delineated as a proposed public street on any tentative subdivision map
approved by the city, except those installed or erected upon public utility facilities now existing,
without obtaining the proper written approval of the director of public works or his designated
representative.
(c)Any opening in or removal of any pavement, sidewalk or curbing, street, alley or avenue and all other
excavations made by the grantee shall be made under the supervision and direction of the director of
public works or his designated representative, under permits issued for such work by the proper
officials of the city, and shall be accomplished in such a manner as to give the least inconvenience to
the inhabitants of said city, and the public generally, and all such pavements, sidewalks, curbings and
excavations shall be replaced and repaired in as good condition as before, with all convenient speed,
by, and at the expense, of the grantee, which shall at all times make and keep full and complete
plats, maps and records showing the exact locations of its facilities located within the public ways,
streets and alleys of said city. Grantee shall deliver to the city maps showing the locations of all its
underground facilities and shall keep such maps up to date at all times. Said distribution lines of
grantee shall be buried wherever any other utility distribution lines are required to be, or are being,
installed underground. Wherever possible, both telephone lines and lines of grantee shall be buried
simultaneously in the future; and no additional street crossing with overhead wires shall be permitted.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1; Ord. of 5-21-73, § 1; Ord. No. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-87)
Cross reference--Subdivisions, App. B.
Sec. 8-186. Removal and abandonment of property of grantee.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 211/735
(a)In the event that the use of any part of the CATV system is discontinued for any reason for a
continuous period of twelve (12) months, or in the event such system or property has been installed
in any street or public place without complying with the requirements of grantee's franchise or this
article, or the franchise has been terminated, cancelled or has expired, the grantee shall promptly,
upon being given ten (10) days' notice, remove from the streets or public places all such property
and poles of such system other than any which the director of public works or his designated
representative may permit to be abandoned in place. In the event of such removal, the grantee shall
promptly restore the street or other area from which such property has been removed to a condition
satisfactory to the public works direct.
(b)Any property of the grantee remaining in place thirty (30) days after the termination or expiration of
the franchise shall be considered permanently abandoned. The director of public works or his
designated representative may extend such time not to exceed an additional thirty (30) days.
(c)Any property of the grantee to be abandoned in place shall be abandoned in such manner as the
director of public works or his designated representative shall prescribe. Upon permanent
abandonment of the property of the grantee in place, the property shall become that of the city, and
the grantee shall submit to the director of public works or his designated representative an instrument
in writing, to be approved by the city attorney, transferring to the city the ownership of such property.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1; Ord. No. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-87)
Sec. 8-187. Changes required by public improvements.
The grantee shall, at its expense, protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate in the same street or
other public place or remove from the street or other public place, any property of the grantee when
required by the city engineer by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street vacation, freeway and
street construction, change or establishment of street grade, installation of sewers, drains, water pipes,
power lines, signal lines and tracks of any other type of structures or improvements by public agencies;
provided, however, that the grantee shall in all such cases have the privileges and be subject to the
obligations to abandon any property of the grantee in place, as provided in section 8-186 hereof.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-188. Failure to perform street work.
Upon failure of the grantee to commence, pursue or complete any work required by law or by the
provisions of this article or by its franchise to be done in any street or other public place, within the time
prescribed, and to the satisfaction of the director of public works or his designated representative, the
director of public works or his designated representative may, at his option, cause such work to be done
and the grantee shall pay to the city the cost thereof in the itemized amounts reported by the director of
public works or his designated representative to the grantee within thirty (30) days after receipt of such
itemized report. (Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1; Ord. No. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-87)
Sec. 8-189. Faithful performance bond.
(a)The grantee shall, concurrently with the filing of and acceptance of award of any franchise granted
under this article, file with the city clerk and at all times thereafter maintain in full force and effect for
the term of such franchise or any renewal thereof, at grantee's sole expense, a corporate surety
bond in a company and in a form approved by the city attorney, in the amount of fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000.00) renewable annually, and conditioned upon the faithful performance of grantee,
and upon the further condition that in the event grantee shall fail to comply with any one or more of
the provisions of this article, or of any franchise issued to the grantee hereunder, there shall be
recoverable jointly and severally from the principal and surety of such bond any damages or loss
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 212/735
suffered by the city as a result thereof, including the full amount of any compensation, indemnification
or cost of removal or abandonment of any property of the grantee as prescribed hereby which may
be in default, plus a reasonable allowance for attorney's fees and costs, up to the full amount of the
bond; said condition to be a continuing obligation for the duration of such franchise and any renewal
thereof and thereafter until the grantee has liquidated all of its obligations with the city that may have
arisen from the acceptance of said franchise or renewal by the grantee or from its exercise of any
privilege therein granted. The bond shall provide that thirty (30) days' prior written notice of intention
not to renew, cancellation or material change be given to the city.
(b)Neither the provisions of this section nor any bond accepted by the city pursuant hereto, nor any
damages recovered by the city thereunder, shall be construed to excuse faithful performance by the
grantee or limit the liability of the grantee under any franchise issued hereunder or for damages,
either to the full amount of the bond or otherwise.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-190. Indemnification of city.
(a)The grantee shall, concurrently with the filing of an acceptance of award of any franchise granted
under this article, furnish to the city and file with the city clerk, and at all times during the existence of
any franchise granted hereunder, maintain in full force and effect, at its own cost and expense, a
liability insurance policy in the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00), in a
company approved by the city manager and in a form satisfactory to the city attorney, indemnifying
and saving harmless the city, its officers and employees from and against any and all claims,
demands, actions, suits and proceedings by others, against all liability for damages by reason of or
arising out of any failure by the grantee to secure consents from the owners, authorized distributors
or licensees of programs to be delivered by the grantee's CATV system, and against any loss, cost,
expense and damages resulting therefrom, including reasonable attorney's fees, arising out of the
exercise or enjoyment of its franchise, irrespective of the amount of the comprehensive liability
insurance policy required hereunder.
(b)The grantee shall, concurrently with the filing of an acceptance of award of any franchise granted
under this article, furnish to the city and file with the city clerk, and at all times during the existence of
any franchise granted hereunder, maintain in full force and effect, at its own cost and expense, a
general comprehensive liability insurance policy, in protection of the city, its officers, boards,
commissions, agents and employees, in a company approved by the city manager and a form
satisfactory to the city attorney, protecting the city and all persons against liability for loss or damage
for personal injury, death and property damage, occasioned by the operations of grantee under such
franchise, with minimum liability limits of two hundred and fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for
personal injury or death of any one person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for
personal injury or death of two (2) or more persons in any one occurrence, and fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00) for damage to property resulting from any one occurrence.
(c)The policies mentioned in the foregoing paragraph shall name the city, its officers, boards,
commissions, agents and employees as additional insured and shall contain a provision that a written
notice of cancellation or reduction in coverage of said policy shall be delivered to the city ten (10)
days in advance of the effective date thereof; if such insurance is provided by a policy which also
covers grantee or any other entity or person other than those above named, then such policy shall
contain the standard cross-liability endorsement.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-191. Inspection of property and records.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 213/735
(a)At all reasonable times, the grantee shall permit any duly authorized representative of the city to
examine all property of the grantee, together with any appurtenant property of the grantee situated
within or without the city, and to examine and transcribe any and all maps and other records kept or
maintained by the grantee or under its control which deal with the operations, affairs, transactions or
property of the grantee with respect to its franchise. If any such maps or records are not kept in the
city, or upon reasonable request made available in the city, and if the council shall determine that an
examination thereof is necessary or appropriate, then all travel and maintenance expense
necessarily incurred in making such examination shall be paid by the grantee.
(b)The grantee shall prepare and furnish to the city engineer and the city clerk at the times and in the
form prescribed by either of said officers, such reports with respect to its operations, affairs,
transactions or property as may be reasonably necessary or appropriate to the performance of any of
the rights, functions or duties of the city or any of its officers in connection with the franchise.
(c)The grantee shall at all times make and keep in the city full and complete plans and records showing
the exact location of all CATV system equipment installed or in use in streets and other public places
in the city.
(d)The grantee shall file with the director of public works or his designated representative, on or before
the last day in March of each year, a current map or set of maps drawn to scale, showing all CATV
system equipment installed and in place in streets and other public places of the city.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1; Ord. No. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-87)
Sec. 8-192. Filing generally; office of grantee; refusal of service.
(a)When not otherwise prescribed in this article, all matters herein required to be filed with the city shall
be filed with the city clerk.
(b)The grantee shall maintain an office within the city limits or at a location which subscribers may call
without incurring added message or toll charges so that CATV maintenance service shall be promptly
available to subscribers.
(c)No person in the existing service area of the grantee shall be arbitrarily refused service; provided,
however, that the grantee shall not be required to provide service to any subscriber who does not pay
the applicable connection fee or monthly service charge.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-193. Use of utility poles and facilities; agreement.
When any portion of the CATV system is to be installed on public utility poles and facilities, certified
copies of the agreements for such joint use of poles and facilities shall be filed with the city clerk.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-194. Application for franchise.
(a)An application for a franchise under this article shall be in writing, shall be filed with the city clerk and
shall contain the following information:
(1) The name and address of the applicant. If the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of
each partner shall also be set forth. If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall also state
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 214/735
the names and addresses of its directors, main officers, major stockholders and associates and the
names and addresses of parent and subsidiary companies.
(2) A statement and description of the CATV system proposed to be constructed, installed,
maintained or operated by the applicant; the proposed location of such system and its various
components; the manner in which applicant proposes to construct, install, maintain and operate the
same; and, particularly, the extent and manner in which existing or future poles or other facilities or
other public utilities will be used for such system.
(3) A statement of the number of channels the grantee proposes to make available in the system,
including the number of educational channels to be provided.
(4) A statement indicating the facilities to be given by the grantee to schools within the city, and to the
city government.
(5) A statement or schedule in a form approved by the city manager of proposed rates and charges
to subscribers for installation and services, and a copy of proposed service agreement between the
grantee and its subscribers shall accompany the application.
(6) A copy of any contract, if existing, between the applicant and any public utility providing for the
use of facilities of such public utility, such as poles, lines or conduits.
(7) A statement setting forth all agreements and understandings, whether written, oral or implied,
existing between the applicant and any person with respect to the proposed franchise or the
proposed CATV operation. If a franchise is granted to a person posing as a front or as the
representative of another person and such information is not disclosed in the original application,
such franchise shall be deemed void and of no force and effect whatsoever.
(8) A financial statement prepared by a certified public accountant, or person otherwise satisfactory
to the council, showing applicant's financial status and his financial ability to complete the
construction and installation of the proposed CATV system.
The council may at any time demand, and applicant shall provide, such supplementary, additional or
other information as the council may deem reasonably necessary to determine whether the
requested franchise should be granted.
(b)Upon consideration of such application, the council may refuse to grant the requested franchise or the
council may by ordinance grant a franchise for a CATV system to any such applicant as may appear
from said application to be in its opinion best qualified to render proper and efficient CATV service to
television viewers and subscribers in the city. The council's decision in the matter shall be final. If
favorably considered, the application submitted shall constitute and form part of the franchise as
granted.
(c)Any franchise granted pursuant to this article shall include the following condition:
"The CATV system herein franchised shall be used and operated solely and exclusively for the
purpose expressly authorized by Ordinance of the City of Rock Island and no other purpose
whatsoever."
Inclusion of the foregoing statement in any such franchise shall not be deemed to limit the authority
of the city to include any other reasonable condition, limitation or restriction which it may deem
necessary to impose in connection with such franchise pursuant to the authority conferred by this
article.
Sec. 8-195. Franchise renewal.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 215/735
Any franchise granted under this article is renewable at the application of the grantee, in the same
manner and upon the same terms and conditions as required herein for obtaining the original franchise,
except for the amount of the franchise acceptance fee payable by the grantee for the renewal of the
franchise, which said fee shall be negotiated with the city council existing at that time, and except those
which are by their terms expressly inapplicable; provided, however, that the council may at its option
waive compliance with any or all of the requirements of section 8-194 hereof.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-196. Acceptance and effective date of franchise.
(a)No franchise granted pursuant to the provisions of this article shall become effective unless and until
the ordinance granting same has become effective and, in addition, unless and until all things
required in this section and sections 8-189, 8-190(a) and 8-190(b), hereof are done and completed,
all of such things being hereby declared to be conditions precedent to the effectiveness of any such
franchise granted hereunder. In the event any of such things are not done and completed in the time
and manner required, the council may declare the franchise null and void.
(b)Within twenty-five (25) days after the effective date of the ordinance awarding a franchise, or within
such extended period of time as the council in its discretion may authorize, the grantee shall file with
the city clerk his written acceptance, in form satisfactory to the city attorney, of the franchise, together
with the bond and insurance policies required by sections 8-189, 8-190(a) and 8-190(b) hereof,
respectively, and his agreement to be bound by and to comply with and to do all things required of
him by the provisions of this article and the franchise. Such acceptance and agreement shall be
acknowledged by the grantee before a notary public, and shall in form and content be satisfactory to
and approved by the city attorney.
(Ord. of 9-28-70, § 1)
Sec. 8-197. Rate adjustment.
(a)A franchisee under this article requesting a rate adjustment shall give notice to the city clerk of the
amount of the proposed rate adjustment and the effective date of said adjustment. Said notice shall
be given to the clerk sixty (60) days before the effective date of the rate adjustment.
(b)The city council may, after consideration of said notice, within fifteen (15) days of the effective date of
the proposed rate adjustment, request the franchisee to appear before the council to substantiate the
basis for the rate adjustment, and after a hearing on said matter, may either approve or disapprove
said adjustment.
(c)In the event the city council does not request the appearance of the franchisee as provided in
subsection (b), then the proposed rate adjustment shall be effective in accordance with the
provisions of the notice given under subsection (a).
(Ord. of 11-3-79, §§ 2--4).
Sec. 8-198. Tampering with cable television equipment.
It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an authorized representative of the cable television
franchise holder in the city to charge or supply any person services from any cable television company
with the intent to cheat or defraud such cable television company by installing, rearranging, connecting
or tampering with any facilities or equipment or by any trick or contrivance or by any other device or
means whatsoever. Further it shall be unlawful for any person to connect to the facilities or equipment of
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 216/735
cable television franchise holder in the city without authorization from the cable television franchise
holder.
(Ord. of 12-6-76, § 1)
State law reference--Cable television service offenses, 720 ILCS 5/16-10.
Secs. 8-199--8-220. Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. GREAT RIVER PLAZA 1
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-221. Purpose; intent.
This article is designed to promote the public interest by enhancing the attractiveness of the plaza
environment; to provide opportunities for creative, colorful, pedestrian focused activities; to encourage
activities which add charm, vitality, diversity; and provide minimum standards for the usage of the plaza,
with the intent of preserving the appearance and function of the plaza for all present and future citizens
of the city.
(Ord. No. 92-68, § 1, 4-3-92)
Sec. 8-222. Definitions:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms and words are defined as provided in this section:
Activity Permit: The permit required under section 8-230 of this chapter.
Emergency Vehicle: Any vehicle needed and/or required in an emergency situation, including, but not
limited to, ambulances, police, fire and utility service.
Fire Lane: An area consisting of those sections of the plaza surfaces having a thickness of at least
seven inches (7") and the entire public right of way of Second Avenue, at the intersection of
Seventeenth, Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets.
Food Vendor: Any person who engages in the selling of foodstuffs while moving around the plaza or
while in a stationary position without the benefit of a permanent or nonambulatory booth or similar
construction.
Great River Plaza Or Plaza: An area of the city containing outdoor pedestrian improvements which
consists of the following streets and sidewalks:
(1) The entire public right of way of Second Avenue between Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets
and Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets.
(2) Public sidewalks on the north and south sides of Third Avenue between Seventeenth and
Nineteenth Streets.
(3) The sidewalk on the east side of Seventeenth Street between First and Third Avenues.
(4) Sidewalks on the east and west sides of Eighteenth Street between First and Third Avenues.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 217/735
(5) Sidewalks on the west side of Nineteenth Street between First and Third Avenues.
(6) Arts Alley: The municipally owned property extending from the public right of way of Second
Avenue between Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets to the alley right of way between Seventeenth
and Eighteenth Streets and lying between the Quad City Arts Center and the Renaissance Center
buildings.
Nonfood Vendor: Any person who engages in the selling of any goods, wares, tokens or any other article
other than foodstuffs or any person soliciting contributions while moving around the plaza or while in a
stationary position without the benefit of a permanent or nonambulatory booth or similar construction.
Plantings: All trees, shrubs, bushes, plants, grass and flowers that are located on the plaza.
Plaza Cafe: That portion of the plaza, kept, used, maintained and held out to the public as a place where
food and beverages are sold or served in conjunction with a business operating within the adjoining
premises.
Plaza Cafe Permit: The permit required under section 8-231 of this chapter.
Plaza Fixtures: All permanent street furniture, equipment, special utilities and features constructed as
part of the plaza, including planters, benches, podium, trash receptacles, tree grates, flowerpots, sound
and irrigation systems, pedestrian and tree lights, sewer, water and electrical lines and any other fixtures
which may be added.
Plaza Surfaces: The walking surfaces and curbing covering the plaza consisting of exposed aggregate,
concrete, decorative tile pavers and any replacement materials which may be used.
Portable Sandwich Board Signage: A portable "A" shaped double faced freestanding sign not exceeding
two feet (2') in width and four feet (4') in height, constructed of durable materials that present a finished
appearance, which is not permanently secured or attached to the ground or any other structure.
Public Use: The actions of the individual public toward and on the plaza fixtures, plaza surfaces and
plantings.
Vehicle: Any human, animal, motor, engine or gravity powered device for transportation.
Vendor: All persons or entities who are identified in the definitions of food or nonfood vendors as defined
herein.
Vendor Permit: The permit required under section 8-232 of this chapter. (Ord. 92-68, 4-3-1992; Ord. 94-
66, 7-25-1994; Ord. 045-2009, §§ 1, 2, 7-13-2009; Ord. 056-2011, 7-25-2011)
DIVISION 2. PERMITTED ACTIVITIES
Sec. 8-223. Specified:
The city shall schedule all activities and uses of the plaza, provided that the activities and uses shall not
interfere with allowed public uses or violate any laws of the state and ordinances of the city and that a
valid permit has been secured. These activities include, but are not limited to, the following:
(1) Presentation of entertainment of a musical, theatrical, cinematic, choreographic or athletic
character.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 218/735
(2) Sponsoring of dances, contests, rallies, auctions, festivals, raffles, lectures, informative
demonstrations and ceremonies.
(3) Placement of displays involving public information and exhibits of art, handicrafts and other
objects of public interest.
(4) Operation of outdoor cafes, restaurants or other food service facilities.
(5) Sale of items that complement or enhance the mix of products available in the downtown.
(6) Fundraising activities and solicitation by student groups and civic, charitable, not for profit,
religious, service and fraternal organizations. (Ord. 92-68, 4-3-1992)
DIVISION 3. PERMITS-GENERAL CONDITIONS
Sec. 8-224. Duties:
Every permittee under this division shall have the duty to:
(1) Cooperate with inspection of the premises, goods, or articles at any reasonable hour by the
authorized agent, officer or employee of the city or its designee.
(2) Ascertain and at all times comply with all laws, ordinances and regulations, and all state statutes,
applicable to such permitted business or premises, including, but not limited to, all building, zoning,
fire and health regulations.
(3) Post and maintain any and all permits delivered for use in a conspicuous place.
(4) During the course of business, not call out, cry, or by the use of any device make any noise or call
attention to the sale of any goods, wares, merchandise or service whatsoever, or in any manner
obstruct or interfere with the orderly flow of pedestrian traffic.
(5) Maintain the area within a twenty five foot (25') radius of any cart, structure or location in a neat,
clean and hazard free condition, and shall not use plaza disposal facilities for disposal of permittee's
waste.
(6) Remove structure, cart, furniture or equipment from the plaza area at the close of business for the
day. No structure, cart, furniture or equipment shall be permitted to remain on the plaza overnight. All
structures, carts, furniture and equipment shall be of a type and maintained so as to enhance the
aesthetic and overall appearance of the plaza. The city reserves the right to determine the
acceptability of structures, carts, furniture or equipment for use on the plaza.
Violation of the duties enumerated in this section shall be grounds for revocation of a permit. (Ord.
92-68, 4-3-1992; Ord. 17-2001, § 1, 2-19-2001)
Sec. 8-225. Indemnification:
All users of the plaza shall indemnify and hold harmless the city from and against any and all loss, cost,
damages or expenses to persons or property, including property of the city, arising out of or claimed to
have arisen out of such use. Furthermore, all users shall defend, at no cost to the city, any such claims
or suits, provided that the city may, at its sole option, join in the defense of such claim or suit without
relieving the user from any of its promises or obligations under this section. (Ord. 92-68, 4-3-1992)
Sec. 8-226. Insurance:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 219/735
The holder of any permit shall obtain and keep in full effect at all times comprehensive general public
liability and property damage insurance, covering any personal injury or property damage arising out of
the permitted use, with liability limits of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage, and
three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for personal injury, and where alcoholic beverages are to
be served, shall obtain and keep in effect at all times liquor liability or "dramshop" insurance with liability
limits equal to the maximum recovery permitted by 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-15. The policy
shall name the city, its officers, employees and agents, as insurers and shall provide that the insurance
is primary insurance and that no other insurance maintained by the city will be called upon to contribute
to a loss covered by the policy. The policy shall further provide thirty (30) days' notice of cancellation or
material change to the policy. (Ord. 92-68, 4-3-1992)
Sec. 8-227. Application Procedure:
(a)Applicants for plaza use permits shall submit on the appropriate forms an application to the city clerk.
Each application shall state: name and address of applicant, permit and space desired, period of
time, goods or services for sale, a description or photo of any cart, booth, structure, table, chairs, or
other equipment and a drawing to scale of their location, and any electrical or other services desired.
All applications must be accompanied by proof of issuance of all necessary building, health or other
required permits or licenses.
(b)The city clerk shall ascertain that each applicant has obtained insurance, executed an indemnification
agreement, and complied with all other rules and regulations of the city. When all necessary criteria
have been met, the city clerk may issue the permit except as provided in section 8-230 of this article.
(c)The permittee shall have thirty (30) days to become operational. Failure to do so may result in
revocation of the permit.
(d)Permits may be canceled upon ten (10) days' notice of either the city or permittee with cause. (Ord.
92-68, 4-3-1992)
Sec. 8-228. Designation Of Plaza Zones; Permitted Use:
In order to more effectively carry out the provisions of this article, the plaza shall be divided into the
following zones:
Zone 1: The area between Seventeenth Street and Eighteenth Street adjacent to structures along
the north and south sides of the plaza and Arts Alley. Permitted uses in zone 1 shall consist primarily
of activities and events that are passive in nature. Such activities and events may consist of, but are
not necessarily limited to, theatrical performances, musical presentations where amplification levels
are low, display of artwork, cultural activities and plaza cafes.
Zone 2: The area between Eighteenth Street and Nineteenth Street adjacent to structures along the
north and south sides of the plaza. Permitted uses in zone 2 shall consist of all uses permitted in
zone 1 plus more active uses, including amplified musical concerts.
Zone 3: All areas other than those designated as zone 1 or zone 2. Permitted uses in zone 3 shall
consist primarily of vendor sales and plaza cafes. (Ord. 92-68, 4-3-1992; Ord. 94-66, 7-25-1994)
Sec. 8-229. Termination Of Permit:
Any permit may be revoked or terminated for violation of this article or for violation or breach of permit
conditions. (Ord. 92-68, 4-3-1992)

DIVISION 4. PERMITS-SPECIAL CONDITIONS
Sec. 8-230. Activity Permits:
Activity permits shall be valid for one to four (4) consecutive days and shall be issued upon approval and
conditions set by city council after recommendations by the chief of police and city clerk. Amplification
must be specifically requested. Activities which involve outdoor musical entertainment utilizing sound
amplification equipment shall be kept at a decibel level and positioned in such a manner so as to
minimize disruption to residents of the surrounding downtown area; and such entertainment scheduled
for Sunday through Thursday shall cease at eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M., unless otherwise extended by
action of the city council; entertainment scheduled for a Friday event shall cease on Saturday at twelve
thirty o'clock (12:30) A.M. and entertainment scheduled for a Saturday event shall cease on Sunday at
twelve thirty o'clock (12:30) A.M., unless otherwise extended by action of the city council. Any
entertainment may be terminated sooner in the event that it threatens to disturb the peace or that it is
otherwise warranted. (Ord. 92-68, 4-3-1992; Ord. 49-2004, § 1, 4-26-2004; Ord. 080-2009, § 1, 11-23-
2009)
Sec. 8-231. Plaza Cafe Permits:
Plaza cafes may be located on that portion of the plaza and Arts Alley directly adjoining the applicant's
building frontage. Except in the case of liquor licensed establishments, the cafe shall allow at least five
feet (5') for pedestrian passage between the building and cafe. In the event that two (2) liquor licensed
establishments are on the opposite sides of the plaza so that free passageway exists between them,
then a five foot (5') passageway shall be required between the two (2) plaza cafes, except in Arts Alley
where the cafe area may directly adjoin the building frontage provided a minimum five foot (5')
pedestrian passage is maintained between the space delineated for cafe use and the farthest extension
of the planter boxes which abut the exterior wall of the opposing building. Plaza cafes with a liquor
license shall demarcate the area in which liquor is to be served and restrict access to prevent entry of
minors in accordance with the provisions of chapter 3 of this code. Plaza cafes may consist of tables,
chairs and other movable nonpermanent equipment and structures. Plaza cafe permits shall be valid for
a period of one year beginning March 1. Plaza cafes may operate during the hours of operation of their
adjoining business. However, during those periods for which an activity permit has been issued, plaza
cafes may operate only with the approval of the holder of the activity permit. Plaza cafes authorized to
sell alcoholic beverages shall be subject to the hour restrictions provided in chapter 3 of this code. (Ord.
92-68, 4-3-1992; Ord. 94-66, 7-25-1994; Ord. 99-60, § 1, 8-9-1999)
Sec. 8-232. Vendor Permits:
All carts or booths and other structures or equipment shall conform to the following requirements and
restrictions:
(1) Regulations: Meet all applicable City, State and Federal regulations.
(2) Benefit, Enhance The Plaza: Benefit the public or enhance the ambiance of the plaza.
(3) Maintenance: Be maintained in a high quality state of repair.
(4) Size Requirements:
a. No cart may exceed twenty one (21) square feet in area.
b. No booth may exceed ten feet by eight feet (10' x 8') in dimensions.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 221/735
The number of food vendor permits shall be limited to two (2) daytime vendors and three (3) nighttime
vendors. The number of nonfood vendors shall be limited to one nighttime vendor. Daytime vendors may
operate between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and two o'clock (2:00) P.M. and shall remove their
equipment and supplies from the plaza by two fifteen o'clock (2:15) P.M. daily. Nighttime vendors may
operate between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and three o'clock (3:00) A.M. daily. Food vendors
only shall operate at fixed locations approved by the City. Vendor permits shall be valid for the period
beginning March 1 and ending the last day of February, annually. Vendor operations shall not interfere
with pedestrian traffic. During those activities for which an activity permit has been issued, the vendor
will be allowed to operate only with the approval of the person or organization holding the activity permit.
However, vendors may be required to relocate upon request from the activity permit holder. The City
shall approve any alternate location. Priority for the issuance of vendor permits shall be given to Rock
Island businesses and/or residents. Vendor permits shall be issued to encourage a diversity of products.
The permittee is required to remain operational for a minimum of four (4) times per month during the
months of May through September. Lack of operation during this period of time shall be grounds for the
revocation of the permit. (Ord. 92-68, 4-3-1992; Ord. 93-71, 7-12-1993; Ord. 99-12, 2-22-1999; Ord. 17-
2001, 2-19-2001; Ord. 15-2004, 2-2-2004; Ord. 057-2011, 7-25-2011; Ord. 031-2018, 6-25-2018)
