DIVISION 6. PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES
Sec. 8-234. Specified:
(a)Public uses not allowed on public streets and sidewalks by this code shall be prohibited on the plaza.
(b)Persons and domesticated animals shall be prohibited from entering or placing any objects, materials,
or substances in the plaza planters or causing another person to enter or place the former in the
plaza planters except for necessary maintenance and emergencies.
(c)Portable sandwich board signs are permissible in front along the sidewalk and entrance of the
business, provided a minimum walking distance of five feet (5') shall be maintained to allow for the
pathway of pedestrians. No portable sandwich board sign shall be illuminated, nor shall the sign
contain moving parts or have balloons, streamers or similar adornments attached to it. The city
prohibits portable sandwich board signs being displayed during district special events (activities).
Portable sandwich board signs shall only be displayed during business operating hours and shall be
removed at the end of each business day. Businesses shall be prohibited from displaying more than
one portable sandwich board sign. Such sign must not present a risk to public safety; and must be
removed in adverse weather conditions. The city does not require a permit for said signs. Any
business erecting a portable sandwich board sign shall indemnify and hold harmless the city of Rock
Island and its officers, agents and employees from any claim arising out of the presence of the sign
on city property or rights of way. Portable sandwich board signs placed in violation of this section will
result in immediate and permanent removal of said sign.
(d)The city shall prohibit from the plaza any activity the content or intent of which violates any laws of the
state and ordinances of the city.
(e)Also prohibited from the plaza shall be those activities involving equipment, objects, materials, or
vehicles either prohibited on the plaza by this article or capable of causing damage to the plaza.
(f)No person shall cause damage or discoloration to the plaza surfaces, plaza fixtures and plantings by
application of salts, chemical corrosives, petroleum derivatives, any substances which adhere or
leave permanent or nonpermanent markings, vehicle markings from unauthorized vehicles,
maintenance equipment not approved by the city, or physical abuse.
(g)No person shall apply any chemicals or other substances to plaza surfaces for the purpose of snow
and/or ice removal.
(h)Any person failing to comply with this section shall be responsible for all repair and/or replacement
costs, in addition to penalties established under this article.
(i)No person shall operate or park any motor vehicle on the plaza with the exception of emergency
vehicles or city vehicles used in connection with maintenance of the plaza.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 223/735
(j)No person shall place or allow the placement of any activities, public uses or prohibited vehicles in the
"fire lane" as defined under this article.
(k)No person shall bring onto the plaza any horse, livestock or animal considered to be a mode of
transportation except under the provisions of article XIIA, "Horsedrawn Carriages And Vehicles", of
this chapter or when in conjunction with an approved activity.
(l)No person, firm or corporation shall place or suspend over the plaza any goods or merchandise, or
cause or permit the same to be done or placed or deposited on the plaza, or cause or permit the
same to be done, any personal property of any nature.
(m)No person shall be on the "Great River Plaza" between the hours of three fifteen o'clock (3:15) A.M.
and five thirty o'clock (5:30) A.M. except for those persons employed by a business located on the
plaza; persons having their residence located on the plaza or those persons actively engaged in the
maintenance of the plaza area.
(n)Activity permit holders under section 8-230 of this chapter may prohibit any "animal" as defined in
section 7-111 of this code, with the exception of trained seeing eye dogs, from entering the plaza
area specifically occupied by the permitted activity.
(o)(1) Loitering By Underage Persons Prohibited: Between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight
and three o'clock (3:00) A.M., Monday through Sunday, no person between seventeen (17) and
twenty (20) years of age is permitted to loiter, congregate or remain in the public areas of the Great
River Plaza in the areas defined as follows: An area of the city containing outdoor pedestrian
improvements which consists of the following streets and sidewalks:
a. The entire public right of way of Second Avenue between Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets
and Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets.
b. Public sidewalks on the north and south sides of Third Avenue between Seventeenth and
Nineteenth Streets.
c. The sidewalk on the west side of Seventeenth Street between First and Third Avenues.
d. Sidewalks on the east and west sides of Eighteenth Street between First and Third Avenues.
e. Sidewalks on the east side of Nineteenth Street between First and Third Avenues.
f. Arts Alley: The municipality owned property extending from the public right of way of Second
Avenue between Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets to the alley right of way between
Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets and lying between the Quad City Arts Center and the
Renaissance Center buildings.
g. The city parking facilities identified as lot C, lot F, and lot G in section 9-91 of this code.
(2) Exceptions: The prohibition established in subsection (o)(1) of this section does not apply to the
following:
a. A person between seventeen (17) and twenty (20) years of age who is lawfully going to,
attending, participating in or leaving from a permitted plaza activity as identified in section 8-223 of
this chapter during the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight to three o'clock (3:00) A.M.,
including, but not limited to, dining at a restaurant, cafe or other food service facility located in
those areas identified in subsection (o)(1) of this section;
b. A person who is in the company of a responsible parent or legal guardian;

DIVISION 7. ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 8-235. Penalties:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and
upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute
a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 92-68, § 1, 4-3-1992)
Sec. 8-236. Interpretation:
The provisions of this article shall be minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public
health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity and general welfare. Where this article imposes greater
restrictions than are imposed or required by other provisions of law or ordinance, the provisions of this
article shall prevail. (Ord. 92-68, § 1, 4-3-1992)
Sec. 8-237. Administration:
This article shall be administered by the city. The police department shall have the specific responsibility
for administration of article provisions dealing with the carrying out of public uses. (Ord. 92-68, § 1, 4-3-
1992)
Sec. 8-238. Appeals And Variances:
(a)Appeal To City Manager: Any person aggrieved by any ruling of any person charged with the
administration of this article may take an appeal to the city manager or a designated representative.
(b)Appeal To Council: Appeals relating to administrative decisions on activities shall be made in writing
to the city council.
(c)Variances Authorized: The city council may vary the application of this article in harmony with its
general purpose and intent where there are practical difficulties or particular hardships in the way of
carrying out the strict letter of any provisions of this article. Requests for variances shall be in writing
to the city council.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 225/735
(d)Decisions Of Council: All decisions and findings of the city council on appeal or upon request for a
variance shall in all instances be final, subject to review by a court as may be provided by law. (Ord.
92-68, § 1, 4-3-1992)
Secs. 8-239-8-270. Reserved:
ARTICLE VIII. JUNKYARDS 1, 2
Sec. 8-271. Definition:
As used in this article, a "junk dealer" is any person, firm or corporation operating a business at which
personal property is or may be salvaged for reuse, resale or reduction or similar disposition and is
owned, possessed, collected, accumulated, dismantled or assorted, including, but not limited to, used or
salvaged base metal or metals, their compounds or combinations, used or salvaged rope, bags, paper,
rags, glass, rubber, lumber, millwork, brick and similar property, except animal matter, and used motor
vehicles, machinery or equipment which is used, owned or possessed for the purpose of wrecking or
salvaging parts therefrom. (1963 Code art. 6-2; Ord., 10-18-1976)
Sec. 8-272. License - Required:
No person shall locate, build, construct, keep, operate or maintain any junk store or junkyard in the City
without having first obtained a license from the City therefor. No license shall be issued for any such junk
store or junkyard within three hundred feet (300') of any church, hospital, public or parochial school or
the ground thereof; nor shall either a junkyard or junk store be built, constructed, kept, conducted,
operated or maintained on any site where two-thirds (2/3) of the buildings within a radius of three
hundred feet (300') of the proposed site are used exclusively for resident and retail store purposes or
used exclusively for residence purposes. (1963 Code art. 6-2)
Sec. 8-273. License - Application; Fee:
An applicant for a license as provided for in this article shall state the name of the person, firm or
corporation making the application; the place where said junk store or junkyard is to be located; a
statement to the effect that the proposed site for said junk store or junkyard does not conflict with the
provisions of section 8-272 of this article and shall be accompanied by an annual license fee of six
hundred dollars ($600.00), payable in accordance with section 8-2 of this chapter. Any new business
starting up after November 1 of the current year shall only be required to pay one-half (1/2) of the stated
fee for the remainder of the current license year only. (Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 8-274. Bond:
(Rep. by Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 8-275. Obstructing Walks Or Streets:
No person operating or maintaining a junkyard or junk store in the City shall place or store any article or
articles whatsoever upon the sidewalks, parkways or streets of the City or upon the property of another.
(1963 Code art. 6-2(K))
Secs. 8-276--8-290. Reserved.

ARTICLE IX. MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 1
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-291. Definitions.
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively
ascribed to them by this section:
Employees: Any and all persons other than the masseurs or masseuses, who render any service to the
permittee, who receive compensation directly from the permittee and who have no physical contact with
customers and clients.
Health Officer: The Health Officer of the City of Rock Island or his authorized representative.
Massage: Any method of pressure on or friction against or stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping,
pounding, vibrating or stimulating of the external soft parts of the body with the hands or with the aid of
any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance, with or without such supplementary aids as rubbing
alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powder, creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparations
commonly used in this practice.
Massage Establishment: Any establishment having a fixed place of business where any person, firm,
association or corporation engages in, or carries on, or permits to be engaged or carried on any of the
activities mentioned in the definition of massage in this section.
Masseur Or Masseuse: Any person who, for any consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of
massage as defined in this section.
Out Call Massage Service: Any business, the function of which is to engage in or carry on massages at
a location designated by the customer or client rather than at a massage establishment.
Permittee: The operator of a massage establishment.
Sexual Or Genital Area: The genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or perineum of any person, or the vulva
or breasts of a female. (Ord., 1-17-1977)
Sec. 8-292. Violations:
(a)Every person, except those persons who are specifically exempted by this article, whether acting as
an individual, owner, employee of the owner, operator or employee of the operator, or whether acting
as a mere helper for the owner, employee or operator, or acting as a participant or worker in any way,
who gives massages or conducts a massage establishment or who in conjunction with the massage
establishment gives or administers, or practices the giving or administering of baths as defined
herein without first obtaining a license and paying a license fee so to do from the City or shall violate
any provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine in a sum not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six (6)
months or by both such fine and imprisonment.
(b)Any owner, operator, manager or permittee in charge or in control of a massage establishment who
knowingly employs a person performing as a masseur or masseuse, as defined in this article, who is
not in possession of a valid, unrevoked permit or who allows such a masseur or masseuse to
perform, operate or practice within such a place of business shall be subject to a fine in a sum not
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 227/735
less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a
period not to exceed six (6) months or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord., 1-17-1977)
Sec. 8-293. Exceptions:
This article shall not apply to hospitals, nursing homes, sanitaria or persons holding an unrevoked
certificate to practice the healing arts under the laws of the State, or persons working under the direction
of any such persons or in any such establishments, nor shall this article apply to barbers or
cosmetologists lawfully carrying out their particular profession or business and holding a valid,
unrevoked license or certificate of registration issued by the State. (Ord., 1-17-1977)
Sec. 8-294. Maintaining Nuisance 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2.1:
Any building used as a massage establishment in violation of this article with the intentional, knowing,
reckless or negligent permission of the owner thereof, or the agent of the owner managing the building,
together with all fixtures and other property used in violation of this article are hereby declared to be a
public nuisance. (Ord., 1-17-1977)
Sec. 8-295. Permit; Display; Renewal:
Every person to whom or for whom a permit shall have been granted pursuant to the provisions of this
article shall display said permit in a conspicuous place within the massage establishment so that the
name may be readily seen by persons entering the premises. All persons who operate a massage
establishment or who are employed as a masseur or masseuse must file applications for renewal of
permits not more than two (2) months nor less than one month prior to termination of an existing permit.
(Ord., 1-17-1977)
Sec. 8-296. Operating Requirements:
(a)Cleanliness: Every portion of a massage establishment, including appliances and apparatus, shall be
kept clean and operated in a sanitary condition.
(b)Employees; Dressing Rooms: All employees shall be clean and shall wear suitable clean outer
garments whose use is restricted to the massage establishment. A separate dressing room for each
sex must be available on the premises with individual lockers available for each employee and for
each customer. Said lockers shall be equipped with a key lock or number combination locking device.
Doors to such dressing rooms shall open inward and shall be self-closing.
(c)Linens: All massage establishments shall be provided with clean, laundered sheets and towels in
sufficient quantity which shall be laundered after each use thereof and stored in an approved,
sanitary manner. No towels or sheets shall be laundered or dried in any massage establishment
unless such establishment is provided with approved laundry facilities for such laundry and drying.
Approved receptacles shall be provided for the storage of soiled linens and paper towels.
(d)Bathrooms, Etc.: Wet and dry heat rooms, shower compartments and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly
cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs shall be thoroughly cleaned after each use.
(e)Residential Uses: If the massage establishment is in any building used for residential or sleeping
purposes, any room used for massage shall not be used for residential or sleeping purposes;
provided, however, that the inspector may allow such room to be used for residential or sleeping
purposes if he finds that the health and safety of the patrons of such establishment will not be
jeopardized.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 228/735
(f)Advertising: No massage establishment granted a license under the provisions of this article shall
place, publish or distribute or cause to be placed, published or distributed any advertising matter that
depicts any portion of the human body that would reasonably suggest to prospective patrons that any
service is available other than those services as described in section 8-291, nor shall any massage
establishment indicate in the text of such advertising that any service is available other than those
services as described in said section.
(g)Locked room. No massage service may be carried on within any cubicle, room, booth or any area
within a massage establishment which is fitted with a door capable of being locked.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-297. Out call service.
No out call massage service may be operated other than by a licensed massage establishment. All
massages performed by an out call massage service must be performed in the manner prescribed in
section 8-296. Any masseuse or masseur who provides any massage services at any hotel or motel
must first register his or her name and permit number with the owner, manager or person in charge of
the hotel or motel.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-298. Inspections.
The police department and the department of public health shall from time to time, and at least twice a
year, make an inspection of each massage establishment granted a permit under the provisions of this
article for the purposes of determining that the provisions hereof are complied with. Such inspections
shall be made at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner. It shall be unlawful for any permittee to
fail to allow such inspection officer access to the premises or to hinder such officer in any manner.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Cross references--Health, Ch. 7; police, Ch. 12.
Sec. 8-299. Employment of masseurs and masseuses.
It shall be the responsibility of the permittee for the massage establishment or the employer of any
persons purporting to act as masseurs and masseuses to ensure that each person employed as a
masseur or masseuse shall first have obtained a valid permit pursuant to this article.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-300. Employment of minor.
It shall be unlawful for any owner, proprietor, manager or other person in charge of any massage
establishment to employ any person who is not at least eighteen (18) years of age.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-301. Identification card.
The chief of police shall provide each masseur and masseuse granted a permit with an identification
card which shall contain a photograph of the masseur or masseuse and the full name and permit
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 229/735
number assigned to the said masseur or masseuse, which must be worn on the front of the outermost
garment at all times during the hours of operation of any establishment granted a permit pursuant to this
article.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Secs. 8-302--8-315. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. ESTABLISHMENT PERMIT
Sec. 8-316. Required.
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on, or to permit to be engaged in,
conducted or carried on, in or upon any premises in the city, the operation of a massage establishment
as defined in this article, without first having obtained a permit from the chief of police, after approval by
the health officer.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-317. Application--Filing; fee.
(a)Every applicant for a permit to maintain, operate or conduct a massage establishment shall file an
application in duplicate under oath with the chief of police under a form provided by said chief of
police and pay a nonrefundable filing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to the city collector, who
shall issue a receipt which shall be attached to the application filed with the chief of police.
(b)The chief of police shall within five (5) days refer copies of said application to the health department,
building inspection department, fire department and planning department. These departments shall
within thirty (30) days inspect the premises proposed to be operated as a massage establishment
and make written recommendations to the chief of police concerning compliance with the codes that
they administer.
(c)Within ten (10) days of receipt of the recommendations of the aforementioned departments, the chief
of police shall notify the applicant that his application is granted, denied or held for further
investigation. The period of such additional investigation shall not exceed an additional thirty (30)
days unless otherwise agreed to by the applicant. Upon the conclusion of such additional
investigation the chief of police shall advise the applicant in writing whether the application is granted
or denied.
(d)Whenever an application is denied or held for further investigation, the chief of police shall advise the
applicant in writing of the reasons for such action.
(e)The failure or refusal of the applicant to promptly give any information relevant to the investigation of
the application or his or her refusal or failure to appear at any reasonable time and place for
examination under oath regarding the said application or his or her refusal to submit to or cooperate
with any inspection required by this article shall constitute an admission by the applicant that he or
she is ineligible for such permit and shall be grounds for denial thereof by the chief of police.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-318. Same--Contents.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 230/735
(a)The application for a permit to operate a massage establishment shall set forth the exact nature of the
massage to be administered and the proposed place of business and facilities therefor.
(b)In addition to the foregoing, any applicant for a permit, including any partner or limited partner of a
partnership applicant, and any officer or director of a corporate applicant and any stockholder holding
more than ten (10) percent of the stock of a corporate applicant shall furnish the following
information:
(1) Name and address.
(2) Written proof that the individual is at least eighteen (18) years of age.
(3) All residential addresses for the past three (3) years.
(4) The applicant's height, weight, color of eyes and hair.
(5) The business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the three (3) years immediately
preceding the date of application.
(6) The massage or similar business license history of the applicant; whether such person, in
previously operating in this or an other city or state under license, has had such license revoked or
suspended, the reason therefor and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of
suspension or revocation.
(7) All criminal or city ordinance violation convictions, forfeiture of bond and pleadings of nolo
contendere on all charges, except minor traffic violations.
(8) The fingerprints and photograph of the applicant.
(9) If the applicant is a corporation, or a partner of a partnership is a corporation, the name of the
corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-319. Facilities.
No license to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an inspection by the appropriate
city inspectors reveals that the establishment complies with each of the following minimum
requirements:
(1) Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths and showers shall be made waterproof
with approved waterproofed materials and shall be installed in accordance with the city's building
code. Plumbing fixtures shall be installed in accordance with the city's plumbing code.
a. For toilet rooms, toilet room vestibules and rooms containing bathtubs, there shall be a
waterproof floor covering, which will be carried up all walls to a height of at least six (6) inches.
Floor shall be covered up on base with at least three-fourth-inch cover. The walls of all toilet rooms
and rooms containing bathtubs shall be finished to a height of six (6) feet with a smooth, nonabsorbent
finish surface of Keene cement, tile or similar material.
b. Steam rooms and shower compartments shall have waterproof floors, walls and ceilings
approved by the inspector.
c. Floors or wet and dry heat rooms shall be adequately pitched to one (1) or more floor drains
properly connected to the sewer. (Exception: Dry heat rooms with wooden floors need not be
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 231/735
provided with pitched floors and floor drains.
d. A source of hot water must be available within the immediate vicinity of dry and wet heat rooms
to facilitate cleaning.
(2) Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. When five (5) or more employees and
patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the same time, separate toilet facilities shall be
provided. A single water closet per sex shall be provided for each twenty (20) or more employees or
patrons of that sex on the premises at any one time. Urinal may be substituted for water closets after
one water closet has been provided. All toilet rooms shall be equipped with self-closing doors
opening in the direction of ingress to the toilet rooms. Toilets shall be designates as to the sex
accommodated therein.
(3) Lavatories or washbasins provided with both hot and cold running water shall be installed in either
the toilet room or the vestibule. Lavatories or washbasins shall be provided with soap in a dispenser
and with sanitary towels.
(4) All portions of massage establishments and baths shall be provided with adequate light and
ventilation by means of windows or sky lights with an area of not less than one-eighth of the total
floor area, or shall be provided with approved artificial light and a mechanically operating ventilating
system. When windows or skylights are used for ventilation, at least one-half of the total required
window area shall be operable. To allow for adequate ventilation, cubicles, rooms and areas provided
for patrons' use not served directly by a required window, skylight or mechanical system of ventilation
shall be constructed so that the height of partitions does not exceed seventy-five (75) percent of the
floor-to-ceiling height of the area in which they are located.
(5) All electrical equipment shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the city's
electrical code.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-320. Issuance; duration.
Upon receipt of the recommendations of the departments referred to in section 8-317, and the certificate
of the health officer that the establishment is in compliance with all of the requirements of section 8-296,
the chief of police shall issue a permit to maintain, operate or conduct a massage establishment, unless
he finds:
(1) That the operation as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not have complied with all
applicable laws, including but not limited to, the building, health, planning, housing, zoning and fire
codes of the city; or
(2) That the applicant and any other person who will be directly or indirectly engaged in the
management and operation of a massage establishment has been convicted of:
a. A felony.
b. An offense involving sexual misconduct with children.
c. Prostitution, soliciting for a prostitute, pandering, keeping a place of prostitution, pimping or other
offense opposed to decency and morality.
The chief of police, at his discretion, may issue a permit to any person convicted of any of the crimes
in paragraph (2)(a)--c) if he finds that such conviction occurred at least four (4) years prior to the date
of application, the applicant has had no subsequent convictions and the applicant has shown
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 232/735
evidence of rehabilitation sufficient to warrant the public trust. Every massage establishment permit
issued pursuant to this subdivision will terminate at the expiration of one year from the date of its
issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Cross references--Buildings and building regulations, ch. 4; fire prevention and protection, ch. 6; health,
ch. 7; planning and development, ch.11; zoning, app. A.
Sec. 8-321. Transfer.
No permit for the operation of a massage establishment issued pursuant to the provisions of this article
shall be transferable except with the written consent of the chief of police and approval of the health
officer, provided, however, that upon the death or incapacity of the permittee the massage establishment
may continue in business for a reasonable period of time to allow for an orderly transfer of the permit.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Sec. 8-322. Revocation; suspension.
(a)Any permit issued for a massage establishment may be revoked or suspended by the chief of police
after a hearing for good cause or in any case where any of the provisions of this article are violated
or any employee of the permittee, including a masseur or masseuse, is engaged in any conduct at
permittee's place of business which violates any of the provisions of this article or any state law
which provides for imprisonment, and permittee has actual or constructive knowledge of such
violation or the permittee should have actual or constructive knowledge by due diligence, or where
any applicant has made a false statement on an application for a permit under this article or in any
case where the permittee or licensee refuses to permit any duly authorized police officer or health
inspector of the city and the county to inspect the premises or the operations therein. Such permit
may also be revoked or suspended by the chief of police, after hearing, upon the recommendations
of the health officer that such business is being managed, conducted or maintained without regard
for the public health or health of patrons or customers or without due regard to proper sanitation or
hygiene.
(b)Any violation of this article by any employee of the permittee, including a masseur or masseuse, shall
be cause for suspension of the permit for not more than thirty (30) days in the first instance. Any
subsequent violation of this article by any employee of the permittee, including a masseur or
masseuse, shall be cause for suspension or revocation of the permit.
(c)The chief of police, before revoking or suspending any permit, shall give the permittee at least ten
(10) days written notice of the charges against him or her and the opportunity for a public hearing
before the chief of police, at which time the permittee may present evidence bearing upon the
questions. In such cases, the charges shall be specific and in writing.
(Ord. of 1-17-77, § 1)
Secs. 8-323--8-335. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. MASSEUR OR MASSEUSE PERMIT
Sec. 8-336. Required; fee.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 233/735
Any person, including an applicant for massage establishment permit, who engages in the practice of
massage as defined in this article, shall file an application for a masseur or masseuse permit with the
chief of police upon a form provided by said chief of police and shall pay a nonrefundable filing fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for an original application and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for a renewal
application, to the city collector, who shall issue a receipt which shall be attached to the application filed
with the chief of police.
(Ord. of 1-7-77, § 1; Ord. No. 91-14, § 8, 2-11-91)
Sec. 8-337. Application form.
The application for a masseur or masseuse license shall contain the following:
(1) Name and residence address.
(2) Social security number and driver's license number, if any.
(3) Applicant's weight, height, color of hair and eyes.
(4) Written evidence that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age.
(5) Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the three (3) years immediately
preceding the date of application.
(6) Whether such person has ever been convicted of any crime, except misdemeanor traffic
violations. If any person mentioned in this paragraph has been so convicted, a statement must be
made giving the place and court in which such conviction was had, the specific charge under which
the conviction was obtained and the sentence imposed as a result of such conviction.
(7) The name and address of the recognized school attended, the date attended and a copy of the
diploma or certificate of graduation awarded the applicant showing that the applicant has completed
not less than seventy (70) hours of instruction.
(8) The chief of police shall have the right to take fingerprints and a photograph of the applicant and
the right to confirm the information submitted. (Ord., 1-17-1977)
Sec. 8-338. Issuance:
The chief of police may issue a masseur or masseuse permit within twenty one (21) days following a
hearing unless he finds that the applicant for a masseur or masseuse permit has been convicted of an
offense involving the use of force and violence on the person of another that amounts to a felony. (Ord.,
1-17-1977)
Sec. 8-339. Revocation:
A masseur or masseuse permit issued by the chief of police shall be revoked or suspended where it
appears that the masseur or masseuse has been convicted of any offense which would be cause for
denial of a permit upon an original application, has made a false statement on an application for a permit
or has committed an act in violation of this article. The chief of police in revoking or suspending a
masseur or masseuse permit shall give the permit holder a written notice specifying the grounds
therefor. Such person may within ten (10) days of such revocation or suspension file a written request
with the chief of police for a public hearing before the chief, at which time the masseur or masseuse may
present evidence at the hearing upon the question. The decision of the chief of police upon such hearing
shall be a final appealable order. (Ord., 1-17-1977)

ARTICLE X. PAWNBROKERS 1
Sec. 8-356. Definition:
Any person who lends money on deposit or pledge of personal property, bonds, notes or other valuable
things or securities, or who deals in the purchasing of personal property on condition of selling the same
back again at a stipulated price, is, for the purposes of this article, a pawnbroker. (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-2)
Sec. 8-357. License - Required:
No person shall exercise or carry on the business of pawnbroker within the city without being duly
licensed therefor. (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-1)
Sec. 8-358. License - Duration; Bond; Fee:
The city clerk with the approval of the city council shall grant a pawnbroker's license to any person of
good character who may apply therefor, upon said person giving bond with approved security in the sum
of five hundred dollars ($500.00), conditioned upon the faithful observance of all ordinances of the city
applicable to the business so licensed and paying to the city collector the sum required for said license.
Said license may be issued for six (6) months or for one year, but not beyond the end of the municipal
year, and the applicant shall pay therefor, for one year, two hundred dollars ($200.00) and for six (6)
months, one hundred dollars ($100.00). (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-3; Ord., 2-23-1976)
Sec. 8-359. Hours Of Business:
No person licensed under this article shall receive on deposit or pledge any personal property or other
valuable thing before six o'clock (6:00) A.M. nor after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. during January, February,
March, April, October, November and December of each year, nor before five o'clock (5:00) A.M. nor
after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. during the months of May, June, July, August and September of each year.
(1963 Code § 6-2(L)-9)
Sec. 8-360. Time Of Redemption Or Removal Of Pledge:
No personal property received in deposit or pledge by any person licensed under this article shall be
sold or permitted to be redeemed or removed from the place of business of such licensed person for
twenty four (24) hours after a report required to be delivered to the chief of police shall have been
delivered as required by 205 Illinois Compiled Statutes 510/7. (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-8)
Sec. 8-361. Dealings With Minors 2:
No person licensed under this article shall take or receive in pawn or purchase any article, property or
effects from any minor, or claimed by any minor. (1963 Code § 6-2(L)-10)
Secs. 8-362 - 8-375. Reserved:

ARTICLE XII. TAXICABS 4, 5
Sec. 8-396. License - Required:
No automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle shall be used for the transportation of persons for
hire within the city, whether said vehicle secures its passengers from a public stand or stands upon the
street or whether the same is kept in a private garage, unless every such vehicle is licensed as provided
in this article. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-1)
Sec. 8-397. License - Application; Fee; Term; Bond; Insurance 6:
(a)The owner of any automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle for which it is desired to secure a
license under this article shall make application to the city clerk setting forth therein the name of such
owner or owners, a description of the vehicle for which it is desired to secure a license and the place
where such vehicle is kept, if the same is kept in a private garage. The applicant shall be provided
the application form by said city clerk. The city clerk, upon receipt of such application, shall issue or
cause to be issued a license for such vehicle upon payment by the applicant of a license fee of fifty
dollars ($50.00) per annum. Such license fee shall be paid to the city collector, and upon payment
thereof, a license shall be issued, attested by the city clerk, authorizing the use of such vehicle in
accordance with the provisions of this article until the expiration of such license. And each license
when granted shall expire at the end of the municipal year following the issuance of such license.
(b)Provided, however, that the owner of any such automobile, autocar, cab, motor vehicle or other
similar vehicle shall first exhibit to the city clerk a certificate issuing from the office of the secretary of
state of Illinois, or an affidavit of said owner certifying that he, his agent, servant or operator has fully
complied with the requirements of the Illinois Compiled Statutes governing chauffeurs engaged in
driving automobiles, motor vehicles or similar vehicles for hire, and further certifying that said owner,
his agent or operators have posted good and sufficient bond or policy of insurance to the office of the
secretary of state of Illinois pursuant to the requirement of the Illinois Compiled Statutes governing
the same. Said requirements of said Illinois Compiled Statutes are incorporated as requirements of
this section by reference thereto. Failure of any owner or operator licensed hereunder to file such
certificate or affidavit with the city clerk, after ten (10) days' notice given to him by said clerk to so file,
shall be deemed sufficient ground for revocation of any license issued hereunder. Failure to perform
the requirements of this section shall be deemed an offense and shall subject any such offender to
the penalties provided for a violation of this code. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-2; Ord., 2-23-1976)
Sec. 8-398. Limitation Of Licenses:
(a)The total number of taxicab licenses which shall be issued by the city shall not exceed fifty (50).
(b)Prior to the granting of a license to new applicants for licenses under the provisions of this article, the
application shall be referred to the city council for its investigation and recommendation. All new
applicants shall submit their fingerprints to the Rock Island police department and submit the
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 236/735
required, nonrefundable processing fee for the purpose of conducting a criminal history check prior to
the issuance of a taxicab license. (1963 Code § 6-4(T)-4; Ord. 006-2017, 2-13-2017)
Sec. 8-399. Taxicab Drivers - Investigation:
At the time a taxicab driver is hired by any licensee under this article, said licensee shall submit to the
chief of police the name of said driver and any background information said licensee has concerning
said driver and also an authorization in writing from said driver authorizing the police department to
make a background check of said driver, including checking of any available criminal record, along with
the required, nonrefundable processing fee for the purpose of conducting said criminal history check.
Upon receipt of said information, authorization and the required fee, the chief of police shall make or
cause to be made a careful and diligent inquiry as to the character and record of said driver for honesty,
sobriety and capability, and if it shall be found that such applicant is lacking in any of such respects, the
chief of police shall notify the licensee of the information that resulted from said investigation. (Ord. 006-
2017, 2-13-2017)
Sec. 8-400. Taxicab Drivers - License Fee:
The annual license fee for a taxicab driver shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) or ten dollars ($10.00) if
purchased after October 31 of the same license year, and such annual licensing period shall commence
on May 1 of each year. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-14; Ord., 8-10-1981; Ord. 87-34, 4-6-1987)
Sec. 8-401. Taxicab Drivers - Record:
(a)The chief of police shall keep at his office a record in which shall be kept the name and residence of
each licensed driver or operator together with the names of persons endorsing his application, and
shall carefully note opposite each such licensed driver's name such information as he may gain
concerning said licensee and as may be necessary to provide a complete record of said licensee's
conduct and qualifications as a driver or operator.
(b)The chief of police may suspend or revoke any taxicab driver's license when in his opinion the
licensee does not have the qualifications specified in this article for said license. (1963 Code § 6-
2(T)-13)
Sec. 8-402. Taxicab Drivers - Transfer Of License:
It shall be unlawful for any person to transfer any taxicab driver's license from one person to another.
(1963 Code § 6-2(T)-15)
Sec. 8-403. Safety Inspection:
(a)All vehicles used and licensed as taxicabs shall at all times be maintained in proper mechanical
condition. It shall be necessary to present the city clerk an affidavit that the particular vehicle used
has a license to operate as a taxicab for said vehicle.
(b)The chief of police shall have the authority to order the owners of any vehicles used as taxicabs in the
city to take said vehicles out of operation if said vehicles are found to be in unsafe mechanical
condition. Said vehicles shall remain out of operation until proper repairs on said vehicles are made
to place said vehicles in proper mechanical condition. (1963 Code § 6-2(T)-3)
Sec. 8-404. Public Stands:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 237/735
(a)Use: Any automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle licensed under the provisions of this article
may stand at such places, and at no other places, as may from time to time be designated by the
council for that purpose.
(b)Location:
(1) General: The following places are public stands where taxicabs, autocars and all other vehicles
let to hire or used for transporting persons or property for hire shall stand while waiting for such
employment:
a. One parking space on the west side of Seventeenth Street between Second and Third Avenues
immediately north of the Sheraton Hotel driveway.
b. One parking space on the south side of Third Avenue between Nineteenth and Twentieth
Streets.
c. Two (2) parking spaces on the north side of Second Avenue between Nineteenth and Twentieth
Streets.
d. Two (2) parking spaces on the south side of Second Avenue immediately west of Nineteenth
Street.
The chief of police shall assign the above spaces to the respective taxicab companies or concerns.
When such spaces or stands have been so assigned, no other taxicab company or concern shall use
any other taxicab space, except the space or spaces to which they have been assigned as aforesaid.
(2) Public Places: Public stands shall also be deemed to exist at hotels, theaters and other public
places at such times and for such length of time as may be reasonably necessary for the receiving
and discharging of passengers at such places.
(c)Parking - Distance From Corner: No automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle entitled to use
such stands shall be permitted to stand anywhere thereon in such manner as to obstruct the
entrance to any building, structure or place, nor shall any automobile, autocar or other similar vehicle
entitled to use stands be permitted to stand within twenty feet (20') of any of the intersecting streets
or avenues upon which any of the stands are located.
(d)Parking - Off Street Facilities: No automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle licensed under the
provisions of this article shall park in or occupy any of the off street parking facilities of the city. (1963
Code § 6-2(T)-5; Ord. 85-19, 6-24-1985; Ord. 88-73, 12-19-1988)
Sec. 8-405. Designation Of Car:
Every automobile, autocar, cab or other similar vehicle licensed under the provisions of this article shall
have the name of the owner thereof plainly painted in letters at least one and one-half inches (11/2") in
height, and the number at least four inches (4") in height, in a conspicuous place on the outside of each
side of such vehicle, and such name and number shall be kept so painted plainly and distinctly at all
times while such vehicle is in use during the continuance of such license. Upon the expiration of such
license (unless same is forthwith renewed) such name and number shall be at once erased from such
vehicle and such vehicle shall not thereafter be used with such name or number thereon. (1963 Code §
6-2(T)-6)
Sec. 8-406. Property Left In Car By Passenger:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 238/735
Whenever any package, article or baggage or goods of any kind shall be left in or upon any vehicle
licensed under the provisions of this article, the operator of such vehicle shall, upon discovery of such
package, baggage or goods, forthwith deliver the same to the shift commander at the police station in
the city.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 7)
Sec. 8-407. Posting of rates; overnight parking.
(a)Number of passengers, rates posted. No operator or person in charge or control of any automobile,
autocar, cab, motor vehicle or other similar vehicle licensed hereunder shall contemporaneously
convey more than five (5) passengers scheduled for more than five (5) destinations, and no charge
for any additional passengers in excess of one and not in excess of five (5) shall be made where all
said passengers board the vehicle licensed hereunder at the same place of origin and all are
discharged at the point of termination of any one trip. A copy of the schedule of rates herein provided
to be charged in the said zones herein established shall be placed and kept in each vehicle licensed
hereunder in a conspicuous place in each of the said vehicles as to be at all times openly visible to
any or all of the public using said vehicles for public transportation.
(b)Overnight parking. Between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., each taxicab company
operating in the city may have one (1) cab parked at each of the following locations:
(1) Zone No. 1, which shall be on Second Avenue between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets.
(2) Zone No. 2, which shall be Sixteenth Street between Second and Third Avenues.
(3) Zone No. 3, which shall be Seventeenth Street between Second and Third Avenues.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 8; Ord. of 12-6-65, § 1; Ord. of 12-11-72, § 1; Ord. of 1-21-74, §§ 1--3;
Ord. of 8-11-75, § 1; Ord. of 9-12-77, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of -15-79, § 1; Ord. of 5-21-79, § 1; Ord. of 2-9-81, §
1; Ord. No. 83-49, §§ 1, 2, 12-19-83)
Sec. 8-408. Seating of passengers.
No person operating under a taxicab license, shall, as principal, agent or employee, permit any person
to stand or sit upon the runningboard, fender or hood of the automobile, autocar or other similar vehicle
while said vehicle is in operation. (Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 9)
Sec. 8-409. Advance payment; giving information.
Any person licensed under this article may demand his legal fare to be paid in advance by any person
seeking to employ him, and may refuse to convey any person who shall fail to comply with such
demand. Any person so licensed shall give to any person requesting the same, his name and the
number of his license.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 10)
Sec. 8-410. Records.
Each operator of a licensed vehicle used and operated as a taxicab shall keep records on a daily basis
indicating on said records the time and place each passenger is picked up and delivered and the
amount charged for each fare. These records shall be kept by owners of said vehicle for one (1) year.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(T), § 11)

ARTICLE XIIA. HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES AND VEHICLES
Sec. 8-411. Definitions.
(a)Horse-drawn carriage and vehicle means any vehicle which is operated or pulled by a horse which
may be hired for the transportation of passengers and which is operated within the city limits.
(b)City means the City of Rock Island, Illinois.
(c)Coach operator's license means a license granted by the city to a person, authorizing that person to
operate a horse-drawn vehicle upon the streets of the city.
(d)Open stand means a public place alongside the curb of a street or elsewhere in the city, which has
designated as reserved exclusively for the use of horse-drawn carriages and vehicles.
(Ord. No. 92-23, § 1, 2-3-92)
Sec. 8-412. License required.
The operation of any horse-drawn vehicle upon the streets of the city for the purpose of transporting
persons for hire or as a contractual service is a violation of this article unless operated in accordance
with valid licenses issued pursuant to this article.
The city clerk is authorized to issue licenses pursuant to this article as follows: Horse-drawn carriage
business, vehicle licenses and coach operator's licenses.
(Ord. No. 92-23, § 1, 2-3-92)
Sec. 8-413. Application for license.
Applications for horse-drawn carriage business licenses shall be made to the city clerk on forms
provided by the city clerk. In addition to other information required by this article, the application shall
contain the following information:
(a)The name and address of the applicant.
(b)The applicant's work or corporate history for the past five (5) years. If the applicant is a corporation,
the information shall also be given for the chief administrative officer who will be in charge of the
Rock Island operations. The corporation shall list all its officers and all other businesses operated by
the corporation. If the corporation is a foreign corporation, a copy of the certificate to do business in
the state shall be provided.
(c)A list of all felony and misdemeanor convictions including traffic violations by the applicant for the past
ten (10) years. If the applicant is a corporation, such information shall be given for the chief
administrative officer in charge of Rock Island operations.
(d)The number of carriages to be operated pursuant to the license, and the seating capacity,
manufacturer, and scale drawing or photograph of each carriage.
(e)A proposed route and operations schedule for the business.
(f)A schedule of rates and charges to be made to passengers, which rates shall not be changed without
ten (10) days' prior notice to the city clerk.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 240/735
The application shall be verified under oath and include a written agreement by the applicant to
operate the business, if licensed, strictly in accordance with this article, and indemnify and hold
harmless the city for all judgments, liens and expenses arising out of the operations permitted by the
license.
(Ord. No. 92-23, § 1, 2-3-92)
Sec. 8-414. Carriage route and operations schedule.
(a)Horse-drawn carriage businesses shall operate only upon routes and pursuant to schedules approved
as provided in this section. The route and operations schedule filed with the city clerk shall contain
the following:
(1) A map of the routes on which the carriages will operate.
(2) A schedule of hours of operations.
(3) The location of the site or sites to be used for off-street storage, stabling and loading of carriages
and horses.
(b)The city clerk shall refer all route and operations schedules to the traffic engineering committee for
review. The traffic engineering committee shall recommend to the city council such routes and
schedules that represent safe and appropriate use of city streets. The traffic engineering committee
shall also review and recommend to the city council any temporary variances from the established
routes for special purposes. Requests for route variance shall be made no less than fourteen (14)
days prior to the effective date of the requested variance.
(c)Any route and operations schedule approval shall be subject to the right of the chief of police to
prohibit the use of any route at certain times, when such operation would be inconsistent with other
special events or public safety requirements, by giving forty-eight (48) hours' notice of such
prohibition.
(d)Any request for a variance from the route and operations schedules because of a special event or
celebration must be approved by the city clerk and the chief of police. Such a request must be
submitted to the city clerk's office at least four (4) days prior to the date of the event.
(Ord. No. 92-23, § 1, 2-3-92; Ord. No. 93-90, § 1, 10-25-93)
Sec. 8-415.7. Annual license fees.
The annual fee for a horse-drawn carriage business license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
business and one (1) carriage. Each additional carriage shall be licensed for fifty dollars ($50.00). A
coach operator's license shall be issued for an annual fee of ten dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. No. 92-23, § 1, 2-3-92)
ARTICLE XIII. TRANSIENT MERCHANTS 1
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-416. Definitions.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 241/735
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation of this article:
Residence: Every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes, by one (1) or more persons,
contained within any type of building or structure.
Transient merchant: Any person, the nature of whose business activity indicates the intent to remain in
business in the city for less than one (1) year, who:
(1) Offers for sale tangible personal property or personal services, or
(2) Takes or attempts to take orders for the sale of tangible personal property or services, including
advertising or subscriptions to be furnished or performed in the future.
(Code 1963, Ch. VI, Art. II(R), § 2; Ord. No. 82-44, § 1, 10-25-82)
Sec. 8-417. Penalty.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to
imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days, or a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Each sale or solicitation of a sale made without a license or bond in violation of this article shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. No. 82-44, § 14, 10-25-82)
Sec. 8-418. Sales.
(a)No person shall engage in activities regulated under this article on public property without first
procuring special authorization from the city council.
(b)No person shall shout, or use any sound device upon any of the public places of the city or upon any
private premises in said city, where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom to be
capable of being plainly heard from the public places, for the purpose of attracting attention to any
goods, wares, merchandise or services which such person proposes to sell.
(c)No person shall engage in business as a transient merchant in defiance of any notice exhibited at a
residence or business indicating that peddlers or solicitors are not welcome or not invited.
(d)No person shall engage in the activities regulated under this article from door to door prior to 9:00
a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. of any weekday or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday.
(Ord. No. 82-44, § 4, 10-25-82)
Sec. 8-419. Fixed location.
(a)No transient merchant shall engage in business at a fixed location without the written permission, by
lease or otherwise, of the owner or person in control of the property. This written agreement shall be
signed by the parties and shall include the dates the transient merchant shall be conducting
business. This agreement shall be displayed by the transient merchant at such fixed location when
he is doing business there.
(b)A transient merchant doing business at a fixed location shall provide sufficient off-street parking
space for his employees and customers.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 242/735
(c)Any display of tangible personal property, or signs or advertisements therefor, shall be at least fifteen
(15) feet from the curbline. All signs and advertisements used in connection with the business
licensed in this article shall comply with the appropriate sections of this Code.
(d)The owner or person in control of the property shall furnish bathroom facilities for the use of the
transient merchant.
(e)A transient merchant doing business at a fixed location shall do so only in areas properly zoned for
business activity. A transient merchant selling food items shall comply with all applicable provisions
of the city's health code.
(Ord. No. 82-44, § 5, 10-25-81)
Sec. 8-420. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 8-421. Required; Application:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a transient merchant in the city without
first obtaining a license as provided in this division.
(b)An application for a transient merchant license shall give the following information:
(1) The name or names of the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business,
whether such person will act as proprietor, agent, consignee or employee, during the time that it is
proposed it will be carried on in the city; the local address or addresses of such person while
engaged in such business.
(2) The permanent address or addresses of such person; whether such person will act as proprietor,
agent, consignee or employee and the credentials establishing such relationship; the name and
address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation,
under the laws of what state the same is incorporated.
(3) The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business and the
length of time during which it is proposed that said business shall be conducted.
(4) The place or places other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where applicant
within three (3) years next preceding the date of said application conducted a transient business,
stating the nature thereof and giving the post office box number and street address of any building or
office in which said business was conducted.
(5) A statement of the nature and character of the tangible personal property or service to be sold or
offered for sale by the applicant in the city; whether the goods are new, damaged or rejects; whether
the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or by sample; where the goods or
property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where goods or products are
located at the time said application is filed.
(6) Whether or not the person having management or supervision of the applicant's business,
whether such person will act as proprietor, agent, consignee or employee, has been convicted of a
felony within the five (5) years immediately preceding the date of said application or of the violation of
any law or ordinance relating to the same or similar business to be conducted by applicant, the
nature of such offense and the punishment therefor.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 243/735
a. All applicants, whether such person will act as proprietor, agent, consignee or employee, shall
submit their fingerprints to the Rock Island police department and submit the required,
nonrefundable processing fee per submission for the purpose of conducting a criminal history
check prior to the issuance of a transient merchant license.
(7) Whether the applicant has ever applied for a license under this article, which has been denied.
(8) Whether the applicant has ever held a license under this article, which has been revoked. (1963
Code §§ 6-2(R)-1, 6-2(R)-3; Ord. 82-44, 10-25-1982; Ord. 006-2017, 2-13-2017)
Sec. 8-422. Bond:
(a)Except as provided in this article, each applicant for a transient merchant license or a blanket license
hereunder shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the city, in the penal sum therein set forth,
executed by applicant as principal, and by a corporate surety upon which service of process may be
made in the state, the bond to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall
comply with the provisions of all of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state, regulating
and concerning the sale of goods, subscriptions, wares, merchandise or personal property of any
nature, including foodstuffs, or for services, including advertising, and will pay all judgments rendered
against the applicant for any violation of ordinances or statutes or any of them together, with all
judgments and costs that may be recovered against applicant by any person or persons for damage
growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such
business with applicant, whether said misrepresentation or deception was made or practiced by the
owners or by their servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale, or the
solicitation of the sale, or through any advertisements of any character whatsoever, printed or
circulated with reference to the subject matter of such sale or any part thereof. Action on the bond
may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond shall be further
conditioned to indemnify and pay the city for any penalties or costs occasioned by the enforcement of
this article and shall not be retired until after a lapse of one year from the expiration of each license.
(b)The following persons shall be exempt from the requirement of posting bond: Transient merchants
selling subscriptions, tangible personal property or services, where each sale does not exceed fifty
dollars ($50.00) to any person or to any member of any purchaser's immediate family within any
consecutive three (3) month period and where, in addition, no payment, down payment or deposit
whatsoever is required to be made or paid until the property is actually delivered or the services are
actually performed.
(c)Any person claiming an exemption under the provisions of this section shall make request therefor in
writing and shall state in said request that the applicant shall not make any sales in violation of the
provisions of this section.
(d)All licenses issued where the transient merchant is exempt from the posting of bond under this
section shall contain the following language: "No bond has been furnished the city of Rock Island by
the holder of this license".
(e)The penal sum of the bond required under the provisions of this article is one thousand dollars
($1,000.00), or two (2) times the value of the tangible personal property or service to be sold or
offered for sale or the average inventory to be carried by the transient merchant as shown by the
application, whichever amount is greater.
(f)The applicant for a blanket license shall in all cases furnish a bond described in subsection (a) of this
section in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. 82-44, § 9, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 8-423. Duplicate And Individual Licenses:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 244/735
A transient merchant license may be issued to a person carrying on the business of transient merchant
in this city through employees. Such employees shall carry a duplicate license issued to the person,
which license shall be obtained at the city clerk's office. If the business of transient merchant in this city
is carried on through agents who are not employees or by consignees, or by an unincorporated firm or
association, each person so conducting the business of transient merchant in this city shall be required
to have a separate license, but not post a separate bond if one is posted by the corporation. (Ord. 82-44,
§ 10, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 8-424. Blanket License:
(a)The owner or person in control of any real property located in the city, upon which a permanent
business and building is located, who conducts events regulated and required to be licensed under
this article, or who leases the premises to transient merchants for such regulated events, may
procure a blanket annual license, and the individuals conducting the various concessions there will
not be required to obtain individual licenses, under the following conditions:
(1) The owner or person in control of such real property shall be required to submit in writing to the
city clerk, on forms provided by the clerk, the locations of the premises upon which such activities are
to be conducted, the names and addresses of the officers and directors or other governing body of
the owner of the premises and the name, permanent address and business address of the person in
charge of managing such property. Said person shall also sign a statement that, in the event the
license is granted, he will comply with all the provisions of this article and that he guarantees that the
transient merchant leasing property from him shall also comply with all the provisions of this article.
(2) The licensee shall make the provisions of this article a part of any agreement for the use of the
premises for any purpose to which the provisions of this article are applicable.
(3) It shall be the responsibility of licensee not to permit any person to operate or conduct a business
on the premises as transient merchant who is not entitled to conduct such business under the
blanket license.
(b)Any person conducting or sponsoring an activity described in subsection (a) of this section may
secure a single event blanket license for the same uses and purposes and on the same terms and
conditions as the annual blanket license. A single event blanket license shall be valid for a period of
six (6) months and may be used for fourteen (14) cumulative days during said six (6) month period.
(Ord. 82-44, § 11, 10-25-1982; Ord. 82-74, § 1, 2-28-1983)
Sec. 8-425. Exemptions:
Persons engaged in the following described activities are exempt from the duty of applying for a
transient merchant license:
(1) Persons selling at wholesale to merchants for the purpose of resale.
(2) Persons selling or distributing newspapers.
(3) Persons selling tangible personal property or services to business enterprises.
(4) Persons who sell, at their permanent residence in the city, works of art or craft made or created
by such person or a member of such person's immediate family.
(5) Persons licensed by the state to sell real estate or insurance or licensed as transient vendors of
drugs.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 245/735
(6) Persons selling or distributing livestock feeds as defined by the laws of the state 1.
(7) Persons selling or delivering tangible personal property or services through a permanent business
licensed by the city.
(8) Persons selling at events for which a blanket license has been obtained.
(9) Persons selling or distributing on their property fresh fruit or vegetables cultivated by such person.
(10) Persons selling tangible personal property at a garage, basement or yard sale held at one of the
person's premises.
(11) Persons conducting and selling admissions to or for theatricals, shows, rides, sports and games,
concerts, circuses, carnivals or any other public amusement where no sales of other products are
involved and such sales are made on the premises where the event is to be conducted.
(12) Persons selling food and beverages at a food service establishment regulated pursuant to the
health code of the city.
(13) A religious, charitable, patriotic, social service, civic or political nonprofit organization. (Ord. 82-
44, § 12, 10-25-1982)
Sec. 8-426. Issuance; Fees; Display:
(a)If an application for a license under this article contains a complete statement of the information
required and all material required to be submitted therewith is filed with the city clerk, the clerk,
subject to the provisions of section 8-421 of this chapter, shall issue within twenty one (21) days,
upon posting of the bond required by section 8-422 of this chapter, the license. The license issued
hereunder shall not be transferable. There shall be no refund of the license fee.
(b)Before a license shall be issued, applicant shall pay to the city collector a license fee according to the
following schedule:
(1) Blanket License:
a. Single event blanket license, fifty dollars ($50.00).
b. Blanket annual license, three hundred dollars ($300.00).
(2) Transient Merchant's License:
a. For one day, twenty five dollars ($25.00); for each additional day, five dollars ($5.00).
b. For one month, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
c. For three (3) months, two hundred dollars ($200.00).
d. For six (6) months, two hundred seventy five dollars ($275.00).
e. For one year, four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00).
(3) Duplicate License: Five dollars ($5.00).
(c)Each transient merchant shall at all times while doing business in the city keep in the possession of
such person the license required by this article and shall, upon request, display the license as
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 246/735
evidence of compliance with the requirements of this article. (Ord. 82-44, §§ 3, 7, 8, 10-25-1982; Ord.
007-2013, 3-4-2013)
Sec. 8-427. Denial; Revocation:
(a)The city manager may deny, within twenty one (21) days, a license to any applicant under this article
who has:
(1) Held a license under this article that has been revoked within two (2) years of the date of the
present application.
(2) Failed to make a complete application.
(3) During the past two (2) years, a history of:
a. Fraudulent applications for similar licenses.
b. Misrepresentation of the quality of merchandise or services offered for sale.
c. Crimes involving personal injury.
(b)The city manager may revoke any license issued under the provisions of this article by sending a
notice of revocation by certified mail to the license holder at his last known address, return receipt
requested, or by personal service on the license holder or its officers for any of the following causes:
(1) Information showing that the license was erroneously issued initially.
(2) For any violation of the provisions of this article.
(3) For any violation of any city or state law regulating the sales activities of the license holder.
(c)The license shall stand denied or revoked unless within five (5) days after denial or receipt of the
notice of revocation from the city manager the applicant or holder files a written request for a public
hearing on the city manager's action. A public hearing shall be conducted before the city council on
whether a license should be denied, reinstated or revoked, as the case may be. The city council may
order the license issued or reinstated either conditionally or unconditionally, or revoke the license.
Ten (10) days' notice of the time and place of the public hearing shall be given to the license holder,
who shall have an opportunity to appear before the city council and present any evidence or
arguments he may have why the action taken by the city manager should not be approved by the city
council. (Ord. 82-44, § 13, 10-25-1982)
Secs. 8-428--8-430. Reserved.
ARTICLE XIV. TREE REMOVERS, TREE TRIMMERS, ETC. 1
Sec. 8-431. Definitions:
As used in this article:
Tree Remover: Any person, firm or corporation that, for profit, removes a tree stump or a tree standing in
any street, alley, parkway, boulevard or other public or private place in the city of Rock Island.
Tree Trimmer: Any person, firm or corporation that, for profit, diagnoses the condition of a shade, forest
or ornamental tree and recommends or supervises the treatment of any such tree, by feeding or
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 247/735
fertilizing, or by pruning, trimming, bracing, treating cavities or other methods, or protects or attempts to
protect any such trees from damage by insects or disease by spraying or any other method. (1963
Code, ch. VI, art. II(U), §§ 1, 3; Ord., § 1, 2-11-1965)
Sec. 8-432. Tree Remover Generally:
(a)No person engaged in the business of removing trees shall remove any tree standing in any street,
alley, parkway, boulevard or other public or private place in the city without first obtaining a tree
remover's license from the city clerk. No tree remover's license shall be issued by the city clerk to
any person until said clerk is shown evidence that said person has in effect insurance by a reputable
insurance company authorized to do business in the state, covering public liability of twenty five
thousand dollars ($25,000.00) per person and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) per accident, and
also twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) liability coverage for property damage. In addition thereto
said applicant shall show sufficient evidence of insurance coverage for workers' compensation
claims. Said insurance coverage shall be kept in effect at all times while said licensee is engaged in
the business as aforesaid in the city. The license fee for such business or occupation shall be one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per year.
(b)The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
(1) The United States Of America, the state, the county or the city, any department, bureau or agency
of any of the foregoing or any official representative of any of the foregoing in the pursuit of his official
duties.
(2) Any person who engages in tree removing as defined above on his own premises.
(3) Any public utility, including its authorized employees and agents, when engaged in tree removal
for the purpose of line clearance and in order to ensure the continuity of utility service to the public.
(4) Any person holding a valid city tree trimming license. (1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(U), § 4; Ord. 87-
34, § 5, 4-6-1987; Ord. 004-2011, 2-7-2011)
Sec. 8-433. Tree Trimmer Generally:
(a)No person engaged in the business of trimming trees shall trim, feed or treat in any manner any trees
standing in any street, alley, parkway, boulevard or other public or private place in the city without
first obtaining a tree trimmer's license from the city clerk. The license fee for such business or
occupation shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year. Any person being issued a tree
trimmer's license shall show the city clerk sufficient evidence that said person has in effect insurance
by a reputable insurance company authorized to do business in the state, covering public liability of
twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) per person and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) per
accident, and also twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) liability coverage for workers' compensation
claims. Said insurance coverage shall be kept in effect at all times while said licensee is engaged in
the business as aforesaid in the city.
(b)The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
(1) The United States Of America, the state, county or city, any department, bureau or agency of any
of the foregoing or any official representative of any of the foregoing in the pursuit of his official
duties.
(2) Any person who engages in tree trimming as defined above on his own premises.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 248/735
(3) Any public utility, including its authorized employees and agents, when engaged in tree trimming
for the purpose of line clearance and in order to ensure the continuity of utility service to the public.
(1963 Code, ch. VI, art. II(U), § 2; Ord., § 1, 10-12-1981; Ord. 87-34, § 6, 4-6-1987; Ord. 004-2011,
2-7-2011)
Sec. 8-434. Reserved:
Sec. 8-435. Tree Trimmings Removed By Licensee:
Any person having a license as provided in this article shall immediately and at his own expense remove
all tree trunks, limbs, branches, twigs or brush and dispose of same at a place designated by the chief
building inspector or at such other place as is provided for the disposal of same. (1963 Code, ch. VI, art.
II)
Sec. 8-436. Planting And Maintenance Of Trees On Public Property - Permit 1:
(a)Required: No person shall plant or set out any trees in any street, alley, parkway, boulevard or other
