public place without first procuring a permit therefor from the director of public works or his
designated representative.
(b)Application: Any person desiring to acquire a permit as aforesaid shall make application to the
director of public works or his designated representative therefor and include therein the number of
trees to be planted or set out; the location, grade and variety of each tree, the method of planting and
such other information as the director of public works or his designated representative shall find
reasonably necessary to determine whether a permit shall issue.
(c)Conditions For Issuance: Upon proper application being made as aforesaid, the director of public
works or his designated representative shall issue the permit provided for herein, when he finds that
the proposed planting conforms to the specifications and general regulations set forth hereunder.
(1) No trees shall be planted in a boulevard where sewer or water lines presently exist or where
future plans indicate the need of said lines.
(2) Trees shall be set out so as not to cause undue maintenance and so as not to interfere with any
utilities.
(3) The director of public works or his designated representative may require the applicant to furnish
a detailed planting plan which shall accurately show:
a. The proposed street, together with its subdivision of pavement, curb, gutter, parking strip and
sidewalk areas to a definite indicated scale.
b. The variety of each tree proposed to be planted and of those already existing within the
proposed street lines.
c. The distance between trees in any one row. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I; Ord., 4-9-1964; Ord. 87-
22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 8-437. Planting And Maintenance Of Trees On Public Property - Procedures:
(a)Generally: All work done under a permit issued under section 8-436 of this chapter shall be performed
in strict accordance with the terms thereof and with the following regulations:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 249/735
(1) The trunks of all trees planted must not be less than two and one-half inches (2 1/2") in diameter,
when measured one foot (1') above the ground.
(2) No tree shall be placed in such a location where, in the opinion of the city engineer, said tree shall
cause a traffic hazard when planted, or in the future.
(3) All trees shall be planted at least thirty feet (30') apart. Trees of the larger growing varieties shall
be spaced more than thirty feet (30') apart if considered desirable by the director of public works or
his designated representative.
(4) No tree shall be planted where the space between the curb and sidewalk is less than six feet (6').
Trees of the large growing varieties shall be permitted only where the space between the sidewalk
and the curb is adequate to appropriately accommodate them.
(5) No tree shall be planted nearer than three feet (3') from the curb line or the outer line of the
sidewalk.
(6) No tree shall be planted on any street or public place except the following varieties: sugar maple,
pin oak, red oak, ginkgo, honey locust (thornless varieties), columnar maple, littleleaf linden, hopa
crab, Washington hawthorne and any other varieties specifically approved by the director of public
works or his designated representative; provided, however, that Chinese elm, box elder, willow,
poplar, and similar fast growing, brittle wood species, which may be subject to attack by insects or
diseases, are prohibited.
(b)Duties Of Owners: All persons planting trees under authority of section 8-436 of this chapter and this
section shall assume the following duties:
(1) To trim said trees so as to prevent a traffic hazard or interference with the proper lighting of public
highways by any streetlights and so that the clearance of any overhanging portion thereof shall be a
minimum of twelve feet (12').
(2) To treat or remove any tree so diseased or insect ridden as to constitute a safety hazard or a
hazard to other trees or plants planted on public property.
(c)Compliance: When the director of public works or his designated representative shall find it necessary
to order the trimming, preservation or removal of trees which constitute a hazard under subsection
(b) of this section, he shall serve a written order to correct the dangerous condition upon the person
to whom a permit to plant has been issued. Said notice shall be given by mailing a copy of said order,
by registered mail, to the owner of the abutting property as indicated by the property tax assessment
records of the county. When a person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply within the time
specified in the order, the director of public works or his designated representative shall remedy said
condition or contract with others for such purpose and charge the cost thereof to the person to whom
the order is directed. (Ord., 4-9-1964; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Secs. 8-438-8-440. Reserved:
ARTICLE XV. RAFFLES 1
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-441. Definitions:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 250/735
When used in this article and unless otherwise distinctly expressed, the following words and phrases
shall have the meanings set out herein:
Net Proceeds: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable sums expended for prizes,
local license fees and other reasonable operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
Nonprofit, Charitable, Educational, Religious, Fraternal, Veterans And Labor: Shall have the same
meaning ascribed to them in 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 15/2(b).
Raffle: A form of lottery, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-2(b) conducted by an
organization licensed under this article, in which:
(1) The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance, represented and differentiated
by a number or by a combination of numbers or by some other medium, one or more of which
chances is to be designated the winning chance;
(2) The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some other method based on an
element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part of persons conducting or connected with the
lottery, except that the winning chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited
sporting contest.
Rock Island County Model Raffle Ordinance: An ordinance in substantially the same form, and
containing the same provisions and limitations as are set forth in this subject ordinance to be enacted by
any municipality located within Rock Island County, Illinois, and intended to regulate the conduct of
raffles within the jurisdiction of the respective municipality. (Ord. 078-2011, 10-10-2011)
Sec. 8-442. Penalty:
Violation of any provision of this article shall subject the person, firm, or organization to a fine in a sum
not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 97-68, 7-
28-1997)
Sec. 8-443. Conduct Of Raffles, Generally:
The conducting of raffles licensed under this article is subject to the following restrictions:
(1) The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the
organization permitted to conduct that game.
(2) No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may participate in the
management or operation of the raffle.
(3) No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in the management or
operation of the raffle; however, this shall not prohibit the payment of rent or a permit fee for use of
facilities to hold a raffle if said rent or fee is not dependent upon the raffle proceeds and is binding
upon the parties at the time made.
(4) Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on the license and winning
chances may be determined only at those locations specified on the license.
(5) A person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age may participate in the conducting of raffles
or chances only with the permission of a parent or guardian. A person under the age of eighteen (18)
years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied
by his parent or guardian. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 251/735
Sec. 8-444. Manager:
All operations of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a single raffle manager
designated by the organization. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-445. Records:
(a)Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep records of its gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are
determined. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be
documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item
or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of net proceeds shall
be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount, and date of payment.
(b)Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be segregated from other revenues of the
organization, including bingo gross receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same
nonprofit organization pursuant to license therefor, issued by the department of revenue of the state,
and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records of its raffles. The
person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles
shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the organization.
(c)Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to its membership, and to the
licensing local unit of government, its receipts, expenses and net proceeds from raffles and the
distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this section.
(d)Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3) years, and organizations shall make
available their records relating to operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and
places. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Secs. 8-446-8-450. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 8-451. License Required:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to conduct a raffle or chance in the city without
having first obtained a license therefor pursuant to this article or in violation of the terms of such license.
(Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-452. Reciprocity With Other Municipalities In County:
Any person, firm or corporation who has in his immediate possession a valid license issued to the
person, firm or corporation by another municipality or political subdivision located in Rock Island County,
Illinois, which municipality or political subdivision has enacted the Rock Island County model raffle
ordinance (this article), shall be exempt from the requirements of this division to have obtained a license
from the city. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-453. Eligibility:
Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable, labor, fraternal, educational or veterans'
organizations that operate without profit to their members and which have been in existence
continuously for a period of five (5) years immediately before making application for a license and which
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 252/735
have had during that entire five (5) year period, a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out their
objectives. Licenses shall be issued to a nonprofit fundraising organization that the licensing authority
determines is organized for the sole purpose of providing financial assistance to an identified individual
or group of individuals suffering extreme financial hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident
or disaster. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-454. Restrictions On Issuance:
No such license shall be issued to:
(1) Any person who has been convicted of a felony;
(2) Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling promoter;
(3) Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection (1) or (2) of this section, has a
proprietary, equitable or credit interest or in which such a person is active or employed;
(4) Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1) or (2) of this Section, is an officer,
director or employee, whether compensated or not;
(5) Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (1) or (2) of this Section, is to participate
in the management or operation of a "raffle" as defined in this Article. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-455. Applications:
(a)Application for such licenses shall be made to the City Clerk no later than thirty (30) days prior to the
commencement of sales or advertisement of sale of raffle chances.
(b)The application for license must specify the area or areas within the City in which raffle chances will
be sold or issued, the time of determination of winning chances and the location or locations at which
winning chances will be determined.
(c)The application for license must contain a sworn statement attesting to the not-for-profit character of
the prospective license organization and shall be signed by the presiding officer and secretary of the
organization.
(d)The application for license must state the residence of the applicant and all addresses of offices
within the licensing municipality and, if the raffle drawing is to be conducted within the licensing
municipality, the address of the location of the drawing.
(e)Prior to approval, any application which indicates that the sale of raffle chances would be in an area
outside the corporate limits of the City, or which indicates that the location or locations of determining
winning chances is outside the corporate limits of the City, shall be referred to the licensing authority
of such jurisdiction for comment as to zoning status, licensed status of location, and compliance with
licensing regulations.
(f)The City Clerk shall act on a license application within thirty (30) days from the date of application and
shall notify all jurisdictions affected thereby of said action. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-456. Fee:
Fees shall be charged for the making of application and the issuance of a raffle license as follows:
(1) Five dollars ($5.00) for a temporary raffle license for a single raffle;
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 253/735
(2) Fifty dollars ($50.00) for an annual raffle license as defined in Section 8-457 of this Article;
(3) No fee will be charged for the making of application and the issuance of a raffle license for the
medical emergency/financial hardship. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 8-457. Validity; Duration:
A license authorizes the licensee to conduct "raffles" as defined in this Article. Licenses issued pursuant
to this Article shall be valid for one raffle or for a specified number of raffles to be conducted during a
specified period not to exceed one year, and may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this
Article. (Ord. 97-68, 7-28-1997)
Secs. 8-458-8-465. Reserved:
ARTICLE XVI. WATERPROOFING OF BUILDINGS 1
Sec. 8-466. Permit Required:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of waterproofing basements, interiors or
exteriors, or cause the same to be done without first obtaining a separate permit for each building or
structure to be waterproofed from the Building Official. (Ord. 87-91, 10-12-1987)
Sec. 8-467. Obtaining A Permit:
To obtain a permit, the contractor shall have on file in the office of the Building Official, a general
contractor's bond in the amount of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Notification of the construction for
each year, or the cancellation of this bond, must be confirmed by the office of the Building Official.
(1) Application For A Permit : To obtain a permit, the applicant shall file an application therefor in
writing on a form furnished by the Building Official for that purpose. Every application shall:
a. Identify and describe the work to be covered by the permit for which application is made.
b. Describe the land on which the proposed work is to be done by legal description, street address
or similar description that will readily identify and definitely locate the proposed building or work.
c. Indicate the use or occupancy for which the proposed work is intended.
d. Be accompanied by plans, diagrams, computations and specifications if required by the Building
Official. The Building Official may require plans, computations and specifications to be prepared
and designated by an engineer or architect licensed by the State to practice as such.
e. State the value of the waterproofing measure.
f. Be signed by permitter, or his authorized agent, who may be required to submit evidence to
indicate such authority.
(2) Permit Issuance : The application, plans and specifications and other data filed by an applicant for
permit shall be reviewed by the Building Official. Such plans may be reviewed by other departments
of the City to verify compliance with any applicable ordinances under their jurisdiction. If the Building
Official finds that the work described in an application for a permit and plans, specifications and other
data filed therewith conform to the requirements of this Code and other pertinent laws and
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 254/735
ordinances, and that the fees specified in section 304 of the Uniform Building Code have been paid,
he shall issue a permit therefor to the applicant. (Ord. 87-91, 10-12-1987)
ARTICLE XVII. PEDICABS
Sec. 8-468. Definitions:
City : The City of Rock Island, Illinois.
Pedicab : Any vehicle that is a manually operated bicycle-type vehicle pulling a cart for two (2)
passengers equipped with handles and other equipment required by State law by slow-moving vehicles
to operate on the street.
Pedicab Operating License : A license granted to a person and authorizing a person to operate a
pedicab on the streets of the City. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-469. Licenses Required:
The operation of any pedicab vehicle upon the streets of the City for transporting persons for hire or as a
contractual service is a violation of this Article unless operating in accordance with a valid license issued
pursuant to this Article. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-470. Application For License:
Applications for pedicab business licenses shall be made to the City Clerk on a form provided by the City
Clerk. In addition to other information required by this Article, the application shall contain the following
information:
(1) The name and address of the applicant.
(2) The applicant's work or corporate history for the past five (5) years. If the applicant is a
corporation, the information shall also be given for the chief administrative officer who will be in
charge of the Rock Island operations. The corporation shall list all its officers and all other
businesses operated by the corporation. If the corporation is a foreign corporation, a copy of the
certificate to do business in the State shall be provided.
(3) A list of all felony and misdemeanor convictions including traffic violations by the applicant for the
past ten (10) years. If the applicant is a corporation, such information shall be given for the chief
administrative officer in charge of the Rock Island operations.
(4) The number of pedicabs to be operated pursuant to the license and the seating capacity of each.
(5) A schedule of rates and charges to be made to passengers, which rates shall not be changed
without ten (10) days' prior notice to the City Clerk.
The applications shall be verified under oath and include a written agreement by the applicant to
operate the business, if licensed, strictly in accordance with this Article, and indemnify and hold
harmless the City for all judgments, liens and expenses arising out of the operations permitted by the
license. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-471. Pedicab Routing And Operations Schedules:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 255/735
(a)Pedicab business shall operate only within the area of the City located within 1st Avenue to 7th
Avenue and 11th Street to 26th Street and also the City bicycle path. For any special events that the
pedicab business wishes to service, said business shall contact the City Clerk at least four (4) days
before said special events and submit a temporary route to be used by the pedicab business during
said special events. The City Clerk will then review the temporary route with the City Traffic
Engineering Committee and the Police Department prior to authorizing same.
(b)The pedicab business in the City shall operate only between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon
to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight of each day. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-472. Operation Of Pedicab Businesses:
Pedicab businesses shall be operated only with the regulations given in this Section.
(1) A copy of the pedicab license shall be displayed on all pedicabs used in such business. The City
Clerk, upon issuance of the license, shall issue that number of duplicates as requested in the
application identifying each pedicab identified in the application.
(2) Each pedicab used in such business shall have a valid pedicab license issued pursuant to this
Article.
(3) Each pedicab shall be operated by the holder of a valid coach operator's license issued pursuant
to this Article, who shall have such license on his/her person at all times when operating such
vehicle.
(4) When carrying persons for hire or by contract, the vehicle shall be operated only in the approved
area of operations.
(5) Pedicabs shall pick up and discharge passengers only upon the curb lane, while lawfully parked
at designated stands.
(6) Pedicab vehicles, when in motion, shall be operated only in the curb-most traffic lane on any
public street; and the driver shall obey all applicable State and local traffic laws, ordinances and
regulations.
(7) No pedicab vehicle shall be operated on a public street unless a valid liability insurance policy as
specified in this Article is on file with the City Clerk.
(8) It shall be the duty of the driver of the pedicab to inform any person hiring the carriage of all the
rates and charges before any service is rendered, which shall be the same as those on file with the
City Clerk.
(9) Drivers shall carry rate cards and exhibit them on demand.
(10) Occupancy of the pedicab shall not exceed the rated seating capacity of the vehicle.
(11) No passenger shall be allowed to ride on any part of the vehicle when in motion except seated
inside the vehicle.
(12) Drivers shall not solicit patronage in a loud tone of voice or in any manner to annoy or obstruct
the movement of a person, or follow any person for the purpose of soliciting patronage.
(13) Drivers are prohibited from smoking while carrying passengers.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 256/735
(14) No person may drink any alcoholic liquor while such person is operating a pedicab. (Ord. 96-58,
9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-473. Insurance:
Before any permit for a pedicab shall be issued, the owner shall file with the City Clerk an insurance
policy issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in this State, providing insurance
coverage for each and every pedicab owned, operated or leased by the applicant with a minimum of one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for the injury or death of any one person; and three hundred
thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for the injury or death of any number of persons in any one accident,
and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage resulting from any one accident, regardless
of whether the pedicab was being driven by the owner, his/her agent, employee, lessee or permittee.
The policy shall contain a provision requiring the City to be named as an additional insured for the sole
purpose of the City being notified by the insurance company of any cancellation, termination, or
expiration of the policy thirty (30) days prior to that event. The cancellation or other termination of any
insurance policy issued for or in compliance with the provisions of this Section shall automatically
terminate any license issued for the pedicab covered by such insurance policy unless another policy
complying with the provisions of this Section shall be provided and in full force and effect at the time of
such cancellation or termination. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-474. Issuance Of License:
Upon receipt of the completed application for the pedicab business license, approval of the route and
operations schedule, filing of insurance as required, and payment of the application and license fees, the
City Clerk shall issue a pedicab business license to the applicant. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-475. Operation On The Streets Of The City:
(a)No pedicab shall be operated upon the streets of the City for transporting person(s) for hire or by
contract unless licensed by the City Clerk.
(b)Each pedicab will be equipped with a slow-moving vehicle sign approved by the State and attached to
the rear of the vehicle. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-476. Pedicab Operator's License:
(a)No person shall drive a pedicab carrying persons, for hire or by contract, unless he/she is the holder
of a valid pedicab operator's license issued pursuant to this Section.
(b)The application for the pedicab operator's license shall be made under oath to the City Clerk and shall
verify, or establish that the applicant:
(1) Possesses a valid, current operator's license issued by the State.
(2) Is at least eighteen (18) years of age.
(3) Is free of defective vision, defective hearing, and any other infirmities that would render him/her
unfit for safe operation of a public vehicle.
(4) Is free of alcohol or drug addition.
(5) Has not, within the ten (10) years immediately preceding his/her application, been convicted of
any felony, or operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or a drug.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 257/735
(6) Has not received more than three (3) moving traffic violations in the immediately preceding twelve
(12) months or five (5) moving traffic violations in the immediately preceding twenty four (24) months
of application.
(7) Has delivered to the City Clerk a certificate signed by the pedicab licensee or other sufficient
evidence that such person is qualified to operate a pedicab.
(c)Upon approval of the application and payment of the necessary fee, the City Clerk shall issue a
pedicab operator's license to the applicant.
(d)Any person not having been duly issued a pedicab operator's license or a person whose license as
such driver has been revoked, any person whose license has been suspended, or any person who
has had his/her state driver's license suspended or revoked (even if he/she has restricted driver's
permit), and who during the time of such suspension or revocation drives a pedicab upon the streets
shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a simple misdemeanor. (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-477. Denial, Suspension Or Revocation:
(a)Any violation of this Article by the holder of a license issued hereunder shall be grounds for
suspension or revocation of the license by the City Clerk.
(b)Any denial of license application may be appealed within fourteen (14) days to the City Council. (Ord.
96-58, 9-9-1996)
Sec. 8-478. Annual License Fees:
The annual fee for a pedicab business license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). Each additional pedicab
shall be licensed for fifty dollars ($50.00). A pedicab operator's license shall be issued for an annual fee
of ten dollars ($10.00). (Ord. 96-58, 9-9-1996)
Secs. 8-479-8-485. Reserved:
ARTICLE XVIII. SALE/POSSESSION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS
Sec. 8-486. Definitions:
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively
ascribed to them:
Minor: Any person under eighteen (18) years of age.
Tobacco Products: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes,
cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or dipping tobacco.
Vending Machine: Any mechanical, electric or electronic, self-service device which, upon insertion of
money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses tobacco products. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
Sec. 8-487. License Generally:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, to give away, deliver or to keep with the intention of
selling at retail, giving away or delivering tobacco products within the City without having first obtained a
tobacco dealer's license therefor pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 258/735
Sec. 8-488. Licensing Procedure:
(a)License Application: Application for a license hereunder shall be made in writing to the City Clerk on a
form provided by the City Clerk's Office.
(b)Licensee Fee: The annual license fee for a tobacco dealer's license shall be one hundred twenty five
dollars ($125.00), payable in accordance with section 8-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 043-2017, 11-6-2017)
Sec. 8-489. Responsibility For Agents And Employees:
(a)Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this
article by an officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed
and held to be the act of such licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner
as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-
1996)
Sec. 8-490. Suspension; Revocation Of License; Fines, Costs:
(a)Once a licensee has been notified of a violation of this article, they shall have five (5) days to file a
written notice of appeal. If no hearing is requested, the Mayor may suspend, revoke, or issue a
written reprimand to any license issued under the provisions of this chapter, if the Mayor determines
that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this article. In lieu of suspension or revocation
of a license, the Mayor may instead levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed shall not exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day on which a violation continues shall
constitute a separate violation.
(b)If no hearing is requested by the licensee and the Mayor determines that a letter of reprimand is
warranted or the license should be suspended or revoked, he shall issue a written order within five
(5) days stating the reasons for the determination, and shall cause a copy of such order to be served
upon the licensee within ten (10) days. In the event a penalty is imposed, the order shall specify the
date by which the penalty shall be paid. If the penalty is not paid by the specified date, the license
shall be suspended for a time determined by the Mayor. All penalties shall be paid at police
headquarters. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
Sec. 8-491. Hearing Procedures:
(a)If a hearing is requested, in writing, before the Code Hearing Officer the Code Hearing Officer shall
schedule a hearing on said matter within thirty (30) days. Said hearing shall be open to the public
and a Court Reporter shall transcribe the proceedings.
(b)If the Code Hearing Officer determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this
chapter, the Code Hearing Officer may suspend, revoke or issue a written reprimand to any license
issued under the provisions of this chapter or, in lieu of suspension or revocation of a license, impose
a fine on the licensee not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each
day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation.
(c)The Code Hearing Officer shall determine the costs incurred by the City for said hearing, including,
but not limited to: Court Reporter fees, the cost of transcript records, attorney fees, the cost of
preparing the mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the City
or such lesser sum as the Code Hearing Officer may allow.
(d)The licensee shall pay said costs to the City within thirty (30) days of notification of the costs by the
Code Hearing Officer. Failure to pay said costs within thirty (30) days of notification is a violation of
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 259/735
this article and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the levy of additional fines.
(e)Witnesses shall be sworn; but the hearing shall be informal, and the strict rules of evidence shall not
apply.
(f)In the event the licensee wishes to appeal a decision of the Code Hearing Officer, said licensee shall
pay the cost of the preparation and transcription of the record of the hearing and shall appeal to the
Circuit Court under the provisions of the Administrative Review Act. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
Sec. 8-492. Use Of Premises After Revocation:
(a)When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to said licensee
for the period of six (6) months thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling "tobacco
products" as defined in section 8-486 of this article in the premises described in such revoked
license. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
Sec. 8-493. Prohibited Sales, Delivery - Signs:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver
tobacco products to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
(b)Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein shall be posted by every licensee
at or near every display of tobacco products and on or upon every vending machine which offers
tobacco products for sale. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:
THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO
PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF
AGE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW.
The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background, said letters to be at least one
inch (1") high. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
Sec. 8-494. Minors:
(a)Minimum Age To Sell Tobacco Products : It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer,
associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licenses, to engage, employ or permit
any person under eighteen (18) years of age to sell tobacco products in any licensed premises.
(b)Purchase By Minors Prohibited : It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18)
years to possess any tobacco products, or to misrepresent their identity or age, or to use any false or
altered identification for the purpose of purchasing tobacco products.
(c)Possession By Minors Prohibited : It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18)
years to possess any tobacco products; provided that the possession by a person under the age of
eighteen (18) years is under the direct supervision of the parent or guardian of such person in the
privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
Sec. 8-495. Certain Free Distributions Prohibited:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of selling or otherwise distributing,
promoting or advertising tobacco products, or any employee or agent of any such licensee or person,
in the course of such licensee's or person's business, to distribute, give away or deliver tobacco
products free of charge to any person on any right of way, park, playground or other property owned
by the city or the school district. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 260/735
Sec. 8-496. Vending Machines-Locking Devices:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give away, deliver or to keep with the
intention of selling, giving away or delivering tobacco products by use of a vending machine, unless
such vending machine is equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking device controlled by
the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons under the age of eighteen (18) years.
(b)Any premises where access by persons under the age of eighteen (18) years is prohibited by law, or
premises where the public is generally not permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the
use of employees of a business located at such premises, shall be exempt from the requirements of
subsection (a) of this section. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996)
Sec. 8-497. Remedies For Violation:
(a)Any violation of the provisions of this article, except as otherwise provided in this section, shall be
punishable by a minimum fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00). In the event any person is accused
of a violation hereof and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued
for the violation, that person so accused may pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the
sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for and in full satisfaction of said violation.
(b)Any violation committed by a minor of subsection 8-494(b) or (c) of this article, as a first offense, shall
be punishable by a minimum fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event any minor is accused of a
violation hereof and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for
the violation, that minor so accused may pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum
of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for and in full satisfaction of said violation. In lieu of any citation
payment or any fine mentioned herein for the first offense, a person may notify the chief of police, in
writing, of their intention to complete a "tobacco use" class or other similar class put on by the
American Lung Association, at such minor's sole cost and expense, and if such person shall
successfully complete such class and provide proof of completion to the chief of police, in writing,
then any such citation cost or fine for first offense shall be waived.
(c)These fines are in addition to administrative provisions for suspension, revocation or forfeiture of a
license issued pursuant to this article; and payment of such fine shall not constitute an admission of
guilt or innocence for purposes of such administrative proceedings for suspension, revocation or
forfeiture.
(d)Any duly appointed and authorized security officer for the School District #41 or any subdivision
thereof, or any other peace officer, shall have authority to sign all complaints and charge any
violations of this section that takes place on School District #41 property. Any duly appointed and
authorized administrator for the Alleman High School or any subdivision thereof, or any other peace
officer, shall have authority to sign all complaints and charge any violations of this section that takes
place on Alleman school property. (Ord. 96-67, 9-16-1996; Ord. 96-83, 10-28-1996)
ARTICLE XIX. TATTOO ESTABLISHMENTS AND TATTOO ARTISTS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 8-498. Definitions:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 261/735
Aseptic Technique : A practice that prevents and hinders the transmission of disease-producing
microorganisms from one person or place to another person or place.
Certificate Of Inspection : Written approval from the health authority that said tattooing establishment
has been inspected and meets all of the terms of this article relating to physical facilities, equipment
and layout for operation of such business. Said writing shall be on a form designated by the health
authority for such purpose.
City : The city of Rock Island, Illinois.
Facial Tattoo : Any tattoo applied above the jawline, anterior to the ear and frontal hairline including
the eyelids, eyebrows or lips.
Health Authority : The health inspector or authorized representative.
Operator : Any individual, firm, partnership, company, corporation or association that owns or
operates an establishment where tattooing is performed.
Sanitize : To treat a clean surface and destroy pathogenic microorganisms.
Single Service Items : Articles intended for one time, one person use and are to be discarded after
use.
Tattoo Artist : Any individual who performs or practices the art of tattooing, on the person of another.
Tattoo, Tattooed, Tattooing : An indelible mark or decorative design created by the introduction of
dyes or pigments beneath the surface of the skin with the aid of needles or other devices. (Ord. 12-
2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 8-499. License Required; Fees:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating a tattooing establishment
within the city without first paying an annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and
payable to the city clerk's office upon written approval from the health authority and to engage in
such business in accordance with the provisions hereof.
(b)It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct any tattooing within the city without a tattoo license,
respectively, which shall be issued pursuant to the provisions of this article, or to employ any person
as a tattooer, who has not paid for such tattoo artist's annual license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for
each artist, and payable to the city clerk's office, upon written approval from the health authority.
(c)No tattoo artist shall practice tattooing in any place other than a tattoo parlor having a valid license.
(d)No tattoo artist shall apply a tattoo to any person who appears to be or admits to being under the
influence of intoxicating substances, including, but not limited to, alcohol, drugs, paints and glues.
(e)No tattoo artist shall apply a tattoo in violation of section 12-10 of the Criminal Code of 1961.
(f)Immediately after tattooing, the tattoo artist shall advise the client, in writing, on the care of the tattoo
and instruct the client to consult a physician at the first sign of infection. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-
2000)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 262/735
Sec. 8-500. Display Of License:
Every person to whom a license shall have been granted shall display said license in a conspicuous
place. Failure to display said license shall be grounds for revocation. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-501. Exceptions To Provisions Of Article:
The requirements of this article shall have no application and no effect upon and shall not be construed
as applying to any person, firm or corporation licensed by the state to practice medicine or licensed by
the state to practice any of the healing arts. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-502. Application:
Any person desiring to obtain or renew a license to operate a tattooing establishment or a tattoo artist's
license shall make application to the city clerk who shall refer all such applications to the health
inspector for an appropriate investigation. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-503. Contents Of Application:
(a)The application for a tattooing license required by this article shall contain the following information:
(1) Full name and current address;
(2) The two (2) previous addresses of the applicant immediately prior to the current address;
(3) Written proof that the applicant is over the age of eighteen (18) years;
(4) Applicant's height, weight and color of eyes and hair;
(5) The tattooing license history of the applicant, including whether such person in previous operation
in this or another area has had his license revoked or suspended, the reason thereof, and any
business activity or occupation subsequent to the action of suspension or revocation;
(6) A certificate of a medical doctor designating that the applicant has recently been examined and is
free of any contagious or communicable disease which in the opinion of the medical doctor can be
transmitted during the tattooing process. Immunization for hepatitis B is strongly recommended. (Ord.
12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-504. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. REQUIREMENTS AND PROCEDURES
Sec. 8-505. Tattooing Hygiene Procedure:
(a)All tattoo artists shall comply with the following:
(1) No employee, while infected with a disease in a communicable form, or who is a carrier of a
disease which can be transmitted during the tattooing process; and no employee while affected with
a boil, infected wound or acute respiratory infection shall provide tattooing to a client.
(2) No employee shall provide tattooing to any skin surface that shows evidence of any rash, boils,
infections or other unhealthy conditions or disease.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 263/735
(3) Employees shall thoroughly wash their hands and the exposed portions of their arms with soap
and warm water before starting work, during work as often as is necessary to keep them clean, and
after smoking, eating, drinking and using the toilet. Employees shall keep their fingernails clean and
trimmed.
(4) Employees providing tattooing shall, in addition to thoroughly washing, use single-use latex or
vinyl examination gloves, as a barrier to potentially infective blood.
(5) Employees shall not use tobacco in any form, or eat or drink while tattooing a client. (Ord. 12-
2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-506. Tattooing Procedure:
(a)The tattoo artist shall explain in writing the following to each client before a tattoo application and
maintain a copy of the informed consent signed by the client for at least five (5) years:
(1) The application procedure.
(2) Possible tissue reactions, infections and dye reactions following application.
(3) Importance of after-application care.
(b)The area of skin to be worked on shall first be thoroughly washed and scrubbed for a period of two (2)
minutes with warm water to which has been added an antiseptic liquid soap. A sterile single-use
sponge shall be used to scrub the area. After shaving and before the tattooing is begun, a solution of
seventy percent (70%) alcohol or other effective germicidal solution shall be applied to the area with
a single-use sponge used and applied with a sterile instrument;
(c)For tattooing, single-service or individual containers of dye or ink shall be used for each patron, and
the container therefor shall be discarded immediately after completing work on a patron; any dye in
which the needles were dipped shall not be used on another person;
(d)Whenever a new sterile tube is used that contains a different color of dye or ink, a separate or new
sterile needle shall also be used. Excess dye or ink shall be removed from the skin with an individual
single-use sterile sponge or a disposable paper tissue which shall be used only on one person and
then immediately discarded. After completing work on any person, the tattooed area shall be washed
with sterile gauze saturated with an antiseptic soap solution approved by the health officer, or a
seventy percent (70%) alcohol solution. The tattooed area shall be allowed to dry and petroleum jelly
from a collapsible or plastic tube shall be applied, using sterile gauze. A sterile gauze dressing shall
then be fastened to the tattooed area with adhesive;
(e)Only clean single-service stencils may also be used;
(f)Only sterilized needles and tubes or tips, in good condition, shall be used for tattooing;
(g)Persons tattooed shall be provided with printed instructions regarding tattoo care during the healing
process and shall be instructed to consult a physician if signs and symptoms of an infection develop;
(h)Single-use needles, razors or other sharp materials must be disposed of immediately upon
completion of tattooing within EPA and OSHA approved sharps disposal containers.
(i)Used tattoo needles and other infectious waste shall be stored, treated, and disposed of in accordance
with the provisions of title XV of the environmental protection act 1 which regulates the management
and disposal of infectious waste. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 264/735
Sec. 8-507. Facial Tattoos:
(Rep. by Ord. 089-2005, § 1, 10-17-2005)
Sec. 8-508. Physical Facilities:
All tattoo parlors shall comply with all of the following requirements in order to qualify for a license:
(1) The tattooing room and waiting areas shall be separated by a solid partition or barrier that
prevents unauthorized entry into the tattooing room and provides privacy for clients.
(2) All floors, walls, ceilings, and procedure surfaces shall be constructed from materials that are
easily cleanable, smooth, nonabsorbent, durable, light colored, and in good repair. The tattoo
establishment shall be maintained in a sanitary condition.
(3) A separate, readily accessible hand sink with hot and cold running water, shall be provided at
each workstation, for the exclusive use of the tattoo artist for hand washing and preparing the client
for tattooing. The hand sink will be under pressure with a mixing valve or combination faucet. Soap,
an approved hand drying device such as disposable paper towels, and a refuse container with a
cover shall be provided at each hand sink.
(4) All tattooing establishments shall be provided with at least one utility sink or curbed cleaning
facility with a floor drain for the cleaning of mops or similar wet floor cleaning equipment and for the
disposal of mop water or similar liquid waste.
(5) Adequate lighting and ventilation shall be provided within the tattoo establishment.
(6) No animals of any kind shall be allowed in a tattoo establishment except for canine accompanying
the visually disabled.
(7) Effective measures shall be taken by the tattoo operator to prevent and maintain the tattoo
establishment free of pest and/or rodent infestations.
(8) An adequate number of lockers or other suitable facilities shall be provided and used for orderly
storage of employees' clothing and other belongings.
(9) Smoking and the use of tobacco in any form shall be prohibited in the tattooing room.
(10) Any other business or dwelling shall be completely separated from the tattoo parlor by at least a
solid partition from the floor to the ceiling. Only tattooing shall be permitted in a tattooing room. (Ord.
12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-509. Equipment:
(a)All service table surfaces shall be constructed of nonporous, easily cleanable material, and sanitized
after each client.
(b)All inks, dyes, needles and equipment shall be specifically manufactured for performing body art
procedures and shall be used according to the manufacturer's instructions. All dyes or pigments used
in tattooing shall be nontoxic, free from adulteration and made from materials generally regarded as
safe.
(c)Sterile single-service or sterile individual containers of dye or ink shall be used for each patron. Ink
cups shall be for single patron use with the ink cup holder constructed from material that is easily
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 265/735
cleanable and nonabsorbent.
(d)All tubes, needle bars and instruments used in the tattoo procedure that are not sterile single patron
use and disposable shall be thoroughly cleaned and steam sterilized or dry-heat sterilized between
patrons. After sterilization, equipment used in the tattoo procedure shall be stored in a dry, clean
cabinet or other tightly covered container reserved for the storage of such instruments. Each tattoo
artist will be provided with a storage cabinet for the exclusive storage of instruments, dyes, pigments,
carbon, stencils, and other paraphernalia used in the parlor.
(e)Needles shall be disposable, sterile, single patron use or shall be reusable needles and shall be
thoroughly cleaned and steam sterilized or dry-heat sterilized between patrons. Needles, tubes, and
tips shall be constructed in a manner that permits easy cleaning and sterilization. Needles and
assemblies designed to be disposable shall be used one time, on one person only, and then
discarded in accordance with subsection 8-506(i) of this division.
(f)Razors shall be single patron use and disposable, or shall have the handle of the razor sterilized with
a new blade used for each patron. Alum or other material used to stop the flow of blood shall be used
only in liquid or powder form.
(g)Topical ointment or medications shall be packaged for single patron use. All bandages and dressings
shall be sterile and single use.
(h)All instruments used for tattooing shall remain stored in sterile packages until just prior to the
performance of the tattoo procedure. All instruments, equipment and facilities shall be maintained in
a clean and sanitary condition. When assembling instruments used for the tattoo procedure, the artist
shall wear disposable medical gloves and use medically recognized techniques to ensure that the
instruments and gloves are not contaminated. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-510. Sterilization Procedure:
(a)Each tattoo parlor engaged in the practice of tattooing shall utilize sterilization equipment adequate in
size to accommodate needles, tubes, tips and other related utensils and equipment and only
sterilization equipment with the capacity to make a permanent record of the temperatures and
pressures in the machines may be used. All records shall be permanently retained by the licensee
and made available for inspection by the health authority on demand.
(b)After each use, the needles and assemblies shall be cleansed to remove protein residue (blood and
tissue) and sterilized.
(c)One of the following methods of sterilization shall be used:
(1) Autoclave - steam under pressure.
a. One hundred twenty one degrees Celsius (121°C) (250°F) at greater than ten (10) psi for not
less than thirty (30) minutes after the chamber of the autoclave has been evacuated of air and has
reached temperature; or as specified in the manufacturer's operator's manual.
(2) Dry heat sterilization.
a. One hundred seventy degrees Celsius (170°C) (338°F) for not less than two (2) hours after the
sterilizer has reached temperature; or
b. As specified in the manufacturer's operator's manual.
(3) Other methods approved by the health authority.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 266/735
(d)Sterilization shall be monitored by the use of chemical and heat sensitive (color change) indicators
with each batch of equipment sterilized or by other methods approved by the department.
(e)Sterilized equipment shall be stored wrapped or covered in a manner that ensures the equipment will
remain sterile until used. Each batch shall be labeled with the date of sterilization. If exposed to any
potential source of contamination, the equipment shall be resterilized before use.
(f)Sterile equipment stored, in an approved manner and not used within thirty (30) days after sterilization,
shall no longer be considered sterile and shall be resterilized before use.
(g)An equipment fault manual shall be kept by licensee and made available at all times to the health
authority containing a record of all sterilization equipment failures and the remedies taken to correct
the failure.
(h)Sterilizers shall be monitored monthly by an independent testing laboratory. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-
2000)
Sec. 8-511. Inspections:
During the business hours of the tattooing establishment, the health authority may conduct periodic
inspections for the purpose of determining whether or not said establishment and the persons
performing the art of tattooing thereon are in compliance with all applicable health provisions contained
within this article and other pertinent ordinances. It shall be unlawful for any person or operator of a
tattooing establishment wilfully to prevent or restrain the health officer from entering any licensed
establishment where tattooing is being performed for the purpose of inspecting said premises, after
proper identification is presented to the operator. Where the health authority has reasonable grounds to
believe that a communicable disease has possibly been transmitted at a licensed tattoo parlor it may
require testing of the tattoo artist and employees. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-512. No Guarantee Or Warranty:
The purpose of this article is to protect the public interest by reducing the dangers involved in
unregulated practice of tattooing. Neither the issuance of a license, the making of an inspection without
finding violations, or any other act by the health officer or by any other city official shall constitute a
guarantee or warranty that any equipment or any treatment is safe or effective, or that any tattooing
establishment will perform without making errors. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
DIVISION 4. REVOCATION OF LICENSE
Sec. 8-513. Hearing Prerequisite To Revocation Of License; Notice:
No license shall be revoked until after due notice and a hearing shall have been held before the
administrative hearing officer to determine just cause for such revocation. Notice of such hearing shall
be given in writing and served at least ten (10) days but not more than twenty (20) days prior to the date
of the hearing thereof. The notice shall state the grounds of the complaint against the holder of such
license and shall designate the time and place where such hearing will be had. Said notice shall be
served upon the license holder by delivering the same personally or by leaving such notice at the place
of business or residence of the license holder in the custody of a person of suitable age and discretion.
In the event the license holder cannot be found, and the service of such notice cannot be otherwise
made in the manner herein provided, a copy of such notice shall be mailed, registered and postage fully
prepaid, addressed to the license holder at his place of business or residence at least ten (10) days prior
to the date of such hearing. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 267/735
Sec. 8-514. Grounds Of Revocation:
The license of a tattooing establishment may be revoked for any legitimate reason, including, without
limitation, any one or more of the following grounds:
(1) That the holder is addicted to the habitual use of intoxicating liquors, narcotics or stimulants to
such an extent as to incapacitate such person for the performance of his professional duties for any
period of time.
(2) That the holder is guilty of fraudulent, false, misleading or deceptive advertising.
(3) That the holder is guilty of wilful negligence in the practice of tattooing or has been guilty of
employing, allowing or permitting any unlicensed person to perform tattooing in his establishment.
(4) That liquor is being sold or consumed within the establishment.
(5) That the establishment has abandoned the practice of tattooing or that the individual licensee has
abandoned the same practices. For the purposes of this subsection, "abandonment" shall mean that
the activities regulated hereunder, or any of them, have ceased or otherwise not conducted for a
period of sixty (60) days at the establishment in question, or where an individual licensee has
abandoned the activities regulated hereunder, or any of them, for a like period.
(6) That the licensee, whether an establishment or individual, has violated any provision of this
article, whether or not an action has been commenced in circuit court.
(7) Any licensee, whether an establishment or individual, who has had its license revoked three (3)
times shall be ineligible for any license hereunder for a period of five (5) years beginning with the
effective date of the third revocation. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-515. Tattooing Establishments Practicing When Provisions Of Article
Become Effective:
Any person, firm or corporation who is actually engaged in the practice of tattooing at the time of final
passage of ordinance 12-2000 and meets all the requirements except as to adequacy of facilities, and
upon payment of the prescribed fee, shall be granted a license. Such person shall have thirty (30) days
from the effective date of ordinance 12-2000 from which this article is derived to bring his facilities into
compliance with this article. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
DIVISION 5. REGULATION; PENALTY
Sec. 8-516. Federal, State And Local Regulation:
Wherever federal, state, or local laws, ordinances, rules or regulations conflict with the provisions of this
article, then the law, ordinance, rule or regulation which is most strict shall apply, and it shall not be a
defense to an action under this article, or to a request for suspension or revocation of the license(s)
provided herein, that this article does not specifically enumerate the proscribed, prohibited or regulated
conduct. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Sec. 8-517. Penalty:
In addition to the revocation and suspension of any license, any person violating any provision of this
article shall be fined not less then twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 268/735
on which a violation occurs or continues. Complaints for violation of provisions of this article may be
brought to the administrative hearing officer. (Ord. 12-2000, § 1, 2-14-2000)
Chapter 9
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 1, 2
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 9-1. Definitions:
Whenever in this chapter the following terms are used, they shall have the meanings respectively
ascribed to them in this section:
Loading Zone : That space or area defined by ordinance as being reserved for the exclusive use of
vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials.
Parkway : That part of the street which lies between the property line and the curb.
Property Line : The line marking the boundary between any street and the lots or property abutting
thereon.
Public Building : A building used by the city or by any park district, school district, the state of Illinois
or the United States government. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. I)
Sec. 9-2. Penalty 3:
Except as otherwise provided herein:
Any individual violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than two hundred dollars
($200.00) or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months for any offense.
Any firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than two
hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. X)
Sec. 9-3. Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted 4:
The provisions of the Illinois vehicle code, as amended, except for those provisions which by their nature
can have no application to the city, are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter with
the same force and effect as if set forth at length herein. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any
of the provisions of the Illinois vehicle code.

Sec. 9-4. Miscellaneous Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any ordinance establishing or
eliminating stop intersections, yield right of way intersections, bus stops, through streets, cab stands or
other motor vehicle or traffic restrictions at specific locations, or authorizing traffic signals, or prohibiting
a right turn on a red light, or relating to a mass transit district; and all such ordinances are hereby
recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this code.
This chapter is intended to and shall be in addition to all other ordinances, rules and regulations
concerning traffic, parking and the use of the streets, and shall not be taken to repeal any other
ordinance or part of any ordinance unless in direct conflict therewith. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. XII)
Sec. 9-5. Tickets:
For offenses other than driving while intoxicated or reckless driving, police officers, after making note of
the license number of the vehicle (and name of the offender where possible), may issue a traffic violation
ticket notifying the offender to appear in court at the time designated for hearing such cases. Such
officer may sign a complaint for the issuance of a warrant if the offender does not appear at the time and
place so specified. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. X)
Sec. 9-6. Riding On Fenders, Etc.:
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon the fenders, hood, top, running boards or outside step of
any vehicle. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. IV)
Sec. 9-7. Toy Vehicles Generally:
It shall be unlawful for any person upon skates or a coaster, sled or other toy vehicle to go upon any
roadway other than at a crosswalk. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. IV)
Sec. 9-8. Vehicles Prohibited On Certain Streets:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any truck, except for the purpose of making a delivery and
then for one block only, on any street so designated by ordinance and properly signposted. For the
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 270/735
purposes of this section the term "truck" refers to any truck required to have a class "D" license under
the provisions of the Illinois vehicle code. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. VII; Ord. 88-57, § 1, 9-1-1988)
Sec. 9-9. Scene Of Fire:
The fire department officer in command, or any fireman designated by him, may exercise the powers
and authority of a policeman in directing traffic at the scene of any fire or where the fire department has
responded to any emergency call for so long as fire department equipment is on the scene, in the
absence of or in assisting the police. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. I)
Sec. 9-9.1. Sound Amplification Systems:
(a)Prohibited : No driver of any motor vehicle within the city of Rock Island shall operate or permit the
operation of any sound amplification system which can be heard outside the vehicle from seventy
five feet (75') or more, when the vehicle is present upon a highway, unless such system is being
operated to request assistance or warn of a hazardous situation. This section does not apply to
authorized emergency vehicles.
(b)Penalty : Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than
seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00). In the event a
person accused with a violation of this section does not wish to contest the allegation, said person
may pay to the city of Rock Island police headquarters, within seven (7) days of the issuance of the
notice of violation, a penalty in the sum of seventy five dollars ($75.00), which payment shall be in full
satisfaction of the violation. (Ord. 98-87, § 1, 10-26-1998; Ord. 98-90, § 1, 11-2-1998; Ord. 72-2001,
§ 1, 9-17-2001)
Sec. 9-9.2. Unlawful Use Of Electronic Communication Devices:
(a)As used in this section "electronic communication device" means an electronic device, including, but
not limited to, a handheld wireless telephone, handheld personal digital assistant, or a portable or
mobile computer, but does not include a global positioning system or navigation system or a device
that is physically or electronically integrated into the motor vehicle.
(b)A person may not operate a motor vehicle on a roadway while using an electronic communication
device.
(c)This section does not apply to:
(1) A law enforcement officer or operator of an emergency vehicle while performing his or her official
duties;
(2) A driver using an electronic communication device for the sole purpose of reporting an
emergency situation and continued communication with emergency personnel during the emergency
situation;
(3) A driver using an electronic communication device in hands free or voice operated mode, which
may include the use of a headset;
(4) A driver of a commercial motor vehicle reading a message displayed on a permanently installed
communication device designed for a commercial motor vehicle with a screen that does not exceed
ten inches tall by ten inches wide (10" x 10") in size;
(5) A driver using an electronic communication device while parked on the shoulder of a roadway;
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 271/735
(6) A driver using an electronic communication device when the vehicle is stopped due to normal
traffic being obstructed and the driver has the motor vehicle transmission in neutral or park;
(7) A driver using two-way or citizens band radio services;
(8) A driver using two-way mobile radio transmitters or receivers for licensees of the federal
communications commission in the amateur radio service;
(9) A driver using an electronic communication device by pressing a single button to initiate or
terminate a voice communication; or
(10) A driver using an electronic communication device capable of performing multiple functions,
other than a handheld wireless telephone or handheld personal digital assistant (for example, a fleet
management system, dispatching device, citizens band radio, or music player) for a purpose that is
not otherwise prohibited by this section.
(d)A person who violates this section shall be fined a maximum of seventy five dollars ($75.00). In the
event a person is accused of a violation and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a
complaint is issued for the violation, then the person so accused may pay to the city, at police
headquarters, a penalty in the sum of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for and in full satisfaction of the
violation. (Ord. 029-2014, 3-24-2014)
Sec. 9-10. Bicycles-Bicycle Sales-Registration:
(a)Bicycle Dealer's License : It shall be unlawful to deal in sales of three (3) or more bicycles within any
calendar year without a bicycle dealer's license. "Bicycle", for the purpose of this section, is any
bicycle twenty inches (20") or more in size.
(b)License Procedure:
(1) License Application: The application for a license hereunder shall be made in writing to the City
Clerk on a form provided by the City Clerk's Office. Licenses are nontransferable.
(2) License Fee: The license fee for a bicycle dealer's license shall be free and the license shall
remain in effect from the date of issue until the business is closed, sold, or ownership is transferred.
(c)Mandatory Registration Of Bicycles: It shall be mandatory for all bicycle dealers dealing in the retail
sale of bicycles within the City, to register all bicycles size twenty inches (20") and over at the time of
sale. The registration forms and bicycle license plates shall be made available to the businesses at
no cost through the Police Department. The completed registration forms shall be picked up twice a
month by a member of the Police Department. It shall be the responsibility of the business owner
and/or manager to notify the Police Department if they are in need of additional registration forms
and/or license plates. Persons registering a bicycle at the bicycle dealer or at police headquarters
shall not be charged a fee.
(d)Fine: Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of these ordinances relating to
bicycle dealer's license and procedures shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(e)Operation Of A Bicycle Without A License: No person who resides within this City shall ride or propel
a bicycle on any street, highway, road, etc., or upon any public way set aside for the exclusive use of
bicycles unless such bicycle has been licensed and a license plate is attached thereto as provided
herein. That in the event a bicycle has been purchased outside the corporate limits of the City or was
sold within the City and has not been processed for a license plate as set forth above, the bicycle
shall be licensed through the procedure set below:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 272/735
(1) Registration Agency: Applications for registration should be issued by the Chief of Police.
(2) Application Form: The application for a bicycle license shall be on a form provided by the City.
(3) Proof Of Ownership: The Chief of Police shall refuse to issue a license where he has reason to
believe the applicant is not the owner of, or entitled to possession of, the bicycle.
(4) Inspection: The Chief of Police or an officer assigned such responsibility shall inspect each
bicycle before licensing the same and shall refuse a license for any bicycle which he determines is in
unsafe mechanical condition.
(5) Registration Plate Or Tag: Upon issuing a bicycle license, the Chief of Police must also issue a
plate or tag, which shall be firmly attached to the bicycle in a manner as to be plainly visible from the
rear.
(6) Records: The Chief of Police shall keep a record of the number of each license, the date issued,
the name and address of the person to whom issued and the number on the frame of the bicycle for
which issued.
(7) Duration-Transfer Of Ownership; Renewal: A bicycle license shall remain valid as long as it
remains the property of the initial owner. If sold, traded, given away, etc., the new owner shall
reregister the bicycle in their name.
(8) Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) or more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). In the event a person
accused with a violation of this section who does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time
that complaint is issued for said violation, said person may pay to the City at the Rock Island police
headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for and in full satisfaction of said
violation. In the event a person is found guilty of violating the provisions of this section a second or
more time, he or she shall be fined in an amount equal the minimal fine. (1963 Code art. 11-8; Ord.,
2-23-1976; Ord., 8-14-1978; Ord. 96-64, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-69, 7-28-1997)
Sec. 9-11. Car Owner Responsibility Assignment:
This chapter is declared necessary for the preservation of the public peace, health, safety and welfare of
the people of the City, and is intended to address a public nuisance created by individuals operating
motor vehicles upon the streets and highways of this City. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-
1997)
Sec. 9-12. Public Nuisance:
(a)A motor vehicle that is used in the violation of any of the offenses contained in this section shall be
declared a public nuisance and the owner of record shall be subject to having said vehicle
impounded for lengths of impoundment described in section 9-13 of this article and shall also be
liable to the City for the penalties indicated in section 9-13 of this article to include the fees for the
towing and storage of the vehicle and fines.
(1) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle who is in violation of section 9-9.1
of this article.
(2) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle where the windows of the motor
vehicle are obstructed in violation of the Illinois Vehicle Code 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-
503(a) and (b).
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 273/735
(3) The driver of a motor vehicle who is in violation of the Illinois Vehicle Code 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/6-101 entitled "Drivers Must Have Licenses and Permits" and the violator has an invalid
driver's license or the violator's driver's license has been expired for more than six (6) months.
(4) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is in violation of section 10-90,
"Truancy Prohibited", of this Code.
(5) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is in violation of 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 555/1 - Child Curfew Act and/or subsection 10-59(a) of this Code, entitled "Curfew
for Persons Under Seventeen Years of Age".
(6) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle while being twenty (20) years of
age or younger is in possession of alcohol in violation of subsection 3-10(c), "Purchase And
Consumption By Minors Prohibited", of this Code.
(7) The driver of a motor vehicle who is in violation of the Illinois Vehicle Code 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/6-303 entitled "Driving While Driver's License, Permit Or Privilege to Operate a Motor
Vehicle Is Suspended Or Revoked".
(8) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is in violation of the Illinois
Cannabis Control Act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/4(a), (b), (c), (d) or (e), entitled "Possession
of Cannabis" and/or Illinois Cannabis Control Act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/5(a), (b), (c), (d)
and (e), entitled "Manufacture Or Delivery of Cannabis". Possession of cannabis up to ten grams (10
g) shall not be subject to this section.
(9) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle who is in violation of the Illinois
Vehicle Code 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501 entitled "Driving While Under the Influence of
Alcohol, Other Drug Or Drugs, Intoxicating Compound Or Compounds Or Any Combination Thereof".
(10) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is in violation of the Illinois
Criminal Code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1(a)(4), entitled "Unlawful Use of Weapons".
(11) The motor vehicle is used in the commission of, or attempt to commit a violation of Illinois
Criminal Code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.2, entitled "Aggravated Discharge of a Firearm"
and/or Illinois Criminal Code, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.5, entitled "Reckless Discharge of
a Firearm".
(12) The driver or any other person in possession of a motor vehicle is in violation of the Illinois
Controlled Substances Act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/402, entitled "Possession
Unauthorized by This Act".
(13) The motor vehicle unlawfully flees or attempts to flee and elude a peace officer in violation of the
Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-204 or 5/11-204.1.
(b)The driver or other person in possession of the motor vehicle shall be arrested or cited for the
violations of the State Statute(s) or City ordinance(s) as indicated in subsections (a)(1) through (a)
(13) of this section. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997; Ord. 98-88, 10-26-1998; Ord. 72-
2001, 9-17-2001; Ord. 18-2004, 2-2-2004; Ord. 051-2012, 7-23-2012; Ord. 024-2018, 6-11-2018)
