Sec. 9-14. Fines And Subsequent Violations:
All lengths of impoundment and fines imposed shall double upon any subsequent violation of this article.
(Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997)
Sec. 9-14.1. Impoundment With Respect To Sound Amplification Systems
Violations:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this or other ordinances, there shall be no impoundment of an
owner's vehicle for the vehicle's operation as a public nuisance in violation of subsection 9-12(a)(1) of
this chapter when that vehicle has not been so operated as a public nuisance in violation of subsection
9-12(a)(1) of this chapter for a period of two (2) or more years. However, the owner of a vehicle that is
not impounded because of the preceding sentence shall pay a fine of seventy five dollars ($75.00) if the
vehicle is found to have been operated as a public nuisance in violation of subsection 9-12(a)(1) of this
chapter. For second and subsequent operations of a given owner's vehicle as a public nuisance in
violation of subsection 9-12(a)(1) of this chapter that occur within two (2) years of the most recent
violation of that section, all other provisions of sections 9-11 through 9-20 of this chapter shall be fully
operable. (Ord. 72-2001, § 1, 9-17-2001)
Sec. 9-15. Seizure, Impoundment And Hearings Request:
Whenever a police officer has reasonable suspicion to believe that a vehicle is subject to seizure and
impoundment pursuant to this article, the police officer shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a
facility controlled by the City or its agents. When the vehicle is towed, the police officer shall notify the
person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation, if there is such a
person, and the owner of said vehicle of the fact of the seizure and the vehicle owner's right to post a
cash bond as indicated in subsections 9-16(a)(1) through (a)(6) of this chapter to retrieve possession of
their vehicle pending a hearing to be held by the City's Code Hearing Officer. When the vehicle is not
impounded for a first offense pursuant to section 9-14.1 of this chapter, the police officer shall notify the
vehicle's owner that second and subsequent uses of the vehicle as a public nuisance in violation of
subsection 9-12(a)(1) of this chapter that occur within two (2) years of the most recent use as a public
nuisance shall result in the impoundment of the vehicle pursuant to this section. The notification shall
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 275/735
also explain the vehicle owner's right to a hearing with respect to the alleged violation. When a vehicle is
impounded, the officer shall also notify the owner and person in control of the vehicle of the owner's right
to a probable cause hearing as set forth in subsection 9-17(i) of this chapter. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996;
Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997; Ord. 72-2001, § 1, 9-17-2001)
Sec. 9-15.1. Vehicle Involved In An Unlawful Attempt To Flee And Elude A Peace
Officer:
(a)Declared A Nuisance: A vehicle involved in an unlawful attempt to flee and elude a peace officer in
violation of section 11-204 or 11-204.1 of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code 1 and is not immediately
stopped by the police and the driver placed under arrest is declared to be a public nuisance under
subsection 9-12(a)(13) of this chapter and said vehicle is subject to being immediately towed by the
police.
(b)Vehicle Subject To Seizure And Impoundment: Whenever a police officer has observed a vehicle
engaged in an unlawful attempt to flee and elude and believes that there exists probable cause to
tow said vehicle, and locates said vehicle on a public thoroughfare or within a parking lot under City
ordinance control or a parking lot open to the general public within the City of Rock Island, Illinois,
before the end of his or her watch, then said vehicle may be seized and impounded by the Rock
Island Ppolice Department. Notice shall be given to the person in control of the vehicle and the owner
of the vehicle as described in subsection (g) of this section.
(c)Incident Report: Whenever a police officer has observed a vehicle engaged in an unlawful attempt to
flee and elude and said vehicle is not located by the police before the end of his or her watch, said
officer shall at the end of his or her watch prepare a written incident report which provides a record, if
possible, of the make, model, year, color, state of registration, license plate number, identification of
the driver, location of the incident and the date and time of the incident. Said report shall include
information sufficient to support the determination of probable cause to tow, including information of
the officer's attempts to stop the vehicle at the time of the occurrence, and that the driver failed or
refused to stop after the officer activated the squad car's emergency signal equipment and that
pursuit of the vehicle was abandoned for public safety reasons.
(d)Interim Seizure: Upon completion of the report, the officer shall give the report to the watch
commander or his or her designee for interim seizure and impoundment authorization of said vehicle.
Once authorized, said vehicle may be seized and impounded by police based upon the reporting
officer's probable cause for a period of ninety six (96) hours prior to the filing of a "notice of intent to
impound" as described in subsection (e) of this section. If said vehicle is towed within the ninety six
(96) hour period and before a "notice of intent to tow" is filed as described in subsection (e) of this
section, notice shall be given to the person in control of the vehicle and the owner of the vehicle as
described in subsection (g) of this section. "Notice of intent to tow" under subsection (e) of this
section may be filed at any time after the officer prepares his or her written incident report.
(e)Notice Of Intent To Impound: If said vehicle is not located within ninety six (96) hours, the police
department may file a "notice of intent to impound" with the administrative clerk of MUNICES. Once
filed, said vehicle may be seized and impounded by police if located on a public thoroughfare or
within a parking lot under city ordinance control, or a parking lot open to the general public within the
city of Rock Island, Illinois, pending a plenary hearing as described in subsection 9-17(b) of this
chapter. The notice of intent to impound shall include the following information:
(1) A statement that the operator on the date, time, and approximate location of the incident in
question failed or refused to stop operation of the vehicle when ordered to do so by the police officer;
(2) A description of the vehicle as contained in the police officer's report;
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 276/735
(3) Notice that a plenary hearing on the merits to contest the eligibility for impoundment of the motor
vehicle shall be scheduled on a specified date at one o'clock (1:00) P.M. in the city hall chambers of
the city of Rock Island, Illinois, 1528 3rd Avenue, Rock Island, Illinois. Said hearing date shall be
scheduled as described in subsection 9-17(b) of this chapter;
(4) Notice that if said vehicle, as described in the notice of intent to impound, is located on a public
thoroughfare or within a parking lot under city ordinance control or a parking lot open to the general
public within the city of Rock Island, Illinois, at any time prior to the scheduled plenary hearing as
described in subsection (e)(3) of this section, that said vehicle is subject to immediate impoundment
and seizure;
(5) That the owner is entitled to have a preliminary hearing and/or post bond to retrieve the vehicle
prior to the scheduled plenary hearing as described in subsection (g) of this section.
(f)Delivery Of Notice: Upon filing the "notice of intent to impound" with the administrative clerk of
MUNICES, notice shall be sent by regular mail to the vehicle's owner of record. The notice is
presumed delivered upon it being deposited with the United States postal service with proper
postage being affixed thereto.
(g)Preliminary Hearing And Posting Of Bond:
(1) Whenever any officer of the Rock Island police department has probable cause to believe that a
vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to subsection (b), (d) or (e) of this section,
and said vehicle is located on a public thoroughfare or within a parking lot under city ordinance
control or a parking lot open to the general public within the city of Rock Island, Illinois, said officer
shall seize said vehicle and provide for its towing and impoundment. When the vehicle is towed the
officer shall notify the person in control of the vehicle and the owner of the vehicle of the owner's right
to request a preliminary hearing to determine if there was probable cause to believe that a driver of
said vehicle was involved in an unlawful attempt to flee and elude a police officer and of his or her
right to post a cash bond as indicated in section 9-16(a)(7) of this chapter to retrieve possession of
said vehicle prior to any preliminary hearings or plenary hearings on the merits. Notice shall also be
given to the owner of said vehicle of the date and time of the plenary hearing on the merits as
described in subsection 9-17(b) of this chapter. All hearings on the merits will be held on the
scheduled date and time in the city hall chambers of the city of Rock Island, Illinois.
(2) All requests for preliminary hearing shall be in writing and delivered to the Rock Island police
department within twenty four (24) hours of the seizure. All preliminary hearings shall be held within
seventy two (72) hours, excluding weekends and holidays, after the written request for hearing is
delivered to the police department.
(3) All preliminary hearings will be conducted by the administrative code hearing officer.
(4) The vehicle so seized shall be impounded pending completion of any preliminary hearings or
plenary hearings on the merits and for the minimum time of impoundment set by subsection 9-13(a)
(7) of this chapter if a violation of this section is found.
(5) If, after proceeding with a preliminary hearing, the administrative hearing officer determines there
was probable cause to tow, or if no timely request for preliminary hearing is filed by the owner, said
matter will be scheduled for plenary hearing on the merits. Said hearing date shall proceed as
described in subsection 9-17(b) of this chapter.
(6) All hearings conducted under this section shall proceed in accordance with the rules and
procedures described in subsections 9-17(b) through (h) of this chapter. (Ord. 051-2012, 7-23-2012)

Sec. 9-17. Hearing And Notification:
(a)Within ten (10) business days after a vehicle is seized and impounded pursuant to this article, or not
impounded by operation of section 9-14.1 of this chapter, the city shall notify by certified mail, return
receipt requested, the owner of record, any lienholders or other legally entitled persons of the date,
time and location of a hearing that will be conducted pursuant to this section. When the city does not
know the identity of the registered owner, lienholder or other legally entitled person, the city will
cause the vehicle registration records of the state of Illinois to be searched by the secretary of state
for purposes of obtaining the required ownership information.
(b)A hearing shall be scheduled and held, unless continued by order of the city code hearing officer, on
the first and third Friday of each month on the Friday following the day the vehicle was seized if not
within seven (7) days. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at
the hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing and hearsay evidence shall
be admissible. The hearing shall be open to the public and a court reporter shall transcribe the
proceedings. If the city of Rock Island shall enter into an intergovernmental agreement providing for
the shared use of the code enforcement hearing officer, the notice and hearing date rules established
pursuant to the intergovernmental agreement shall apply to this subsection.
(c)If, after the hearing, the city code hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that
the vehicle had been stolen prior to the alleged violation, he shall enter an order dismissing the
procedure. If, however, he determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was not
stolen prior to the violation, he shall enter an order requiring the vehicle to continue to be impounded
for the applicable length of time provided for in this section and until the owner pays the fees
imposed under sections 9-13 and 9-14 of this chapter if the vehicle is still in the custody of the city. If
the vehicle is not in the city's custody then subsection (d) of this section shall apply.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 278/735
(d)If a bond had been posted and the owner has possession of the vehicle, the city code hearing officer
shall enter an order deducting the fees imposed under sections 9-13 and 9-14 of this chapter as if the
vehicle was actually held for the time period specified from the cash bond that was posted.
(e)In the event the defendant wishes to appeal the decision of the city code hearing officer under the
provisions of the administrative review act, said defendant shall pay the cost of the preparation and
transcription of the record of the hearing and shall appeal to the circuit court.
(f)If the city code hearing officer determines that there is no such probable cause, the vehicle will be
returned without penalty or other fees.
(g)The penalty and fees shall be a debt due and owed to the city. However, if a cash bond has been
posted the bond shall be applied to the fine. If the city code hearing officer determines that the
vehicle was not used with the permission, express or implied, of the owner, he or she shall order the
return of the vehicle or cash bond. In the event it shall become necessary for the city to collect the
debt by filing an action in the circuit court, they shall be entitled to recover, in addition to the amount
due, court costs and reasonable attorney fees.
(h)Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, any lienholder of record may obtain possession
of any seized and impounded vehicles they have a legal lien interest in by: 1) submitting to the city
verified proof that they have commenced foreclosure proceedings against the registered owner of
said vehicle, 2) payment of the towing and storage fees for the periods of time said vehicle was to be
held under section 9-13 of this chapter and 3) providing a written agreement to refund to the city the
net proceeds of any foreclosure sale, over and above the amounts necessary to satisfy any liens, to
be applied by the city to satisfy any penalties and costs imposed under sections 9-13 and 9-14 of this
chapter.
(i)In addition to the hearing procedures set forth in the preceding subsections of this section, every
owner who has his or her car impounded pursuant to this chapter shall be entitled to a probable
cause hearing before the city's code hearing officer, or if he or she is not available, before an
impartial Illinois licensed attorney at law, on the question of whether or not the vehicle has been
operated as a public nuisance in violation of section 9-12(a) of this chapter. This hearing, if
requested, shall occur no later than two (2) business days from the time of the owner's request for
such a hearing. The owner's request for a probable cause hearing must be made in writing to the city
of Rock Island police department within three (3) days of receiving notice of the right to such a
probable cause hearing. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997; Ord. 98-57, § 1, 8-24-1998;
Ord. 33-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 72-2001, § 1, 9-17-2001; Ord. 081-2010, 12-13-2010)
Sec. 9-18. Unclaimed Vehicles:
Any motor vehicle that is not reclaimed within thirty (30) days after the expiration of the time during
which the owner of record may seek judicial review of the city's action under this article, or the time at
which a final judgment is rendered in favor of the city, or the time a final administrative decision is
rendered against an owner of record who is in default may be disposed of as an unclaimed vehicle as
provided by law. As used in this article, the "owner of record" of a vehicle means the record titleholder.
(Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996; Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997)
Sec. 9-19. Fees And Storage:
Fees for towing and storage of a vehicle under this article shall be the same as those charged per the
contract for towing service with the city in effect at the time of same violation. (Ord. 96-66, 9-16-1996;
Ord. 97-50, 7-14-1997)

ARTICLE II. PARKING 1
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 9-26. Penalty:
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, any person who violates any of the parking ordinances of the
city, other than a private parking ordinance violation, a zoned parking ordinance violation, or a violation
of downtown restricted parking use ordinance, and who receives a ticket therefor, shall pay a fine of
twenty dollars ($20.00). In the event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice,
the operator of the vehicle shall pay as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of
forty dollars ($40.00). Any person violating the private parking ordinance in the city shall pay a fine of
twenty five dollars ($25.00). In the event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the
notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the
sum of forty five dollars ($45.00). Any person who violates any of the parking ordinances of the city at a
location where tow away placards have been posted on parking control signs shall pay a fine of fifty
dollars ($50.00). In the event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the
operator of the vehicle shall pay as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of
seventy dollars ($70.00). Any person who receives a ticket for parking at any curb within five feet (5') of
a fire hydrant shall pay a fine of thirty five dollars ($35.00). In the event the fine is not paid within seven
(7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay as a penalty for and in full
satisfaction of such violation the sum of fifty five dollars ($55.00). This section shall not apply to
provisions in this article with different penalties from the above. All fines for parking violations may be
paid by credit card by calling the finance department for the city of Rock Island, Illinois. An additional five
dollar ($5.00) processing fee will be charged for this service. (Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-27. Miscellaneous Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any ordinance prohibiting or
regulating parking on specified public or private property, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized
as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this code. (Ord. 92-12, 1-
20-1992)
Sec. 9-28. Liability Of Owner:
Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any of the provisions of this article, the
person in whose name such vehicle is registered, as well as the operator of the vehicle and the vehicle
itself, shall be subject to the penalty for such violation. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Arts. X and XII; Ord. 92-12,
1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-29. Unattended Vehicles:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 280/735
No vehicle shall be left unattended while the motor of such vehicle is running, and no vehicle shall be left
without a driver on any hill or incline unless the vehicle is secured against moving. (1963 Code, Ch. XI,

Sec. 9-30. Impoundment Of Vehicles Generally:
(a)An unattended vehicle stopped, standing or parked, or occupying any portion of any street, in
violation of any of the provisions of any of the ordinances of the city, including, without limitation,
traffic and parking ordinances and nontraffic ordinances such as those prohibiting the obstruction of a
fire hydrant, or left parked overnight in any city parking lot is hereby declared to be a nuisance, which
may be abated by any agent or employee of the city designated to enforce the parking ordinances of
the city by impounding such vehicle and by removing and conveying such vehicle or by causing such
vehicle to be removed and conveyed to a vehicle pound. A vehicle pound is hereby declared to be
any suitable place designated by the city as a vehicle pound. The owner or operator of such vehicle
may have the same removed from the impoundment by paying the costs and expenses of the
towage and impounding of such vehicle, together with all fines and penalties, as provided in this
chapter.
(b)In all cases of violations herein referred to, the right to impound shall be in addition to any other
remedy provided in this chapter, or any other remedy provided by law. Whenever any vehicle, while
being used without the consent of the owner, shall be stopped, standing, or parked in violation of any
of the provisions of this chapter, such owner shall not be subject to the penalty for such violations.
(1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. X; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 93-11, 3-1-1993)

(Rep. by Ord. 39-00, § 1, 6-26-2000)

Sec. 9-32. No Parking Places:
At any time it shall be unlawful for any person to permit any vehicle to stand in any of the following
places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a
policeman or traffic signal:
(1) In any intersection.
(2) In a crosswalk.
(3) Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or the approach thereto.
(4) Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet (30') of a point on the curb
immediately opposite the end of a safety zone.
(5) Within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal or a through street sign on the approaching side.
(6) Within twenty feet (20') of any intersection.
(7) At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable width of the roadway for
moving traffic to less than eighteen feet (18').
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 281/735
(8) At any curb within five feet (5') of a fire hydrant.
(9) At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway.
(10) Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade crossing.
(11) Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire department station and on the side
of the street opposite the entrance to any such station within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance.
(12) On any sidewalk or parkway except as provided in section 9-33 of this division.
(13) At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
(14) At any bus stop.
(15) On any bicycle or pedestrian path.
(16) In a Rock Island city park in violation of posted parking requirements. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art.
VI; Ord., 5-19-1975; Ord., 12-15-1975; Ord., 1-9-1978; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 93-11, 3-1-1993;
Ord. 030-2007, § 1, 4-23-2007)
Sec. 9-33. Parking On Public Property:
Parking of motor vehicles may be allowed on parkways, boulevards or other areas of dedicated right of
way not being used as part of the traveled way when authorized by special ordinance. Such ordinance
may place conditions, restrictions and limitations on parking. (Ord., 1-9-1978; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-34. Cabstands; Bus Stands; Limited Parking At Bus Stops:
(a)Generally : No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated by special
ordinance as a cabstand, and no vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated
as a bus loading zone except as provided in subsection (b) of this section.
(b)Limited Parking At Bus Stops; Signs :
(1) The following bus stop parking locations located in the city may hereinafter be used for open
parking after seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. each day.
a. Downtown, as being bounded by 15th Street on the west, 24th Street on the east, 1st Avenue
on the north and 5th Avenue on the south, and including twenty one (21) bus stops.
b. At 1230 30th Street.
c. On 14th Avenue at 40th Street.
(2) If a bus parking location is to be available at certain times for public parking, signs shall be added
below the bus stop signs indicating the times that the bus parking location is available for public
parking and any applicable parking time limitations. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. VI; Ord. 89-11, 3-20-
1989; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-35. Parking At Curb:
No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle next to the curb except on one-way streets
where parking is permitted on both sides thereof, and it shall be unlawful for any person to stand or park
any vehicle in a street other than parallel with the curb and with the right hand wheels of the vehicle
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 282/735
within twelve inches (12") of the regularly established curb; except that upon those streets that have

marks with the front wheels at the curb. Trucks may back to the curb for the purpose of loading or
unloading for actual periods of time necessary for loading or unloading, but in no case shall they
interfere with the movement of traffic. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. VI; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)

Sec. 9-37. Loading Zones:
(a) During the times specified in this section, it shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a
passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of
passengers, not to exceed three (3) minutes, and for the driver to stand any vehicle of the second
division, as defined by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-217, being used for carrying freight, goods,
wares or merchandise for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials,
not to exceed thirty (30) minutes, in any of the following places:
(1) In any public alley during any hour of the day or night except that the delivery vehicle shall not
block access to and from the alley at any time.
(2) At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb before the entrance to any hotel
at any time.
(3) At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb before the entrance to a public
building, between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M., except on Sunday.
(4) Directly in front of the entrance to any theater for the purpose of loading or unloading of
passengers or for the purpose of purchasing theater tickets for a period not to exceed three (3)
minutes.
(5) At any other location in the city as is designated by special ordinance. Such ordinance may
designate the hours that the area shall be used as a loading zone. At any other time, the area can be
used generally for parking.
(b)Any person operating a vehicle other than a second division vehicle to pick up or deliver goods or
merchandise may apply at the finance department for a permit to display in the windshield stating
that the vehicle is an authorized delivery vehicle. Such permit will be granted when proof of such use
is presented to the finance department and upon payment of a ten dollar ($10.00) fee per year.
(c)Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined fifteen dollars ($15.00). In the
event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle
shall pay as the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of thirty five dollars
($35.00). (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. VI; Ord., 8-30-1971; Ord., 1-26-1976; Ord., 5-2-1977; Ord., 9-25-
1978; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 100-2001, § 1, 12-17-2001; Ord. 20-2002, § 1, 3-18-2002; Ord.

Sec. 9-38. Alleys:
No person shall park a vehicle within an alley except as provided in section 9-37 of this chapter and shall
then park only in such manner or under such conditions as to leave available not less than ten feet (10')
of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic; and no person shall stop, stand or
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 283/735
park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property.

Sec. 9-39. Double Parking:
It shall be unlawful for any person to double park any vehicle in the city at any time. Any person violating
this provision shall be fined fifteen dollars ($15.00). In the event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days
of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in full satisfaction of
such violation the sum of thirty five dollars ($35.00). (Ord. 005-2010, § 3, 1-18-2010; Ord. 058-2015, 12-
14-2015)
Sec. 9-40. Fire Lanes:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on any area designated as a fire lane by special
ordinance in the city. Any agent or employee of the city designated to enforce the parking ordinances of
the city is hereby authorized to cause any motor vehicle parked in a fire lane in this city to be towed from
the fire lane. In such a case, the owner of the vehicle shall be assessed the cost of towing and any
storage charges in relation thereto plus a fine of thirty five dollars ($35.00). In the event the fine is not
paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay the penalty for
and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of fifty five dollars ($55.00). (Ord. 013-2011, 2-21-2011;
Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-41. Snow Removal 1:
(a)In the event of two inches (2") or more of snow, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or allow a
motor vehicle to remain on any street or avenue in the central business district between the hours of
ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. The "central business district" shall be defined as
the area circumscribed by and including the following:
1st Avenue, 14th Street to 21st Street
5th Avenue, 14th Street to 21st Street
14th Street, 1st Avenue to 5th Avenue
21st Street, 1st Avenue to 5th Avenue
(b)In the event of two inches (2") or more of snow, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or allow a
motor vehicle to remain on any marked snow route until the snow has been cleared.
(c)This section shall affect other parking restriction ordinances that are presently in effect in the city,
except bus stop and loading zone ordinances.
(d)Whenever the city manager or mayor perceives an emergency to exist in the city or in any section or
sections thereof because of snow, freezing rain, sleet, ice, snowdrifts or other natural phenomena
which create hazardous conditions or impede the free movement of fire, police, health, emergency or
other vehicular traffic or otherwise endanger the safety and welfare of the public, the city manager or
mayor may declare an emergency to exist. Notice of the existence of an emergency and the terms
and termination thereof shall be given to the print, radio and television media, which shall be
requested to cooperate with the city in the dissemination of such information to the public. When
given, such notice shall constitute due and proper notice of the emergency and the terms and
conditions thereof.

(e)Any agent or employee of the city designated to enforce the parking ordinances of the city is hereby
authorized to cause any motor vehicle in violation of this section to be towed from any snow route. In
such a case the owner of the vehicle may be assessed the cost of towing and any storage charges in
relation thereto plus a fine of thirty five dollars ($35.00). In the event the fine is not paid within seven
(7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in full

Sec. 9-42. Parking On Private Property 2:
(a)No person, firm or corporation shall park a motor vehicle on private property controlled by a private
parking ordinance passed by the city council without the consent of the property owner. The owner of
said property shall pay an annual fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to the city of Rock Island
and shall post a sign or signs on said premises indicating that:
(1) Parking is prohibited without the consent of the property owner;
(2) Parking a motor vehicle without the consent of the property owner is a violation of city ordinance;
(3) The owner of any vehicle violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of twenty
five dollars ($25.00); and
(4) Any vehicle violating the provisions of this section may be impounded and the owner of the
vehicle shall be responsible for all costs of the towing and impoundment.
The size, design, number and location of these signs shall be approved by the Rock Island public
works department.
(b)The owner of any vehicle violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of twenty five
dollars ($25.00). In the event that the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice,
the owner of the vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum
of forty five dollars ($45.00).
Any vehicle violating the provisions of this section may be impounded as described in section 9-30 of
this chapter. (Ord., 2-19-1979; Ord. 87-54, 4-6-1987; Ord. 91-13, 2-11-1991; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992;

Sec. 9-43. Parking Large Trucks In Residential Zones:

thousand (10,000) pounds or more, abutting or adjacent to any lot zoned under residential

(2) Park a garbage or refuse truck on any public or private property in the city unless the property is
zoned I-1 or I-2, as defined in the zoning ordinance of the city.
(b)Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of twenty dollars ($20.00).
In the event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice, the operator of the

vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of forty dollars
($40.00).
(c)For each day that any such truck remains parked in such an area, it shall be considered a separate

Sec. 9-44. Parking Enforcement Attendants; Positions Created:
There is hereby created the position of parking enforcement attendant. A sufficient number of attendants
shall be employed. These attendants may be employed by the city or may be third party contract
employees. These attendants shall issue parking tickets against any person or persons violating any of
the rules, regulations or ordinances pertaining to parking as set forth in this article. Such parking tickets
shall be placed upon the windshield of any motor vehicle found parked in violation of such regulations
and ordinances. The attendants shall not be members of the police department, nor shall they have the
power to make arrests or direct or regulate traffic; but their authorization and duties shall be limited
strictly to those set forth in this section. (Ord. 052-2014, 7-14-2014)
Sec. 9-45. Impoundment For Unpaid Violations:
(a)Whenever it is determined that any vehicle has accumulated five (5) or more parking tickets or fifty
dollars ($50.00) or more worth of accumulated parking violations as defined in the provisions of this
code, the public works director shall serve notice of such condition to the registered owner of the
vehicle. Service may be made by certified or registered mail or by personal service. The notice shall
state the date and nature of each ticket and the amount presently due and shall inform the vehicle
owner of the following procedures:
(1) The vehicle owner may obtain a review of the tickets by giving written notice to the public works
director within fifteen (15) days of the date of receipt of the notice of unpaid tickets, requesting a
conference with the public works director.
(2) If within fifteen (15) days of the date of the receipt of the notice of unpaid tickets, the vehicle
owner has not either given written notice requesting a conference or paid the full amount of the
unpaid tickets, it shall be deemed that he has waived the right to a conference, and the full unpaid
amount of the tickets shall be due immediately.
(3) If the vehicle owner fails to either give written notice requesting a conference or to pay the full
amount of the unpaid tickets within the prescribed time period, such vehicle shall be subject to
impoundment.
(b)The public works director shall schedule a conference to be held not less than ten (10) days nor more
than thirty (30) days after receiving written notice from the vehicle owner requesting the conference.
After a review of the tickets at the conference, the public works director shall determine the amount
due up to the full amount of the unpaid tickets and shall inform the vehicle owner of the decision.
Unless other arrangements for the payment are made by the public works director and approved by
the finance director, the amount shall be paid within fifteen (15) days. If, after reaching an agreement
concerning payment of the tickets, the vehicle owner fails to make any payment when due, the
vehicle of such owner shall thereupon be subject to impoundment until all payments then due are
made. The public works director and the finance director shall have full authority to make binding
agreements concerning payments due, if any, and may agree to payments and other terms which
they deem to be in the best interests of the city.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 286/735
(c)When any vehicle owner within fifteen (15) days of the date of receipt of the notice of unpaid tickets
required by subsection (a) of this section has not either paid the full amount of the unpaid tickets or
given written notice to the public works director requesting a conference, or when any vehicle owner
after an agreement with the public works director as described in subsection (b) of this section fails to
make any payment when due and such payment has not yet been made, the vehicle of such owner
thereafter found parked and unattended on a public right of way in the city, within the municipal
parking ramp or within a city parking lot, by any agent or employee of the city designated to enforce
the parking ordinances of the city, may be impounded.
(d)Impoundment shall constitute either impoundment by immobilization or by towing.
(1) Impoundment by immobilization shall be accomplished by the attachment of a mechanical device
such as a denver boot consisting of clamps or jaws and a locking device which, when attached to the
wheel of a vehicle, prevents the vehicle from being driven. If a vehicle that has been impounded by
immobilization has not been reclaimed within twenty four (24) hours, the immobilization device may
be released and the vehicle may be impounded by towing.
(2) Impoundment by towing shall be accomplished by removing and conveying such vehicle or by
causing such vehicle to be removed and conveyed to a vehicle pound. A vehicle pound is hereby
declared to be any suitable place designated by the city as a vehicle pound.
(e)Any vehicle impounded pursuant to the provisions herein may be reclaimed by the registered owner
or operator by appearing at the police department. At such time, the owner or the operator shall sign
a certificate that he/she is the owner or operator of the impounded vehicle, pay all charges and costs
incurred in impounding the vehicle, and pay all outstanding parking fines and late payment penalties.
In lieu of paying these charges, costs, fines, and penalties, the owner or operator may execute a
binding payment agreement. The agreement shall be a standard prepared in advance by the public
works director with the approval of the finance director, and it shall contain a payment schedule and
the penalties for failure to fulfill the conditions of the agreement.
(f)The public works director and finance director may designate others to exercise powers and perform
functions provided in this section.
(g)The fine for impoundment by immobilization shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and the fine for
impoundment by towing shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 92-
112, 8-24-1992; Ord. 08-2003, § 1, 2-10-2003)
Sec. 9-46. Suspension Of Driver's License:
(a)Notice Of Intent To Impound: Once the registered owner of a vehicle has been delivered the notice of
intent to impound a vehicle for unpaid parking violations through certified mail, registered mail, or
personal service and allows the fifteen (15) day time period to expire without seeking further review
or breaks an agreement concerning the payment of tickets, the public works director may initiate
driver's license suspension with the Illinois secretary of state and/or file a petition in the circuit court
to have the unpaid fines and penalties rendered as a judgment in favor of the city.
(b)Notice Of Impending Suspension: A notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent to
the owner for any fine or penalty that remains due and owing on ten (10) or more parking violations.
This notice shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the
secretary of state. Failure to pay the fine or penalty owing within forty five (45) days of the notice's
date will result in the public works director notifying the secretary of state that this person is eligible
for initiation of suspension proceedings.
(c)Report Of Public Works Director: The report of the public works director notifying the secretary of
state of unpaid fines or penalties shall be certified and shall contain the following information:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 287/735
(1) The name, last known address and driver's license of the person who failed to pay the fine or
penalty and the registration number of any vehicle known to be registered to such people in this
state;
(2) The name of the municipality making the report;
(3) A statement that the municipality sent a notice of impending driver's license suspension to the
person named in the report at the address recorded with the secretary of state; the date which the
notice was sent; and the address to which the notice was sent.
(d)Suspension Challenge: The vehicle owner may challenge the notice of impending driver's license
suspension within forty five (45) days of the date of the notice. Challenges will be strictly limited to:
(1) The person not having been the owner or the lessee of the vehicle.
(2) The person having already paid the fine or penalty for the ten (10) or more violations indicated on
the certified report.
(e)Obtain Judgment: The public works director may commence a proceeding in the circuit court for the
purpose of obtaining a judgment after the fifteen (15) day time period during which an administrative
review may be sought. This shall not prevent the city from consolidating multiple license plates or
parking violations against a person in such proceeding. (Ord. 95-27, 4-10-1995)
Sec. 9-47. Increased Fine For Unauthorized Use Of A Parking Place Reserved For
Handicapped Persons:
Any person making an unauthorized use of a parking place reserved for handicapped persons in
violation of the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1303.3 shall be fined the sum of three
hundred fifty dollars ($350.00). (Ord. 013-2011, 2-21-2011)
Sec. 9-48. Parking Unattended Trailers On Public Right Of Way Prohibited:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to park a trailer that is detached from its towing vehicle within any
alley, highway, street, right of way, or public property located within the city.
(b)Every trailer parked in violation of this section is hereby declared to be a nuisance which may be
abated by any police officer or parking enforcement attendant by removing and impounding such
vehicle as described in section 9-30 of this chapter.
(c)A trailer is excepted from this prohibition when it is actively engaged in deliveries, lawn maintenance,
construction or other trade activity upon property immediately abutting the parked trailer. However, at
all times, the roadway shall be free for the passage of other vehicles, traffic control signs and signals
shall not be obstructed and sightlines for intersections shall not be obstructed.
(d)The owner of any vehicle violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of twenty
dollars ($20.00). In the event that the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice,
the owner of the vehicle shall pay as the penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum
of forty dollars ($40.00). (Ord. 35-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 31-2002, § 1, 4-8-2002; Ord. 005-2010, § 8,
1-18-2010; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Secs. 9-49 - 9-80. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. ZONE PARKING
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 288/735
Sec. 9-81. Definitions:
For the purpose of this division, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to
them in this section:
Operator: Every person who shall operate, drive or be in control of any vehicle upon any street.
Park: The standing of any vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon any street for a period of time greater
than is reasonably necessary for the loading or unloading of persons or materials.
Parking Lot: That area of city owned property located off street and designated for the parking of motor
vehicles.
Permit: That authorization issued by the city to operators of vehicles complying with the provisions of this
division.
Street: Any public street, avenue, road, boulevard, highway or other public place located in the city and
established for the use of vehicles.
Vehicle: Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon a street.
A bicycle or motor bicycle shall be termed a vehicle.
Zone: Any area designated and marked for parking of a particular and specific duration. (Ord. 86-70, § 1,
12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-82. Zones Generally:
The city council shall establish parking zones upon such streets of the city as it shall select. The council
may add to, change or abandon such parking zones. In selecting, changing or abandoning such parking
zones, the council shall be guided and governed by location, amount of traffic, demand for parking
spaces, congestion of traffic, use of the street, and other traffic conditions. (Ord. 86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986;
Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-83. Parking Zones Established:
Thirty (30) minute, one hour, two (2) hour and four (4) hour parking zones shall hereby be established
and identified by the placement of appropriate parking control signs within the zones. The establishment
of such zones in no way supersedes the existence of any previously established no parking zones,
loading zones, bus lanes or otherwise restricted parking zones. (Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015; Ord. 023-
2016, 5-9-2016)
Sec. 9-84. Marking Spaces:
The city council shall have lines or markings painted or placed upon the curb or street for the purpose of
designating each parking space, and each vehicle parked at any parking space shall park within the
lines or markings so established. It shall be a violation of this division for any person to park any vehicle
in such a position that the same will not be within the area so designated by such lines or markings.
(Ord. 86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-85. Location Of Vehicle:
When a parking space in any parking zone is parallel with the adjacent curb or sidewalk, any vehicle
parked in such parking space shall be parked with the foremost part of such vehicle alongside of and as
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 289/735
near as is practicable to the front of the parking space. When a parking space in any parked zone is
diagonal to the curb or sidewalk, any vehicle parked in such parking space shall be parked at and as
near as possible to the curb. (Ord. 86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-86. Parking Time Limit - Generally:
Upon entering any posted zone parking space, a vehicle may occupy such space for a period of time not
to exceed the posted time limit for the zone. (Ord. 86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-87. Parking Time Limit - Enforcement:
(a)All parking zones shall be enforced during the times posted in the zone. The parking zones shall not
be enforced on New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth Of July, Labor Day, Veterans Day,
Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Eve Day and Christmas Day.
(b)During these times, enforcement personnel will patrol designated streets. Vehicles which have
occupied any given parking space in excess of the posted parking limitation shall be considered as
parking overtime and beyond the period of legal parking and shall be in violation of this division. (Ord.
86-70, § 1, 12-15-1986; Ord. 92-12, § 1, 1-20-1992; Ord. 92-112, § 4, 8-24-1992)
Sec. 9-88. Overtime Parking, Penalties:
The city council shall hereby adopt the following progressive fine structure for overtime parking
violations:
(1) See section 10-107.11, "Schedule Of Penalties For Ordinance Violations", of this code. (Ord. 013-
2011, 2-21-2011; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-89. Moving Of Vehicles Prohibited:
It shall be unlawful for any person to move any vehicle from any designated zone parking space to any
other such space for the purpose of extending the legal parking limit beyond the posted time limit. Upon
observance of or detection of such offense in accordance with section 9-87 of this chapter, the operator
of the vehicle shall be issued a notice of violation and shall pay a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00). In
the event the fine is not paid within seven (7) days of the date of notice, the operator shall pay as the
penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation the sum of forty five dollars ($45.00). (Ord. 005-2010,
§ 10, 1-18-2010; Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-89.1. Reserved:

Sec. 9-90. Definitions:
For the purpose of this division, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to
them in this section:
Operator: Every person who shall operate, drive or be in control of any vehicle upon any street.
Park: The standing of any vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon any street for a period of time greater
than is reasonably necessary for the loading or unloading of persons or materials.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 290/735
Parking Lot: That area of city owned property located off street and designated for the parking of motor
vehicles.
Permit: That authorization issued by the city to operators of vehicles complying with the provisions of this
division.
Street: Any public street, avenue, road, boulevard, highway or other public place located in the city and
established for the use of vehicles.
Vehicle: Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon a street.
A bicycle or motor bicycle shall be termed a vehicle.
Zone: Any area designated and marked for parking of a particular and specific duration. (Ord. 86-70, § 1,

(6) Municipal parking ramp, located between 16th and 17th Streets and 3rd and 4th Avenues. (Ord.

Sec. 9-92. Permit System Established:
(a)The city council shall hereby establish a parking permit system by which specific permits authorize
parking in specific designated locations. A permit shall be obtained from the finance department upon
payment of the appropriate fee. Permits shall be displayed on the front left side of the vehicle's
dashboard or displayed in a vinyl case and affixed to the lower left corner of the rear window of the
vehicle. The permit system shall be established as follows:
(1) Construction permit authorizes the permit holder to park a construction vehicle in any city owned
parking lot, ramp, or on street parking space for any length of time.
(2) Daily/visitor permit authorizes the permit holder to park in any city owned parking lot, ramp, or on
street parking space for one day only.
(3) Rover permit authorizes the permit holder to park in any city owned parking lot, ramp or on street
parking space for any length of time.
(b)Parking permits have the following exceptions:
(1) Permit holders may not park in any space designated for handicapped parking unless displaying
the proper identifying tags or license plates.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 291/735
(2) Permit holders may not park in any marked loading zone, no parking zone, bus lane or other
restricted parking area. (Ord. 058-2015, 12-14-2015)
Sec. 9-93. Permit Fees:
The city council does hereby establish the following fee schedule for parking in the municipal parking
facilities:
(1) Construction parking permits $20.00 per month
(2) Daily/visitor parking permits 5.00 per day
(3) Rover parking permits 80.00 per month
