DIVISION 4. RESIDENTIAL PARKING LIMITATIONS
Sec. 9-97.1. Minimum Size For Residential Permit Parking Area:
The minimum size for residential permit parking areas shall be the lesser of ten (10) contiguous parcels
of property or lots or one complete block unless otherwise approved by the city council. (Ord. 92-78, 4-
27-1992)
Sec. 9-98. Residential Parking Permit:
The city council may designate residential parking areas as either type A area or a type B area.
(1) Type A Area : The resident or residents of a dwelling unit which abuts or is adjacent to a
designated residential parking only area may obtain from the finance department of the city, by
payment of a five dollar ($5.00) fee, a parking permit for each owned, leased, rented or assigned
vehicle. This permit will allow parking adjacent to applicant's residence only without restriction. These
permits shall not be transferable to other vehicles. Each resident issued a parking permit will also
receive without additional fee two (2) visitor parking permits which may be displayed only upon
vehicles not registered to residents of the dwelling and may be transferred between vehicles. Visitor
parking permits may be displayed only on vehicles used by persons not at the home of the resident
to whom the permit was issued, and parking is limited to that area which abuts or is adjacent to the
resident's property only. In the event that a resident does not own any vehicles, two (2) visitor permits
may be obtained by payment of a five dollar ($5.00) fee.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 292/735
(2) Type B Area : The resident or residents of a dwelling unit which abuts or is adjacent to a
designated residential parking only area may obtain from the finance department of the city, by
payment of a five dollar ($5.00) fee, a parking permit for each owned, leased, rented or assigned
vehicle. This permit will allow parking without time restriction in any otherwise legal parking space
within the designated area. These permits shall not be transferable to other vehicles. Each resident
issued a parking permit will also receive without additional fee two (2) visitor parking permits which
may be displayed only upon vehicles not registered to residents of the dwelling and may be
transferred between vehicles. Visitor parking permits may be displayed only on vehicles used by
persons not at the home of the resident to whom the permit was issued. In the event that a resident
does not own any vehicles, two (2) visitor permits may be obtained by payment of a five dollar
($5.00) fee. (Ord. 87-53, 5-18-1987; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992; Ord. 95-61, 8-28-1995)
Sec. 9-99. Permit Issued Annually:
Residential parking permits must be renewed annually by payment of a five dollar ($5.00) fee and are
applicable only to the designated street. (Ord. 87-53, 5-18-1987; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)
Sec. 9-100. Penalty For Unauthorized Use:
The penalty for unauthorized use of a permit shall be a fine of not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00). (Ord. 87-53, 5-18-1987; Ord. 92-12, 1-20-1992)
ARTICLE III. PEDESTRIANS 1
Sec. 9-101. Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any ordinance establishing
pedestrian crossings, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and
effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this code. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. XI)
Sec. 9-102. Adult Crossing Guards:
There are hereby created the positions of adult crossing guards, who shall operate the traffic control at
designated school crossings in the city. They shall be supervised by a city employee or official
designated by the city manager to act in this capacity in addition to his present duties. These persons
shall be responsible for maintaining the traffic control at designated crossings. They shall be responsible
for the enforcement of the proper use of school crossings, and this function shall be separate and
distinct from the police department. The persons working pursuant to this section, whether they receive
compensation or not, are not members of the police department but shall work under the direction of the
police department. (1963 Code, Ch. XI, Art. XI)
Sec. 9-103. Standing On Sidewalk:
It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to stand upon any sidewalk except as near as reasonably possible to
the building line or curb line, if such standing interferes with the use of said sidewalk by other
pedestrians. (1963 Code, ch. XI, art. V)
Secs. 9-104-9-110. Reserved:
ARTICLE IV. PARADES, RUNS, ETC., PERMIT
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 293/735
Sec. 9-111. Permit Required:
No person shall use the public streets in the city for runs, marches, parades and air activities without
having first obtained a permit from the city clerk. Any person violating the provisions of this article shall
be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 83-19, 6-13-1983)
Sec. 9-112. Application:
Any organization or individual desiring to sponsor an activity shall file an application for a permit with the
office of the city clerk on a form provided by the clerk. (Ord. 83-19, 6-13-1983)
Sec. 9-113. Notice Requirement:
(a)Any application for a permit shall be filed with the city clerk at least sixty (60) days prior to the
scheduled event. This sixty (60) day period or any portion thereof may be waived by the city council.
(b)In the case of applications for new events and/or new routes, the sponsor of said new event shall
notify the residents and/or businesses located along said race route, parade route, or other, for that
specific activity, in writing, at least three (3) weeks prior to city council consideration. Prior to council
consideration, sponsor shall notify and obtain written approval or disapproval from the residents
and/or businesses and submit a copy of same to the city clerk. Any resident and/or business who
objects to said event shall have the opportunity to be heard at the city council meeting during which
time the event is to be considered. (Ord. 095-2014, 12-15-2014)
Sec. 9-114. Liability Insurance:
No permit shall be issued until the sponsor of the scheduled event files with the city clerk evidence of
liability insurance coverage for the event in an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) for any one person or five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for any one accident,
with the city being listed as an additional insured, claims or damages which may arise out of the event.
(Ord. 83-19, 6-13-1983)
Sec. 9-115. Review By Police; Issuance:
At such time as an application is filed, it shall be forwarded to the traffic unit supervisor of the police
department for review and estimation of service costs excluding a public works service and police
vehicles used but including charges for auxiliary police and off duty police officers' time. In addition, the
traffic unit supervisor may contact the event sponsor regarding any suggested changes in routing or any
other suggested changes. After the review as aforesaid, the application shall be returned to the city
clerk, who shall then contact the event sponsor regarding the estimated cost. If the cost figure is
acceptable to the sponsor, and the sponsor agrees to pay same, the application and cost estimate shall
be forwarded to the city manager for final review and placement on the council agenda. If the city council
approves the event, the city clerk shall issue a permit allowing the event to take place. After the event
has taken place, the sponsor shall be billed for the actual police and public works services rendered.
(Ord. 83-19, 6-13-1983; Ord. 96-50, 7-22-1996)
Sec. 9-116. Reimbursement Of Excess Costs:
(Rep. by Ord. 96-50, 7-22-1996)
ARTICLE V. NEIGHBORHOOD NUISANCE VEHICLES
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 294/735
Sec. 9-117. Purpose:
The city of Rock Island is committed to maintaining the attractiveness, aesthetics, and safety of all
residential neighborhoods and promoting the health and safety of its citizens. Pursuant to its home rule
authority, the city hereby declares vehicles stored, parked, housed, and repaired as defined herein which
are in violation of this article, to be public nuisances and the city will abate these nuisances by towing or
having the owner of the vehicle or property abate the nuisance. Pursuant to that authority, the city
council finds that such regulations, restraint or prohibition is necessary and desirable to promote or
enhance the public good. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-118. Regulated:
Except as permitted by the zoning ordinances, no person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking,
storage or leaving of any vehicle of any kind which is an abandoned vehicle on private property,
abandoned vehicle on city property, hazardous vehicle, vehicle having evidentiary value, inoperable
motor vehicle, or unregistered vehicle, whether upon public or private property within the city except as
authorized herein. The presence of such vehicle in violation of the provisions hereof is hereby declared a
public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this article.
This section shall not apply to any vehicle enclosed within a building on private property or to any vehicle
stored on the premises of a business enterprise actively operated on the subject premises and being
properly operated in the appropriate business zone pursuant to the zoning ordinance of the city and
engaged in such business enterprise as would properly be associated with the storage of such vehicles.
(Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 39-00, § 3, 6-26-2000; Ord. 78-2000, § 1, 10-9-2000)
Sec. 9-119. Definitions:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article:
Abandoned Vehicle On City Property : One that is left on property owned or operated by the city
(except for a city street or alley) for longer than two (2) hours or in a city owned parking lot for longer
than twelve (12) hours, without permission of the city.
Abandoned Vehicle On Private Property : A vehicle parked or otherwise located on private property
that has not been moved for a period of seven (7) days.
Abandoned Vehicle On Street Or Alley : An abandoned vehicle is one that is abandoned on any
highway, street or alley or other public right of way. Continuous standing of a vehicle on a highway,
street or alley or any public right of way for over a seventy two (72) hour period shall be prima facie
evidence of abandonment of such vehicle.
Administrative Hearing Officer : Defined and created pursuant to section 10-107 et seq., of this code.
Hazardous Vehicle : Any motor vehicle on private or public property that is declared to be a health or
safety hazard by a duly authorized police officer, community service officer, or city inspector, when
the vehicle is found to be:
(1) A breeding ground or harbor for mosquitoes or other insects, snakes, rats, or other pests; or
(2) A point of weed growth and/or other vegetation over ten inches (10") in height; or
(3) A point of collection for pools or ponds of water; or
(4) A point of concentration of gasoline, oil or other flammable or explosive materials; or
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 295/735
(5) So situated that there is a danger of the vehicle falling or turning over; or
(6) A place in which debris, bottles or other solid waste is discarded and is present within the
vehicle or immediately next to or around the vehicle; or
(7) A source of danger for children through entrapment in areas of confinement that cannot be
opened from the inside or from exposed surfaces of metal, glass or other rigid materials.
Inoperable Motor Vehicle : A vehicle from which the engine, wheels or other essential parts have
been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or
otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own power for a period of
at least seven (7) days. Inoperable motor vehicle shall not include: 1) a motor vehicle which has been
rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own power in order to perform ordinary
service or repair operations, 2) any motor vehicle that is kept concealed within a building when not in
use, or 3) a motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in repairing, wrecking or
junking of motor vehicles where properly zoned.
Owner : An individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, governmental agency or any
combination thereof, as evidenced by the title to the vehicle. If no title to the vehicle is available, then
the last record owner as contained in the records of the secretary of state of the state in which the
vehicle was last titled shall be rebuttably presumed to be the current owner.
Seized Vehicle : Any vehicle which is seized as a result of an arrest, pursuant to 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/36-1 et seq., recovery of a stolen vehicle, or any other lawful seizure.
Unregistered Vehicle : One that:
(1) Does not have an attached current registration (license plate) valid in any state; or
(2) Does not have displayed a current temporary registration valid in any state; or
(3) Has a registration (license plate) which is expired pursuant to the laws of the issuing state.
Vehicle : A machine propelled by power, other than human power, designed to travel by use of
wheels, treads, runners or slides and to transport persons or property or pull machinery and shall
include, without limitation, automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy, RV, SUV, snowmobile,
personal watercraft, conversion van, boat, camper, mobile home, pop-up camper, pickup truck, and
wagon.
Vehicle Having Evidentiary Value : Any vehicle which is seized so it can be searched for evidence of
a crime (hit-and-run, blood, fingerprints, etc.). (Ord. 34-00 § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 39-00, § 2, 6-26-2000)
Sec. 9-120. Authority To Abate The Nuisance By Towing:
The chief of police or his designee is hereby authorized to immediately tow away, or cause to be towed
away, any vehicle on any public street, public place, or private property at any time:
(1) When the motor vehicle is a hazardous vehicle, or "abandoned vehicle on city property", as
defined herein;
(2) When the motor vehicle is an evidentiary vehicle;
(3) When the motor vehicle is a seized vehicle;
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 296/735
(4) When the vehicle is on private residential property and is parked there without consent of the
property owner, proprietor or agent of the property, provided:
a. That signs approved by the city posted on the property give notice that parking is prohibited, and
b. That the person requesting the tow signs a statement that he is the owner, proprietor, or agent of
the property with the authority to request the tow. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-121. Pretow Notice Of Removal:
In all other instances of a violation of this article, the chief of police or his designee is hereby authorized
to tow away, or cause to be towed away, any vehicle on any public street, public place, or private
property at any time but shall first give notice of removal to the registered owner of the vehicle, if the
owner can be ascertained and if the vehicle is located on private property, to the owner or occupant of
the private property where the vehicle is located at least seven (7) days before the vehicle is removed.
(1) It shall constitute sufficient notice when a copy of the notice outlined in the pretow notice of
removal is posted upon the vehicle itself and on a conspicuous place upon the private property on
which the vehicle is located; and
(2) A duplicate copy of the pretow notice of removal is sent by registered mail to the registered owner
of said vehicle if one can be determined based on the information on the vehicle such as the
registration (license plate) or VIN number; and
(3) A duplicate copy of the pretow notice of removal is sent by certified mail to the lien holder if one
can be determined based on the information on the vehicle such as the registration (license plate) or
VIN number.
The notice of removal shall identify the vehicle, the statutory grounds for removal, the right of the
vehicle owner to request a pretow hearing before the administrative hearing officer to contest the
grounds for removal prior to the removal date, and the method of making such a request.
In the event that the vehicle owner requests a pretow hearing, the removal shall be delayed until the
next scheduled hearing date of the administrative hearing officer, at which time the administrative
hearing officer shall conduct a hearing as hereinafter provided to determine whether grounds exist for
removal. If the administrative hearing officer finds that grounds exist for removal, the vehicle may be
immediately removed. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-122. Notice Of Hearing:
Whenever a vehicle is towed without pretow notice of removal, the police department shall provide to the
owner of record of the vehicle the notice described in this section no later than twenty four (24) hours
after the time of the tow and any lien holder of record within seventy two (72) hours, except that when a
motor vehicle is towed after three o'clock (3:00) P.M. on a Friday, Saturday, Sunday or holiday or the day
before a holiday, the notice described herein shall be provided no longer than the second working day
after the tow. Whenever a vehicle is towed after a pretow notice of removal has been given, the notice
described in this section shall be provided to the owner and any lien holder of record within four (4)
working days of the tow.
(1) Notice : The notice shall include:
a. Description of the motor vehicle including year, make, model, registration (license plate number),
expiration date, and vehicle identification number (VIN);
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 297/735
b. The present location of the motor vehicle;
c. The basis for the removal of the vehicle;
d. The right of the owner to a hearing;
e. The consequences of the failure to request a hearing;
f. The consequences of the failure to reclaim a motor vehicle;
g. A deadline of seven (7) days from the date of notice, by which the owner must respond.
(2) Delivery Of Notice : The notice required in subsection (1) of this section shall, at the discretion of
the police department, be given by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal delivery.
The date of personal delivery or the date of mailing of the certified letter shall be the date of providing
notice.
(3) Posting Of Notice : A notice containing the requirements set forth for the notice, described in
subsections (1)d through (1)g of this section, shall be posted at the Rock Island police department
and at all tow/impound areas.
(4) Notices On Failure To Act :
a. Consequences Of Failure To Request A Hearing : If the registered or legal owner, lien holder, or
person who is otherwise entitled to possession of a motor vehicle does not request a hearing
within seven (7) days of the delivery or mailing of notice, the right to such hearing shall be forfeited.
A registered or legal owner, lien holder, or person who is otherwise entitled to possession of a
motor vehicle must pay the total cost of the tow and any storage incurred.
b. Consequences Of Failure To Reclaim A Motor Vehicle : If the registered or legal owner, lien
holder, or person who is otherwise entitled to possession of a motor vehicle does not claim and
take possession of said motor vehicle within fifteen (15) days after the tow hearing, the motor
vehicle shall be considered abandoned and shall be disposed of pursuant to state statute. (Ord.
34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-123. Post-Tow Hearing:
A hearing shall be held after a vehicle is towed pursuant to this article, if the owner requests a post-tow
hearing to determine the validity of such tow and any tow or storage charges.
(1) The administrative hearing officer shall conduct the post-tow hearing. The hearing officer shall
have the authority to require the presence of the enforcement officer issuing the citation or any other
city personnel or witnesses at such hearing. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable
opportunity to be heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing
and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. The hearing shall be open to the public and a court
reporter shall transcribe the proceedings.
(2) Hearings shall take place as follows:
a. In those instances where the vehicle has been released upon the deposit of a cash bond in an
amount equal to the tow and storage charge, the hearing shall take place within forty five (45) days
from the date of request following the tow after the posting of cash bond.
b. In those instances where the vehicle remains impounded, the hearing shall take place within
twenty one (21) days from the date of request immediately following the tow.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 298/735
(3) The city must establish said authority by the preponderance of the evidence and shall establish a
prima facie case upon the showing of the documents related to the tow.
(4) If the city's administrative hearing officer determines that there is no such probable cause, the
vehicle will be returned without penalty or other fees.
(5) In the event the defendant wishes to appeal the decision of the city's administrative hearing
officer under the provisions of the Administrative Review Act, said defendant shall pay the cost of the
preparation and transcription of the record of the hearing and shall appeal to the circuit court.
(6) The penalty and fees shall be a debt due and owed to the city. However, if a cash bond has been
posted the bond shall be applied to the fine. If the city's administrative hearing officer determines that
the vehicle was not in violation of this article the administrative hearing officer shall order the return of
the vehicle or cash bond. In the event it shall become necessary for the city to collect the debt by
filing an action in the circuit court, it shall be entitled to recover, in addition to the amount due, court
costs and reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-124. Bonding Procedures:
Whenever the owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle towed pursuant to sections 9-120 and
9-121 of this article wishes to retrieve their vehicle prior to the post-tow hearing, they may do so by
posting a cash bond at police headquarters in an amount twice the fees charged for towing and storage
pursuant to the contract for towing services with the city in effect at the time of the tow for a period of
thirty (30) days from the date of the tow. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-125. Responsibility For Costs Not Recovered:
Any costs incurred by the city for removal, impoundment or destruction of vehicles under this article not
otherwise recovered, shall be paid by the registered owner, person legally entitled to possession, or lien
holder of the vehicle unless the administrative hearing officer determines that no violation has occurred.
(Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-126. Parking, Storing, Housing Of Vehicles:
It shall be a violation of this article for a property owner or renter to park, store, or house upon their
property vehicles that are: inoperable, unregistered, abandoned vehicle on private property, or
hazardous, as defined herein, except a property owner or renter may park, store, or house upon their
property no more than one unregistered vehicle that does not fit into any of the other categories defined
herein unless the vehicle is enclosed in a building and not visible by the public. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-
2000)
Sec. 9-127. Detrimental Health Nuisances Associated With Vehicle Repair In
Residentially Zoned Neighborhoods:
Whenever the pursuit of any vehicle repairs or the maintenance of any vehicle results in the spilling of
solvents, oil, gasoline, or other hazardous substances on the ground (public or private property), or the
condition of things at a specific location where vehicle repairs are being conducted result in a condition
detrimental to the health of any person, the same shall be deemed a health nuisance and shall be
abated. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000)
Sec. 9-128. Enforcement:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 299/735
A police officer, community service officer, or inspector, shall have the authority to: 1) issue a parking
ticket to the owner of a vehicle described herein for violations of this article when the vehicle is parked
on public or city property, or 2) issue a city ordinance citation to the owner of a vehicle described herein
or to the property owner where the vehicle is located for violations of this article when the vehicle is
parked on private property. However, the processing of all tows shall be handled through the abandoned
vehicle division of the Rock Island police department. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 068-2006, § 1, 9-
11-2006)
Sec. 9-129. Penalty And Fines:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense and shall be subject
to a fine. Each act in violation of any of the provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense.
A violation of abandoned vehicle on city property, abandoned vehicle on street or alley, or hazardous
vehicle when the vehicle is on public property shall be charged by the issuance of a parking ticket, as
with other parking violations. The fine for violation of these articles shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00).
A violation of abandoned vehicle on private property or hazardous vehicle when the vehicle is on private
property shall be charged by the issuance of a city ordinance citation, as with other motor vehicle
violations. The first violation of this article shall be a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). In
the event a person is accused of a first violation of this article and does not wish to contest the
allegation, then the person so accused can pay to the city of Rock Island police headquarters a penalty
sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to be paid within seven (7) days of the first violation for and in full
satisfaction of the violation. The fine for any second and subsequent violation of this article within two (2)
years of the first violation shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
These fines shall be in addition to any towing and storage charges. (Ord. 34-00, § 1, 6-5-2000; Ord. 068-
2006, § 1, 9-11-2006)
ARTICLE VI. NEIGHBORHOOD VEHICLES
Sec. 9-130. Purpose:
Whereas, the city council of Rock Island, after considering volume, speed and character of traffic on
streets within the city of Rock Island finds that neighborhood vehicles as defined herein, may safely
travel on and across the streets within the city with the regulations set forth herein and that the public
safety will not be jeopardized by operation of said vehicles in accordance with said regulations except on
roadways prohibited by this article. (Ord. 027-2008, § 1, 4-14-2008)
Sec. 9-131. Definitions:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article:
Neighborhood Vehicle: A self-propelled, electrically powered four-wheeled motor vehicle (or a selfpropelled
gasoline powered four-wheeled motor vehicle with an engine displacement under 1,200
cubic centimeters) which is capable of attaining in one mile a speed of more than twenty (20) miles
per hour, but not more than twenty five (25) miles per hour, and which conforms to federal regulations
under title 49 CFR part 571.500. (Ord. 027-2008, § 1, 4-14-2008)
Sec. 9-132. Prohibited Roadways:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 300/735
(a)General Authorization: Except as expressly prohibited in this section it shall be lawful for any person
who holds a valid driver's license issued in this or any other state to operate a neighborhood vehicle
on any street within the city. (Ord. 027-2008, § 1, 4-14-2008)
Sec. 9-133. General Limitations:
(a)No person shall operate a neighborhood vehicle on any street having a posted speed limit of thirty
five (35) miles per hour or greater, provided that nothing herein shall prohibit a person from driving a
neighborhood vehicle across a street with a posted speed limit of thirty five (35) miles per hour or
greater.
(b)All persons operating neighborhood vehicles shall comply with the applicable requirements of section
11-1426.1 of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., hereinafter
referred to as the Illinois vehicle code.
(c)No neighborhood vehicle may be operated on a street unless, at a minimum it has the following:
brakes, a steering apparatus, tires, a rearview mirror, red reflectorized warning devices in the front
and rear, a "slow moving" emblem (as required of other vehicles in section 12-709 of the Illinois
vehicle code) on the rear of the neighborhood vehicle, a headlight that emits a white light visible from
at least one hundred feet (100') from the rear, brake light, and turn signals. When operated on a
roadway, a neighborhood vehicle shall have its headlight and tail lamps lighted as required by section
12-201 of the Illinois vehicle code.
(d)A person who drives or is in physical control of a neighborhood vehicle on a roadway while under the
influence is subject to sections 11-500 through 11-502 of the Illinois vehicle code.
(e)No neighborhood vehicle shall be left on the roadway in such a way that it disrupts the normal flow of
traffic. All costs related to the removal of any neighborhood vehicle shall be the responsibility of the
owner. (Ord. 027-2008, § 1, 4-14-2008)
Chapter 10
OFFENSES-MISCELLANEOUS 1 Annotations-The city may regulate the
permitting of steam to be released from railroad locomotive engines.
Chicago, R.I. & P. Ry. Co. v. Steckman , 125 Ill. App. 299; affirmed, 224 Ill. 500,
79 N.E. 602 (1906).
A railroad speed limit ordinance is applicable to the case of a railroad
employee injured while at his employment on a railroad right of way. Potter v.
Chicago, M. & St. P. Ry. Co. , 208 Ill. App. 363 (1917).
Where a railroad train was running at a greater rate of speed than the
maximum permitted by ordinance, a prima facie case of negligence was
established against the railroad company. Edwall v. Chicago, R.I. & P. Ry. Co. ,
208 Ill. App. 489 (1917).
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. Misdemeanor Defined Generally 1; Penalty:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 301/735
Except as otherwise provided in this Article, each of the sections in this Article shall be deemed to state
a misdemeanor or misdemeanors, which, if severally or jointly committed by any person or persons
within the territorial jurisdiction of the City, shall subject the offender or offenders, severally to a penalty
of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
The court, in lieu of imposing any fine provided in this Article, may, in its discretion, impose a sentence of
community service. (1963 Code, Ch. XII, Art. I; Ord. 99-11, § 1, 2-22-1999)

136, 12-9-1991)
Sec. 10-6. Obscenity 1:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to commit obscenity within the City. A person commits obscenity
when, with knowledge of the nature of contents thereof, or recklessly failing to exercise reasonable
inspection which would disclose the nature of contents thereof:
(1) He or she sells within the City any obscene book, magazine, pamphlet, paper, photograph,
drawing, motion picture film, video recording, filmstrip or slide.
(2) He or she offers or attempts to sell within the City any obscene book, magazine, pamphlet, paper,
photograph, drawing, motion picture film, video recording, filmstrip or slide.
(3) He or she distributes or gives away within the City any obscene book, magazine, pamphlet,
paper, photograph, drawing, motion picture film, video recording, filmstrip or slide.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 302/735
(4) He or she offers to or attempts to give away within the City any obscene book, magazine,
pamphlet, paper, photograph, drawing, motion picture film, video recording, filmstrip or slide.
(5) He or she prints or publishes within the city any obscene book, magazine, pamphlet, paper,
photograph, drawing, motion picture film, video recording, filmstrip or slide.
(6) He or she exhibits or shows within the City any obscene photograph, drawing, motion picture,
video recording, filmstrip or slide.
(7) He or she produces, directs, or plays a part within the City in any obscene play.
(8) He or she advertises for sale within the City any obscene book, magazine, pamphlet, paper,
photograph, drawing, motion picture film, video recording, phonograph record, filmstrip or slide.
(9) He or she advertises for viewing within the City any obscene motion picture, video recording, play,
filmstrip or slide.
(10) He or she publicly performs an obscene act or otherwise publicly presents an obscene exhibition
of his or her body within the City.
(11) He or she buys or procures in the City for resale in the City any obscene book, magazine,
pamphlet, paper, photograph, motion picture film, video recording, filmstrip, slide or phonograph
record.
(12) He or she buys, leases, or procures in the City for showing in the City, for gain, any obscene
motion picture, video recording, filmstrip or slide.
(b)As used in this Section material is "obscene" when:
(1) It depicts or describes any of the following types of sexual conduct:
a. Ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral
copulation, sodomy;
b. Masturbation;
c. Excretory functions; or
d. Exhibition of the human genitals; and
(2) To the average person, applying contemporary community standards, the dominant theme of the
material taken as a whole appeals to the prurient interest in sex; and
(3) The material is patently offensive because it affronts contemporary community standards in its
description or representation of the sexual conduct; and
(4) The material taken as a whole lacks serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value.
(c)Any person who commits obscenity or any act thereof as defined herein is guilty of a misdemeanor
and shall be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) 1. (1963 Code, Ch. XII, Art. I; Ord. 83-62, 2-20-1984)

Sec. 10-9. Firearms; Explosives; Slingshot; Fireworks; Bow And Arrow; Air Gun:
(a)Prohibited: No person shall, in any part of the city, fire or discharge any cannon, gun, pistol or other
firearm, or set off, fire or explode any torpedo, firecracker, fireball, rocket or other fireworks
whatsoever 1. However, the discharge of firearms by the members of any military organization when
on parade and in accordance with the command of the commanding officer, or by any city officer or
other person in the discharge of any legal duty or necessary and lawful act done in a proper and
careful manner, shall not be deemed a violation hereof 2. No person shall in any part of the city
possess any torpedo, firecracker, fireball, rocket or other fireworks whatsoever. Fireworks as defined
in the fireworks regulation act, 425 Illinois Compiled Statutes 30/2.
(b)Air Guns And Toy Guns: It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge on the streets, avenues,
alleys or other public grounds any air gun or toy gun from which is sent a lead or metal missile.
(c)Slingshots; Bow And Arrow; Exception: It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot a slingshot or bow
and arrow within the corporate limits of the city. However, archery may be practiced if done in a safe
place and under the competent supervision of an adult. The prohibition against shooting a bow and
arrow within the city limits shall not apply to the hunting of deer with a bow and arrow in accordance
with subsection (d) of this section.
(d)Archery Deer Hunting: A person may discharge a long, recurve, compound bow, or crossbow as
permitted by the Illinois department of natural resources regulations and the laws of the state of
Illinois, within the corporate limits of the city during the course of harvesting deer if the following
requirements are met:
(1) The person must possess a valid deer archery permit issued by the state of Illinois and must
comply with all of the conditions of the permit and all applicable laws and regulations of the Illinois
department of natural resources relating to archery deer hunting.
(2) The person must possess a deer hunting permit issued by the city. The cost for this permit shall
be fifty dollars ($50.00). The application procedure necessary for obtaining a permit shall be
according to the city of Rock Island deer management rules and restrictions for deer hunting in
subsection (f) of this section.
(3) The number of locations or "sites" for deer hunting to be permitted shall be set by the city council
on an annual basis. There shall be fourteen (14) permitted "sites" with no more than eight (8) "sites"
located on private property. The size of each "site" whether on public or private property, must have a
minimum of three (3) contiguous acres. City staff shall identify and approve all "sites".
(4) Each hunter shall be authorized to hunt from an approved "stand" located on the permitted
hunting "sites". Each "stand" located on an approved "site" shall have a minimum platform height of
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 304/735
six feet (6'). No person shall knowingly direct an arrow across the boundary of or off the designated
"site". Only one hunter per "stand" at any one time will be allowed. If multiple "stands" are to be
located on a "site", each "stand" shall have a density of no less than five (5) acres.
(5) Locating appropriate hunting "sites" will be the responsibility of the hunter. The hunter shall
provide "site" information to the chief of police who will forward it to the community and economic
development department who will determine if the "site" information complies with this section and
the rules and procedures for deer hunting in subsection (f) of this section. The "site" information
submitted by the hunter shall include a description and address of the proposed hunting "site".
(6) Hunting will only be allowed on those specific days designated as deer bow season by the Illinois
department of natural resources and the city of Rock Island, Illinois.
(7) The total number of deer to be harvested as well as the number of male and female deer allowed
to be harvested per hunter shall be set by rule in subsection (f) of this section.
(8) The manner for removal of a harvested deer shall be set by rule in subsection (f)(1)b of this
section.
This subsection (d) shall only be in force for the bow and arrow deer hunting seasons as approved by
city council.
(e)Penalty: The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this section shall be fifty dollars
($50.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of this section and does not wish to contest
said allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, then the person so accused
may pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for and in full
satisfaction of the violation.
(f)Deer Management Rules And Restrictions: The city of Rock Island permits an archery hunting
program for deer in an effort to better control the deer population within the boundaries of the city,
contingent, however, upon annual council review. The intent is to give control of hunting to the
property owners, yet enable archery hunters to harvest the deer for their use or to provide meat for
social agencies.
Hunting sites will be selected based on criteria including deer concentration, safety, and overall
impact. There are stipulations required of hunters in an effort to make the program as safe as
possible, yet achieve the goal of thinning the number of deer within the city limits.
(1) Hunters:
a. Obtaining A Permit: Hunters must obtain a permit in order to participate in the Rock Island deer
management program. In order to obtain a permit, hunters will need to provide the following:
1. Written permission from the property owner of the site they desire to hunt.
2. Hunters are encouraged to obtain permission from adjacent and abutting property owners,
these properties will be considered part of the hunting site.
3. Proficiency certification from an approved provider.
4. Copy of Illinois hunting license.
5. Completed Rock Island deer management application form.
b. Hunting Rules And Regulations:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 305/735
1. Hunters must adhere to all state of Illinois and department of natural resources guidelines,
rules, and restrictions.
2. Hunters must obtain appropriate state permits and tags.
3. Hunters must have a valid city of Rock Island permit.
4. Hunters will harvest at least two (2) does before harvesting a buck.
5. All deer harvested as part of the deer management program must be checked in at the two (2)
identified fire stations (entire deer).
6. All remains must be removed from the hunting site.
7. Hunters will obtain permission from property owners before tracking or retrieving a deer that
travels out of the approved hunting area. Illinois is not a right to retrieve state.
(2) Hunting Sites: Sites will be approved by the city based upon criteria including deer concentration,
safety, and overall impact.
a. Restrictions And Requirements:
1. Consist of no less than three (3) contiguous acres.
2. One hundred (100) yards from a school, park, or church, unless approved.
3. Situated in a manner that all shots are taken at a downward angle.
4. Shots must not be taken in a way they may carry into an open or occupied area.
5. Only one hunter active per site at any time.
6. Certain sites may have a time restriction when hunting is allowed.
7. All sites will be signed with signage obtained from the Rock Island police department. This
signage will be placed in a manner that is visible to neighboring and abutting property owners
when hunters are active.
8. Hunters cannot use nails, screws or other hardware to affix stands. Only straps or other
noninjuring attachment may be used in trees.
b. Multiple Hunters:
1. Additional hunters may be allowed when using a separate stand at a density of no less than
one hunter per five (5) acres.
2. Property owners may coordinate with multiple hunters to utilize a site, but only one hunter
may actively use a stand at any one time.
(3) Property Owners:
a. Property owners reserve the right to deny hunting on their property.
b. Property owners wishing to hunt or allow hunting on their property must submit their site for
approval to the deer management program manager.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 306/735
c. The city will notify property owners that are adjacent and abutting an approved hunting site in
advance via letter.
d. Property owners with objections or concerns regarding hunting in their vicinity should state their
concern in writing or contact the deer management program manager.
(4) Public Lands: Hunters who are unable to locate a suitable site within Rock Island are eligible to
hunt on selected public lands such as golf courses or other specifically identified areas. The hunters
will follow all of the requirements identified for hunting on private land. In addition, the following
procedures will be used to determine who will hunt on those lands. Larger private properties such as
cemeteries may follow a similar process.
a. Hunting stand areas will be identified by the "controlling agency", a department, board, or
designated individual.
b. Hunter will enter their name into a lottery for a chance of being awarded permission to place a
hunting stand on designated areas.
c. Names will be selected through a drawing with each of the names noted in order.
d. Hunters who are awarded an area, must obtain their city of Rock Island permit before any
hunting takes place.
e. If a hunter exhausts their supply of deer tags and the season is still open, they are to notify the
controlling agency. The controlling agency is then responsible for contacting the next eligible
hunter.
f. The hunter will notify the controlling agency in advance when they plan to be active. This may be
done in person or through a mutually agreed upon process.
(5) Unpermitted Hunting:
a. Any hunting which takes place without appropriate permits will be considered poaching and
treated as such.
b. Any hunting on property which is not approved by the city will be considered poaching and
treated as such.
c. Hunting on property without the property owners explicit permission is impermissible.
d. Any violation of the deer management program rules and guidelines will result in the permanent
revocation of city hunting privileges and subject the hunter to a possible fine for violating the
enabling ordinance. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I; Ord., 12-21-1970; Ord., 1-12-1981; Ord., 1-11-
1982; Ord. 83-57, 2-6-1984; Ord. 91-136, 12-9-1991; Ord. 94-106, 12-12-1994; Ord. 062-2013, 11-
18-2013; Ord. 016-2014, 3-17-2014; Ord. 022-2015, 4-20-2015)

12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 307/735

Sec. 10-20. Assault; Battery 1:
(a)No person shall commit an assault or battery. A person commits an assault when, without lawful
authority, he engages in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a
battery. A person commits battery if he intentionally or knowingly without legal justification and by any
means: 1) causes bodily harm to an individual, or 2) makes physical contact of an insulting or
provoking nature with an individual.
(b)The minimum fine for committing the violation of assault shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event a
person is accused of a violation as aforesaid and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the
time a complaint is issued for the violation, the person so accused may pay to the city at police
headquarters a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation.
(c)The minimum fine for committing the violation of battery shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
In the event a person is accused of a violation as aforesaid and does not wish to contest the
allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, then the person so accused may
pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for
and in full satisfaction of the violation. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I,; Ord., § 2, 1-12-1981; Ord. 83-57, §
1, 2-6-1984)
Sec. 10-21. Disturbing The Peace:
No person shall create, maintain, assist or participate in the creation of a loud or raucous noise, or loud
or raucous talking, or loud or raucous singing on the public streets at any time or place so as likely to
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 309/735
disturb the public peace or quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel, or
other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity.
No person shall allow or cause to be used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument,
phonograph, loudspeaker or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound, on any
residential property in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring
inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person
who is in the residence in which such machine or device is operated and who is a voluntary listener
thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, machine or device
between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. in such a manner as to be
plainly audible at a distance of ten feet (10') from the property on which it is located shall be prima facie
evidence of a violation of this section.
No person shall create, maintain, assist or participate in the creation of a loud or raucous noise, or loud
or raucous talking, shouting, or loud or raucous singing on any residential property in such a manner as
to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel, or
other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity.
Exemption: Persons who have obtained a sound amplification permit shall be exempt during the duration
of the permit. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I; Ord. 90-55, § 1, 8-13-1990; Ord. 50-2004, § 1, 5-3-2004)
Sec. 10-21.1. Public Urination And Defecation Prohibited:
It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate on any street, alley, sidewalk, parkway, public
parking lot, or other public place other than in a facility designed for that purpose. (Ord. 52-2004, § 1, 5-
3-2004)
Sec. 10-22. Penalty For Sections 10-21 And 10-21.1:
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of sections 10-21 and 10-21.1 of this article shall be
fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of section 10-21 and/or 10-21.1 of
this article and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the
violation, the person so accused may pay to the city, at police headquarters, a penalty in the sum of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation. (Ord., § 1, 1-11-1982; Ord. 83-57, § 1, 2-6-
1984; Ord. 53-2004, § 1, 5-3-2004)
Sec. 10-23. Loitering:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to loiter or congregate about or upon any public building or
public property, any stairway, doorway, window or in front of any business or dwelling house, theater,
church or street corner or elsewhere, and by so doing obstruct or interfere with the free passage of
persons entering or occupying such building or premises, or by language, conversation or conduct to
annoy, insult or disturb persons passing along the streets or alleys or occupying, residing in or doing
business in any of such houses or places. The fine for violating this section will be from fifty dollars
($50.00) up to five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 060-2011, 8-8-2011)
Sec. 10-23.1. Loitering For Drug Activities:
(a)Acts Prohibited : It is unlawful for any person to loiter in, on or near any thoroughfare or place open to
the public or near any public or private place in manner and under circumstances manifesting the
purpose of engaging in drug related activity defined as offenses in the Illinois controlled substances
act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 310/735
(b)Circumstances : Among circumstances that may be considered in determining whether such purpose
is manifested are that the person:
(1) Is a known drug user, possessor, or seller. For purpose of this chapter, a "known unlawful drug
user, possessor, or seller" is a person who has, within the knowledge of the arresting officer, been
convicted in any court within this state or any other state of any violation involving the use,
possession or sale of any of the substances referred to in the Illinois controlled substances act, or
such person has been convicted of any violation of any of the provisions of those sections or
substantially similar laws of any political subdivision of this state or of any state; or a person who
displays physical characteristics of drug intoxication or usage, such as "needle tracks"; or a person
who possesses drug paraphernalia.
(2) Is currently subject to an order prohibiting his or her presence in a high drug activity geographic
area.
(3) Behaves in such a manner as to raise a reasonable suspicion that he or she is about to engage in
or is then engaged in an unlawful drug related activity, including, by way of example only, acting as a
"lookout".
(4) Is physically identified by the officer as a member of a "gang" or association which has as its
purpose illegal drug activity.
(5) Transfers small objects or packages for currency in a furtive fashion.
(6) Tries to conceal himself or herself or any object which reasonably could be involved in an
unlawful drug related activity.
(7) Is in an area that is known for unlawful drug use and trafficking.
(8) Is on or in premises that have been reported to law enforcement as a place suspected of unlawful
drug activity.
(9) Is in, or within six feet (6') of, any vehicles registered to a known unlawful drug user, possessor, or
seller, or a person for whom there is an outstanding warrant for a crime involving drug related activity.
(c)Enforcement : Enforcement of this section shall be by an officer of the Rock Island police department
and the Quad City metropolitan enforcement group. (Ord. 93-27, § 1, 4-12-1993)
Sec. 10-24. Noisy Animals-Generally 2:
No person shall, in the city, keep any dog, whelp, bitch, calf, hog or any other animal which, by barking,
howling or other noises, shall disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art.
I)
Sec. 10-25. Noisy Animals-Generally-Penalty:
The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of section 10-24 of this article shall be fifty dollars
($50.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of section 10-24 of this article and does not wish
to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, the person so accused
may pay to the city, at police headquarters, a penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for and in full
satisfaction of the violation. (Ord., § 1, 1-12-1981; Ord. 83-57, § 1, 2-6-1984)
Sec. 10-26. Disorderly Conduct 3:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 311/735
(a)A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
(1) Does any act in such an unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a
breach of the peace.
(2) Transmits in any manner to the fire department of any city, town, village or fire protection district a
false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for
believing that such fire exists.
(3) Transmits in any manner, to another, a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of
any nature is concealed in such place that its explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the
time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such bomb or
explosive is concealed in such place.
(4) Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public employee a report to the
effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no
reasonable grounds for believing that such an offense has been committed.
(5) Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose deliberately looks into a
dwelling on the property through any window or other opening in it.
(6) Conducts himself or herself in a disorderly manner, makes, aids, countenances or assists in
making any improper noise, riot or disturbance in the city or congregates with others in any of the
streets, alleys or public places of the city for unlawful purposes, or for a lawful purpose in a riotous or
tumultuous manner, to the annoyance of the citizens or travelers therein, or aids or abets the same.
(7) Delivers any public speech or holds any public meeting or gathering or gatherings on any streets
or avenues within the city without first obtaining from the city council a permit. If the city council shall
grant a permit, then the permit shall designate upon which street or avenue any such meeting or
gathering may be held or conducted. An application to the city council for the place at which the
meeting or gathering is to be held or conducted shall be filed with the city clerk not less than twenty
four (24) hours before the time of the meeting or gathering.
(8) Makes any kind of false alarm not described above by outcry, bell, other sounding instrument or
other means for disturbing the peace of the city.
(b)The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of subsections (a)(1), (a)(6) 4 and (a)(7) of this
section shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of those
subsections and does not wish to contest the allegations prior to the time a complaint is issued for
the violation, then the person so accused may pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the
sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation.
(c)The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of subsections (a)(2), (a)(3), (a)(4), and (a)(5) of this
section shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of
those subsections and does not wish to contest the allegations prior to the time a complaint is issued
for the violation, then the person so accused may pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in
the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation. (1963 Code, Ch.
XII, Art. I; Ord., § 1, 1-12-1981; Ord. 83-57, § 1, 2-6-1984; Ord. 91-136, § 1, 12-9-1991)

(a)No person shall willfully interrupt or disturb any school or any congregation or assembly meeting for
religious worship, or for any other lawful purpose, by making unnecessary noise or by rude or
indecent behavior, or by profane discourse within such meeting, or so near the same as to disturb the
order or solemnity of such meeting.

Sec. 10-28. Time of closing for places of amusement--Generally.
No person shall, by himself, his agent or servant, keep open or permit or suffer any person to remain at
any public place of amusement kept or owned by him at a later hour than 2:00 a.m., except as otherwise
provided in this Code. The mayor may, in his discretion, upon proper application to him in writing, grant a
special written permit to keep the same open to some hour that shall be specified therein, such permit to
be good for one (1) night only, such permit and application to be filed with the city clerk before taking
advantage of the provisions thereof.
(Code 1963, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 26)

Sec. 10-30. Concealed weapons--Prohibited.
No person shall within the limits of the city carry or wear under his clothes, or concealed about his
person, any pistol, revolver, bowie knife, dirk or other deadly weapon, nor shall he in a threatening or
boisterous manner display or flourish any deadly weapon. This shall not apply to police officers when on
duty. Any such weapon worn, carried or displayed by any person in violation of this section shall be kept
and retained by the chief of police pending final adjudication of the violation.
(Code 1963, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 28)

Sec. 10-32. Resisting or obstructing a police officer; aiding in arrest; impersonation
of officer.
(a)No person shall knowingly resist or obstruct the performance of any police officer or member of the
police department nor shall in any way interfere with or hinder or prevent him from discharging any
authorized act within his official capacity. No person shall interfere with the mayor, the chief of police,
any police officer or any person authorized and required to enforce the laws of the city, nor prevent,
hinder or delay such person in the execution of the duties required of him by any of the ordinances of
the city or laws of the state.
(b)A peace officer making a lawful arrest may command the aid of persons over the age of eighteen
(18). A person commanded to aid a peace officer shall have the same authority to arrest as that
peace officer. No person shall neglect or refuse to give such aid or assistance when commanded to
do so.
(c)No person shall falsely represent himself to be a member of the police department of this city or shall,
maliciously or with the intent to deceive, use or imitate any of the signs, signals or devices adopted
and used by any such person.
(d)The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of subsection (a) shall be one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation of subsection (a) and does not wish to
contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violation, then the person so
accused may pay to the city at police headquarters a penalty in the sum of one hundred dollars
($100.00) for and in full satisfaction of the violation.
(e)The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of subsection (b) shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), and
for subsection (c), one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). In the event a person is accused of a violation
of subsection (b) or (c) and does not wish to contest the allegation prior to the time a complaint is
issued for the violation, then the person so accused may pay to the city at police headquarters a
penalty in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) or one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for and in full
satisfaction of the violation.
(Code 1963, Ch. VII, Art. I, § 4 and Ch. XII, Art. I, § 29; Ord. of 1-12-81, § 1; Ord. of 1-11-82, § 1; Ord.
No. 83-57, § 1, 2-6-84; Ord. No. 91-136, § 1, 12-9-91)
Editor's note--At the discretion of the editor, the provisions of § 1 of Ord. No. 83-57, adopted Feb. 6,
1984, have been treated as amendatory of § 10-32 subsections (d) and (e). Ord. No. 83-57 was not
specifically amendatory of this Code.

Sec. 10-33. Destruction or injury of property--Prohibited.
(a)Generally. No person shall willfully or maliciously destroy, injure, deface or interfere with any bridge,
engine house or other public building, fire engine, fire hose or other property of the city, or any public
property or public work.
(b)Tampering With Telephones. It shall be unlawful for any person to insert, or to attempt to insert into
the coin box or money receptacle of any telephone any slug, button or other substance or to
manipulate or operate, or to attempt to manipulate or operate, in any manner whatever any
telephone instrument or any mechanism or device connected or commonly used therewith, with the
intent to obtain telephone service without paying therefor. It shall be unlawful for any person to inset,
or attempt to insert, into the coin box or money receptacle of any telephone, any slug, button, wire,
hook or other implement or substance with the intent to obtain from such coin box or money
receptacle a legal tender coin of the United States.
(Code 1963, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 30)
State law reference--Obtaining telecommunication services with intent to defraud, 720 ILCS 365/1.

Sec. 10-35. Excavation in street.
No person shall within the limits of this city dig or make any ditch, drain or other excavation, or remove
any sod, earth, sand, gravel or stone in, upon or from any street, avenue, alley or public grounds within
this city, except when in possession of a permit from proper city authority.
(Code 1963, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 31)

drains or sewers of the city, or connect any drain, sewer or pipe therewith, without permission from the
director of public works or his designated representative. (1963 Code, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 32; Ord. 87-22, §

Sec. 10-39. Depositing Rubbish In Streets; Burning Rubbish, Leaves, Etc., In
Streets-Prohibited 1:

alley or public place in the city any leaves, yard waste, ashes, paper, rags, sticks, blocks, posts,
boards, lumber or building material of any kind or any shavings, dirt, tin cans, junk or other rubbish of
any kind or description; and no rubbish of any kind shall hereafter be burned anywhere within the city
of Rock Island, Illinois. No box, barrel or other receptacle for dirt, ashes, paper or other rubbish shall
be placed or allowed to remain in or upon any street or upon any sidewalk in the city, or upon any
public grounds or upon any part thereof.
(b)Any duly appointed and authorized firefighter for the city of Rock Island or any subdivision thereof, or

Sec. 10-40.1. Leaf Burning Prohibited:
(a)The burning of leaves or yard waste is prohibited in the city of Rock Island, Illinois.

be paid at the police department in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00) if paid within seven (7)

forty dollars ($40.00). Any subsequent violation of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).

Sec. 10-40.2. When Open Burning Permitted:
It is permissible to burn vegetation and trees in the city for purposes of preparing a property for

department which shall establish criteria for burning of vegetation and trees consistent with protection of
public health and safety.

Sec. 10-41. Littering Streets; Billposting:
(a)All contractors, truckers, teamsters and all persons hauling dirt, sand, gravel, ashes, rubbish, leaves
or yard waste or other material on streets or alleys shall so construct, keep and maintain their trucks
or wagon boxes, dumps and sideboards with front and rear ends and bottoms at all times as to
prevent the spilling of such material from the same; and in case the same fall into the streets or the
same are scattered in any street or avenue, they shall cause the same to be forthwith removed.
(b)It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or place upon the surface of any of the streets, alleys or
sidewalks of this city any glass, earthenware, metal, stones or other articles or substances likely to
cause injury to travelers or pedestrians or to automobiles or bicycles used on the streets.
(c)No person shall post, paste or in any other way attach or affix to any telephone or electric light pole
within the city any bill, notice, announcement or other advertising medium. (1963 Code, Ch. XII, Art.
I, § 35; Ord. 084-2008, § 1, 12-22-2008)
Sec. 10-42. Rubbish Not To Be Placed In Gutters:
No person shall sweep rubbish, leaves, yard waste or debris from sidewalks into street gutters or place
litter of any sort on streets or in gutters. (1963 Code, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 36; Ord. 085-2008, § 1, 12-22-
2008)
Sec. 10-43. Unlawful Use Of Mailbox:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed in any private mailbox used by the
letter carriers of the city as a receptacle in which to deposit United States mail, any circular, letter, note
or other advertising matter whatsoever unless the same bears United States postage or has been
regularly consigned through the United States mail. (1963 Code, Ch. XII, Art. I, § 37)
Sec. 10-44. Trimming Of Trees On Streets:
It shall be necessary for every person having in charge any tree upon any street or avenue in the city or
any tree which extends over on any street or avenue, to remove all branches which are less than twelve
feet (12') from the ground. All trees shall be trimmed so as not to obscure or obstruct the city lights along
the streets and avenues of the city. (1963 Code, ch. XII, art. I, § 39)

Sec. 10-49. Steel Jaw Animal Traps 1:
It shall be unlawful for any person to rig, set or maintain any steel jaw leg hold trap. Snare or box type
traps or other animal traps that could cause cruelty to animals within the city are prohibited; however,
boxed traps may be used by licensed humane organizations or individuals that have obtained written
approval from the police department, and with this permission, may be used for the capture of stray or
nuisance domesticated animals or wild animals. (Ord., 1-7-1980)
Sec. 10-50. Barbed Wire And Electric Fences:
No person shall install or permit to be installed any barbed wire fences or electrically charged and
regulated fences within the corporate limits of the city except as provided in this section. Barbed wire
fences shall be allowed in residentially zoned areas in the city where livestock is allowed to be kept
under the provisions of the city ordinances, and barbed wire installations shall also be allowed on top of
security fences which are at least six feet (6') in height. Low voltage (not to exceed 24 volts), low
amperage electric fences are allowed in posted fenced in areas in residential areas after the issuance of
a permit by the chief building inspector for said fence based on his inspection of the proposed
improvement. Any permitted electrified fence shall be tagged with a sign large enough to warn persons
that such fence is electrified. (Ord., 11-3-1975; Ord. 91-61, 5-13-1991; Ord. 96-22, 4-8-1996)
