granted even if a Certificate of Appropriateness would not ordinarily be issued.
(d)Architectural Review Guidelines: In making a determination whether to issue or deny a Certificate of
Appropriateness, the commission shall consider, among other things, the effect of the proposed
construction, alteration, removal or demolition upon the exterior architectural features and upon the
historic, aesthetic or architectural value, characteristics and significance of the landmark or of the
Locally Designated Historic District. The criteria to be used by the commission in making its
determination shall include, but not be limited to:
(1) The maintenance of the significant original qualities or character of the structure or property
including, if significant, its landscape. The removal or alteration of any historic or distinctive
architectural features should be avoided when possible.
(2) The compatibility of proposed new additions and new construction to the original architecture of
the landmark or styles within the Locally Designated Historic District shall be evaluated against the
following general guidelines:
a. Height: The height of the proposed structure or additions or alterations should be compatible
with surrounding structures.
b. Proportions Of Structure's Front Facade: The proportion between the width and height of the
proposed structure should be compatible with nearby structures.
c. Proportions Of Openings Into The Facility: The proportions and relationships between doors and
windows should be compatible with existing structures.
d. Relationship Of Building Masses And Spaces: The relationship of a structure to the open space
between it and adjoining structures should be compatible.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 373/735
e. Roof Shapes: The design of the roof should be compatible with adjoining structures.
f. Landscape And Appurtenances: Landscaping and the use of appurtenances should be sensitive
to the individual structure, its occupants and their needs. Further, the landscape treatment should
be compatible with surrounding structures and landscapes.
g. Scale Of Structure: The scale of the structure should be compatible with surrounding structures.
h. Directional Expression Of Front Elevation: Street facades should blend with other structures with
regard to directional expression. When adjacent structures have a dominant horizontal or vertical
expression, this should be carried over and reflected.
i. Architectural Details: Architectural details and materials should be incorporated as necessary to
relate the new with the old and to preserve and enhance the inherent characteristics of that area.
(3) Alterations should be made in accordance with the Preservation Administrator of the Interior's
"Standards for Historic Preservation Projects" and other guidelines that may be developed and used
by the commission for Certificate of Appropriateness review purposes as revised from time to time:
a. Every reasonable effort shall be made to provide a compatible use for a property which requires
minimal alteration of the building, structure or site and its environment, or to use a property for its
originally intended purpose.
b. The distinguishing original qualities or character of a building, structure or site and its
environment shall not be destroyed. The removal or alteration of any historic material or distinctive
architectural features should be avoided when possible.
c. All buildings, structures and sites shall be recognized as products of their own time. Alterations
that have no historical basis and which seek to create an earlier appearance shall be discouraged.
d. Changes which may have taken place in the course of time are evidence of the history and
development of a building, structure or site and its environment. These changes may have
acquired significance in their own right, and this significance shall be recognized and respected.
e. Distinctive stylistic features or examples of skilled craftsmanship which characterize a building,
structure or site shall be treated with sensitivity.
f. Deteriorated architectural features shall be repaired rather than replaced, wherever possible. In
the event replacement is necessary, the new material should match the material being replaced in
composition, design, color, texture and other visual qualities. Repair or replacement of missing
architectural features should be based on accurate duplications of features, substantiated by
historic, physical or pictorial evidence rather than on conjectural designs or the availability of
different architectural elements from other buildings or structures.
g. The surface cleaning of structures shall be undertaken with the gentlest means possible.
Sandblasting and other cleaning methods that will damage the historic building materials shall not
be undertaken.
h. Every reasonable effort shall be made to protect and preserve archeological resources affected
by or adjacent to any project.
i. Contemporary design for alterations and additions to existing properties shall not be discouraged
when such alterations and additions do not destroy significant historical, architectural or cultural
material and such design is compatible with the size, scale, color, material and character of the
property, neighborhood or environment.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 374/735
j. Wherever possible, new additions or alterations to structures shall be done in such manner that if
such additions or alterations were to be removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of
the structure would be unimpaired.
(e)Review Process:
(1) If the commission finds that the work proposed in the application will not adversely affect any
historically or architecturally significant features of the landmark or structure or property within a
Locally Designated Historic District and is appropriate or consistent with the spirit and purposes of
this article, it shall authorize, by a majority vote, the Preservation Administrator to issue a Certificate
of Appropriateness and forward copies to the applicant and the Inspection Division.
(2) If the commission finds that the proposed work will adversely affect or destroy any significant
historic, aesthetic or architectural feature or value of the landmark or structure or property within a
Locally Designated Historic District or is inappropriate or inconsistent with the spirit and purposes of
this article, it shall deny the application by a majority and shall so direct the Preservation
Administrator to notify the applicant within ten (10) days of the decision.
a. The commission shall state briefly its reasons therefor in writing and it may make
recommendations to the applicant with respect to the appropriateness of design, arrangement,
texture, scale, material, color, location or other elements of appearance of the building or structure
involved.
b. In cases of disapproval accompanied by recommendation, the applicant may be heard again
before the commission if within sixty (60) days of the date of receipt of notice of disapproval of the
application they amend their application to conform to the recommendations or makes application
for a Certificate of Economic Hardship as provided for in section 11-114 of this division. The
applicant shall be heard at the next regular meeting of the commission after receipt of the
amended application and the commission shall approve or disapprove the amended application by
resolution passed by a majority vote.
c. At the request of the applicant, within fifteen (15) days following disapproval of an application,
the commission shall hold a public hearing. The commission shall also hold a public hearing upon
receipt of an application for a Certificate of Economic Hardship pursuant to section 11-114 of this
division.
d. Notice of the date, time, place and purpose of the public hearing shall be sent by regular mail to
the applicant, to property owners within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the property for which an
application has been made, and said notice shall be published in a newspaper of general
circulation. The notice shall be sent not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing. The
notice shall state the location, including the common street address of the property and a brief
description of the proposed alteration for which an application has been made and the differences
of opinion between the applicant and the commission.
e. At the public hearing the commission shall take testimony presented by the owner(s) and any
other interested parties concerning the effect of the proposed alteration, demolition or removal
upon the exterior architectural features and the review criteria in subsection (d) of this section.
f. Within fifteen (15) days following completion of the public hearing, the commission shall issue or
deny the Certificate of Appropriateness or Certificate of Economic Hardship and transmit copies of
its decision to the applicant. (Ord. 054-2018, 9-24-2018)
Sec. 11-114. Certificate Of Economic Hardship:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 375/735
(a)Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this article to the contrary, the commission may issue a
Certificate of Economic Hardship to allow the perform of work for which a Certificate of
Appropriateness has been denied.
(b)Applicants claiming economic hardship shall be required to apply to the Redevelopment Division to
determine eligibility for rehabilitation assistance. The eligibility for and availability of financial aid shall
be considered by the commission in making its decision.
(c)An applicant for a Certificate of Economic Hardship may submit any or all of the following information
in order to assist the commission in making its determination on the application:
(1) The amount paid for the property, the date of purchase and the party from whom purchased
(including a description of the relationship, if any, between the owner and the person from whom the
property was purchased).
(2) The assessed value of the land and improvements thereon according to the two (2) most recent
assessments.
(3) Real Estate Taxes for the previous two (2) years.
(4) Remaining balance on mortgage, if any, and annual debt service, if any, for the previous two (2)
years.
(5) All appraisals obtained within the previous two (2) years by the owner or applicant in connection
with their purchase, financing or ownership of the property.
(6) Any listing of the property for sale or rent, price asked and offers received, if any.
(7) Any consideration by the owner as to profitable adaptive uses for the property.
(8) If the property is income producing, the annual gross income from the property for the previous
two (2) years, itemized operating and maintenance expenses for the previous two (2) years, and
annual cash flow before and after debt service, if any during the same period.
(9) Form of ownership or operation of the property, whether sole proprietorship, for-profit or not-forprofit
corporation, limited partnership, joint venture or other.
(10) Evidence of any substantial decrease in fair market value, unfavorable tax impact, or additional
cost of work resulting from the denial of a COA.
(11) In the case of a proposed demolition, the economic feasibility of rehabilitation or reuse.
(12) Any other information, including the Income Tax bracket of the owner, applicant or principal
investors in the property, reasonably necessary for a determination as to whether the property can be
reasonably used or yield a reasonable return to present or future owners.
(d)If the commission finds that without approval of the proposed work, the property cannot obtain a
reasonable economic return therefrom, then the application shall be delayed for a period not to
exceed three (3) months. During this period of delay, the commission shall investigate plans and
make recommendations to the City Council to allow for a reasonably beneficial use or a reasonable
economic return, or to otherwise preserve the subject property. Such plans and recommendations
may include, but not be limited to, a relaxation of the provisions of this article, a reduction in Real
Property Taxes, financial assistance, Building Code modifications and/or changes in zoning
regulations.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 376/735
(e)If by the end of this three (3) month period, the commission has found that without approval of the
proposed work, the property cannot be put to a reasonable beneficial use or the owner cannot obtain
a reasonable economic return therefrom, then the commission shall issue a Certificate of Economic
Hardship approving the proposed work. If the commission finds otherwise, it shall deny the
application for a Certificate of Economic Hardship. (Ord. 054-2018, 9-24-2018)
Sec. 11-115. Appeals:
(a)When a Certificate of Appropriateness or a Certificate of Economic Hardship is approved or denied
for either a landmark or a structure within a historic district, the applicant or any interested party may,
within thirty (30) days, appeal the commission's decision to the City Council. The Council may
receive comments on the contents of the record but no new matter may be considered by the
Council. The City Council may affirm the decision or recommend changes by a majority vote of the
Council after due consideration of the facts contained in the record submitted to the Council by the
commission. The Council may overturn the commission's decision by a majority vote of a quorum of
the Council. If the Council decides that a Certificate of Economic Hardship should be issued, the
Preservation Administrator shall notify the applicant and the Inspection Division within seven (7) days
of the Council's decision and the Inspection Division then shall issue the permit within fifteen (15)
days.
(b)If the Council concurs with the commission's decision not to issue a Certificate of Economic Hardship,
the Preservation Administrator shall notify the applicant and the Inspection Division within seven (7)
days. (Ord. 054-2018, 9-24-2018)
Secs. 11-116-11-120. Reserved:
ARTICLE VI. ENTERPRISE ZONE
Sec. 11-121. Boundaries:
The City designates as an enterprise zone the real estate included within the boundaries as described in
exhibit A, as attached hereto and incorporated herein (but not reproduced at length in this Code). (Ord.
84-67, 12-17-1984; Ord. 84-84, 2-25-1985; Ord. 86-04, 2-24-1986; Ord. 86-19, 4-28-1986; Ord. 93-69,
7-12-1993; Ord. 93-70, 7-12-1993; Ord. 95-37, 5-15-1995; Ord. 97-74, 8-11-1997; Ord. 97-79, 9-15-
1997; Ord. 57-2004, 5-10-2004; Ord. 062-2005, 8-8-2005; Ord. 052-2006, 7-24-2006; Ord. 038-2007, 5-
21-2007; Ord. 058-2013, 10-21-2013; Ord. 059-2013, 10-21-2013)
Sec. 11-122. Findings:
The City does now declare and find that the enterprise zone as above described meets the qualifications
of 20 Illinois Compiled Statutes 655/4 in that the area is a contiguous area, compromises a minimum
one-half (1/2) square mile, not more than ten (10) square miles in total area, exclusive of lakes and
waterways, is a depressed area, is entirely within the Municipality and satisfies all additional criteria
established by regulation of the Department of Commerce and Community Affairs consistent with the
purposes of the Illinois Enterprise Zone Act. (Ord. 84-67, 12-17-1984)
Sec. 11-123. Zone Administrator:
(a)The position of "Zone Administrator" is hereby created. The Zone Administrator shall be the
Community Development Director, who is an employee of the City. The duties of the Zone
Administrator shall be performed in addition to the regular duties of the Community Development
Director position.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 377/735
(b)It shall be the power and duty of the Zone Administrator to:
(1) Supervise the implementation of the provisions of this article and the Illinois Enterprise Zone Act;
(2) Act as a liaison between the City, the State Department of Commerce and Community Affairs,
designated zone organizations; and other State, Federal, and local agencies, whether public or
private;
(3) Conduct an ongoing evaluation of the enterprise zone program and submit such evaluative
reports on an annual basis to the Mayor or the City Council;
(4) Promote the coordination of other relevant programs, including, but not limited to, housing,
community and economic development, small business, financial assistance and employment
training within the enterprise zone;
(5) Recommend qualified designated zone organizations to the City Council;
(6) Complete and submit reports as required by the Department of Commerce and Community
Affairs; and
(7) Have other such duties as specified by either the Mayor or the City Council. (Ord. 84-67, 12-17-
1984; Ord. 84-84, 2-25-1985)
Sec. 11-124. Role Of Community Development Department:
The City will direct and target business assistance and business retention programs through its
Community Development Department. The Zone Administrator will assume the lead role in coordinating
the delivery of existing programs and services and the establishment of new programs and services to
address the needs of the zone. (Ord. 84-67, 12-17-1984)
Sec. 11-125. Designated Zone Organizations:
The Zone Administrator shall recommend to the City Council one or more organizations that qualify as
designated zone organizations under the provisions of the Illinois Enterprise Zone Act. Upon approval of
the City Council, for a term of years set by the City Council, the organization may:
(1) Provide or contract for provision of services including, but not limited to, crime watch patrols
within zone neighborhoods; volunteer daycare centers; or other types of public services as provided
by ordinance or regulation and as provided for in section 8 of the Illinois Enterprise Zone Act;
(2) Provide a forum for business, labor and government action on enterprise zone innovations;
(3) Receive title to publicly owned land;
(4) Solicit and receive contributions to improve the quality of life in the zone area; and
(5) Perform such other functions as the City Council may deem appropriate, not inconsistent with the
Illinois Enterprise Zone Act. (Ord. 84-67, 12-17-1984)
Sec. 11-126. Land Acquisition And Clearance:
The City shall provide technical assistance with commercial and industrial land acquisition and clearance
activities which may be proposed to occur within the enterprise zone. (Ord. 84-67, 12-17-1984)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 378/735
Sec. 11-127. "One Stop" Development Review:
The city will establish a "one stop" development review process for commercial and industrial projects
such that the community development department would secure the review and approval of all other city
departments. (Ord. 84-67, 12-17-1984)
Sec. 11-128. Certain Fees Waived:
(a)The city hereby waives application fees for industrial development revenue bond proposals for
projects which will be located within the enterprise zone.
(b)The city hereby waives application fees for commercial and industrial zoning changes of board of
zoning appeal authorizations for projects which will be located within the enterprise zone. (Ord. 84-
67, 12-17-1984)
Sec. 11-129. Priority Given To Certain Loan Applications:
The city shall give priority to fundable projects within the enterprise zone for applications to the
commercial industrial revolving loan fund. (Ord. 84-67, § 8, 12-17-1984)
Sec. 11-130. Rental Rehabilitation:
The city shall give priority for the rental rehabilitation program such that candidate projects from within
the zone would be favored provided said properties are located in residentially zoned areas. (Ord. 84-67,
§ 9, 12-17-1984; Ord. 84-84, § 2, 2-25-1985)
Sec. 11-131. Urban Homesteading:
The city shall give priority for the urban homesteading program such that available homes in residentially
zoned areas of the enterprise zone would be favored for city acquisition and disposition to eligible
households. (Ord. 84-67, § 10, 12-17-1984; Ord. 84-84, § 3, 2-25-1985)
Sec. 11-132. Urban Shopstead:
(a)Pursuant to section 10 of the Illinois enterprise zone act 1, the city hereby establishes an urban
shopstead program. Under the urban shopsteading program, the city may sell to a designated zone
organization a structure or portion thereof it owns for a sum not to exceed one hundred dollars
($100.00). The designated zone organization shall agree to renovate or remodel the property to meet
the standards and level of maintenance stated in the agreement between the designated zone
organization and the city. The designated zone organization may sell or lease such structure to
commercial or industrial businesses pursuant to the procedures set forth in the sales agreement
between it and the city. The designated zone organization may retain the structure in whole or in part
for its own use. Any proceeds derived from the use, lease or sale of such property shall be used for
cost recovery and for activities entered into pursuant to section 8 of the act.
(b)The urban shopstead program shall be subject to rules and guidelines issued by the zone
administrator, with the approval of the council of the city, provided such rules and guidelines are not
inconsistent with the act. (Ord. 84-67, § 16, 12-17-1984)
Sec. 11-133. Landmarks And Historic Places:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 379/735
The city shall provide technical assistance within local landmark designations and National Register of
Historic Places nominations pursuant to the use of investment tax credits for rehabilitation of properties
located within the enterprise zone. (Ord. 84-67, § 13, 12-17-1984)
Sec. 11-134. Technical Assistance To Certain Organizations:
(a)The city shall provide technical assistance to the community caring conference in its organization and
support of block clubs within the enterprise zone. (Ord. 84-67, §§ 14, 15, 12-17-1984; Ord. 68-2004,
§ 2, 6-14-2004)
Sec. 11-135. Tax Deduction For Building Materials:
Each retailer who makes a qualified sale of building materials to be incorporated into real estate in the
Rock Island enterprise zone by remodeling, rehabilitation or new construction, may deduct receipts from
such sales when calculating the tax imposed by the Illinois retailers' occupation tax act 2. A "qualified
sale" is defined as a sale of building materials that will be incorporated into real estate as part of a
building project for which a building permit has been obtained and for which a certificate of eligibility for
sales tax exemption has been issued by the zone administrator. (Ord. 84-67, § 4, 12-17-1984; Ord. 68-
2004, § 3, 6-14-2004)
Sec. 11-136. Property Tax Abatement Incentive:
The city of Rock Island authorizes and directs the Rock Island county clerk to abate ad valorem taxes
imposed upon real property, located within the Rock Island enterprise zone area, upon which new
improvements have been constructed or upon which existing improvements have been renovated or
rehabilitated, subject to the following conditions:
(1) Property tax abatement shall apply only to the taxes corresponding to an increase in assessed
valuation attributable to the construction of improvements and the renovation of existing
improvements for which a building permit is required and has been obtained; no portion of tax
attributable to the assessed valuation of land shall be abated.
(2) Tax abatement shall begin with the first tax bill reflecting a full property tax assessment on
improvements. No abatement shall be offered for taxes attributable to a partial assessment.
(3) Tax abatement shall be at the rate of seventy five percent (75%) of taxes due and payable to the
city of Rock Island in the applicable tax year. Said tax abatement shall be granted to improvements
for which a certificate of occupancy is granted on or after January 1, 2005.
(4) Tax abatement shall be offered for a period of three (3) consecutive tax years. Said abatement for
a specific project will cease after the third year of abatement or upon the expiration of the enterprise
zone, whichever is sooner.
(5) Tax abatement shall apply only to nonresidential improvements which result in an increase in
assessed valuation of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or more.
(6) No abatement shall be granted to any project within the boundaries of a tax increment
redevelopment project area. (Ord. 86-58, §§ 1, 2, 11-24-1986; Ord. 87-10, § 1, 2-2-1987; Ord. 92-31,
§ 1, 2-24-1992; Ord. 68-2004, § 4, 6-14-2004)
Sec. 11-137. Redevelopment Sales Tax Increments 3:
(a)The city council hereby makes the following findings:

(1) The city council adopted tax increment financing pursuant to the provisions of the act 4 in respect

available for inspection in the office of the city clerk), and all conditions and provisions of the act 5
and amendment (public act 84-1417), have been complied with since the adoption of tax increment

(2) The redevelopment project area, described in attachment A would not reasonably be developed

(d)The city shall deposit in its special tax allocation fund all incremental revenues from the municipal
retailers' occupation tax act, the municipal service occupation tax act, and local real property taxes,
received with respect to property within the redevelopment project area. (Ord. 86-57, §§ 1-4, 11-17-
1986)
ARTICLE VII. SITE PLANS
Sec. 11-138. Administrative Approval Requirements:
If a building or parking lot permit is applied for and no zoning action is required, an administrative site
plan approval will be required. Riverfront corridor overlay district site plan review application information
and performance standards shall apply in making application for administrative site plan review
approval. (Ord. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-1991)
Sec. 11-139. Site Plan Review Committee:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 381/735
An administrative site plan review committee is hereby created consisting of the planning and
redevelopment administrator, city engineer, fire chief, parks director, and chief building inspector, or their
designees. Committee meeting shall be called on an as needed basis for site plans not requiring a public
hearing review. An application for a building or parking lot permit shall be promptly forwarded by the
planning and redevelopment administrator to the site plan review committee. Review must be completed
within fifteen (15) days of the receipt of the city of a complete site plan review application. If, in the
committee's judgment, the site plan review application does not contain sufficient information to enable
the committee to properly carry out its responsibilities, the committee may request additional information
from the applicant. In that event, the fifteen (15) day period previously referred to shall be suspended
pending the receipt of all information requested by the committee. (Ord. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-1991)
Sec. 11-140. Appeal Process:
If the site plan review committee approves a site plan, a building or parking lot permit may then be
issued. If the site plan review committee does not approve a site plan, the applicant may appeal the
committee's decision to the city council. A notice of appeal must be filed with the planning and
redevelopment administrator no later than fifteen (15) days after receipt by the applicant of the decision
of the site plan review committee. (Ord. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-1991)
Sec. 11-141. Exemption from site plan requirements.
As with Riverfront Corridor Overlay District site plan requirements, one- and two-family residences are
exempt from city-wide site plan review requirements. In addition, site plans shall not be required for the
renovation or expansion of an existing structure or use unless access points would be changed or a
substantial increase in traffic to the site would be generated.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
ARTICLE VIII. PARKING LOTS
Sec. 11-142. Penalty.
Every violation of any provision of this article shall subject the offender to a fine of not less than one
dollar ($1.00) and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), for each offense.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
Sec. 11-143. Permits for off-street parking lots.
No person shall expand an existing parking lot or construct a new parking lot of five (5) or more spaces
without first having obtained a written permit therefor issued by the planning and redevelopment
administrator or his designated representative. No person shall expand any existing parking lot or
construct a new parking lot within the Downtown 2000 area without first having obtained the permit. Prior
to obtaining a permit for such expansion or new construction, the applicant shall submit to the planning
and redevelopment administrator or his designated representative a landscape/site plan as required in
the zoning ordinance and plans showing the construction specifications of surface improvements. The
director of public works or his designated representative shall set construction specifications for all offstreet
parking lots, and he shall provided for proper inspection of construction.
Cross reference--Zoning, App. A.
Sec. 11-144. Construction.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 382/735
All off-street parking lots required to obtain a permit as identified in section 11-143 shall be laid to the
line and grade of, and shall conform to surface thickness and other specifications of the director of public
works or his designated representative.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
Sec. 11-145. Landscaping and screening requirements for off-street parking lots.
The provisions of this section for the installation and maintenance of landscaping and screening
requirements are intended to protect the character and stability of residential, commercial, industrial and
conservation areas and to enhance the aesthetic and visual image of the city.
(1)Parking lots of five (5) or more spaces shall be set back ten (10) feet from the front property line(s).
Landscaping requirements within the front yard(s) include that the yard be seeded or sodded with
lawn. Rock ground cover may be used but may not exceed twenty (20) percent of the landscaped
front yard setback. In addition, one (1) canopy tree for every five (5) parking spaces and a minimum
five (5) percent ground landscape coverage of shrubs and evergreens/conifers shall be required.
The ten-foot front yard setback may be reduced to five (5) feet if there is a continuous twenty-six (26)
inch solid wall/fence or shrubbery hedge provided. Sodding, rock ground cover, canopy tree and
ground landscape coverage requirements will still be applied if a solid wall/fence is provided. Sodding
and/or rock ground requirements will still be applied if a shrubbery fence is provided.
(2)Parking lots of five (5) or more spaces shall be set back five (5) feet from side and rear property lines.
Landscaping requirements within the side and rear yards include that the yard be seeded or sodded
with lawn. Rock ground may be used, but may not exceed twenty (20) percent of the landscaped side
and rear yard setback. In addition, one (1) canopy tree for every five (5) parking spaces and a
minimum of five (5) percent ground landscape coverage of shrubs and evergreens/conifers shall be
required.
When a side and/or rear yard is adjacent to a residential use, a continuous four-foot solid wall/fence
or shrubbery hedge shall also be provided within the five-foot setback yard. If a four-foot shrubbery
hedge is provided, canopy tree and ground landscape coverage shall not be required.
(3)Wherever landscaping and screening requirements may interfere with traffic vision, the height and
placement shall be determined by the city engineer.
(4)Trees and other landscaping shall be of a species which are hardy to the area and have measured
diameters of such identified in section 11-150. Prohibited trees are identified in section 11-151.
(5)Subject to the approval of the site plan review committee, alternate landscaping plans may be
submitted for consideration.
(6)A landscape/site plan will be required to be submitted for staff review prior to issuing a parking lot
development permit for parking lots of five (5) spaces or more. The following basic standards should
be set:
a. Drawn to scale.
b. Identify location of landscaping or other feature.
c. Specify nature of material (i.e., species, variety, etc.)
d. Specify number of plants, shrubs, trees, etc. by species.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 383/735
All parking areas abutting to or visible from a public street with the Downtown 2000 area shall be
required to submit a landscaping/site plan for review prior to issuance of a parking lot permit.
(7)Landscaping and screening must be maintained in good condition, free of refuse and debris, and
provide a healthy, neat and orderly appearance at least equal to the original installation. It shall be
the owner's responsibility to see that the landscaping is maintained.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
Sec. 11-146. Appeal process.
If the site plan review committee approves a site plan, a parking lot permit may then be issued. If the site
plan review committee does not approve a site plan, the applicant may appeal the committee's decision
to the city council. A notice of appeal must be filed with the planning and redevelopment administrator no
later than fifteen (15) days after receipt by the applicant of the decision of the site plan review
committee.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
ARTICLE IX. BUFFER YARD REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 11-147. Intent.
The provisions of this article are to provide specific landscape and screening buffer yard requirements to
reduce the incompatibility between zoning districts of different intensity and type. These buffer yards will
lessen the adverse impacts of more intense land uses upon residential areas and/or other areas of less
intense land use by reducing noise, visual and other environmental impacts.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
Sec. 11-148. Buffer yard requirements.
In addition to landscaping and screening requirements for off-street parking areas, buffer yard standards
will also apply for site plans requiring a zoning change, special use permit, and nonexempt site plan
review requirements. The buffer yard requirement is determined by the difference between the zoning
district of the subject property and the zoning district of adjacent properties. The specific requirements
are identified in sections 11-149 and 11-150 and the accompanying table. "Schedule of Buffer Yard
Requirements" in section 11-153. Landscaping and screening requirements for off-street parking areas
apply to the sides of the property abutting a public street right-of-way. A list of prohibited tree species is
identified in section 11-151.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
Sec. 11-149. Description of buffer yards A through D.
(a)Type A Buffer: The standard buffer within type A is eight (8) feet wide and contains the following
number of required plants per one hundred (100) feet:
a. One (1) canopy tree.
b. One (1) understory tree.
c. Six (6) shrubs.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 384/735
d. One (1) evergreen/conifer.
(2) Depending on the space available, the applicant may choose one of several alternative buffer
widths to provide a type A buffer each with a different amount of required plantings reflected as a
multiplier of the required plant units per one hundred (100) feet. These alternatives include the
following:
a. Twenty-foot wide buffer with fifty (50) percent of the required plant units per one hundred (100)
feet.
b. Sixteen-foot wide buffer with sixty (60) percent of the required plant units per one hundred (100)
feet.
c. Twelve-foot wide buffer with eighty (80) percent of the required plat units per one hundred (100)
feet.
d. Four-foot wide buffer with ninety (90) percent of the required plant units and a continuous hedge
set back three (3) feet from the property line or fence.
(b)Type B Buffer:
(1) The standard buffer with type B is ten (10) feet wide and contains the following number of
required plants per one hundred (100) feet:
a. Two (2) canopy trees.
b. Two (2) understory trees.
c. Six (6) shrubs.
d. Two (2) evergreens/conifers.
(2) Depending on the space available, the applicant may choose one of several alternative buffer
widths to provide a type B buffer each with a different amount of required plantings. Type B buffer
alternatives range from a twenty-five-foot wide buffer with fifty (50) percent of the required plantings
to a five-foot wide buffer with ninety (90) percent of the required plantings and a continuous hedge or
fence.
(c)Type C Buffer:
(1) The standard buffer within type C is fifteen (15) wide and contains the following number of
required plants per one hundred (100) feet:
a. Three (3) canopy trees.
b. Two (2) understory trees.
c. Nine (9) shrubs.
d. Three (3) evergreens/conifers.
(2) Depending on the space available, the applicant may choose one of several alternative buffer
widths to provide a type C buffer, each with a different amount of required plantings. Type C buffer
alternatives range from a twenty-five-foot wide buffer with sixty (60) percent of the required plantings
to a six-foot-wide buffer with ninety (90) percent of the required plantings and a continuous fence.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 385/735
(d)Type D Buffer:
(1) The standard buffer within type D is fifteen (15) feet wide and contains the following number of
required plants per one hundred (100) feet:
a. Three (3) canopy trees.
b. Two (2) understory trees.
c. Fifteen (15) shrubs.
d. Five (5) evergreens/conifers.
(2) Depending on the space available, the applicant may choose one of several alternative buffer
widths to provide a type D buffer each with a different amount of required plantings. Type D buffer
alternatives range from a twenty-five-foot-wide buffer with sixty (60) percent of the required plantings
to an eight-foot-wide buffer with ninety (90) percent of the required plantings and a continuous fence.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
Sec. 11-150. Minimum standards for plantings.
(a)Canopy Trees: Two (2) inches diameter, six (6) inches above ground level and ten (10) feet in height
when planted.
(b)Understory Trees: One (1) inch diameter, six (6) inches above ground level, and six (6) feet in height
when planted.
(c)Shrubs: Twenty-four (24) inches in height when planted. Forty (40) percent or more must reach
mature height of six (6) or more.
(d)Evergreens/Conifers: Two (2) inches diameter, six (6) inches above ground level, and six (6) feet in
height when planted; twenty (20) feet minimum height at maturity.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
Sec. 11-151. Prohibited trees.
The following weak-wooded and generally undesirable trees, for urban conditions, shall be prohibited for
use in meeting any of the landscaping and screening requirements for off-street parking areas and/or
bufferyard requirements:
(1) Ailanthus (tree of heaven).
(2) Box elder.
(3) European mountain ash.
(4) European white birch.
(5) Mulberry.
(6) Poplar.
(7) Purple-leaf plum.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 386/735
(8) Russian olive.
(9) Siberian elm.
(10) Silver maple.
(11) Willow.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)
Sec. 11-152. Maintenance of landscaping and screening.
Buffer yard landscaping and screening must be maintained in good condition, free of refuse and debris,
and provide a healthy, neat and orderly appearance at least equal to the original installation. It shall be
the owner's responsibility to see that the landscaping is maintained.
(Ord. No. 91-87, § 1, 7-22-91)

Chapter 12
POLICE 1
Sec. 12-1. Creation Of Department:
There is hereby created a police department in the city. The department shall be supervised by a police
chief. The police chief shall be subject to the direction and control of the city manager. (1963 Code, Ch.
II, Art. III)
Sec. 12-2. Personnel 1:
(a)Chief Of The Department: Except as provided herein the police department shall consist of the chief
and such personnel as shall from time to time be appointed and dismissed by the board of fire and
police commissioners. The chief of the police department shall be appointed and dismissed by the
city manager with the approval and consent of a majority of the members of the city council. No chief
shall be dismissed without a public hearing before the city council if he requests same.
(b)Appointment Of Deputy Chief Of Police: The chief of the police department shall appoint a deputy
chief of police from the promoted ranks of police captain or police lieutenant. The deputy chief of
police shall be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police. The deputy chief of police
shall serve in such a position until such time as the chief of police determines otherwise.
(c)Removal Of The Deputy Chief Of Police: If the chief of police determines that it is necessary and
desirable to appoint another person to the position of deputy chief of police, then the previously
appointed person shall, to the extent he or she was a sworn officer of the police department prior to
being appointed deputy chief of police, automatically return to his or her prior rank, together with all
authority, responsibility and compensation commensurate with such prior rank. (1963 Code, Ch. II,
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 388/735
Art. III and Ch. VII; Ord., § 1, 8-12-1963; Ord., § 1, 3-19-1964; Ord., § 1, 4-27-1970; Ord., § 1, 8-10-
1970; Ord., § 1, 10-12-1970; Ord., § 1, 10-1-1973; Ord., § 1, 7-12-1976; Ord. 044-2009, § 1, 6-15-
2009)
Sec. 12-3. Auxiliary Police:
(a)The mayor may, with the advice and consent of the city council, appoint auxiliary police officers not to
exceed fifty (50) in number from names furnished him by the chief of police.
(b)Auxiliary police officers shall not be members of the regular police department and shall not possess
conservator of the peace powers as defined at 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-15-25.
(c)Auxiliary police officers shall serve at the direction and control of the chief of police and shall have the
following powers and duties:
(1) To aid or direct traffic in the municipality;
(2) To aid in the control of natural or manmade disasters;
(3) To aid in case of civil disorder;
(4) To act at the direction and control of the chief of police in any other activity, other than those
activities traditionally reserved to those who are vested with conservator of the peace powers.
(d)Auxiliary police officers may wear uniforms. Uniforms and identification symbols worn by auxiliary
police officers must be different and distinct from those worn by regular police officers.
(e)Auxiliary police officers may, with prior permission of the chief of police, carry firearms while on duty.
(f)All auxiliary police officers shall successfully complete the forty (40) hour mandatory firearms training
course before being permitted to carry a firearm, as specified in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-
30-20. Upon completion of the course of training, the chief of police shall file a certificate attesting to
the auxiliary police officer's successful completion of the required forty (40) hour mandatory firearms
training course.
(g)Auxiliary police officers shall receive no compensation for services rendered. (1963 Code, Ch. VII;
Ord., § 1, 2-13-1978; Ord., § 1, 11-24-1980; Ord. 024-2007, § 1, 3-19-2007)
Sec. 12-4. Pension Fund Board Creation 2:
There is hereby created a board of trustees of the police pension fund, consisting of five (5) members,
two (2) members of which shall be appointed by the mayor, serving a term of two (2) years each. Two (2)
members shall be elected from the regular police force of the city by the active members thereof. The
fifth member of the board shall be elected by and from the beneficiaries of the police pension fund. The
elected members of the board shall serve for a term of two (2) years. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III)
Sec. 12-5. Pension Fund Board Duties 3:
The board of trustees shall manage, invest and control the police pension fund and all monies pertaining
thereto in the manner provided by statute. (1963 Code, Ch. II, Art. III)
Sec. 12-6. Fees For Fingerprinting Services:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 389/735
A fee in the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be charged by the police department for providing the
following services:
(1) To provide, upon request of an individual or business, the fingerprints of an individual for
submission under the conviction information request of the state of Illinois.
(2) For providing fingerprints for any other purpose when requested by an individual or business of a
particular individual. (Ord. 91-137, § 1, 12-16-1991)
Chapter 13
PUBLIC WORKS, STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 1 2 3
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 13-1. Public Works Department Created:
There is hereby created a Public Works Department in the City. This department shall be administered
by a Director of Public Works appointed by and subject to the direction and control of the City Manager.
The Director shall supervise the various divisions of this department, and in addition thereto he shall
perform such further duties as may from time to time be directed by the City Manager. (1963 Code art. 2-
3)
Sec. 13-2. Duties Of Director:
The Director of Public Works shall supervise and coordinate all activities relating to street operations,
garage operations, engineering, sewer operations, and water operations; and in addition thereto, he
shall perform such further duties as may from time to time be directed by the City Manager. (Ord. 87-22,
3-23-1987)
Secs. 13-3-13-20. Reserved:
ARTICLE II. SOLID WASTE 4
Sec. 13-21. Definitions:
The following definitions shall apply in this article:
Commercial Refuse: That rubbish and garbage from commercial establishments and industrial plants.
Containers: Residential refuse containers shall be metal or plastic, waterproof, ratproof and flytight, with
handles. Plastic bags may be used but must be tied closed. Commercial refuse containers shall be
waterproof, ratproof and flytight.
Garbage: The animal and vegetable waste resulting from handling, preparation, processing, cooking or
consumption of food; animal waste; and any waste material edible to rats, with the exception of
sewerage and dead animals.
Nuisances: As defined in section 7-234 of this Code.
Refuse: All garbage and rubbish within the City limits.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 390/735
Residential Refuse: That rubbish and garbage accumulated from dwellings.
Residential Solid Waste Disposal Rules: The Public Works Department rules and regulations governing
the collection and disposal of solid waste from residential properties.
Rubbish: Any waste material except that which is defined as "garbage" excluding sewerage, yard waste
and dead animals. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 88-46, 8-22-1988; Ord. 96-41, 6-10-1996; Ord. 001-
2006, 1-16-2006)
Sec. 13-22. General Conditions:
(a)It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any refuse upon any street, alley, lane or public or
private property in the City.
(b)It shall be the responsibility of the owner of record to keep the property in compliance with this article.
(Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 96-41, 6-10-1996)
Sec. 13-23. Enforcement:
(Rep. by Ord. 96-41, 6-10-1996)
Sec. 13-24. Storage Facilities For Refuse:
(a)Residential, commercial and industrial buildings shall have an animalproof garbage storage area or
animalproof containers.
(b)All rubbish in commercial and residential areas shall be disposed of in containers which prevent
scattering.
(c)It shall be the responsibility of the owner of record and/or tenant to keep the garbage and rubbish
area free from garbage and rubbish on the ground 1.
(d)In residential areas, the garbage and rubbish storage areas shall be located behind the front building
line of the property. Garbage and rubbish storage areas shall not be located on the alley right-of-way.
(e)Garbage shall be stored in animalproof containers or in plastic bags which will be stored in the
animalproof garbage storage area. When garbage and rubbish are mixed, the rubbish must be
handled in the same manner as garbage.
(f)A minimum pick up once a week is required of all commercial and residential garbage and rubbish,
weather permitting. This may be waived in writing by the Director of Public Works or his designated
representative in a case where special equipment is used.
(g)Every outside garbage and rubbish storage container shall be so maintained that no odors permeate
any dwelling unit.
(h)In areas or establishments serviced by private haulers, the containers will be located on the private
property. The Director of Public Works or his designated representative may order a specific location
for the container if the City receives complaints concerning the location of the container. Screening of
this area shall conform to standards found in the zoning ordinance. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-
22, 3-23-1987; Ord. 96-41, 6-10-1996; Ord. 001-2006, 1-16-2006; Ord. 008-2010, 2-8-2010)
Sec. 13-25. Collection; Removal Generally:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 391/735
The Public Works Department shall provide solid waste collection and disposal services to residential
properties in Rock Island with four (4) or fewer dwelling units as described in the residential solid waste
disposal rules. Effective January 1, 2018, the refuse charge shall be eleven dollars ($11.00) per month,
per dwelling unit.
Residential properties with more than four (4) dwelling units may elect to receive solid waste and
disposal services from the Public Works Department or make alternate arrangements. If the services
provided by the Public Works Department are used, effective January 1, 2018, the refuse charge shall
be eleven dollars ($11.00) per month, per dwelling unit. (Ord. 057-2017, 12-18-2017)
Sec. 13-26. Collection Of Brush:
Brush in piles must be removed from a property within thirty (30) days of breaking or cutting. (1963 Code
art. 6-2; Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 001-2006, 1-16-2006)

(a)Offal and septic tank pumpings will be handled only by written permission of the Director of Public
Works or his designated representative and shall be in approved equipment.
(b)Disposal of sewage in holding tanks of travel trailers and boats shall be done at sanitary dumping
stations or as the public health sanitarian (Director of Public Works) may approve. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-
1982; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 13-28. Animal Wastes 2:
Animal wastes must be cleaned up twice a week, and no odor is to be present at the property line at any
time. Animal wastes shall be handled as garbage. (Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982)
Sec. 13-29. Dead Animals:
An owner may bury dead animals twenty four inches (24") below the surface of the ground. (Ord. 82-28,
9-27-1982)
Sec. 13-30. Containers Generally:
(Rep. by Ord. 001-2006, § 4, 1-16-2006)

(a)No person shall own, for use within the corporate limits of the city, any commercial refuse or garbage
container without identifying upon the side of the container the name of the owner in letters at least
four inches (4") in height. Any container not identified by the name of the owner is in violation of this
section.
(b)No damaged containers shall be used for the collection of refuse garbage. The owner of a damaged
container with refuse or garbage in it shall repair it within seven (7) days of written notice from the
director of public works or his designated representative of the city.
(c)The owner of any refuse or garbage container shall keep the container in a clean and sanitary
condition and shall cause the container to be emptied at least every seven (7) days, if not necessary
prior to that time. The owner of the container who receives written notice from the director of public

works or his designated representative of the city that the container requires cleaning shall clean the
container within seven (7) days of the notice.
(d)Any container without identification of the owner on it, which is left on public or private property

Sec. 13-32. Needles, Syringes, Lancets And Sharp Objects:

Sec. 13-33. Commercial Rubbish And Garbage Haulers 2:
The following regulations apply to all haulers of septic tank pumpings, offal, garbage and rubbish:
(1) Vehicles and containers for hauling garbage shall be watertight and equipped with tight covers
and shall be subject to approval by the director of public works or his designated representative.
(2) Vehicles and containers for hauling rubbish shall be so constructed and equipped as to prevent
loss of contents when the vehicle is being operated on public streets.
(3) No hauler may store waste materials mentioned in this article within the city without written
permission of the director of public works or his designated representative.
(4) It shall be the responsibility of the commercial hauler to empty containers when full. The container
must be emptied within twenty four (24) hours after notification by the public works director or
designated representative. A telephone call to the hauler's office is considered to be notification.
(Ord. 82-28, 9-27-1982; Ord. 87-22, 3-23-1987; Ord. 96-41, 6-10-1996)

(Rep. by Ord. 96-41, 6-10-1996)

Sec. 13-37. Nuisances:
(Rep. by Ord. 96-40, 6-10-1996)
Sec. 13-38. Removal Of Weeds And Grass; Lien:
(a)The public works director of the city may provide for the removal of weeds and/or grass over ten
inches (10") in height on private property within the city when the owner of such property, after
reasonable notice, refuses or neglects to cut said weeds or grass. "Weeds" shall be defined as all
grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than trees or shrubs, provided, however, this term shall
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 393/735
not include cultivated flowers and gardens, including, but not limited to, native planting used for
aesthetic and/or wildlife promotion, to attract and aid wildlife, and/or offset and control any soil loss
problems either occurring or predicted, and/or promote stormwater infiltration into the soil, and/or
transpiration of stormwater by plants. If the cultivated flowers and gardens are within a three foot (3')
distance of the property line, an agreement allowing the construction of cultivated flowers and
gardens must first be obtained from the adjoining property owner nearest the proposed garden
construction. If an agreement cannot be made between adjacent property owners, a three foot (3')
buffer shall be maintained between the property line and said cultivated flowers and gardens.
Reasonable notice shall consist of one publication of this section in a newspaper of general
circulation within the city in addition to the following:
(1) When the property owner has been cited for a violation of this section during the previous growing
season, he shall be notified by letter at the beginning of the current season of his obligation to
provide for the cutting of weeds or grass on the property. The notice shall constitute reasonable
notice for the entire growing season.
(2) When the property owner has not been cited for a violation of this section during the previous
growing season he shall be provided, by letter, a seven (7) day time period in which to provide for the
removal of weeds and grass currently in violation of this section. This letter will also constitute
reasonable notice for the remainder of the growing season. If subsequent violations are observed
during the same growth season, the grass and weeds will be cut immediately and the owner will be
billed for the cost thereof.
(b)Upon refusal or neglect of any person to cut weeds or grass, the public works director may cause the
weeds or grass to be cut and shall collect from the property owner the cost for service. The charge
for that service shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00) per man hour it is necessary to complete the
work, with a minimum charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per parcel. These costs shall be billed
to the property owner along with an additional thirty dollar ($30.00) lien charge per parcel. If mowing
charges are fully paid within thirty (30) days, the thirty dollar ($30.00) lien charge will be removed. If
mowing charges are not fully paid within thirty (30) days, a second billing notice will be sent to the
property owner. Upon refusal or neglect of any person to pay such second notice within seven (7)
days, the city clerk may cause a lien to be placed on the parcel, which lien shall be superior to all
subsequent liens and encumbrances except tax liens if a notice of lien is filed in the office of the
county recorder of deeds within twelve (12) months of the date of completion of cutting weeds or
grass by the city. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:
(1) A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof.
(2) The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service.
(3) The date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the city.
(c)However, the lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have
arisen subsequent to the weed or grass cutting prior to the filing of such notice, and the lien of the
city shall not be valid as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienholder whose rights in and
to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. Upon payment of the cost and expense by
the owner of or persons interested in such property after the notice of lien has been filed, the lien
shall be released and the release may be filed on record as in the case of filing notice of lien.
(d)In addition to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, in the event of a violation of any of the
provisions of this section, the city may serve a notice of violation requiring violators to appear before
the administrative hearing officer pursuant to section 10-107 et seq., of this code. Notice is
adequately served when certified mail is sent to the owner of record for property in question. The
penalty for a first violation of this section shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00). Consecutive violations
within two (2) years at the same property are as follows:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 394/735
(1) Second offense in two (2) years: One hundred dollars ($100.00).
(2) Third offense in two (2) years: Two hundred dollars ($200.00).
(3) Fourth and all subsequent offenses in two (2) years: Four hundred dollars ($400.00).
(e)The city attorney is authorized to and may initiate litigation in the small claims court of the 14th judicial
circuit to recover weed mowing bills and liens. The city is authorized to contract with any licensed
collection agency for the collection of the sums accruing pursuant to subsection (b) of this section,
and the collection agency may recover from the property owner, in addition to those sums,
reasonable collection expenses, including court costs and attorney fees. (Ord. 85-11, 5-13-1985;
Ord. 87-38, 4-13-1987; Ord. 87-47, 4-27-1987; Ord. 88-28.1, 5-23-1988; Ord. 91-14, 2-11-1991; Ord.
91-53, 5-6-1991; Ord. 34-2001, § 1, 4-23-2001; Ord. 77-2004, § 1, 7-26-2004; Ord. 087-2014, 12-1-
2014)

Sec. 13-40. Billing And Collection Procedures:
(a)Billings for refuse charges shall be rendered by the finance department on a monthly or quarterly
basis at the discretion of the finance department.
(b)When refuse charges are not paid on or before the due date stated on the bill, a penalty shall be
added. Failure to receive a bill does not entitle the owner or customer to a remission of penalty.
(c)In the event that the city deems it necessary to refer past due refuse charges to the city attorney or a
collection agency for collection, the city may additionally recover its actual expenses so incurred,
including court costs, collection agency fees and reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 008-2010, § 3, 2-8-
2010)
Sec. 13-41. Service Charges Billed In Common:
The refuse charge may be billed on a common statement and collected along with other charges. If the
refuse charge is included on a common statement and the customer payment is insufficient to pay the
total of all portions of the statement, the payment will be applied in the following priority:
Refuse charge
Stormwater charge
Sewer charge
Water charge
Water service repair program charge
Sewer lateral repair program charge
(Ord. 008-2010, § 3, 2-8-2010)
