ARTICLE III. STREETS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 13-51. Names Generally:
The streets of this city, unless otherwise specifically designated by ordinance, shall be named and
designated as follows: The streets running north and south shall be called "streets", and they shall be
numbered from "one" upward, commencing at First Avenue as the avenue bordering on the Mississippi
River and numbering toward the south. Half-streets and avenues and courts may be specially
designated by the council. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. I)
Sec. 13-52. Street Name Signs:
The names of all streets and avenues as the same have been established by ordinance shall be plainly
designated by suitable metal signs conspicuously placed. There shall be at least one such sign placed at
each street intersection. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. I)
Sec. 13-53. Houses And Lots To Be Numbered:
The following shall be the plan of numbering the houses, lots and parts of lots fronting on any street,
avenue or public place of the city: The numbering of streets running north and south shall commence at
First Avenue; and the numbers shall run from one hundred (100) up to two hundred (200), so far as
necessary, and shall be used consecutively for the distance of the first block or fractional block, the even
numbers for the right-hand or west side of the street, and the odd numbers for the left-hand or east side
of the street. One number shall be left for and applied to each twenty feet (20') of distance; and in any
case where a building or place of business occupies less than twenty feet (20'), a fraction number shall
be used. The numbers from two hundred (200) to three hundred (300) shall in like manner be used for
the second block and in like manner for succeeding blocks, consecutively. The numbering of avenues
running east and west shall be done in like manner, commencing at First Street, even numbers being
used for the right-hand or south side of the avenue and odd numbers for the left-hand or north side of
the avenue. Each lot and part of lot fronting on any street, avenue or public place of the city not already
correctly numbered shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this division. (1963 Code,
Ch. XIII, Art. I)
Sec. 13-54. Numbers To Be Affixed To Buildings:
(a)Each of the figures of every street address number shall be not less than three inches (3") in height
and plainly marked so as to be easily read and be firmly and conspicuously affixed on the front part
of the buildings to which the same are attached.
(b)When notified by the chief building inspector to install house numbers, it shall be the duty of the
owners or occupants of all buildings fronting on any street, avenue or public place of the city to
proceed and number their buildings as herein required within thirty (30) days after such notice has
been given.
(c)No person being the owner or occupant of any building now erected and fronting on any street,
avenue or public place of the city, which is not already correctly numbered, who, after being notified
as aforesaid that the proper street numbers are of record in the city hall, shall for thirty (30) days
refuse or neglect to number any building or buildings owned or occupied by him in conformity with
the provisions of this division, or shall number any such building with any number other than that
designated by the aforesaid record. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 396/735
Sec. 13-55. Permanent Improvements; Water Pipes, Etc.:
(a)Whenever any street or alley in the city is to be permanently improved by paving or otherwise, one
copper water service pipe shall be laid from the water main on such street or alley to one foot (1')
from the lot line for each lot or part of lot having a separate water service, and all iron water service
pipes in the streets so to be improved shall be removed to the lot line on each side of such street or
alley.
(b)The cost of laying such copper water service pipes shall be borne by the owners of the property to be
served; and if after a reasonable notice from the city to lay such copper service pipe any property
owner shall neglect or refuse to lay the same, the city may proceed to lay it and collect the cost
thereof from the property owner. The city may order the installation of copper service pipes as a
separate improvement, by special assessment, in the judgment of the council. All connections with
water, sewer or gas pipes and all other supply and outlet pipes of whatever kind or nature along the
streets so to be improved must be made and laid when the streets, alleys, etc., are open and
excavated for the improvements, or prior thereto. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I)
Sec. 13-56. Railroads 1:
(a)Not To Obstruct Streets: No railroad corporation, railroad engineer, railroad conductor or other person
shall obstruct any public highway in the city, by stopping any train upon or by leaving any car or
locomotive engine standing on its tracks where the same intersects or crosses such public highway,
for a period longer than ten (10) minutes.
(b)Sewers Under Tracks: No railroad company operating within the limits of the city shall, in the
construction of its roadbed or the maintenance of its line or lines of railway, hinder or obstruct any
waterway, sewer or gutter, but shall provide, in accordance with specifications approved by the city
council, construct and maintain sufficient sluice ways, extensions of sewers or gutters under its
tracks and right of way at its own expense; and if the company fails to do so, the city shall construct
the same at the expense of the company.
(c)Speed: No railroad corporation, by itself or its agent, shall run any passenger train within the limits of
the city at a greater speed than ten (10) miles per hour, nor any other train, locomotive, engine or car
at a greater rate than six (6) miles per hour.
(d)Penalty: Any railroad corporation that shall of itself, or by any agent or employee, violate or fail to
observe any of the provisions of this section, and any agent or employee of any railroad corporation
or other person who shall violate or fail to observe the same, shall for each violation or failure to
observe the same, where no other penalty is imposed, be fined in the sum of not less than five
dollars ($5.00) nor exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. (1963 Code, ch. XIII,
art. III)
Secs. 13-57-13-70. Reserved:
DIVISION 2. EXCAVATIONS 1, 2
Sec. 13-71. Application For Permit:
(a)No person shall dig, excavate, remove, cut or in any manner tunnel under or break the surface of any
part of any street, highway, avenue, alley or right of way unless an excavation permit to do so has
been issued by the city engineer or his designated representative, according to the conditions of this
division. The excavation permit shall show the date of application, the place of the excavation, the
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 397/735
estimated date when the same will be made, the permit fee and name of the applicant, who shall
state that the person has filed with the city engineer a bond as required in this division.
(b)The excavation permit shall be void ten (10) days after the date of issue if the initial work has not
been started, and the person granted the permit shall perform the work with all possible speed. From
the time the public right of way is excavated, the permit holder shall have seven (7) workdays
(weather permitting) to complete all work, including the permanent pavement patch. The permit shall
always be in the possession of the person in charge of the work allowed, or in the possession of the
individual working at the location so that the permit may be produced for inspection at any time upon
request by authorized city officials.
(c)A separate excavation permit shall be required for each uninterrupted alteration of the surface or
undersurface of any street, avenue, highway or alley; provided that when multiple cuts are made at
approximately the same time for purposes of repairing or servicing the underground utilities, one
permit fee shall apply for each three hundred foot (300') section of gas main over which such multiple
cuts are made. Similarly, minimum charges for resurfacing, provided for hereinafter, shall apply to
each such three hundred foot (300') section.
(d)The fee for each permit issued shall be eighty dollars ($80.00), which shall be paid to the engineering
division of the public works department at the time the permit is issued. No refunds shall be made on
excavation permits.
(e)In case of a break of a gas main or of other emergency which might in the opinion of the city engineer
prove harmful to the public health or welfare or cause serious damage, the city engineer or his
representative may grant an "emergency" permit verbally, to be entered subsequently as a written
permit as hereinabove provided.
(f)The city engineer shall have the authority and it shall be his duty to exercise his judgment in the public
interest, in the issuance of excavation permits, with respect to the size, location, specifications and
timing of excavations or other qualifications affecting same. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord., §§ 1 - 3,
4-12-1976; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987; Ord. 87-34, § 17, 4-6-1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988; Ord.
13-2003, § 1, 2-10-2003; Ord. 013-2009, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-72. Bond:
(a)No person shall be issued an excavation permit unless a bond has been executed to the city, with a
certificate that the bond is presently in full force and effect, in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) with good and sufficient sureties to be approved by the city engineer and conditioned
on the faithful performance of all duties required by ordinances, rules and regulations of the city
engineer and the city. It shall be a further condition of the bond that the obligors will hold the city
harmless from any and all damages sustained by reason of neglect or incompetence on the part of
such person in the performance of work done or careless or improper guarding of excavations made
or trenches dug, or by reason of any other cause whatsoever, growing out of the negligence or
carelessness of such person for the issuance of a permit provided for in this division. The bond shall
be further conditioned that such person will promptly pay the city any and all sums or amounts due or
that may become due or owing by reason of, and under the terms and conditions of this division, and
in the manner and at the time or place as provided for herein.
(b)No person shall be issued an excavation permit whose bond shall not have been filed and approved
as herein set forth, provided, that a plumber who has executed a bond as provided in the plumbing
ordinance and which contains all of the conditions set forth in this division, shall be considered to
have met the requirements for bond. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987; Ord.
88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 398/735
Sec. 13-73. Notification Before Improvement:
Whenever improvement of any street, avenue, highway or alley is ordered by the city council, it shall be
the duty of the city engineer or his designee to notify all pertinent utility companies and all property
owners abutting the improvements and other interested persons of such order advising them to take
steps, prior to the construction of said improvement, to perform all desired or necessary excavations for
placing pipes, conduits, sewers, wires or other facilities in such public ways under, over, on or adjacent
to the improvement. Such persons so notified shall make such excavations before the improvement
work is begun, or at such time deemed convenient by the city engineer prior to completion of the
improvement. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988)
Sec. 13-74. Backfilling And Resurfacing-By Private Utility Companies:
Private utility companies shall be responsible for backfilling, resurfacing and safeguarding excavations
made by these companies in street rights of way, and also backfilling and safeguarding excavations
made on boulevards or other city property. These companies shall be liable for the maintenance of
backfilling and resurfacing for a period of four (4) years after the date the permit is issued for the
excavations, and shall hold the city harmless for all claims for damages that may result because of
excavations during that period. Backfilling and resurfacing shall be done in accordance with
specifications provided by the city engineer. The sinking or deterioration within the aforesaid period of
years shall be held to be the responsibility of the utility company, who shall upon direction of the city
engineer reexcavate and properly refill and resurface the street cut. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord. 87-
22, § 21, 3-23-1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988; Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-75. Backfilling And Resurfacing - By Others:
The excavation permit holder shall be responsible for backfilling, resurfacing and safeguarding
excavations in the city right of way, and also backfilling and safeguarding excavations made on
boulevards or other city property. The excavation permit holder shall be liable for the maintenance of
backfilling and resurfacing for a period of four (4) years after the date the permit is issued for the
excavations, and shall hold the city harmless for all claims for damages that may result because of
excavations during that period. The excavation permit holder shall be responsible for the permanent
repairs for a period of four (4) years after the date the repair is completed. This responsibility shall
include all costs for reopening the street/excavation, correcting the cause of the problem and replacing
the permanent repair. Backfilling and resurfacing shall be done in accordance with specifications
provided by the city engineer. Permanent repairs may only be conducted by a licensed, bonded
contractor in accordance with article V of this chapter.
(1) Inspection Request: The excavation permit holder shall notify the engineering department twenty
four (24) hours in advance of any work to be done in order that an inspection may be scheduled.
(2) Temporary Repairs: All temporary pavement patch repairs shall be completed as follows:
a. Backfill Within Two Feet Of Streets, Alleys, Sidewalks, Driveways And Other Paved Surfaces:
With the exception of the top eight inches (8") of the excavation, the backfill material shall be sand
meeting Illinois department of transportation gradation FA-6 or an equivalent approved by the city
engineer. The backfill material shall be thoroughly compacted by methods approved by the city
engineer.
b. Backfill For Areas More Than Two Feet From Paved Surfaces: The entire excavation should be
backfilled with earthen material free from broken concrete, asphalt, large rocks or other debris. The
backfill material shall be thoroughly compacted by methods approved by the city engineer.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 399/735
c. Surface Restoration; Paved Surfaces: The excavation permit holder shall be responsible for
placing a temporary pavement patch and/or permanent pavement patch on all pavement
excavations as soon as the repair has been completed. The temporary patch shall conform to the
following minimum standards:
1. Street and alley patches: Two inches (2") of well compacted, cold mix asphalt placed on six
inches (6") of well compacted stone.
2. Driveways and sidewalks: Two inches (2") of well compacted, cold mix asphalt.
3. All temporary pavement patches completed between December 1 - April 1 should be
completed using six inches (6") of PCC pavement placed on six inches (6") of well compacted
stone.
The excavation permit holder is responsible for maintaining the temporary patches until the
permanent patch has been completed. During this maintenance period, the permit holder shall
make any repairs as soon as possible after notification from the city. If the permit holder fails to
make the necessary repairs within twenty four (24) hours, the city will make the repairs and charge
the permit holder for all the costs, including any barricading and signing necessary to protect the
public.
d. Surface Restoration Outside Paved Areas: All areas disturbed by the construction shall be
resodded or reseeded at the discretion of the adjacent property owner. Unless other arrangements
can be documented, the permit holder is responsible for watering the restored area until the new
growth is well established. (Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-76. Service Classification:
(a)There shall be a charge by the city for the following services rendered for the repair of excavations at
rates to be set from time to time by the city council:
(1) Saw cutting.
(2) Pavement removal and PCC replacement.
(3) Pavement removal and PCC replacement with bituminous surface.
(4) Pavement removal and brick replacement.
(5) Pavement removal and seal coat replacement.
(6) Pavement removal and PCC sidewalk replacement.
(7) Pavement removal and PCC driveway replacement.
(8) Adjust castings.
(9) Construction inspection.
(b)The public works department shall compute the amounts to be billed based on the above schedule of
charges and shall promptly mail invoices to the persons named on the excavation permits, itemizing
the services rendered in behalf of each permittee and the charges therefor.
(c)Services rendered in behalf of the city's sewer and water utilities shall be charged against the sewer
and water operation and maintenance funds respectively at the same rates as provided for above
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 400/735
with the amounts credited to the engineering fund. Such payments and credits shall constitute
interfund transfers. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. I; Ord., § 1, 9-3-1964; Ord., § 4, 4-12-1976; Ord., § 1, 2-
9-1981; Ord. 87-22, § 13, 3-23-1987; Ord. 88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988)
Sec. 13-77. Barricades And Signs, Etc.:
The excavation permit holder shall ensure that the work is performed with minimal inconvenience and
safety hazard to the public. The permit holder shall provide, erect, and maintain all barricades and signs
necessary to protect the work and the public. If the signing and barricading at any excavation is found to
be inadequate and the permit holder is unable or unwilling to correct the problem immediately, the city
will make the necessary corrections; and all the costs for this work will be charged to the permit holder.
No street or alley may be closed without the permission of the city engineer. Fire hydrants, gutters, and
storm inlets adjacent to the work may not be obstructed without the permission of the city engineer. (Ord.
88-18, § 1, 4-4-1988)
Secs. 13-78-13-79. Reserved:
DIVISION 3. ROLL-OFF CONTAINERS
Sec. 13-80. Application For License:
(a)No person shall place a roll-off box, storage cube or similar container on the property of the city of
Rock Island without a license issued by the city engineer.
(b)No person shall be issued a license to place containers on the property of the city of Rock Island until
the city engineer has received a certificate of insurance indicating that the owner of the container has
liability insurance coverage of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per accident for accidents
involving containers placed on the property of the city of Rock Island and the city of Rock Island is
identified as an additional insured on the insurance policy.
(c)The fee for the license shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per calendar year.
(d)The placement and condition of containers placed on the property of the city of Rock Island must
comply with the city of Rock Island roll-off container policy in section 13-82 of this division. (Ord. 051-
2006, § 1, 7-24-2006)
Sec. 13-81. Correction Of Deficiencies:
(a)In the event that a container is located on the property of the city of Rock Island in violation of this
division or the city of Rock Island roll-off container policy, the public works department may correct
the deficiency or remove the container without prior notice to the container owner.
(b)Within thirty (30) days after correction of the deficiencies or container removal, the city engineer shall
notify the owner of the container of the costs of the deficiency correction or container removal,
including administrative costs, and the deadline for payment.
(c)The city attorney is authorized to and may initiate litigation in the small claims court of the 14th judicial
circuit to recover costs. In addition, the city may contract with any licensed collection agency for the
collection of the costs and the collection agency may recover from the property owner, in addition to
those sums, reasonable collection expenses, including court costs and attorney fees. (Ord. 051-
2006, § 1, 7-24-2006)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 401/735
Sec. 13-82. Roll-Off Container Policy:
Effective September 1, 2006, roll-off boxes, storage cubes and similar containers ("container") may be
placed on city property under the following conditions:
(1) The owner of the container must have a valid license to place containers on city property issued
by the city engineer.
(2) The container must have legible markings indicating the name and business address of the owner
and a twenty four (24) hour emergency contact telephone number.
(3) The container may not impede use of a sidewalk, alley or driveway.
(4) The container may not be placed within ten feet (10') of a fire hydrant.
(5) The container may not be placed within twenty feet (20') of an intersection.
(6) If placed on a street, the container must be placed in a legal parking area within one foot (1') of
the curb or edge of the roadway.
(7) The container must have reflective stripes and/or reflectors on all corners that are clearly visible
at night to approaching motorists.
(8) The outside of the container must be clean and free of graffiti.
(9) The container may not create a safety hazard.
(10) Containers may not remain on city property for more than fourteen (14) consecutive days
without the written approval of the city engineer.
In the event that a container on city property violates this policy, the public works department may
correct the deficiency or remove the container and the container owner will be responsible for the costs.
(Ord. 051-2006, § 1, 7-24-2006)
Sec. 13-83. Criminal Penalties:
Any person violating this division shall, upon an adjudication of guilt or a plea of no contest, be fined a
minimum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) to a maximum of one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00). Each separate day on which a violation is committed or continues shall constitute a
separate offense. (Ord. 051-2006, § 1, 7-24-2006)
Secs. 13-84-13-90. Reserved:
ARTICLE IV. SIDEWALKS 3
Sec. 13-91. Penalty:
Every violation of any provision of this article shall subject the offender to a fine of not less than one
dollar ($1.00), and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), for each offense. (1963 Code, ch. XIII,
art. II)
Sec. 13-92. Permits For Sidewalks, Drives, Curb Cuts 4:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 402/735
(a)No person shall construct a sidewalk, driveway entrance or curb or cut a curb on a public right of way
in the city without first having obtained a written permit therefor issued by the director of public works
or his designated representative, and unless such person shall hold a valid concrete flat work license
in accordance with article V of this chapter. The fee for a permit for construction of driveway
entrances or sidewalks shall be three cents ($0.03) per square foot with a minimum fee of sixty five
dollars ($65.00). The fee for a permit for cutting a curb shall be sixty five dollars ($65.00) for each
twenty five (25) continuous feet of curb or fraction thereof. Prior to obtaining a permit for such
construction the applicant shall submit to the director of public works or his designated representative
a rough sketch showing the contemplated construction with dimensions and measurements
indicating proposed location, extent and type of work to be done. The director of public works or his
designated representative shall set line, grade and specifications for all sidewalks, driveway
entrances and curbs on public property, and he shall provide for proper inspection of construction of
sidewalks, driveway entrances and curbs and of curb cutting.
(b)No permit or fee shall be required for the construction of sidewalks in new subdivisions, provided such
sidewalks are shown on the approved subdivision plans and are located on property to be dedicated
to the city in conjunction with such subdivision approval, and provided further that such sidewalk or
driveway entrances are actually constructed at the same approximate time that the other street
improvements are constructed, pursuant to the city's regulations governing new subdivisions.
(c)When a driveway entrance is constructed, or a curb is cut to permit a driveway entrance, any existing
sidewalk must be removed, and the area where the sidewalk existed shall be repaved according to
specifications of the director of public works or his designated representative and it shall then be
considered as part of the driveway entrance. In such case, a sidewalk permit shall not be required
but only a permit for a driveway entrance. (1963 Code, ch. XIII, art. II; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987;
Ord. 87-34, § 18, 4-6-1987; Ord. 91-14, §§ 4, 5, 2-11-1991; Ord. 99-08, § 1, 2-15-1999; Ord. 13-
2003, §§ 2, 3, 2-10-2003; Ord. 013-2009, § 2, 2-2-2009; Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-93. Concrete Flat Work Bonds See § 13-117 of this chapter.2:
(Rep. by Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-94. Construction:
All sidewalks shall be laid to the line and grade of, and shall conform to, the specification of the director
of public works or his designated representative. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-
1987)
Sec. 13-95. Width:
Sidewalks hereafter constructed in the city shall be of cement or concrete and shall have the following
minimum widths in the territory described:
(1) In areas zoned for single-family residence four feet (4').
(2) In areas zoned for multiple-family use, five feet (5').
(3) In areas zoned for commercial or business use, ten feet (10').
Whenever the right of way so permits in residential zones, the sidewalks shall be constructed so that
the edge nearest the property line is not less than one foot (1') from the property line. (1963 Code,
Ch. XIII, Art. II)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 403/735
Sec. 13-96. Location Of Gutters, Shade Trees:
All gutters hereafter constructed shall be located on the lines between that part of the street devoted to
vehicle travel and that part set off for sidewalk purposes. No trees shall be planted or placed in any
street, boulevard or parkway in the city unless authorized by the city. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II)
Sec. 13-97. Damage To Sidewalks:
If any person shall break or otherwise damage any tile, concrete, brick, plank or any part of any
sidewalk, footpath or curbing, he shall within twenty four (24) hours thereafter cause the same to be well
and sufficiently repaired and mended; and no person shall break, damage or remove any concrete,
brick, tile, stone or plank, or any part or portion of any walks in the city, except for the purpose of
replacing the same with new material, under the direction of the director of public works or his
designated representative and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII,
Art. II; Ord. 87-22, § 21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 13-98. Stoops, Platforms, Railings, Cellar Doors:
No stoop, porch, platform, railing, cellar door or steps shall be allowed to extend from any building or lot
into or upon any sidewalk; nor shall any cellar door rise or project above the surface of the sidewalks;
however, upon good cause shown, the city council may grant a permit to owners of commercial buildings
to make an opening on the sidewalks adjacent to their property if the opening is adequately covered and
sufficiently protected when open in a manner that is satisfactory to the director of public works or his
designated representative and the owner makes a written agreement to hold the city harmless for any
liability arising out of the opening and has insurance coverage for the liability in an amount satisfactory to
the director of public works or his designated representative. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 87-22, §
21, 3-23-1987)
Sec. 13-99. Windows, Showcases, Steps:
No bay window or other window shall extend into, upon or over any sidewalk, nor shall any sign, except
as provided in this code, nor shall any show bill, showcase or other thing be placed upon or project over
the sidewalk in front of or from the wall of any building, nor shall any steps be hereafter constructed or
placed upon or over any sidewalk, street or other public way. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II)
Sec. 13-100. Personal Property On Public Sidewalks:
(a)No person shall place upon or suspend over any sidewalk, any goods or merchandise, or cause or
permit the same to be done or place or deposit on any sidewalk, or cause or permit the same to be
done, any personal property of any nature whatsoever.
(b)Newspaper vending machines may be allowed on sidewalks after the owner thereof receives prior
authorization from the city clerk subsequent to the submission of a liability insurance policy with limits
approved by the city attorney. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 83-25, § 1, 7-11-1983)
Sec. 13-101. Painting, Etc.:
No person shall paint, paste, post, print or nail any handbill or sign, poster, advertisement or notice of
any kind, or other matter or thing whatever, on, nor in any manner whatever deface any curbstone, or
any part or portion of any sidewalk, or any tree, lamppost, telegraph pole, electric light pole, hydrant,
public building or any other thing or any private wall, door, building, gate or fence. The owner of any
sign, poster or advertisement placed in violation of this section shall also be guilty of the violation if he
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 404/735
knew or should have known that the sign, poster or advertisement was placed on his behalf in violation
of this section. (1963 Code, Ch. XIII, Art. II; Ord. 058-2005, § 1, 7-11-2005)
Secs. 13-102-13-115. Reserved:
ARTICLE V. FLAT WORK LICENSES
Sec. 13-116. Licenses For Sidewalks, Driveways, Curb Cuts, Excavation Repairs:
No person shall construct a sidewalk, driveway entrance or curb, cut a curb, or conduct a permanent
excavation repair on a public right of way in the city unless such person shall hold a valid concrete flat
work license, which may be obtained from the director of public works or his designated representative
by filing a concrete flat work license application along with a current concrete flat work bond and a
license application fee of seventy five dollars ($75.00). (Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
Sec. 13-117. Concrete Flat Work Bonds:
Every person engaging in the business of the construction of concrete walks, driveway entrances or
curbs, conducting permanent utility repairs, or any property owner installing his own sidewalks, driveway
entrances or curbs before entering upon the construction of any such concrete flat work in or upon any
public street or avenue in the city, shall file with the director of public works a bond in the penal sum of
ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) running to the city with sureties to be approved by the director of
public works, conditioned upon obligated satisfactory performance of all duties required by the
ordinances, rules and regulations of the city council, and that he will suitably guard and protect any
excavation or obstruction and defend, save, keep harmless and indemnify the city from all actions, costs,
damages and expenses whatsoever, including attorney fees, which shall or may at any time happen to
come to it for or on account of any injuries or damages received or sustained by any person or persons,
caused by any negligence in either the execution or protection of the work being done, and guarantee
the material and workmanship of the concrete flat work for a period of four (4) years ensuing after the
date of its acceptance by the public works department. The bond shall be approved by the director of
public works or his designated representative before being filed. The bond shall be on file in the public
works department and shall be renewed from year to year during the time of work of concrete flat work
as above referred to. (Ord. 011-2016, 3-7-2016)
ARTICLE VI. RESPONSIBLE BIDDER
Sec. 13-118. Defining Responsible Bidder:
The definition of responsible bidder is expanded in the case of bidders for construction projects, new
facilities or renovation of current facilities and road projects over twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00).
In determining who is the lowest responsible bidder, the city may consider those factors set out in 55
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1022(b). Additionally, the city may also consider the following factors in
determining who is the lowest bidder:
(1) Certificate/proof to transact business within the state of Illinois.
(2) Evidence of compliance with:
a. Federal employer tax identification number or social security number (for individuals).
b. "Equal opportunity employer" provisions.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 405/735
(3) Certificates of insurance indicating the following coverages: general liability, workers'
compensation, automobile, hazardous occupation, product liability and professional liability.
(4) Participation in apprenticeship and training programs applicable to the work to be performed on
the project which are approved and registered with the United States department of labor's office of
apprenticeship and training. The required evidence includes a copy of all applicable apprenticeship
standards and agreements for any apprentice(s) who will perform work on the public works project.
(5) Compliance with all the provisions of the Illinois prevailing wage act, including wages, medical
and hospitalization insurance and retirement for those trades as covered in the act.
(6) Disclosure of the names and addresses of each subcontractor from whom the contractor has
accepted a bid and/or intends to hire on any part of this project.
(7) A copy of the written program for the prevention of substance abuse.
a. The bidder shall certify that only workers that are enrolled and tested in company based
controlled substance and alcohol testing programs will be allowed to participate on the project.
(8) Statements as to past performances, which shall give an accurate and complete record of all
work projects completed in the last three (3) years by the contractor.
(9) The contractor and officers of the contractor disclose any tax lien or delinquency in the last five
(5) years.
(10) Bidder shall certify that all employees expected to perform work on the project have completed a
ten (10) hour or greater OSHA safety program within the last five (5) years. Only workers that have
satisfactorily completed a ten (10) hour or greater OSHA safety program will be allowed to participate
on the project. The bidder must have copies of employee OSHA cards on file, and the city may
request the bidder provide copies of employees' OSHA cards; failure to produce an employee's
OSHA card may result in a determination that the bidder is not a responsible bidder.
(11) Bidder shall demonstrate the efforts taken to employ local workers with strong consideration
given to bidders employing residents of the city of Rock Island.
(12) Bidder provides written record of compliance with state of Illinois DBE requirements for public
works projects, including the hiring of women and minority workers to perform the contracted work.
(13) Any other factors which are relevant to the determination of a bidder's ability to carry out the
requirements of the project in accordance with what may be expected or demanded under the terms
of the contract.
It shall be the sole responsibility of the contractor to comply with all the submission requirements at the
time it submits its bid to the city of Rock Island. (Ord. 052-2016, 11-21-2016)

RECREATIONAL AND CULTURAL FACILITIES 1
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. PARK AND RECREATIONAL SYSTEM
Sec. 14-16. Establishment:
There is hereby established in the city a recreation system in the lands, public parks or buildings
heretofore designated or set apart by the city for use as playgrounds or recreation centers. (1963 Code,
ch. III, art. I)
Sec. 14-17. Park And Recreation Board 1-Creation:
There is hereby established in the city a park and recreation board to be known as the Rock Island park
and recreation board, which board shall consist of six (6) members to be appointed by the mayor by and
with the consent of the city council, to serve without compensation. The board shall have the power to
provide, maintain, improve and conduct parks, playgrounds and recreation centers in the city. Any
money appropriated by the city council for such purposes shall be expended under the board's direction.
At the close of each fiscal year, and at any other time when requested by the city council, the board shall
make a report to the council of all monies received and expended by the board. The board shall use the
central accounting facilities provided by the city clerk's office. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. II; Ord. 001-2017,
1-23-2017)
Sec. 14-18. Park And Recreation Board-Term Of Office 2:
The term of office of the members of the park and recreation board shall be for a period of five (5) years
or until their successors are appointed and qualified, except that the members of the board first
appointed shall be appointed for such terms that the term of one member shall expire annually
thereafter. If any vacancy occurs in the office of any member, the mayor shall appoint a successor to
serve for the unexpired term. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. I)
Sec. 14-19. Park And Recreation Board-Oath And Bond 3:
Each member appointed to the park and recreation board shall before entering upon the duties of his
office take the oath of office required by law and shall execute to the city a bond in a sum not less than
five hundred dollars ($500.00), with one or more sureties, to be approved by the city council, conditioned
as required by law. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. I)
Sec. 14-20. Park And Playground Rules:
(a)No person, in any park or playground in the city, shall:
(1) Permit unleashed and/or unaccompanied animals on any such premises.
(2) Throw stones or missiles by hand, slingshot or otherwise.
(3) Carry or discharge firearms or set off fireworks. This prohibition against discharge of a firearm as
provided herein shall not apply to the hunting of deer with a bow and arrow in accordance with the
provisions of subsection 10-9(d) of this code.
(4) Cut, mark, break, climb upon or in any way injure or deface trees, shrubs, plants, flowers,
buildings, fences, bridges or other structures or property, whether real or personal, on any such
premises.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 407/735
(5) Remove from any such premises sod, trees, plants or other movable property, or pick flowers of
any kind on any such premises.
(6) Race with horses, bicycles, automobiles, motorcycles or similar vehicles; drive or ride on drives
on any such premises at more than fifteen (15) miles per hour; nor shall horseback riding be
permitted except on established bridle paths.
(7) Sell, consume or be in possession of beer, wine or other intoxicating liquor, or enter or be upon
the premises of any park or playground while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. The sale and
possession of beer, wine or other intoxicating liquor is permitted if it is purchased from employees of
the Rock Island park and recreation department or from a qualified vendor or licensee issued a
temporary liquor license, and only in those areas previously so designated by the Rock Island park
and recreation board. The Rock Island park and recreation board may also approve the "gifting" of
liquor for private rentals at previously designated park and recreation areas or facilities as stipulated
by operational policy. After receiving approval by the park and recreation board, all applications for
"gifting" of liquor at a private rental must be received by the liquor commissioner's office no later than
seven (7) days in advance of the scheduled event. Upon approval, an approval letter from the liquor
commissioner will be sent to the applicant and the policy department.
(8) Lie or sleep on tables or benches on any such premises.
(9) Tell fortunes or play any games of chance.
(10) Distribute circulars or advertisements or post notices, bills or other paper upon any structures or
tree on any such premises, or advertise by any other means.
(11) Take any bird eggs or bird nests; fish in the lagoons, unless permitted at such times as
designated by the park and recreation board; kill or disturb any waterfowl, birds or wildlife.
(12) Light any fires on any such property other than in established fireplaces.
(13) Place ashes, garbage, papers or rubbish of any kind on any such premises other than in
containers provided for that purpose.
(14) Drive or park motor vehicles on the grass areas.
(15) Wear inappropriate clothing. Bathing clothes are permitted in established bathing pool areas.
(16) Be on any premises between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.,
unless authority is granted and the party is under proper supervision. The playgrounds will be open
and closed for use at the direction of the playground supervisor, and anyone in the playgrounds
when they are closed will be considered as trespassing on such property.
(17) No golf shall be played in any of the parks, nor shall practicing of golf be permitted, except in
areas designated by the park board.
(18) No baseball or softball games shall be permitted, except in areas established for the playing of
such games.
(19) Conduct himself in a disorderly manner in any building or within any such premises.
(20) Allow any boats with motors in or operated in Lake Potter in Sunset Park north of a line across
the neck of the lake, which is marked with buoys and a rope, other than in areas specifically
designated therefor.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 408/735
(21) Waterski, water plane, swim or ride a surfboard within Lake Potter in Sunset Park or in the
channel connecting the lake with the Mississippi River except for events approved by the Park Board.
(22) Operate a motorboat at a speed in excess of eight (8) miles per hour within Lake Potter or in the
channel connecting the lake with the Mississippi River.
(23) Drive a tractor or tractor and semitrailer through any park in the City nor park any tractor or
tractor and semitrailer in any park in the City without the specific authorization of the City Council.
(24) Operate a bicycle or motorized vehicle on the Sunset Park "walk-jog" path.
(25) Allow a dog to litter on the Sunset Park "walk-jog" path.
(26) Fish off any of the docks in Sunset Marina or Schwiebert Riverfront Park.
(27) Be in or upon that portion of Sunset Marina in Sunset Park as described on exhibit A on file with
the City Clerk and made a part of this section by reference, except those persons who have boats
and have leased docking area in Sunset Marina or their invited guests and suppliers and customers
of the City's lessees.
(28) Dock overnight, or use a courtesy dock for more than a four (4) hour period, except for marina
facilities designated for that purpose.
(29) Boats may not be left unattended for more than ten (10) minutes at boat ramp docks.
(30) Sell merchandise, goods, services, food or other articles in any City park without the written
permission of the Park and Recreation Director.
(31) Enter any secured, enclosed structure owned or controlled by the Park Board, or under the
supervision of the Park Board without the written permission of the Park and Recreation Director.
(32) Hold any boating event, fishing tournaments, contest or competition which uses boats, sailboats,
or other craft on Potter Lake without written permission of the Park Board.
(33) Park for more than three (3) hours at a time at the Lincoln Park tennis court lot, the Webber Park
parking lot, or other lots designated with specific time limits.
(34) Disobey posted parking requirements, unless otherwise authorized by the Park and Recreation
Director or the Park and Recreation Board.
(35) Raft boats together while tied to a dock or ramp.
(36) Drink alcoholic beverages while on the docks or ramps.
(37) Grill or cook on the docks or ramps.
(38) Swim or dive off of any docks or ramps.
(39) Congregate, sunbathe, picnic or loiter on the docks.
(40) Allow unattended children on the docks.
(41) Block access on the docks.
(42) Dock a boat after twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight at Schwiebert Riverfront Park without first
obtaining permission to do so from the Park Board.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 409/735
(43) Use the docks during Park Board approved special events.
(44) Fish off of Potter's Lake boat ramp docks. Fishing is only allowed off of Potter's Lake pedestrian
docks.
(b)The minimum fine for a violation of the provisions of this section shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00).
In the event a person is accused of a violation of this section and does not wish to contest the
allegation prior to the time a complaint is issued for the violations, the person so accused may pay to
the City, at police headquarters, a penalty in the sum of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for and in full
satisfaction of the violation. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. I; Ord., 7-12-1976; Ord., 10-25-1976; Ord., 1-12-
1981; Ord., 2-8-1982; Ord. 83-57, 2-6-1984; Ord. 87-65, 8-10-1987; Ord. 88-03, 1-4-1988; Ord. 99-
88, 11-8-1999; Ord. 025-2007, 4-9-2007; Ord. 034-2009, 5-4-2009; Ord. 083-2011, 11-7-2011; Ord.
063-2013, 11-18-2013; Ord. 030-2014, 3-24-2014; Ord. 056-2018, 9-24-2018)
Sec. 14-21. Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance designating the
names and boundaries of City parks, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full
force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. (1963 Code, ch. III, art. I)
Sec. 14-22. Special Use Activity:
No special use activity shall take place in any park, playground, special facility or other property under
jurisdiction of the Park and Recreation Board without the issuance of a special use permit by the Park
and Recreation Board. Any person or organization desiring to have a special use activity shall submit a
special use application to the Park and Recreation Board for review and final disposition. The board
shall consider the special use application at its first meeting held after the filing of said application. The
board shall have the authority to establish a fee for the special use facility commensurate with their costs
to the Rock Island Park and Recreation Department. For the purpose of this section, a "special use"
activity shall be defined as any activity, event, speech, gathering, observance, ceremony or
entertainment event not sponsored by the Rock Island Park and Recreation Department. This type of
activity is distinguished from "routine use" by:
(1) The use of the facility is not within the intended use of the facility and such use restricts or limits
the intended use of a park facility by the general public;
(2) The use of additional mechanical equipment, portable generators, staging, tentage, food
dispensing equipment, loudspeakers, or other items not available on the site; or
(3) The advertising and promotion of the activity, identifying the park location as the site of the event.
Any person, firm, corporation or organization violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a
fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 88-39, 7-11-
1988)
Secs. 14-23-14-35. Reserved:
ARTICLE III. LIBRARY 1
Sec. 14-36. Establishment 2:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 410/735
The establishment of the Public Library and Reading Room of this City, and the acceptance by the City
of the donation of the books, pamphlets, papers, fixtures and other property of the Young Men's Library
Association, upon the condition of such donation, as set forth in the ordinances of the City passed
August 12, 1872, are hereby approved and confirmed; and the Public Library and Reading Room shall
henceforth be kept up and maintained as such for the use of the inhabitants of the City and shall be
called the "Rock Island Public Library and Reading Room". (1963 Code, ch. III, art. II)
Sec. 14-37. Board Of Directors-Created 3, 4:
There is hereby created a board of directors to consist of nine (9) members for the Rock Island Public
Library. The board of directors shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council as
provided by state statute, and shall be chosen from the citizens at large, with reference to their fitness
for such office, and not more than one member of the city council shall be at any one time a member of
the board. Directors shall hold office for three (3) years as provided by law. The mayor may remove any
board member on any formal charge as provided by law. Vacancies in the board of directors occasioned
by removals, resignation or otherwise shall be reported to the mayor and be filled in like manner as
original appointments. No director shall receive compensation as such. (1963 Code, ch. II, art. III)
Sec. 14-38. Board Of Directors-Duties 5:
The board of library directors shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their own
guidance and for the government of the Rock Island Public Library as may be expedient and not
inconsistent with the state statutes or ordinance. They shall also perform such other duties as are
imposed by statute or ordinance. (1963 Code, ch. II, art. III)
Sec. 14-39. Penalty For Injury To Or Failure To Return Library Materials 1:
Any person who shall carelessly, wilfully or maliciously cut, tear, write upon, deface, injure or destroy any
book, pamphlet, periodical, newspaper, plate, picture, engraving or any other property or thing of value
belonging to or under the control of the Rock Island public library and reading room or who shall fail to
return thereto any book, pamphlet, periodical, newspaper, plate, picture, engraving or any other thing of
value belonging to or under the control of the library and reading room, according to the requirements of
the bylaws and rules thereof, or after a notice so to do, shall be subject to a fine of not less than one
dollar ($1.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). All such fines shall, when collected, be paid
to the city treasurer and by him credited to the library fund. (1963 Code, Ch. III, Art. II)
Secs. 14-40-14-50. Reserved:
ARTICLE IV. ARTS COMMISSION 2, 3
Sec. 14-51. Creation; Composition:
There is created in the city an arts commission consisting of twelve (12) members, who shall be
appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council from nominees submitted by the arts
commission. Seven (7) members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. At least one member of
the commission shall be selected from membership of the board of the Rock Island art guild and one
member from the board of the Quad Cities Arts Council. All members of the commission shall be
residents of the city. (Ord., § 1, 6-7-1976)
Sec. 14-52. Purpose; Powers:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 411/735
The purpose of the arts commission is to select and acquire works of art for exhibition and/or permanent
display in the city. The commission shall raise and disburse funds (private and public) for the acquisition
of artworks. The commission shall select sites for the artworks and shall oversee any maintenance to the
works and sites. (Ord., § 3, 6-7-1976)
Sec. 14-53. Appointment Of Executive Director 4:
Upon recommendation of the arts commission and with approval of the mayor and city council and at a
time when sufficient funds are available, an executive director of the commission shall be hired. (Ord., §
4, 6-7-1976)
Sec. 14-54. Officers:
The officers of the arts commission shall consist of a chairman, vice chairman, recording secretary and
treasurer, all of whom shall be elected by simple majority of the commission members. The duties of the
chairman shall consist of calling meetings and directing the activities of the commission and appointing
committees. The duties of the vice chairman shall be to act in the place of the chairman in the event the
chairman is unavailable or incapacitated to perform his or her duties. The duties of the recording
secretary shall consist of informing members of all meetings and keeping minutes and records of the
meetings. The duties of the treasurer shall consist of maintaining the account of the commission,
submitting financial reports at each meeting and approving a yearly financial statement. (Ord., § 5, 6-7-
1976; Ord., § 1, 7-26-1976)
Sec. 14-55. Meetings:
There shall be six (6) regular meetings of the arts commission during each year, with the annual meeting
to be held in May of each year, at which time the officers of the commission shall be elected. Special
meetings of the commission may be called at any time at the discretion of the chairman. A change of
procedure for calling and holding meetings shall be made at any time by a vote of a simple majority of
the commission members, with the vote to be taken at least thirty (30) days prior to the effecting of the
proposed change or changes. (Ord., § 6, 6-7-1976)
Sec. 14-56. Term Of Office:
The members of the arts commission shall be appointed for two (2) year terms with six (6) members
being appointed in each year providing that in order to initiate arrangements of staggered terms, the
terms of the six (6) members initially appointed as aforesaid shall be for one year, which shall be
determined by lot. Members who serve two (2) consecutive terms can be reappointed after a one year
absence from the commission. (Ord., § 2, 6-7-1976)
Secs. 14-57-14-70. Reserved:

Corporation, the stock of all of which corporation is now owned and possessed by the city. The real
estate is situated in the city, bounded and described as follows:

Beginning at the northeast corner of Section 2, Township 17 North, Range 2 West of the Fourth Principal

deeds in and for the county.
(1963 Code, Ch. III, Art. III)
Sec. 14-72. Purpose:
The Hauberg Civic Center shall be used and maintained to promote citizen activity in the fields of
graphic arts, music, literature, dramatics, local and Indian history, natural history, horticulture, social
sciences and such other cultural, patriotic and educational purposes as may from time to time be
deemed advantageous, and shall be used for meetings of groups interested in the same, particularly
groups that have no headquarters of their own. (1963 Code, Ch. III, Art. III)
Sec. 14-73. Governing Body 1:
The Hauberg Civic Center shall be governed by the Rock Island park board who shall oversee
programming, set fees, policy and maintain the building. (1963 Code, Ch. III, Art. III; Ord. 99-88, § 1, 11-
8-1999)
Secs. 14-74-14-75. Reserved:
Chapter 15
TAXATION 1
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 15-1. Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 413/735
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any ordinance establishing a special
service area, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the
same extent as if set out at length in this code. (1984 Code)
Sec. 15-2. Retailers' Occupation Tax:
(a)(1) Effective July 1, 2010, a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered
with an agency of this state's government, at retail in this municipality at the rate of one and twenty
five one-hundredths percent (1.25%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of
such business, while this section is in effect; and
(2) Effective July 1, 2010, a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this municipality in
the business of making sales of service, at the rate of one and twenty five one-hundredths percent
(1.25%), effective July 1, 2010, of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by
such serviceman as an incident to sale of service.
(3) Such "home rule municipal retailers' occupation tax" and the "home rule municipal service
occupation tax" shall not be applicable on the sales of food for human consumption which is to be
consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food
which has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription
medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles used
by diabetics.
(4) The imposition of these home rule taxes are in accordance with the provisions of 5/8-11-1 and
5/8-11-5, respectively, of the Illinois municipal code 65 ILCS, as amended.1.
(b)The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto, shall
be collected and enforced by the department of revenue of the state. The department of revenue
shall have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of this section. (Ord. 011-2010, § 1, 3-
8-2010)
Sec. 15-3. Service Occupation Tax:
(a)A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this city in the business of making sales of
service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the cost price of all tangible personal property transferred
by those servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as
an incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-
11-5. The exclusion contained in section 2(e) of the "service occupation tax act" approved July 10,
1961, as amended 35 ILCS 115/1.2, shall not apply to property within the city. The farm machinery and
equipment exclusion contained in section 3-5 of said act, as amended 35 ILCS 115/3-5.3, shall not
apply to persons engaged in the business of making sale of service within the city.
(b)Every supplier or serviceman required to account for municipal service occupation tax for the benefit
of this city shall file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state
department of revenue required by section 9 of the "service occupation tax act" approved July 10,
1961, as amended 35 ILCS 115/9.4.
(c)At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of
tax hereby imposed. (1963 Code, ch. X; Ord., 7-14-1967; Ord., 7-18-1967; Ord., 4-8-1968; Ord., 8-
25-1969; Ord., 2-19-1979; Ord., 1-26-1981)
Sec. 15-4. Use Tax:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 414/735
(a)A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-6 upon
the privilege of using in the city any item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside
Illinois at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's
government. The tax shall be at a rate of one percent (1%) of the selling price of such tangible
property with "selling price" to have the meaning as defined in section 2 of the use tax act, approved
July 14, 1955 35 ILCS 105/2.5.
(b)Such tax shall be collected by the state department of revenue for the city and shall be paid, or an
exemption determination must be obtained from the state department of revenue, before the title or
certificate of registration for the personal property is issued.
(c)The farm machinery and equipment exclusion contained in section 3 of the "use tax act" approved
July 14, 1955, as amended 35 ILCS 105/3-5.6, shall not apply to the privilege of using in the city any
item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a retailer and
which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's government. (Ord., 10-14-1974; Ord., 1-26-
1981)
Sec. 15-5. Automobile Renting Occupation Tax 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.7:
(a)A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting automobiles in this city
at the rate of one percent (1%) of the gross receipts from such rentals made in the course of such
business, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-7.
(b)Every such person engaged in such business in the city shall file on or before the last day of each
calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by sections 2 and 3 of "an act
in relation to a tax upon persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property to
purchasers for use or consumption" approved June 29, 1933, as amended 35 ILCS 120/2, 120/3.8.
(c)At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of
tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. (Ord., 1-4-
1982)
Sec. 15-6. Automobile Renting Use Tax 2:
(a)A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in this city an automobile which is rented from a
renter outside Illinois and which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's government at the
rate of one percent (1%) of the rental price of such automobile, in accordance with the provisions of
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-8.
(b)The tax provided for in this section shall be collected from persons whose Illinois address for titling or
registration purposes is given as being in this city.
(c)The tax imposed by this section shall be paid to the state department of revenue. (Ord., 1-4-1982)
Sec. 15-7. Fire Insurance Tax 3 4:
(a)All corporations, companies and associations not incorporated under the laws of this State and which
are engaged in the City in effecting fire insurance shall pay to the Treasurer of the City a tax or
license fee amounting to two percent (2%) of the gross receipts received by their agency in the City;
and at that rate such corporations, companies and associations shall pay upon the amount of all
premiums which during the year ending on every July 1, shall have been received for any fire
insurance effected or agreed to be effected on property situated within the City by or with such
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 415/735
corporations, companies or associations, respectively, in accordance with an act of the general
assembly of the State entitled "An act to enable cities, towns and villages, organized under any
general or special law to levy and collect a tax or license fee from foreign fire insurance companies
for the benefit of organized fire departments".
(b)The money paid over to the City as a result of the tax levied by this Section shall be set aside and
appropriated for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department. The City Treasurer shall
pay the funds received from the aforementioned tax to the treasurer of the Foreign Fire Insurance
Tax Revenue Administration Board. The Board treasurer will deposit the funds in the Foreign Fire
Insurance Fund, and such funds shall be invested in the same manner and under the same
guidelines as the City investment policies. The funds shall be under the care and supervision of the
Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Revenue Administration Board as hereinafter created and shall be
expended for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department. The Board shall, in
accordance with City budget and appropriations procedures, annually prepare a budget for the funds
which shall be considered by the City Council together with the Fire Department budget, and the
approved expenditures shall be included in the annual budget ordinance.
(c)There is hereby established a Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Revenue Administrative Board which shall
consist of five (5) members. The Board shall consist of the Fire Chief, a battalion or assistant chief, a
captain or lieutenant, and two (2) firefighters. The battalion or assistant chief, captain or lieutenant,
and firefighters shall be elected by secret written ballot of all the commissioned members of the Fire
Department held on the third Tuesday of April in even-numbered years. The term of Boardmembers
shall be for two (2) years and shall commence on May 1 following election; however, the original
Boardmembers shall have an abbreviated term commencing thirty (30) days following passage
hereof (February 25, 1991). The original Board shall be elected at an election to be held within
twenty one (21) days following passage hereof. If a vacancy occurs in office because a member
terminates his service with the Fire Department for any reason, is promoted out of the ranks he
represents, or resigns, the Fire Chief shall appoint a person to fulfill the remaining term. If there is no
exclusive bargaining agent recognized, the Chief shall appoint a person to fill the remaining term of
the remaining ranks' representatives.
(d)The Board shall select from its members a person to serve as secretary of the Board. The secretary
shall serve in accordance with the bylaws adopted by the Board. The Board shall select a person to
serve as treasurer of the Board, or in the alternative, appoint the Finance Director to serve as its
treasurer. If no person is selected to serve as treasurer or in the event of any vacancy in the office of
treasurer of the Board, the Finance Director shall serve as its treasurer until the vacancy is filled.
Nothing herein shall prevent a person serving on the Board from serving as treasurer, but no
additional compensation shall be paid to such person or to the Finance Director.
(e)The Board shall have the power to expend money provided by the foreign fire insurance tax in
accordance with written bylaws and to make gifts to the City of property, supplies or money for the
use, maintenance and benefit of the Fire Department and to adopt bylaws establishing the manner of
selection of a chairman and the other officers of the Board; the rules of procedure for the conduct of
its meetings, the establishment of regular meeting times and places and the manner of calling special
meetings; the authority of its officers; and other necessary matters dealing with the administration of
the Fund; however, the bylaws may not violate the following:
(1) A quorum shall not exist without either the Fire Chief or the battalion or assistant chief
representative being present; however, if both the Fire Chief and the battalion or assistant chief
representative are absent for three (3) consecutive meetings, a quorum can exist without either the
Fire Chief or the battalion or assistant chief representative being present so that regular business
may be conducted.
(2) No bylaw or amendment thereto shall be effective until same has been on file with the City Clerk
for at least ten (10) days.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 416/735
(3) The purposes for which funds may be expended shall not include purposes other than the
following:
a. Expenditures for safety devices.
b. Expenditures for training or training materials.
c. Expenditures for health or physical fitness devices, education, or screenings, but no member of
the Fire Department shall be entitled to additional paid leave, pension, insurance, or other welfare
benefits as a result of expenditures authorized by subsection (e)(3)a, (e)(3)b or (e)(3)c of this
Section.
d. Furniture, appliances, and other materials necessary to equip and operate the firehouses.
e. Department supplies and equipment, including specialized equipment such as cardiopulmonary
resuscitation dolls, jaws of life, etc.
f. Bonding for the treasurer.
g. Pension contributions to the Fire Pension Fund, but not contributions required of individual
members of such Fund.
(f)The Board shall have the duty to submit to the City Council on or before April 30 of each year a report
detailing meetings, actions, funds received and funds dispersed for the previous year ending on
March 31. In addition, the Board shall require that accounts be kept in accordance with generally
accepted accounting principles for government entities and use a centralized accounting system
provided by the City Finance Department. Further, no purchase of equipment, supplies or other
property shall be made unless upon the order of the Fire Department.
(g)The Board shall have the duty to require its treasurer to post a surety bond acceptable to the City in
the penal sum of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) each conditioned on the faithful
performance of the duties of office and the payment of all monies received by such officer according
to law and ordinance. (1963 Code, Ch. X(I), §§ 1, 2; Ord. 91-19, §§ 1, 2, 2-25-1991)
