https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 442/735
shall be deemed in full force and effect as of the date the simplified municipal telecommunications tax
act or this article is repealed or becomes ineffective. (Ord. 70-2002, §§ 2, 3, 8-26-2002)
ARTICLE X. PREPARED FOOD AND LIQUOR TAX
Sec. 15-107. Definitions:
For the purpose of this article, unless the context otherwise requires, the following words or terms shall
have the meanings respectively applied to them:
Liquor : Any "alcohol", "spirits", "wine" or "beer" as defined, set forth and regulated in chapter 3 of this
code, which is sold at retail either for consumption on the premises where sold or is sold in its original
package for consumption off the premises.
Prepared Food Facility : Establishments subject to the licensing requirements of chapter 7 of this code
as a food service establishment which sells prepared food at retail for immediate consumption and which
provides for on and/or off premises consumption whether or not such facility is conducted along with any
other use(s) in a common premises or business establishment.
(a) "Prepared food facility" does not include food store (except facilities therein which sell prepared
food and liquor), churches, public or private schools, boarding houses, daycare centers, nursing
homes, retirement centers or similar residential care facilities or programs for the central preparation
of meals to be delivered and consumed at private residences of invalids or the elderly, coin operated
automatic food item dispensing machines, hospital (except facilities therein, subject to the state of
Illinois retailer occupation tax pertaining to food sales) and facilities of not for profit associations or
corporations.
Prepared Foods : Any solid, liquid (including both alcoholic and nonalcoholic liquid), powder or other
food substance used, or intended to be used, for human consumption, and which has been prepared for
immediate consumption on and/or off the premises.
Purchase At Retail : To obtain for use or consumption in exchange for a consideration, whether in the
form of money, credits, barter or any other nature, and not for resale.
Retailer : Any person who sells or offers for sale, prepared food and/or liquor for use and not for resale.
Retailer Liquor Facility : Any establishment licensed under the provisions of chapter 3 of this code. (Ord.
10-2004, § 1, 1-26-2004)
Sec. 15-108. Tax Imposed:
Commencing on April 1, 2011, a tax, in addition to any and all other taxes, is imposed upon the
purchase of prepared foods and liquor at retail at any prepared food facility or liquor facility within the city
of Rock Island, at the rate of 1.5 percent of the sales price of such prepared food and liquor, the ultimate
incidence of any liability for payment of which shall be borne by the purchaser. (Ord. 009-2011, 2-14-
2011)
Sec. 15-109. Collection Of Tax By Retailer:
The owner and operator of each prepared food facility and each liquor facility within the city of Rock
Island shall jointly and severally have the duty to collect and account for the tax from each purchase at
the time that the consideration for the purchase is made. (Ord. 10-2004, § 1, 1-26-2004)
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 443/735
Sec. 15-110. Books And Records:
The owner and operator of each prepared food facility and each liquor facility within the city of Rock
Island shall jointly and severally have the duty to maintain complete and accurate books, records and
accounts, showing the gross receipts for sale of prepared food and liquor and the taxes collected each
day, which shall be made available to the city for examination and for audit by the city upon reasonable
notice and during customary business hours. (Ord. 10-2004, § 1, 1-26-2004)
Sec. 15-111. Transmission Of Tax Collection:
The owner and the operator of each prepared food facility and each liquor facility within the city shall
jointly and severally have the duty to cause to be filed, a sworn return with the finance director for each
facility and for each licensed premises located in the city. The return shall be prepared and submitted on
forms prescribed by the city and filed on or before the last day of the calendar month next succeeding
the month for which the return is made. The return shall also be accompanied by payment to the city of
all taxes imposed by this article, which are due and owing for the period covered by the return. The
return shall also be accompanied by a copy of the return filed with the Illinois department of revenue for
sales within the city of Rock Island covering the same reporting period. (Ord. 10-2004, § 1, 1-26-2004)
Sec. 15-112. Late Payment Penalty:
If any tax imposed by this article is not paid when due, a late payment penalty equal to five percent (5%)
of the unpaid tax shall be added for each month, or any portion thereof, that the tax remains unpaid and
the late payment penalty shall be paid along with the tax imposed. (Ord. 10-2004, § 1, 1-26-2004)
Sec. 15-113. Transmittal Of Excess Tax Collections:
If any person collects an amount upon a sale not subject to the tax imposed hereby, but which amount is
purported to be the collection of the tax, or if a person collects an amount upon a sale greater than the
amount of the tax imposed herein and does not for any reason return it to the purchaser who paid it
before filing the return for the period in which it occurred, that person shall account for and pay over
those amounts to the city of Rock Island along with the tax properly collected. (Ord. 10-2004, § 1, 1-26-
2004)
Sec. 15-114. Enforcement License Suspension, Revocation:
Payment and collection of the tax and any late payment penalty may be enforced by action in any court
of competent jurisdiction and failure to collect, account for and pay over the tax and any late payment
penalty shall be cause for suspension or revocation of any city license issued for the prepared food
facility or liquor facility applicable to the premises thereof, all in addition to any other penalties in this
chapter. (Ord. 10-2004, § 1, 1-26-2004)
Sec. 15-115. Rules And Regulations:
The finance director of the city of Rock Island may promulgate rules and regulations not inconsistent
with the provisions of this article concerning the enforcement and application of this article. The term
"rules and regulations" includes, but is not limited to, a case by case determination whether or not the
tax imposed by this articles applies. (Ord. 10-2004, § 1, 1-26-2004)
Sec. 15-116. Penalty:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 444/735
Any person operating a prepared food facility or a liquor facility within the city failing or omitting to pay
the tax when due, or failing or omitting to collect, or to account for, or to pay over the tax and any late
payment penalty, or failing to maintain or allow examination of the books and records provided herein or
elsewhere by law or ordinance, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars
($200.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense, and each day a violation
continues shall be considered a separate violation. (Ord. 10-2004, § 1, 1-26-2004)
Chapter 16
UTILITIES 1 2 3 Annotation-Where a water utility ordinance was strictly
enforced against one person but not against others of the same class, and
there was no irreparable injury, the property remedy was at law and not in
equity. City of Rock Island v. Wagner , 45 Ill. App. 444 (1892).
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 16-1. Ordinances Not Affected By Code:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall affect any ordinance pertaining to specific
locations which requires a hookon charge for water or sewer service, which provides for the installation
of utilities underground or which authorizes a private sewer, and all such ordinances are hereby
recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this code.
(1963 Code, Ch. IX, Art. I)
Secs. 16-2-16-20. Reserved:
ARTICLE II. WATER 1
Sec. 16-21. Rules And Regulations For City Water Service:
The rules and regulations in this article shall be considered a part of the contract with every consumer of
city water and each consumer of city water shall be governed by and subject to the rules and
regulations; and it is hereby made the duty of the director of public works to enforce the same. (Ord. 18-
2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-22. Application For Water Service Connection:
(a)Application For Water Service: An application for water service connections and the installation of
water meters must be made at the office of the finance department of the city in the city hall, by the
owner or agent of the property to be served, upon forms furnished by that office. Such application
shall state the official house number or number of the premises and the size of the pipe required.
Every application for water supply shall state that the same is made subject to all rules and
regulations then in force or that may thereafter be adopted by the city.
(b)Owner To Sign All Applications: All applications for water service shall be signed by the owner of the
premises, or an agent or designee thereof, and such application shall contain an agreement to pay
all water service charges. Such application when accepted by the city collector shall constitute a
contract between the applicant and the city.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 445/735
(c)Contract Sale: The contract holder in contract sale of property shall be considered the owner of the
property and ultimately responsible for delinquent charges.
(d)Rental Property: The landlord of a property shall ultimately be responsible for delinquent charges
even if the service is in the name of the tenant. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002; Ord. 029-2008, § 1, 4-
21-2008)
Sec. 16-23. Connections To Be Made Under City Supervision:
The making of all service connections, laying pipes and setting of water service fixtures in streets and
public grounds shall be made by duly licensed plumbers working in compliance with the requirements of
permits issued by the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-24. Alteration Of Or Addition To Service Pipes:
No additions or alterations whatsoever in or about any service conduit, service pipe or water cock shall
be made by any person without a plumbing permit issued by the city. Whenever water service through
an existing service pipe is to be permanently discontinued for any reason, the existing service pipe shall
be disconnected at its connection to the water main and the curb box and stop must be removed at the
expense of the service owner. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-25. Separate Connections:
There shall be a separate service pipe laid from the main to each building. Such service pipe shall be
laid on a straight line at right angles to the water main and connections made within two (2) lines drawn
parallel to the sides of the building to be served. In the event that there is more than one water main
available to serve the building, the public works department will decide which water main to use. If the
city council determines a strict enforcement of this requirement to be unreasonable, a special permit
may be issued to the owner authorizing a variance to the provisions of this section. Where services are
laid to premises, where there are no water mains available for direct connection, a small temporary main
will be permitted to be laid as provided in section 16-33 of this article. In all cases each building served
must have an independent service shutoff. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-26. Service Outside City Limits:
Water service may be provided outside the city limits. In such cases that the property to be served is not
part of an incorporated municipality, water service may only be provided upon the approval of the city
council and the applicant therefor shall pay the cost of the extension of the water main and shall pay
double the water rate for all water furnished. In addition thereto, the plumbing to be serviced thereby
must be inspected and approved by the city plumbing inspector. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-27. Service Curb Cocks:
(a)A curb stop box, shutoff and related appurtenances within the building for controlling the supply of
water to consumers shall be placed on every service in accordance with the standard drawings
provided by the public works department. Any variation in the location for setting of such stop boxes,
as herein provided for, shall be made only when authorized by the director of public works.
(b)Whenever a meter cannot be set on the premises without danger of freezing, difficulty of reading or
other cause detrimental to service by the public works department, the director of public works may
demand the installation of an outside meter box and shutoff, the type to be designated by him.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 446/735
(c)The outside shutoff and stop box shall be under the sole control of the city public works department
and no person except an employee or person specifically authorized by the city public works
department shall open the cover of such box, turn on or off water or interfere with a service curb cock
in any way. However, licensed plumbers may turn on or off the water for testing plumbing or making
repairs, but whenever so used the shut off must be left closed if found closed and open if found open
by the plumber who uses it.
(d)The valves, curb box and shutoff must be kept in good condition and ready for use at all times by the
property owner. Should the property owner neglect to maintain such valves, curb box and shutoff in
proper condition to be used, and if the stop box is found to be filled up, or the stop box or shutoff is
found to be out of repair at any time, the city public works department shall have the right to clean or
repair the same when needed without giving notice, and charge the cost thereof to the owner, and if
payment is refused, may turn off the water in the service until the same is paid. The city will not be
responsible for any damage due to the breaking of a service or stopcock, done while setting,
resetting or repairing a water meter, or turning water off or on.
(e)Owners of premises having water services which do not have separate curb stopcocks and boxes for
each building, or which otherwise do not conform to the requirements in this section at the time of its
passage, shall be required to put in such curb stopcock or make such other changes as are
necessary to conform to these requirements when so instructed by the public works department.
(Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-28. Service Pipe:
The water service pipe from the water main to the water meter shall be constructed in accordance with
the standard drawings provided by the public works department. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-29. Connection Between Different Services:
When there are two (2) or more services on premises, the piping from each service must be kept
separate, and no connection made from one to the other. If the city council determines that the strict
enforcement of this requirement is unreasonable, a special permit may be issued to the owner
authorizing a variance. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-30. Maintenance Of Service Pipes:
All service pipes and fixtures from the street water main to the premises, including the corporation cocks
at the mains and the valves on each side of the meter, shall be installed and maintained at the expense
of the property owners, and any leaks or other defects in the same shall be promptly repaired by them. If
the defects are not properly repaired within ten (10) days after written notice, the water may be turned off
by the public works department until such repairs have been made and the expense thereof shall be
charged against such owner and must be paid before water shall be turned on again. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1,
3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-31. Breaks In Service Or Fixtures:
The city shall not be held responsible by reason of the breaking of any service pipe or apparatus, water
coil or for failure in the supply of water. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-32. Right To Shut Off Or Turn On Water:
The city may, when necessary, without notice, shut off or turn on the water in its mains for any purpose
and no claims shall be made against the city by reason of the breakage of any service pipe, service
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 447/735
cock, or from any other damage that may result from improper fixtures, open or improper connections or
for any other causes. The public works department shall give notice of shutting off water if conditions are
such that it is reasonably possible to do so. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-33. Temporary Mains:
No temporary water mains shall be allowed in the city except as provided by special ordinance passed
by the city council. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-34. Water Rates Established:
(a)Generally: The rates for water used by every person using water from or through the city waterworks
shall be as determined from time to time by the city council, and shall be paid by the owner of the
premises where the water is taken.
(b)Unmetered Water Rates: The quantity of use of unmetered water shall be estimated by the building
official and the rate paid for such use shall be the same as that charged general customers. It shall
be the duty of the building official to collect fees for water used by builders in all building operations.
(Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-35. City Collector To Have Charge Of Collections:
The city collector shall have charge of the collection of all water and/or sewerage service bills. The city
collector shall give a receipt for all monies so paid to him. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-36. Bills And Collection Policies:
(a)Billings For Water Service: Billings for water service shall be rendered by the finance department on a
monthly or quarterly basis at the discretion of the finance department.
(b)When A Bill Is Delinquent: If a bill for water service remains unpaid for thirty (30) days or more after it
is rendered, the city may shut off water service to the property. If the city thereafter records a lien with
the recorder of deeds for the delinquent charges incurred, any subsequent purchaser who takes title
to the property after the lien is recorded, is responsible for payment of all the delinquent charges and
penalties. If water service has been shut off and a lien has been recorded prior to the new purchaser
taking title to the property, water service shall not be restored to the property until all delinquent
charges and penalties, including shutoff charges, have been paid in full and arrangements for
restoring service has been made with the city. If a subsequent purchaser of the property takes title
after the delinquent charges have been incurred by the prior owner, but before the city records a lien
for these unpaid charges, the subsequent purchaser shall not be responsible for payment of the
delinquent charges and, if applicable, water service shall be reinstated to the property. Any unpaid
charges for water service incurred by a prior owner where a lien has not been filed before the
property is sold or transferred to a bona fide purchaser are the responsibility of the prior owner, and
the city retains the right to seek repayment of those charges by means available to it by law.
(c)Notice Of Shutoff For Nonpayment: When city records reflect that premises are occupied, the water to
those premises shall not be shut off for nonpayment without giving at least five (5) days' notice to the
persons residing therein. The notice shall be given by contacting the persons occupying the premises
personally, or by posting on the front door or in a public hallway of the property, notice of the
proposed shutoff action by the city. The notice shall comply with 765 Illinois Compiled Statutes
735/1.2 et seq. A fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00) shall be charged for each shutoff notice.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 448/735
(d)Monthly Bills: The city collector may put any water service on a monthly payment basis, if it is judged
to be in the best interest of the city to do so. In such cases the bills shall be due not less than fifteen
(15) days following the date of the statement.
(e)Late Fee: When water bills are not paid on or before the due date stated on the bill, a penalty of five
percent (5%) shall be added. Failure to receive a bill does not entitle the owner or customer to a
remission of penalty.
(f)Billing To Address Other Than Service Address: Written notice must be given by the owner or
authorized agent if it is desired that bills be forwarded to any other address than the premises
supplied.
(g)Payment In Advance: The city shall have full power and authority to require payment in advance for
the use of water furnished by it in and upon any building, place or premises, and in case prompt
payment for the same shall not be made, it may shut off the water from such building, place or
premises and shall not be compelled again to supply the building, place or premises with water until
arrears together with the costs and expense of turning the water off and on shall be fully paid.
(h)Special Service Bill: All bills for installation of special water service connections or service repairs,
special meter reading services and for the installation and repair of meters shall be payable to the
city collector as soon as such work is completed and the bill is rendered, and if the bills are not
promptly paid, the city water supply may be turned off by the city until all such bills have been paid.
(i)Combined Bill; Partial Payment: The water charge may be billed on a common statement and
collected along with other charges. If the water charge is included on a common statement and the
customer payment is insufficient to pay the total of all portions of the statement, the payment will be
applied according to the priority shown in section 13-41 of this code.
(j)Issuance Of Bills: All water and sewer accounts will be billed as soon as possible after readings are
obtained. Each bill will be due not less than fifteen (15) days after its issuance.
(k)Average Bills: If a current reading is not obtained, an average bill will be issued, based upon the
consumption history of the account. If for any reason adequate history is not available, a bill will be
issued for two thousand five hundred (2,500) cubic feet of consumption. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-
2002; Ord. 029-2008, § 2, 4-21-2008; Ord. 009-2010, § 1, 2-8-2010; Ord. 065-2012, 10-15-2012;
Ord. 091-2014, 12-15-2014)
Sec. 16-37. Adjustment Of Water Charges:
In any case of a dispute over the amount of a bill, or over the accuracy of a meter, the city shall at the
request of the consumer test the meter, in the presence of the consumer or his agent. If it is found upon
such test that the meter registers a greater amount of water than has actually passed through said meter
(allowing 2 1/2 percent for accuracy) the bill will be adjusted to conform with the correct amount passing
through the meter. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-38. Responsibility In Turning On Water Services:
In turning on water services, the city shall not be responsible for any damage that may occur by reason
of improper fixtures, open or improper connections or for any other causes. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-
2002)
Sec. 16-39. Discontinued Use Of Water:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 449/735
Owners or customers desiring to discontinue the use of water shall give notice thereof to the city
collector, who shall cause the water to be turned off and the meter removed. When water service is
discontinued, all water and sewer charges for such service shall become due and payable. A service
charge shall be made at the time service is discontinued, either at the customer's request, or for
nonpayment of charges. A charge fixed by the city council from time to time shall be made for every
special reading requested by a customer. The city may withhold water supply until all unpaid bills against
the property have been paid. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-40. Water Meters:
(a)All water furnished consumers shall be metered other than water used for construction purposes paid
for pursuant to subsection 16-34(a) of this article. All meters shall be furnished and set by the city or
a licensed and registered plumber but owners must provide a suitable location in the piping system
for same. Meters shall be placed on service pipes in accordance with the standard drawings provided
by the public works department. There shall be a suitable place provided for the meter so as to keep
it dry and clean, protected from freezing, and readily accessible at all times to the city. All valves and
fittings necessary to comply with the requirements and to provide connection to the meter, except a
coupling or flange at each end of meter, shall be provided by the owner of premises to be served.
(b)For services larger than two inches (2") in diameter, the city reserves the right to install two (2) or
more meters of smaller size. Where meters are so placed, each meter shall have a valve or shutoff
on both inlet and outlet pipe in addition to the basement shutoff.
(c)Where a service pipe larger than two inches (2") in diameter is used, the plumber shall call at the
public works department for instructions regarding the fittings and space to be provided for the water
meters.
(d)In case two (2) or more meters are desired for measuring water to different tenants in the same
building from one service connection, they shall be so placed that no one of them shall measure
water which has passed through another one. Each meter shall be equipped with a separate locking
shutoff.
(e)Water meters shall be of the size and type necessary to ensure accurate registration of the water
requirements of the premises. Size of meters for large buildings, apartments or flats shall be
designated by the city at the time of application for water supply, the size of meters so specified by
the city being always subject to change, from time to time, thereafter as the demand or other
conditions may develop to be out of accord with the provisions of this article. The city reserves the
right to require an increase in the size of the meter, as in these rules provided, in any case where, in
the discretion of the city, the use of water in larger quantities places any meter under undue or
unusual strain. The size of the meter which shall in either event be required shall be determined by
the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-41. Owners To Protect Meters:
(a)The owner or occupant of premises where a meter is installed shall be held responsible for its care
and protection from freezing or hot water and from other injury or interference from any person or
persons. In case of any injury to the meter, or in case of its stoppage or imperfect working, he shall
give immediate notice to the office of the finance department. In all cases in which meters are broken
or damaged by negligence of owners or occupants on premises, or by freezing, hot water or any
other injuries, the necessary repairs to all city owned meters shall be made by the city, and the costs
of such repairs paid for by the owner or occupant. The charge shall be based on the amount of
damage at the current parts and labor cost, not to exceed the cost of a new meter. If the meter is
found to be damaged beyond repair, it shall be billed at the current price of a new meter; the cost of
such repairs shall be paid for by such owner or occupant, and in case payment thereof is neglected
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 450/735
or refused, the water supply shall be turned off and shall not be turned on until full payment has been
made, including a fee fixed by the city for turning on the water again. Damaged meters may be
repaired by the city without first giving notice thereof to the owner of the premises served by such
meter.
(b)No person shall in any way interfere with the proper registration of a water meter, and no person
except an authorized employee of the city shall break a seal of a meter; however, in case of
emergency a plumber registered in the city may break such seal for draining pipes or stopping water
leaks. The plumber shall notify the public works department of this action the next regular business
day after breaking the seal and explain the nature of the emergency.
(c)Whenever a water meter is installed on a water service on premises that are to be remodeled,
removed or destroyed, or where the service is discontinued so that the water meter is no longer
needed, the owner of such premises shall give notice to the finance department to remove such
meter, and free access to such meter must be provided at least twenty four (24) hours after notice is
given so that the meter may be removed. The owner of the premises shall be held responsible for the
meter until such written notice is given, and if the meter is covered or lost, he shall be required to pay
for the same at the actual value. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-42. Repairing Meters:
(a)Right Of Entry: The city reserves the right at any reasonable time to enter any premises supplied by
the city water and exchange any meter, for repairs or other cause, as may be deemed necessary by
the city.
(b)Meters Out Of Order: If any meter, at any time, fails to register the quantity of water consumed, the
same shall be determined and charges made based on the average quantity registered during the
last preceding year prior to the date of failure, as the city collector shall order and direct. If an
average is not available, a bill will be issued for two thousand five hundred (2,500) cubic feet of
consumption.
(c)Leakage: No deduction shall be made on account of leakage after the water has passed through and
been registered by the meter. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-43. Unlawful To Obstruct Meters, Etc.:
No person shall in any manner obstruct the access of any stopcock, hydrant, water meter, dial or valve
connected with any water pipes within the city by means of any rubbish, refuse, building material, fuel or
any other article, thing or hindrance, particularly the obstruction of meters that will interfere with the
ready access to a meter at any and all times. Neglecting to comply with this provision, the consumer at
once becomes liable and the city water supply will be turned off at the street, after notice has been
given, until the obstruction shall be removed. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-44. Water Lien For Unpaid Water Fees:
Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid for thirty (30) days after it has been rendered, the
unpaid charges can result in the city taking steps to file a lien with the recorder of deeds reflecting
nonpayment of those charges. Prior to filing a lien, the city shall prepare and send in accordance with
state law, a delinquency notice to the owner of record of the property receiving the water service,
advising the owner that the water fees have become delinquent and that nonpayment of the outstanding
charges and penalties may create a lien on the property. Said notice of delinquency shall advise the
owner that he or she has seven (7) days from the date of mailing of the notice to pay all amounts owed
or else a notice of lien will be filed with the recorder of deeds. Said lien shall include any unpaid fees for
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 451/735
services rendered to the property after the mailing of the notice of delinquency. (Ord. 066-2012, 10-15-
2012)
Sec. 16-45. Molestation Or Injury To Water Mains:
(a)Any person who may be working in any street of this city who may molest or in any way damage the
city water mains, or appurtenances thereto, shall be responsible to the city for any and all such
damages, and he, or his heirs, representatives or assigns shall bear all expense of such replacement
or repair made necessary thereby, and he shall also be responsible for damage to surrounding
properties on account of the damage to water mains.
(b)Whenever any construction is taking place or where digging for any reason is being done, the public
works department shall estimate the location of underground utility facilities owned by the city in
accordance with the JULIE (joint utility locating information for excavators; Illinois one call system)
obligations mandated by Illinois law. A reasonable charge for any such service after the initial
location above provided for shall be paid by the person requesting such service. The city shall not be
responsible for any costs incurred by any person or party due to the inaccuracy of estimated
locations provided by the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-46. Fire Hydrants:
(a)All fire hydrants except those that are connected directly to an internal fire protection system that is
not owned by the city are hereby declared to be public hydrants and shall be tested, maintained,
repaired and replaced as needed by the city. If a public fire hydrant is located on private property, the
owner of the private property shall allow the city unrestricted access for the purpose of testing,
maintaining, repairing and replacing the hydrant.
(b)Fire hydrants that are directly connected to an internal fire protection system that is not owned by the
city must be tested and maintained by the owner of the internal fire protection system in accordance
with the requirements of the fire department.
(c)If a public fire hydrant is attached to a water main that is not owned by the city, the water main shall
be maintained at the expense of the owner in accordance with the requirements of the public works
department. If any leaks or other defects are not properly repaired at the expense of the owner within
ten (10) days after written notice from the public works department, the water may be turned off by
the public works department until such repairs have been made. The expense of turning off the water
shall be charged against such owner and must be paid before water shall be turned on again.
(d)No person other than the members of the fire department, the public works department or those
specially authorized by the public works department shall open any of the public fire hydrants or
attempt to draw water from the same or in any manner interfere with or injure any of the public fire
hydrants in the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-47. Waste Of Water:
No person shall allow the water to run to waste through defective pipes, faucets or other fixtures;
however, a reasonable time, not exceeding forty eight (48) hours, shall be allowed to repair the same. In
case of neglect or refusal by the person to cause the fixtures to be repaired, the public works department
may withhold the water supply. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-48. Stopcock And Valve Services:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 452/735
The city shall not be responsible for any accidents caused by stopcocks or valve boxes that stand above
the surface of the ground, pavement or sidewalks and the property owners shall keep all stopcocks or
valve boxes flush with the surface at their location. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-49. Inspections Generally:
(a)Inspectors, foremen, meter readers or any other employee or agent of the city whose duty it may be
to enter upon private premises to make inspections and examinations of water meters, pipes, fixtures
or appurtenances thereto, for any reason whatsoever in connection with the city water supply will be
provided with a badge or other credentials to identify them as authorized agents and representatives
of the city.
(b)Any officer, inspector, foreman, meter reader or authorized agent or employee of the city upon
presentation of his badge or other credentials provided for in subsection (a) of this section, shall be
given free access at any and all reasonable hours to any premises supplied by the city water, for the
purpose of making any inspection thereof pertaining to the water system.
(c)In case any authorized agent or employee of the city is refused admittance to any premises, or being
admitted is hindered or prevented in making such examination, the city may cause the city water
supply to be turned off from the premises after giving twenty four (24) hours' notice to the owner or
occupant of said premises.
(d)No person not an authorized agent or employee of the city shall have, wear or exhibit any badge or
credential of the city. It shall be the duty of every such officer, agent or employee of the city upon
resignation or dismissal forthwith to surrender and deliver to the director of public works all badges
and credentials of the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-50. Connection Between City And Other Supply:
No person shall cause a connection to be made or allow one to exist with the city water supply for
commercial, domestic, sanitary, fire protection or boiler feed purposes, or for any other purpose
whatsoever, where water foreign to the city water supply is used for a second source of supply. (Ord. 18-
2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-51. Connections With Other City Systems:
Any water connections now existing between the city and any adjoining city, and those connections now
existing in the industrial district, i.e., the double check valve connections, shall be allowed to remain until
a demand is made by the city to sever or alter these connections, at which time they shall be
disconnected or changed as directed by such department or departments. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-
2002)
Sec. 16-52. Installation Of Water Mains:
(a)Water mains shall be installed under the standard specifications of the city for laying water mains and
under the supervision and inspection of the director of public works or his designated representative.
(b)All water mains of four inch (4") size or larger now in place or that may be placed in public right of way
or public utility easements, so dedicated, excluding service and fire protection lines of four inch (4")
size and larger, shall become the donated property of the city. The responsibility, jurisdiction and
maintenance thereof shall thereafter be administered by the city public works department.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 453/735
(c)The city water mains hereafter installed shall be inspected and tested by the director of public works
or his designated representative. Any water mains installed without inspection shall be opened by the
contractor or plumber for inspection, at his own expense, at the request of the director of public
works or his designated representative.
(d)No contractor or plumber shall turn on or off any valve of four inches (4") or over, on any city owned
water mains without the permission of the public works department. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-53. Extensions; New Subdivisions:
The following is the policy adopted by the city council in regard to the extension of water lines to and into
new subdivisions of the city:
(1) The city council will consider the extension of water and/or sewer service to the project area,
provided a project of adequate magnitude is proposed to assure a fair return on the city's investment
within a reasonable period of time.
(2) Where the line is brought to the project area by the city, the developer will be expected to extend
the line within the project area. Such extensions must be in accordance with city specifications, must
be looped in accordance with sound hydraulic practices, in all aspects, including pipe sizes and other
approvals, to be under the jurisdiction of the director of public works or his designated representative.
The minimum size of water line extensions will be eight inch (8") diameter. In those instances in
which pipe sizes specified by the director of public works or his designated representative exceed
eight inches (8"), such requirement will be submitted to the city council, and if the city council agrees
with the need for the larger diameter line, the city will bear the cost of the difference between an eight
inch (8") line and the larger sized line specified.
(3) In the case of all subdivisions and line extensions, the city has the right to authorize other
subdividers to hook onto water lines extended and installed by another subdivider if, in the opinion of
the city engineer, the lines are adequately sized to handle the added load. If the hook on is to a line
size larger than eight inches (8") in diameter, the city will follow the same policy with respect to
extending the line, as pertains under subsection (2) of this section.
(4) Where the city extends a line at city expense, and at a later time, properties fronting on the line
request permission to hook on, the cost of the line will be apportioned as follows:
a. The city will bear the cost of the line in excess of eight inch (8") diameter.
b. The cost of the eight inch (8") line will be apportioned (1/2 to each side) to properties fronting on
the line. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-54. Water Shortage-Definition:
For the purpose of this article an inadequate supply of water shall be deemed to exist when the city is
unable to refill the reservoirs and storage tanks on a daily basis because of the high demand for water
due to weather conditions or because the city's water facilities are inadequate to provide the refilling as
aforesaid due to other causes. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-2002)
Sec. 16-55. Duties Of Manager:
It shall be the duty of the city manager to make a determination that an inadequate supply of water
exists in the city when the refilling process described in the preceding section is not completed on a daily
basis. After making said determination, the provisions of sections 16-54 and 16-56 of this article shall not
be enforced until the city manager informs the news media of the city of the determination so that the
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 454/735
residents of the city will be notified of the determination. If conditions permit a delay in enforcement, a
notice shall also be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-
2002)
Sec. 16-56. Use Of Water:
No person shall use the city water supply for the watering of lawns or noncommercial washing of motor
vehicles during that period of time when there exists in the city an inadequate supply of water in the
city's reservoirs and storage tanks due to weather conditions or other causes. (Ord. 18-2002, § 1, 3-11-
2002)
Sec. 16-57. Backflow Prevention Device:
All plumbing installed within the city of Rock Island shall be installed in accordance with the Illinois
plumbing code, 77 Illinois administrative code section 90. If in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code
in the judgment of the public works director, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for
the safety of the public water supply system, the public works director will give notice to the water
customer to install such an approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense,
install such an approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois plumbing
code, Illinois environmental protection agency and all applicable local regulations, and shall have
inspections and tests made of such approved devices upon installation and annually thereafter, at a
minimum. The owner of the premises shall maintain records to document that testing, servicing and
repairs are conducted as required.
(1)No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or permit to be
maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the
regular public water supply of the city of Rock Island enter the supply or distribution system of said
municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection
and use of such supply shall have been approved by the public works director and the Illinois
environmental protection agency.
(2)It shall be the duty of the public works director to cause surveys and investigations to be made of
industrial and other properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or
potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be
made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two (2) years, or as often as the
public works director shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and
available for review for a period of at least five (5) years.
(3)The approved cross connection control device inspector shall have the right to enter at any
reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution
system of the city of Rock Island for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross
connections, and that the public works director or his authorized agent shall have the right to enter at
any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution
system of the city of Rock Island for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the owner,
lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the public works director any
information which he may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such
property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the public
works director, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this
section.
(4)The public works director of the city of Rock Island is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue,
after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any property wherein any
connection in violation of the provisions of this section is known to exist, and to take such other
precautionary measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 455/735
public water supply distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until such
conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the provisions of this section, and
until a reconnection fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) is paid to the city of Rock Island. Immediate
disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the director of public works is assured that
imminent danger of harmful contamination or pollution of the public water supply, provided that, in the
reasonable opinion of the public works director or the Illinois environmental protection agency, such
action is required to prevent actual or potential contamination or pollution of the public water supply.
Neither the public water supply, the director of public works, or its agents or assigns shall be liable to
any customer for any injury, damages or lost revenues which may result from termination of said
customer's water supply in accordance with the terms of this section, whether or not said termination
was with or without notice.
(5)The consumer responsible for back siphoned material or contamination through backflow, if
contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an illegal cross connection or an
improperly installed, maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear
the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system. (Ord. 90-37, § 1, 5-21-1990; Ord. 79-2002, §
1, 9-16-2002)
ARTICLE III. SEWERS 1, 2
Sec. 16-81. Management Of Sewer:
The management and supervision of the sewer division of the city and any and all property pertaining
thereto shall be under the direction of the director of public works. In addition to the foregoing, the
director of public works shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by the city manager.
(1963 Code, Ch. IX, Art. I; Ord. 87-22, § 16, 3-23-1987; Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990)
Sec. 16-82. Definitions:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as
follows:
(a)Federal Government:
(1) Federal Act: The federal clean water act (33 USC 466 et seq.) as amended (Pub. L. 95-217).
(2) Administrator: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency.
(3) Federal Grant: The U.S. government participation in the financing of the construction of treatment
works as provided for by title II, grants for construction of treatment works, of the act and
implementing regulations.
(b)State Government:
(1) State Act: The Illinois antipollution bond act of 1970.
(2) Director: The director of the Illinois environmental protection agency.
(3) State Grant: The state participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as
provided for by the state act and for making such grants as filed with the secretary of state of the
state of Illinois.
(c)Local Government:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 456/735
(1) City: The city of Rock Island.
(2) Approving Authority: The director of public works.
(d)Person: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual, firm, company, municipal or
private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity.
(e)NPDES Permit: Any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the administrator, or,
where appropriated by the director, after enactment of the federal clean water act to regulate the
discharge of pollutants pursuant to section 402 of the federal act.
(f)Clarification Of Word Usage: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissible.
(g) Wastewater And Its Characteristics:
(1) Wastewater: The spent water of a community. From this standpoint of course, it may be a
combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial
plants, and institutions, together with any ground water, surface water, and stormwater that may be
present.
(2) Sewage: Used interchangeably with "wastewater".
(3) Effluent Criteria: Defined in any applicable NPDES permit.
(4) Water Quality Standards: Defined in the water pollution regulations of Illinois.
(5) Unpolluted Water: Water quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that
would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by
discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided.
(6) ppm: Parts per million by weight.
(7) Milligrams Per Liter: A unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is 0.001
gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters (1,000 ml) of water. It has replaced the unit
formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the
results of water and wastewater analysis.
(8) Suspended Solids (SS): Solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water,
sewage, or industrial waste, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative
determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the IEPA
division of laboratories "Manual Of Laboratory Methods".
(9) BOD (Denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical
oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty degrees
Celsius (20°C), expressed in milligrams per liter.
(10) pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration expressed by
one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA division of laboratories "Manual Of Laboratory Methods".
(11) Garbage: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing
of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of food.
(12) Properly Shredded Garbage: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food
that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow
conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") (1.27
centimeters) in any dimension.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 457/735
(13) Floatable Oil: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from
wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free
of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection
system.
(14) Population Equivalent: A term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a
treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is 0.13 ccf of sewage per day, containing 0.20
pounds of BOD and 0.20 pounds of suspended solids.
(15) Slug: Any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given
constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes
more than five (5) times the average twenty four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal
operation.
(16) Industrial Waste: Any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted to flow or
escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or
from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary
sewage.
(17) Major Contributing Industry: An industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that:
a. Has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average workday; or
b. Has a flow greater than ten percent (10%) of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving
the waste; or
c. Has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under section
307(a) of the federal act; or
d. Is found by the permit issuing authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to
the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or
in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of
effluent from that treatment works.
(18) ccf: The flow measurement unit of hundred cubic feet.
(h)Sewer Types And Appurtenances:
(1) Sewer: A pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids, including stormwater,
surface water and ground water drainage.
(2) Public Sewer: A sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the city. It shall also include
sewers within or outside the city boundaries that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge
into the city sanitary (or combined) system, even though those sewers may not have been
constructed with city funds.
(3) Sanitary Sewer: A sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and
into which stormwaters, surface waters, and ground waters or polluted industrial wastes are not
intentionally admitted.
(4) Storm Sewer: A sewer that carries stormwater, surface water and ground water drainage but
excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water.
(5) Combined Sewer: A sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, stormwater,
surface water and ground water drainage.
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 458/735
(6) Building Sewer: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of
disposal.
(7) Building Drain: That part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge
from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the
building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning five feet (5') (1.5 meters) outside the
inner face of the building wall.
(8) Stormwater Runoff: That portion of the precipitation that is drained into the sewers.
(9) Sewerage: The system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation and
pumping of sewage.
(10) Easement: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
(i)Treatment:
(1) Pretreatment: The treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction into the wastewater
treatment works.
(2) Wastewater Treatment Works: An arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater,
industrial wastes, and sludge; sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or
"wastewater treatment plant" or "pollution control plant".
(j)Wastewater Facilities: The structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and
treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport effluent to a watercourse.
(k)Watercourse And Connections:
(1) Watercourse: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently.
(2) Natural Outlet: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or
ground water.
(l)User Types:
(1) User Class: The type of user "residential", "institutional", "governmental", "commercial", or
"industrial" as defined herein.
(2) Residential User: All dwelling units such as houses, mobile homes, apartments, and permanent
multi-family dwellings.
(3) Commercial User: Includes transit lodging, retail and wholesale establishments, or places
engaged in selling merchandise or rendering services.
(4) Institutional/Governmental User: Includes schools, churches, penal institutions, and users
associated with federal, state, and local governments.
(5) Industrial Users: Includes establishments engaged in manufacturing activities involving the
mechanical or chemical transformation of materials of substance into products.
(6) Control Manhole: A structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged.
Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a control manhole is to
provide access for the city representative to sample and/or measure discharges.
(m)Types Of Charges:
12/20/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Rock Island/index.htm 459/735
(1) Wastewater Service Charge: The charge per quarter or month levied on all users of the
wastewater facilities. The service charge shall be computed as outlined in section 16-85 of this article
and shall consist of the total of the basic user charge and the capital charge.
(2) User Charge: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of operation, maintenance
and replacement.
(3) Basic User Charge: The basic assessment levied on all users of the public sewer system.
(4) Debt Service Charge: The amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest, principal
and coverage of (loan, bond, etc.) outstanding debt.
(5) Capital Improvement Charge: A charge levied on users to improve, extend or reconstruct the
sewage treatment works.
(6) Capital Cost Charge: Charges for costs other than the operation, maintenance and replacement
costs, i.e., debt service and capital improvement costs.
(7) Replacement: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or
appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the
capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation
and maintenance" includes replacement.
(8) Useful Life: The estimated period during which the collection system and/or treatment works will
be operated.
(9) Sewerage Fund: The principal accounting designation for all revenues received in the operation
of the sewerage system. (Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990)
Sec. 16-83. Sewer Service To Extend Across Entire Frontage:
No person shall extend a City sewer to service his property unless the sewer line is extended across the
entire frontage of the property at the property owner's expense. In the event compliance with this
provision is impossible because of physical conditions or impractical because of unique circumstances,
the property owner may apply to the City Council for exemption from the requirements of this section.
(Ord., 10-13-1969; Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990)
Sec. 16-84. Sewer Charges Generally:
Each user of the City's sewer service shall be charged for usage of the sewage system at rates
established under this article. Where the sewer user is also a City water user, billing for sewage usage
shall be coincidental with the billing for water usage. In cases where a sewer user is not a water user,
billing shall be made monthly or quarterly as determined by the City Collector. (1963 Code art. 9-1-3;
Ord. 90-33, 5-14-1990; Ord. 001-2005, 1-17-2005)
Sec. 16-85. Rates Generally:
Sec. 16-85.1. Basis For Wastewater Service Charges: The wastewater service charge for the use of and
for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the City shall consist of a service charge and a
volume charge.

Sec. 16-85.2. Three-Part Rate: A three-part rate may be levied to those users whose wastewater varies
significantly from normal domestic concentrations for BOD and SS. The three-part rate would consist of
a service charge plus a unit charge for volume, biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), and total
suspended solids (TSS).
Service charges for customers paying based upon the three-part rate will be calculated by the Public
Works Department on a case by case basis.
The concentration of wastes used for computing BOD and TSS charges shall be established by waste
sampling. Waste sampling shall be performed as often as may be deemed necessary by the City and
shall be binding as a basis for the BOD and TSS charges. In the event a customer requests to be placed
on a three-part rate schedule, the cost of performing the necessary waste sampling shall be charged
directly to the customer.
